1 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Adkins v. Capots


No. 89-712


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 3d 187; 546 N.E.2d 412; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 317


August 29, 1989, Submitted  
November 15, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, No. 88AP-492.

Appellant, James Adkins, an inmate at the Chillicothe Correctional Institute, filed a complaint for a writ of mandamus in the Court of Appeals for Franklin County. Appellant contended that he was convicted of a felony and received an indeterminate sentence of two to ten years; that he was paroled in 1981 and reincarcerated for a parole violation in 1984; and that he had been considered for parole on subsequent occasions, most recently in November 1987, when the Adult Parole Authority "applied the new ohio [sic] parole guidelines * * *, and pursuant to such guidelines, relator's case was continued for eighteen months." Appellant contended that the guidelines violated his constitutional rights to due process and equal protection of the laws, and that the guidelines' use by the authority was therefore an abuse of discretion. He requested the court to compel the authority to grant him a new parole hearing under constitutional guidelines.

Appellee, Chairman of the Adult Parole Authority, filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim on which relief can be granted under Civ. R. 12(B)(6), alleging that  [***2] appellant could show neither clear legal right to relief sought nor a clear legal duty of appellee to grant him that relief. The court of appeals granted the motion to dismiss, upholding the decision of its referee who concluded that appellant could prove no set of facts entitling him to relief in mandamus.

The cause is before the court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

2 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Brown v. Summit County Bd. of Elections


No. 89-1241


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 3d 166; 545 N.E.2d 1256; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 271


August 15, 1989, Submitted  
October 25, 1989, Opinion released


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: The court denied the writ of mandamus on August 16, 1989 with an entry which stated in part:
"IT IS ORDERED by the court that said writ be, and the same is hereby, denied consistent with the opinion to follow." (See 45 Ohio St. 3d 701, 543 N.E. 2d 806.)
The following opinion is "the opinion to follow."


PRIOR HISTORY: IN MANDAMUS.

ON MOTION TO DISMISS.

Relator, James E. Brown, has filed a complaint for a writ of mandamus in this court wherein he challenges the constitutionality of a provision of the Charter of the city of Stow that prescribes a two-year durational residency requirement for candidates for the office of city councilman.

He alleges that he is a resident of Stow, Ohio; that on June 13, 1989 he filed a Nominating Petition and Statement of Candidacy with the respondent Summit County Board of Elections for the office of Councilman, First Ward for the full term commencing January 2, 1990; and that on July 10, 1989 the board of elections notified him that it would not certify his nominating petition because he would be unable to meet the Stow Charter residency requirement of two years' continuous residency prior to the date of his election.

Section 4.03 of the Stow Charter [***2] provides:

"Each councilman elected to represent a ward shall have been for at least 2 years prior to the date of his election, and during his term of office shall be, a continuous resident and qualified elector of the ward he represents, or territory annexed thereto."

Relator seeks to compel the board of elections to place his name on the ballot for the primary election to be held September 12, 1989, alleging he meets all requirements other than the two-year durational requirement of the Stow Charter.

Respondent board of elections admits that a primary election is scheduled for September 12, 1989, and that it has refused to place relator's name on the ballot because he will not have been a resident of Stow for two years at the time he would take office. The board of elections admits that relator is qualified to run for the position except for not having been a resident of Stow for two years prior to the time he would be elected. Respondent city of Stow in its answer states that the durational residency requirement is necessary in order to ensure knowledgeable candidates. Respondent Stow also seeks to dismiss relator's complaint.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator candidate filed a complaint for a writ of mandamus wherein he challenged the constitutionality of Stow Ohio, Charter § 4.03, which prescribed a two-year durational residency requirement for candidates for the office of city councilman. Respondent city filed a motion to dismiss the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The candidate sought election as a city councilman. Respondent board of elections refused to place his name on the ballot because he did not meet the residency requirement found in § 4.03 of the city's charter. The candidate filed a complaint, seeking a writ of mandamus, alleging that § 4.03 violated the equal protection provisions of the federal and state constitutions. The city filed a motion to dismiss. The court overruled the motion, holding that the candidate was entitled to challenge the constitutionality of § 4.03 by mandamus. The court rejected respondents' argument that the candidate had an adequate remedy at law by appealing under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506. The court denied the writ, holding that the city had a legitimate interest in imposing the two year residency requirement for the office of city councilman and that the requirement was rationally related to a legitimate city purpose. Whatever effect the requirement had on the candidate's right to travel interstate was too attenuated to warrant invocation of the strict standard of review.


OUTCOME: The court overruled the city's motion to dismiss and denied the writ of mandamus.

 

3 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Boston


No. 88-774


SUPREME COURT OF OHIO


46 Ohio St. 3d 108; 545 N.E.2d 1220; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 274


April 6, 1989, Submitted  
October 25, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County, No. 13107.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), contending that he was denied a fair trial in his prosecution on charges that he sexually abused his 2-year-old daughter.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's estranged wife contended that their 2-year-old daughter complained that defendant had molested her during a weekend visitation. A pediatrician and a psychologist examined the child and believed that the she was abused. Defendant was tried on charges of felonious sexual penetration and imposition in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2907.12(A)(1)(b), 2907.05(A)(3). The trial court found that although the child was able to tell the truth and communicate, she was unavailable as a witness due to her refusal to talk. The pediatrician and psychologist testified at trial as to their belief that the child was abused, that she identified her father as the perpetrator, and that she told the truth. On appeal, the court determined that defendant was entitled to a new trial. The court held that although the pediatrician and psychologist were permitted to testify as experts pursuant to Ohio R. Evid. 702-705, and the pediatrician's statements regarding the child's out-of-court identification of her father as the perpetrator were sufficiently trustworthy to be admissible, the trial court committed reversible error by admitting the experts' opinions as to the child's veracity.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and remanded the case to the trial court for further proceedings not inconsistent with the court's opinion.

 

4 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Johnson


No. 88-1524


SUPREME COURT OF OHIO


46 Ohio St. 3d 96; 545 N.E.2d 636; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 261


June 7, 1989, Submitted  
October 18, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County, No. 53323.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which convicted him of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.01(A)(1) and (2). Defendant asserted insufficient evidence, prosecutorial misconduct, improper jury charge, improper jury instructions, and that his death sentence was inappropriate.


OVERVIEW: Defendant entered a hotel where he proceeded to commit robbery and murder the desk clerk that was on duty at the time. He was convicted of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.01(A)(1) and (2). Defendant asserted insufficient evidence, prosecutorial misconduct, improper jury charge, improper jury instructions, and that the trial court erred in denying his motion for acquittal and in imposing the death penalty. The court affirmed defendant's conviction and death sentence, holding that the trial court properly overruled defendant's motion for acquittal pursuant to Ohio R. Crim. P. 29(A). The evidence was such that reasonable minds could reach different conclusions and the facts presented in the case enabled the trier of fact to conclude beyond a reasonable doubt that defendant was guilty of the offense charged, thereby excluding any reasonable theory of innocence. The court concluded that it could not say that but for the alleged error by the prosecutor during his closing argument, the jury's verdict would have been otherwise, and the death sentence was appropriate given the compelling nature of circumstantial evidence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions for aggravated murder and aggravated robbery, and affirmed his death sentence.

 

5 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Cooey


No. 88-351


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 3d 20; 544 N.E.2d 895; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 258


June 6, 1989, Submitted  
October 11, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County, No. 12943.

On the night of August 31, 1986, Wendy Offredo, twenty-one, and Dawn McCreery, twenty, finished their shift at the Brown Derby Restaurant in Montrose, Ohio. Sometime after midnight on September 1, they left for the Harbor Inn, located in Portage Lakes. They never arrived.

Their course of travel along Interstate Route 77 took them underneath the Stoner Street Bridge in Akron. Appellant, Richard Wade Cooey II, on leave from the United States Army, was standing on the bridge with two friends, Clint Dickens and Kenneth Horonetz. They were amusing themselves by throwing things off the bridge. Just as Wendy and Dawn passed below, Dickens threw a large chunk of concrete over the side. The concrete hit Wendy's car, forcing her to pull over.

Cooey and his two friends went to offer assistance to Wendy and Dawn. All five of them got into Cooey's car, and Cooey drove to a shopping mall, where they found a pay telephone on which Wendy called her mother.

While Wendy was talking to her mother, Dickens saw money in her purse. He suggested to Cooey and Horonetz that the three of them rob Wendy and Dawn. Cooey replied, "I'm game [***2] if you're game."

Everyone got back into the car, and the group left the mall. When they realized Cooey was not returning to the site of the "accident," the women asked Cooey where he was going. He pulled out a knife and ordered them to "shut up." He then gave the knife to Dickens, who opened it and held it on the women. Dawn gave up her purse, while she and Wendy asked their assailants not to hurt them. Cooey told Horonetz to tie Dawn's hands, whereupon Horonetz demanded to be let out of the car, and Cooey let him out.

After letting Horonetz out, Cooey drove to an isolated wooded area in Norton, Ohio, where Dickens raped Wendy. Cooey later admitted to police that he tried to have sex with Dawn, but claimed that he stopped. However, the coroner's examination indicated that Dawn had oral and vaginal intercourse before death.

After he was finished with Dawn, Cooey had oral and vaginal sex with Wendy. While he was with Wendy, Cooey said, "Hey, Clint, put on the Bad Company tape." After Cooey was finished with Wendy, he and Dickens put the women back into the car. Dickens then told Cooey that he had not been "really worried," although the women knew what he and Cooey looked like;  [***3] however, now that they knew Dickens' first name, they would have to be killed.

Dickens and Cooey brought the women back outside. Dickens began to beat Dawn with a nightstick belonging to Cooey. Meanwhile, Cooey grabbed Wendy in a choke hold, rendering her unconscious. He tied his bandanna around her ankles to keep her from kicking him. Dickens then tossed Cooey a shoelace, and Cooey strangled Wendy with it while Dickens strangled Dawn with his other shoelace. Cooey also beat both women with the night-stick.

Cooey and Dickens then stole Wendy's jewelry, dragged the bodies away from the road, and hid them in the weeds. After brushing away their tire tracks with branches, they went to a car wash to get rid of the bloodstains on themselves and the car. Finally, they discarded the purses.

The bodies were found later on September 1. The Summit County Coroner concluded that Wendy and Dawn had died of multiple blows to the head -- Wendy received at least three blows and Dawn at least eleven -- with strangulation also contributing to Wendy's death. He also concluded that both women had had oral and vaginal intercourse.

The day the bodies were found, Cooey visited David Jones. He  [***4] tried to sell Jones two watches (one made of black plastic), and other jewelry that was stained with blood. Cooey explained to Jones how he had acquired them: "* * * He said one of his buddies dropped * * * a rock off of a bridge onto the girl's car and that they * * * robbed them and raped them and then dumped them off behind Rolling Acres [Mall]." Cooey also boasted that Jones "should see a billy club now that it wasn't the original color."

That evening, Cooey had a visit from Terry Grant. He confided to Grant that he had killed the women, describing "how he beated [sic] them three times and * * * strangled them with shoelaces * * *." Cooey then showed Grant the nightstick, telling him "this was the stick that he beated [sic] the girls with * * *." The stick was wrapped in black electrical tape. The tape had blood on it.

On September 2, Cooey retrieved the purses and brought them to his house. When Terry Grant came to visit that day, he found Cooey, Dickens, and Horonetz burning the purses and a pair of Cooey's gym shorts.

On the evening of September 2, Akron detectives arrested Cooey at home. Cooey was wearing a watch later identified as Wendy's. He asked the arresting [***5] officers if he could take it off and leave it with his grandmother. They refused permission. Other officers then obtained a warrant to search Cooey's house and car. They found the nightstick in his room and several pieces of Wendy's jewelry in the pockets of a jacket in the car.

While the officers were searching, Cooey was being interrogated by an Akron police officer and a police detective. They questioned him from 10:00 p.m. to 12:34 a.m. (during which time Cooey guided them to Dickens' house), from 1:55 to 2:14 a.m., and from 2:45 to 3:16 a.m. There was also some conversation, of indeterminate length, between 2:14 and 2:45.

The Summit County Grand Jury indicted Cooey for the aggravated murder of Wendy Offredo, charging him with violating R.C. 2903.01(A) and (B). Each aggravated murder count carried three specifications of aggravating circumstances: R.C. 2929.04 (A)(3), R.C. 2929.04(A)(5), and R.C. 2929.04(A)(7). The indictment also charged Cooey with kidnapping Wendy with purpose to engage in sexual activity with her against her will, R.C. 2905.01(A)(4); vaginal and oral rape, R.C. 2907.02(A); and aggravated robbery, R.C. 2911.01(A)(1) and (2). Cooey was also charged with [***6] an identical array of crimes against Dawn McCreery. Finally, he was charged with felonious assault, R.C. 2903.11(A)(2), with regard to dropping the chunk of concrete on Wendy's car.

Cooey was tried by a three-judge panel of the Summit County Court of Common Pleas, which convicted him of all charges and specifications. After Cooey was convicted, the two convictions of aggravated murder under R.C. 2903.01(A) were merged into the two convictions under R.C. 2903.01(B). After the mitigation hearing, Cooey was sentenced to death for each murder. The Court of Appeals for Summit County affirmed the convictions and sentence.

The cause is before us on an appeal as of right.
State v. Cooey, 1987 Ohio App. LEXIS 10341 (Ohio Ct. App., Summit County, Dec. 23, 1987)



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The defendant's convictions for aggravated murder, kidnapping, rape, and aggravated robbery were on direct appeal after affirmance by the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio). The defendant was sentenced to death.


OVERVIEW: The defendant advanced 33 propositions of law in his appeal. The court affirmed the defendant's convictions and sentence of death. The court overruled all of the defendant's objections to issues that primarily affected his convictions. Among other things, the defendant challenged the admissibility of a tape-recorded statement he gave to police. The court rejected the defendant's arguments because the record did not support the defendant's allegation that the police officers had lied to him about a coroner's report, and even assuming the officers had lied the defendant's statement was not necessarily involuntary. The court found that there was sufficient evidence that support the convictions. As to the penalty phase, the court found that the trial court had committed some errors, but because the defendant failed to raise those issues before the appellate court, the court's review was limited to plain error, and none of the errors rose to that level. The court found that the aggravating factors outweighed the mitigating factors beyond a reasonable doubt. Under proportionality review the court found the sentence proportionate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

6 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Harrell v. Board of Educ.


Nos. 88-1501, 88-1502


Supreme Court of Ohio


46 Ohio St. 3d 55; 544 N.E.2d 924; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 257


July 26, 1989, Submitted  
October 11, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Portage County, Nos. 1970 and 1969.

On February 29, 1988, Virginia Harrell, appellee in case No. 88-1501, filed a petition with the Board of Education of the Streetsboro City School District ("Streetsboro"), appellant, pursuant to R.C. 3311.24, seeking transfer of approximately 32.917 acres of land from the Streetsboro City School District to the Kent City School District. 1 The petition consisted of two part-petitions and contained forty signatures. On the date of the petition's filing, all the signers resided within the territory sought to be transferred.


1 Because Streetsboro brings both appeals and they involve many of the same issues, case Nos. 88-1501 and 88-1502 are consolidated sua sponte.

At a public meeting on March 30, 1988, Streetsboro refused to file the petition with the State Board of Education ("state") because it had determined that the petition did not contain the minimum number of valid signatures required by R.C. 3311.24. Specifically, Streetsboro determined that four signatures could not be counted because two of them were printed, not written in cursive, one signer's name did not appear on the list of registered [***2] voters in the territory sought to be transferred, and because Harrell had signed a circulator's affidavit on one of the part-petitions in addition to having signed the petition itself.

On March 31, 1988, Harrell filed an amendment to her initial petition in the form of a supplemental part-petition containing seven signatures. Among them were new signatures for the four signers whose signatures had been invalidated by Streetsboro. The two printed signatures were signed in cursive on the supplemental part-petition, and the circulator's affidavit was completed by someone other than Harrell.

At its next regularly scheduled meeting on April 14, 1988, Streetsboro reaffirmed its decision with respect to Harrell's February 29 petition. Because R.C. 3311.24 provides a filing deadline of "prior to the first day of April in any even-numbered year," Streetsboro also determined that the amendment to the petition filed on March 31 had not been received in time for it to examine the petition's sufficiency before sending it to the state. As a result, Streetsboro also did not file the petition as amended.

An R.C. 3311.24 petition is to be signed by seventy-five percent of the qualified electors [***3] residing within that portion of a city proposed to be transferred and voting at the last general election. According to stipulations filed below, there were sixty-one qualified electors residing in that portion of Streetsboro proposed to be transferred on November 3, 1987, the date of the general election prior to the events at bar. Fifty of those electors were listed in the poll book as having voted in that election. On February 29, 1988, the date that Harrell delivered her initial petition, there were fifty-seven qualified electors residing in that portion of Streetsboro proposed to be transferred. Forty-eight of those electors had voted in the election on November 3, 1987.

Harrell sought a writ of mandamus against both Streetsboro and the state in the Court of Appeals for Portage County on April 1, 1988. The court of appeals granted the writ on July 11, 1988 by directing Streetsboro to file her petition and its amendment with the State Board of Education and by directing the state to accept them. Streetsboro appeals this decision. 2


2 The State Board of Education, on the other hand, has basically acquiesced in the court of appeals' order. Indeed, the state stipulated even prior to the appellate court's decisions in both case No. 88-1501 and case No. 88-1502 that it would consider any petitions filed by Streetsboro as if they had been filed on the statutorily required date. Thus, although a respondent below, the state now opposes Streetsboro's position on appeal.

 [***4] On February 29, 1988, Carmen Celigoj, appellee in case No. 88-1502, filed a petition with Streetsboro pursuant to R.C. 3311.24, seeking the transfer of approximately 15.13 acres of land from the Streetsboro City School District to the Kent City School District. The petition contained the signatures of Carmen Celigoj and Frank Celigoj, the two people who live in and own the territory sought to be transferred. The Celigojs are both registered voters who voted in the general election of November 3, 1987.

At a public meeting on March 30, 1988, Streetsboro refused to submit the petition to the State Board of Education because it had determined that the petition did not contain the minimum number of valid signatures required by R.C. 3311.24. Specifically, Streetsboro determined that Carmen Celigoj's signature was invalid because she had also signed the circulator's affidavit on the petition.

On March 31, 1988, Carmen Celigoj delivered an amended petition in the form of two part-petitions. One of the part-petitions contained her signature and a circulator's affidavit that had been completed by Frank Celigoj. The other part-petition contained the signature of Frank Celigoj and a circulator's [***5] affidavit that had been completed by Carmen Celigoj.

At its next regularly scheduled meeting on April 14, 1988, Streetsboro reaffirmed its decision with respect to Carmen Celigoj's initial petition. Again on the basis of the filing deadline in R.C. 3311.24, Streetsboro also determined that the amended petition was not filed in time for it to determine the petition's sufficiency before sending it to the state. As a result, Streetsboro also did not forward the amended petition.

Carmen Celigoj sought a writ of mandamus against Streetsboro and the state in the court of appeals on April 1, 1988. The court of appeals granted the writ on July 11, 1988 by directing Streetsboro to file her petitions with the State Board of Education and by directing the state to accept them. Streetsboro appeals this decision as well.

Both causes are now before this court on appeals as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgments affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In consolidated actions, the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Portage County, granted mandamus relief in favor of appellee voters and ordered appellant school district to file petitions with the Ohio State Board of Education, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.24, for the transfer of acreage from its school district to another school district. The school district filed an appeal.


OVERVIEW: The school district refused to file the voters' transfer petitions with the state board of education, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.24, as a result of alleged infirmities in the petitions. The intermediate appellate court granted mandamus relief in favor of the voters. In its decision, the intermediate appellate court ordered the school district to file the petitions with the state board of education and ordered the state board of education to accept the petitions. On review, the court affirmed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court. In reaching its decision, the court found that mandamus relief was appropriate based on the facts of the cases. The court held that the voters had a clear legal right to have the school district file the transfer petitions, that the school district was under a corresponding clear legal duty to file the transfer petitions, and that the voters had no plain and adequate remedy at law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the intermediate appellate court.

 

7 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Rossford Exempted Village School Dist. v. State Bd. of Education


No. 88-1243


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 3d 356; 544 N.E.2d 651; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 246


May 10, 1989, Submitted  
September 27, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, No. 86AP-1166.

In February 1986, the three owners of a parcel of property situated within the Rossford Exempted Village School District, 1 Wood County ("Rossford"), and bordering, in part, on the Perrysburg Exempted Village School District, Wood County ("Perrysburg"), requested that their property be transferred from the Rossford to the Perrysburg School District pursuant to R.C. 3311.24. The Rossford Board of Education adopted a resolution rejecting the requested transfer and transmitted both the request for transfer and the board's resolution of disapproval to the State Department of Education. The Rossford board recommended that the transfer be disapproved.


1 The State Board of Education correctly indicated to the court of appeals that the name used by plaintiff should have been "Board of Education of the Rossford Exempted Village School District" rather than "Rossford Exempted Village School District." This fact, however, does not affect the merits of this case and it is understood that the plaintiff is the Rossford Board of Education.

The Secretary of the State Board of Education notified both school districts that [***2] in accordance with the provisions of R.C. 119.07, the state board intended to consider the transfer and that pursuant to R.C. Chapter 119 the parties were entitled to a hearing. Pursuant to that notice, Rossford requested a hearing.

The matter was heard by a referee, who, following a hearing, recommended that the State Board of Education approve the request for transfer. Rossford filed objections to the referee's recommendation. However, at a September 8, 1986 meeting, the State Board of Education overruled the objections and approved the transfer of territory. Rossford appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, naming the State Board of Education and the property owners as defendants.

The property owners filed a motion to dismiss the appeal on the grounds that an order of the State Board of Education approving a transfer of property pursuant to R.C. 3311.24 is a legislative act which is not appealable pursuant to R.C. 119.12. The State Board of Education also filed a motion to dismiss, alleging "lack of subject matter jurisdiction and/or for failure to state a claim upon which relief may be granted." The trial court agreed that the State Board of Education's decision [***3] was a legislative act and dismissed the appeal.

The Tenth District Court of Appeals reversed and remanded the cause to the trial court, holding that a village board of education has a right, pursuant to R.C. 119.12, to appeal the state board's decision in an R.C. 3311.24 proceeding.

This cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State Board of Education challenged an order of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which reversed and remanded a judgment dismissing appellee school district's appeal of the State Board's approval of the transfer of property to another school district pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3311.24.


OVERVIEW: Property owners requested that their property be transferred from the school district to another school district. The State Board approved the transfer, and the school district appealed to the court of common pleas. The court of common pleas dismissed the appeal, finding that the State Board's decision was not appealable. The court of appeals reversed and remanded the case to the trial court. The court held that the State Board's order approving the transfer of school district territory pursuant to § 3311.24 could be appealed to the court of common pleas pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 119.12. The State Board notified the parties that they were entitled to a hearing pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 119, and a hearing was conducted. The order issued by the State Board was an adjudication that determined the rights and duties of the property owners and both school districts. It was an adjudication order resulting from quasi-judicial proceedings and was an appealable order pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 119.12.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order reversing and remanding the judgment dismissing the school district's appeal of the State Board's approval of the transfer of property to another school district.

 

8 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Coleman


No. 87-2074


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 3d 298; 544 N.E.2d 622; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 238


April 25, 1989, Submitted  
September 20, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, No. C-850490.

On July 7, 1984, Alton Coleman (appellant), and Debra D. Brown approached the home of the Reverend and Mrs. Millard Gay of Dayton, Ohio. After conversing with Mr. Gay, they stayed at the Gays' home from July 7 through July 9, 1984. Appellant and Brown accompanied the Gays to religious services in Lockwood, Ohio, on July 9, 1984. The next day, the Gays drove appellant and Brown to downtown Cincinnati and dropped them off.

On July 11, 1984 at approximately 10:00 a.m., Tonnie Storey, age fifteen, left her home in Cincinnati wearing rusty brown cutoff shorts, a beige sleeveless blouse with yellow rings, blue tassel shoes and a Michael Jackson button. She was next seen at Bloom Junior High School at approximately 11:45 a.m. by a teacher.

Later that same day, between 5:00 and 6:00 p.m., a classmate saw Tonnie on the corner of May and Morgan Streets in Cincinnati in the company of a man and a woman. The classmate identified the man as Coleman. When Tonnie had not returned home by 4:30 p.m. that day, her mother called the police and reported her missing.

On July 19, 1984, a body was discovered in an abandoned building [***2] on May Street by a real estate agent. A Michael Jackson button and a pair of brown shorts with keys in the pocket were discovered in the area where the body was found. The keys identified by decedent's father belonged to the Storey residence. The body was badly decomposed and identification was made through fingerprints. The body was identified as that of Tonnie Storey. The cause of death of Tonnie was homicidal asphyxia.

Appellant and Brown were jointly indicted for the murder of Tonnie on October 10, 1984, in a three-count indictment containing specifications. The first specification charged pursuant to R.C. 2929.04(A)(5) was that the aggravated murder was part of a course of conduct involving the purposeful killing of or attempt to kill two or more persons. The second death-penalty specification was dismissed prior to trial. The third specification charged pursuant to R.C. 2929.04(A)(3) was that the offense was committed for the purpose of escaping detection, apprehension, trial, or punishment for another offense.

Appellant was tried separately from co-indictee Brown. The jury found appellant guilty of aggravated murder and guilty of specification No. 1. The mitigation [***3] hearing was held one day after the guilt phase was completed, and the jury recommended the penalty of death.

On June 24, 1985, the trial court accepted the jury's recommendation and sentenced appellant to death. Appellant appealed to the court of appeals which affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

This cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted by a jury of various crimes, including aggravated murder with a specification charged pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 2929.04(A)(5), and the jury accepted the recommendation and sentenced defendant to death. After his conviction and sentence were affirmed by the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), defendant's conviction and sentence were reviewed on appeal as a matter of right.


OVERVIEW: The court affirmed the conviction and sentence. Admission of "other acts" evidence linking defendant to five other murders was proper because it revealed a unique, identifiable plan of criminal activity. Nor was it error to admit testimony by a prosecuting attorney, the only witness available on a critical issue. Claims of error relating to the grand jury, to denial of a motion to change venue, to the timing of trial, and to the severance of his trial from a co-indictee's trial were all rejected. The court rejected claims arising from the trial court's refusal to appoint a jury-selection expert and other juror-related claims, including the trial court's excusing for cause those jurors who refused to impose the death penalty. The court also rejected constitutional claims based on the fact that the penalty phase began the day after the guilt phase concluded because defendant did not claim that mitigating evidence would have been available in any event. Defendant's efforts to invoke his grandmother's constitutional rights were rejected, as were his claims of insufficient evidence, ineffective assistance, and constitutional defects in the state death penalty statute.


OUTCOME: The court upheld the defendant's conviction as well as the jury's imposition of a death sentence.

 

9 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Dickerson


No. 88-662


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 3d 206; 543 N.E.2d 1250; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 227


May 10, 1989, Submitted  
September 6, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County, No. L-85-433.

Defendant-appellant, Frederick Dickerson, and Denise Howard were involved in a relationship between 1978 and March 1985. Out of this relationship, two children, Frederick and Jovan, were born. Howard decided to terminate her relationship with appellant because of verbal and physical abuse he had allegedly inflicted upon her. Shortly thereafter, Howard and her children moved in with Kevin McCoy, who shared a duplex apartment with Davida McClain and her children, Tony, Donya, and Nicole. Nicole was also known as Sue. The apartment was located at 1552 1/2 Pinewood in Toledo, Ohio.

Upon discovering Howard's new address, appellant went there on May 26, 1985 in an attempt to renew his relationship with Howard. When Howard rebuffed appellant's overtures for a reconciliation, appellant assaulted her. This assault was witnessed by Curtis Jewell, a patrolman with the Toledo Police Department who was off-duty at the time. Jewell asked his father to call the police and went to assist Howard. As a result of this incident, appellant was placed under arrest and charged with disorderly conduct. Subsequently, Howard, her [***2] children and McCoy went to the residence of McCoy's mother and returned to the Pinewood apartment at approximately 2:30 a.m. on May 27, 1985. At that time, Howard found a note on her car window from appellant. Approximately an hour later, Howard saw appellant at the side of the Pinewood apartment and promptly called the police. Howard testified that she called the police again at approximately 4:00 a.m. upon hearing someone at the side of the apartment, and phoned them again approximately one-half hour later when she observed appellant near the apartment. Upon investigating each time, the police were unable to locate appellant in the vicinity of the apartment.

Shortly thereafter, however, Howard testified that she heard a window in the apartment bathroom being opened, whereupon she awakened McCoy. McCoy left the bedroom, grabbed a chair and apparently charged toward the bathroom window. Howard ran out the door and down the stairs when she heard a crash and a gunshot. Upon running to a nearby house, she called the police. Before the police could respond to the call, appellant shot McCoy in the chest and in the back of the head. Appellant also shot Nicole McClain twice in the [***3] face. The record indicates that McCoy died at the scene, and that McClain died within approximately two hours of the shootings.

Appellant was arrested at approximately 6:00 a.m. next to the rear stairwell outside the Pinewood apartment. The arresting officers recovered a .22 caliber nine-shot revolver from appellant that was later identified as the murder weapon.

On May 31, 1985, appellant was indicted by the grand jury on two counts of aggravated murder ( R.C. 2903.01 [B]). Each count carried a felony murder specification ( R.C. 2929.04 [A][7]) and a mass murder specification ( R.C. 2929.04[A][5]), as well as firearm specifications ( R.C. 2929.71).

On October 18, 1985, appellant waived his right to a trial by jury. Consequently, his trial before a three-judge panel commenced on November 4, 1985. The guilt phase of the trial concluded the following day, whereupon the panel returned verdicts finding appellant guilty of both counts of aggravated murder, as well as the specifications attached to those counts.

The mitigation hearing took place immediately thereafter, and on November 7, 1985, the panel announced its judgment that the aggravating circumstances outweighed the mitigating [***4] factors beyond a reasonable doubt. Therefore, the panel imposed the death sentence for each count of aggravated murder and two consecutive three-year terms of actual incarceration for the conviction of the two firearm specifications. On November 13, 1985, the panel entered its judgment entry of sentence.

Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed the trial court's judgment of conviction and sentence.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the Court of Appeals (Ohio) which affirmed defendant's conviction for two counts of aggravated murder in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 2903.01(B) and defendant's death sentence.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted in the trial court before a three-judge panel of two counts of aggravated murder in violation of § 2903.01(B), and was sentenced to death. Defendant appealed. On appeal, the court held: (1) defendant's waiver of jury trial was knowing, intelligent and voluntary, even though one member of a three-judge panel presided in a prior criminal proceeding in which defendant was involved; (2) in imposing the death penalty, the trial court's consideration of the method of killing, the youth of one of the victims, the number of shots fired, and the range at which the shots were fired, was proper because those details were relevant to aggravating circumstance that the offense was part of a course of conduct involving purposeful killing of, or an attempt to kill, two or more persons by the offender; and (3) the trial court properly imposed the death penalty, even though the trial court failed to state reasons why it found that the aggravating circumstances outweighed mitigating factors beyond a reasonable doubt and that no mitigating factors were established, because that failure to state an obvious conclusion was not prejudicial error.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions and sentence.

 

10 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


In re Complaint of Residents of Struthers


No. 88-1147


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 3d 227; 543 N.E.2d 794; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 221


May 30, 1989, Submitted  
September 6, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, No. 88-215-WW-CMR.

On or about December 16, 1987, the City Council of the city of Struthers, Ohio, passed Ordinance No. 87-8482, establishing rates to be charged by Ohio Water Service Company for water supplied to the city and its inhabitants for a two-year term commencing January 1, 1988. Section 10 of the ordinance provides in relevant part:

"This Ordinance is hereby declared to be an emergency measure * * *. Said emergency exists by reason of the fact that said rates must be established and contract must be entered into immediately, and, as such, this Ordinance shall take effect immediately upon its passage and approval by the Mayor."

On February 12, 1988, appellant Tony Marchionda, a taxpayer of the city of Struthers, filed a complaint with the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio ("commission") entitled "Taxpayers' Complaint as to Unreasonable and Unjust Rates Pursuant to O.R.C. 4909.36." Attached to the complaint were copies of petitions purporting to bear the signatures of a total of 1,835 registered voters of the city of Struthers who supported the complaint filed before the commission. In objecting to the contract  [***2] rates entered into by the city and the Ohio Water Service Company, the complainants-appellants requested "* * * that this matter be set for hearing at a convenient location here in Mahoning County within a reasonable time in the future."

By entry of March 8, 1988, the commission sua sponte dismissed the complaint on the grounds that it was without jurisdiction to review the terms of the ordinance contract by virtue of the holding in Link v. Pub. Util. Comm. (1921), 102 Ohio St. 336, 131 N.E. 796. Appellants' application for a rehearing was denied.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers challenged the decision of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio that dismissed sua sponte their complaint on the grounds that it was without jurisdiction to review the terms of a two-year ordinance contract entered into by the city council and a water utility for water supplied to the city and its inhabitants.


OVERVIEW: In the dispute over the rates set by the city and the water utility, the taxpayers sought appellate relief but were stopped at the outset by Commission's sua sponte dismissal of their complaint. In affirming that decision, the court noted that the Commission was without jurisdiction to review the terms of the ordinance contract pursuant to Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 5 that allowed municipalities to contract with any company by ordinance. Further, § 5 required 30 days before the ordinance became effective, during which time the only challenges to the contract could come from 10 percent of the electors demanding a referendum. If such referendum were demanded, then the ordinance could not take effect until it had been submitted to the electors and approved by a majority. Thus, the court concluded that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.36 was constitutionally invalid in its provisions allowing 10 percent of the electors to file complaints with the Commission in lieu of seeking a referendum. Therefore, the court ruled that the Commission acted properly, and was neither unreasonable nor unlawful, in dismissing the complaint in reliance on prior caselaw and the constitutional provisions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's decision and its dismissal of the taxpayers' complaint.

 

11 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Doersam v. Industrial Com. of Ohio


No. 88-51


Supreme Court of Ohio


45 Ohio St. 3d 115; 543 N.E.2d 1169; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 216


June 6, 1989, Submitted  
August 23, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, No. 86AP-710.

ON REHEARING.

On November 8, 1973, Robert J. Doersam sustained an injury in the course of his employment. Upon application for workers' compensation benefits, Doersam's claim was initially allowed for myocardial infarction. On September 27, 1983, Doersam suffered a second myocardial infarction, again in the course of his employment. Doersam's second myocardial infarction was fatal.

Appellee, Betty Doersam, the surviving spouse of Doersam, filed a claim for death benefits on behalf of herself and her minor daughter. Her claim was allowed, by a district hearing officer, and appellee was awarded sixty-six and two-thirds percent of Doersam's average weekly wage but not to exceed sixty-six and two-thirds percent of the statewide average weekly wage.

Appellee objected to this award, claiming that she was entitled to receive sixty-six and two-thirds percent of her deceased husband's average weekly wage but not to exceed one hundred percent of the statewide average weekly wage. Based on her objection, appellee appealed the award to the Columbus Regional Board of Review. The regional board affirmed the order of [***2] the district hearing officer. Appellee appealed to the Industrial Commission which affirmed the board of review.

On July 25, 1986, appellee commenced an action in mandamus in the court of appeals. In her mandamus action, appellee challenged the constitutionality of the statutory structure of death benefits found in R.C. 4123.59 (B). Appellee's contention was that the statutory provisions found in R.C. 4123.59(B) denied her equal protection under the law and, in addition, violated Section 26, Article II of the Ohio Constitution and the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.

The court of appeals, acting pursuant to its constitutional authority in original actions, granted appellee's request for a writ of mandamus. The court of appeals ordered the commission "* * * to vacate its order for an award of death benefits and to award said benefits at the maximum compensation provided in R.C. 4123.59."

In issuing its order, the court of appeals held that the statute in question ( R.C. 4123.59[B]) violated the Equal Protection Clause because the classification of death-benefits recipients set forth in R.C. 4123.59(B) had no rational basis and was [***3] therefore violative of both the United States and Ohio Constitutions.

From the judgment of the court of appeals, the commission-appellant appealed to this court. On December 30, 1988, this court issued its first decision in this case. In that decision, State, ex rel. Doersam, v. Indus. Comm. (1988), 40 Ohio St. 3d 201, 533 N.E. 2d 321, we held, by a split vote, that R.C. 4123.59(B), as amended in 1976, was unconstitutional and that the statute was to be reverted to its pre-1976 language.

From that decision, both parties requested a rehearing. This request was joined by amici curiae, AFL-CIO and the United Autoworkers of America.

On February 22, 1989, we granted rehearing and ordered that the issue be rebriefed and the case be set for oral argument.

The cause is now before us as an appeal of right and on rehearing.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee, surviving spouse of a person who died from a myocardial infarction at work, brought a claim for workers' compensation. Appellant company sought review from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which awarded death benefits at the maximum compensation as provided in Ohio Rev. Code § 4123.59.


OVERVIEW: Appellee, in her original action in the court of appeals, challenged the language in Ohio Rev. Code § 4123.59(B) which would have entitled appellee to more per week if the injury occurred after January 1, 1976, and less if it occurred prior to January 2, 1976. The court of appeals found that such language violated the equal protection clause. The court reviewed whether the language in the statute brought about the violation of the constitutional rights of certain "wholly dependent" persons. The court found § 4123.59(B), as written, legislatively created separate classifications of "wholly dependent" persons based only on the date when an injury to a worker occurred. The court could not find that the establishment of the separate classes was for the advancement of any legitimate governmental purpose. Thus, the statute created a suspect class and, therefore, was violative of the guarantee of protection of equal laws. The court found, however, that the remainder of the statute was effective and operable.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

12 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Schump v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.


No. 88-348


Supreme Court of Ohio


44 Ohio St. 3d 148; 541 N.E.2d 1040; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 180; CCH Prod. Liab. Rep. P12,226


April 4, 1989, Submitted  
August 2, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County, No. 13020.

Appellant and cross-appellee, Warren L. Schump, was employed as a truck driver by appellee and cross-appellant, Firestone Tire & Rubber Company ("Firestone"), working out of Firestone's Brookpark Retread Center. On July 12, 1983, Schump was driving a truck within the scope of his employment, which truck was equipped with tires manufactured by Firestone. Evidently one of the front tires blew out, and Schump suffered personal injuries when he lost control of the truck and veered into an embankment.

On March 1, 1985, Schump and his wife filed the instant complaint against Firestone. The first claim for relief alleged various theories of products liability, including strict liability, breach of implied warranty, and negligence. The second claim for relief alleged an intentional tort, i.e., that Firestone "intentionally and/or with the belief that injury was substantially certain to occur, failed to replace the defective truck tire on the tractor-trailer operated by * * * Schump * * *." The complaint also included a claim by Mrs. Schump for loss of her husband's services, society, companionship,  [***2] and consortium. Firestone answered, denying the allegations of liability and asserting seven affirmative defenses.

On May 8, 1986, Firestone filed a motion for summary judgment in its favor on all allegations. In its memorandum in support of this motion, Firestone argued that the evidence does not show intentionally tortious conduct by Firestone, and that because Schump was injured in the course of his employment, his recourse is under the Workers' Compensation Act and not in a civil action for damages. Plaintiffs' response was twofold: (1) that intentional tort actions are not barred, and that such an action may be maintained under the facts of this case; and (2) that a products liability action may be maintained under the "dual-capacity doctrine," since, with regard to the tires on the truck Schump was driving, Firestone's relationship to Schump was both employer to employee and manufacturer to product user.

In its reply, Firestone discussed the 1986 amendment to the Workers' Compensation Act, specifically R.C. 4121.80, and its applicability to plaintiffs' action. Firestone argued that the evidence fails to establish an "intentional tort" as defined in R.C. 4121.80(G)(1),  [***3] and that, under the language of R.C. 4121.80(B), the workers' compensation system has completely abrogated the "common law dual-capacity exception" to employer immunity. In the alternative, Firestone argued that the dual-capacity doctrine is inapplicable here. Thereafter, the parties filed opposing memoranda addressing the constitutionality or retroactively applying the 1986 workers' compensation amendments in this case.

On January 20, 1987, the trial court applied R.C. 4121.80 and granted Firestone's motion for summary judgment as to all issues. Regarding plaintiffs' dual-capacity claim, the court evidently was of the view that R.C. 4121.80(B) had not completely eliminated the dual-capacity doctrine. Nevertheless, the court held that the dual-capacity doctrine is inapplicable in this case. The court also held that under R.C. 4121.80(G), plaintiffs' intentional tort claim could not be maintained.

The court of appeals affirmed in part and reversed in part. Relying on this court's cases on the dual-capacity doctrine, the court agreed that an action under the doctrine may not be maintained here. However, the court sustained plaintiffs' assignment of error regarding the application [***4] of R.C. 4121.80, holding that retroactive application would be unconstitutional. 

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion and cross-motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio) affirmed a grant by the trial court of defendant employer's motion for summary judgment on plaintiff employee and plaintiff spouse's complaint for personal injuries pursuant to the dual capacity doctrine and reversed the grant of summary judgment on the employee and his spouse's intentional tort claim. Both sides appealed.


OVERVIEW: While operating a truck in the course of his employment, the employee was injured when one of the truck's tires, which was manufactured by the employer, blew out. The court held that the grant of summary judgment in favor of the employer on the employee and his spouse's claim under the dual capacity doctrine was proper. In order for the dual-capacity doctrine to apply, there had to be an allegation and showing that the employer occupied two independent and unrelated relationships with the employee, that at the time of these roles of the employer there were occasioned two different obligations to this employee, and that the employer had during such time assumed a role other than that of employer. The employee did not make this showing. The court also found that reversal of the grant of summary judgment on the employee and his spouse's intentional tort claim was proper because retroactive application of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4121.80, which barred this claim, was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: Judgment was affirmed and remanded for consideration of the employee and his spouse's intentional tort claim according to the common law standards applicable to claims predating the effective date of the statutory bar.

 

13 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Bridges v. McMackin


No. 88-2165


Supreme Court of Ohio


44 Ohio St. 3d 135; 541 N.E.2d 1035; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 167


May 30, 1988, Submitted  
July 26, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County, No. 11275.

Appellant, Larry E. Bridges, alleges that he is confined in Marion Correctional Institution, of which appellee is the superintendent. Appellant petitioned the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County for a writ of habeas corpus, although Marion County, where Marion Correctional Institution is located, is not in the Second Appellate District. The court of appeals therefore dismissed the petition on the ground that the court lacked jurisdiction to entertain it under R.C. 2725.03, which provides in pertinent part:

"If a person restrained of his liberty is an inmate of a state benevolent or penal institution, the location of which is fixed by statute * * *, no court or judge other than the courts or judges of the county in which such institution is located has jurisdiction to issue or determine a writ of habeas corpus for his production or discharge."

The cause is before us upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

14 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Klinck


No. 88-630


Supreme Court of Ohio


44 Ohio St. 3d 108; 541 N.E.2d 590; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 157


April 6, 1989, Submitted  
July 19, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Lucas County, Nos. L-87-174 and L-87-173.

On November 21, 1986, the defendant-appellant, Jeannie Ogren, and eighteen others were indicted by the Grand Jury of Lucas County on ninety-four counts of illegal procession of drug documents in violation of R.C. 2925.23. All counts involved pentazocine, a Schedule IV(E)(1) drug on the Ohio Controlled Substance Schedules. Pentazocine is also known as Talwin.

Appellant, and others, filed motions to dismiss, alleging that pentazocine had been placed on the Ohio schedules by the Attorney General of the United States, acting pursuant to an unconstitutional delegation of state legislative authority.

The Court of Common Pleas of Lucas County held that R.C. 3719.43 created an unconstitutional delegation of state legislative authority to a federal agency and dismissed all ninety-four counts of the indictment.

Upon appeal, the court of appeals found R.C. 3719.43 constitutional and reversed. Finding its decision to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Licking County in State v.. Hall (July 1, 1982), No. CA-2854, unreported, the appellate court certified the record of the  [***2] case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which reversed a judgment of the trial court that dismissed all 94 counts of an indictment against defendant and others for the illegal possession of drug documents in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2925.23.


OVERVIEW: Defendant and others were indicted on 94 counts of illegal possession of drug documents in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2925.23. Defendant and others filed motions to dismiss alleging that the drug had been placed on the state schedules by a federal official pursuant to an unconstitutional delegation of state legislative authority. Upon review, the trial court dismissed all 94 counts of the indictment. The trial court held that § 2925.23 created an unconstitutional delegation of state legislative authority to a federal agency. Upon further review, the appellate court reversed the trial court's judgment. The appellate court later determined that its judgment conflicted with a decision rendered in another county and certified the record to the court for a final determination. The appellate court's judgment was affirmed by the court. The court held that the procedure in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3719.43 did not result in an unconstitutional delegation of state legislative authority. The court noted that the state pharmacy board retained control over the decisions made by the federal agency.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

15 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Lawrence


No. 88-1127


Supreme Court of Ohio


44 Ohio St. 3d 24; 541 N.E.2d 451; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 136


February 22, 1989, Submitted  
July 5, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County, No. 52036.

Jeffrey J. Lawrence, appellant herein, his wife Janet, and their children lived next door to Jesse Mooney, his wife Cheryl, and their children in Garfield Heights, Ohio. Although their relationship was initially friendly, several neighborhood disputes caused the friendship to deteriorate to a state of intense hostility.

In the early afternoon hours of August 24, 1985, a party began in the Mooney garage. As the evening wore on, the party involved drinking beer, listening to music, and dancing.

Disturbed by the noise of the party, appellant called the Garfield Heights Police Department shortly after 11:00 p.m. to complain. The investigating officer spoke with Jesse Mooney, found no cause for the complaint, and returned to routine patrol duties. The party continued.

At 1:45 a.m., Cheryl Mooney and Chuck Vlach returned from another party. At this time, the party in the Mooney garage consisted of Jesse, Cheryl, and Heidi Mooney, as well as Thurman and Deborah Dempsey, John Gilbert, and Chuck Vlach. The Garfield Heights Police Department received the next complaint about the party from Janet Lawrence at approximately [***2] 3:15 a.m. The investigating officer returned to the scene and heard low music. He advised Jesse Mooney that the police had received another complaint and asked him to move the party into the house.

After the officer's departure, an angry verbal exchange occurred between the people at the Mooney party and the appellant. Cheryl Mooney yelled towards the Lawrence house suggesting that Janet Lawrence had called the police. Appellant responded by yelling from a second-story window ordering the Mooneys to shut up. Words in the nature of a challenge were shouted back at appellant.

Concerned about her husband's possible reaction to the challenge, Janet Lawrence went upstairs where she found him dressing. As appellant left the bedroom, he picked up some shotgun shells and told Janet to call the police. She called the police as he left the house.

Within minutes, the first shot was fired by appellant from his backyard. The shotgun pellets struck Cheryl Mooney and Thurman Dempsey. As Cheryl Mooney staggered into the garage, Jesse Mooney moved to the front of the garage and fired two shots from a handgun toward appellant's house. Running from his yard and across the front of the Mooney [***3] residence, appellant proceeded up the driveway and fired several more shots. Jesse Mooney was fatally struck with pellets from at least two of appellant's shotgun blasts. Heidi Mooney and Deborah Dempsey were also struck by shotgun pellets. Continuing into the garage, appellant threw Cheryl Mooney on top of her husband and fired a shot at close range causing her death. Appellant then left the area.

On August 30, 1985, Lawrence was indicted by the Cuyahoga County Grand Jury on two counts of aggravated murder, each containing a multiple-murder and a firearm specification, and three counts of attempted murder, all with firearm specifications.

The trial began on March 10, 1986. After the state had rested, appellant called a number of witnesses, including Dr. John P. Wilson, a clinical psychologist. Wilson testified that appellant suffered from four disorders at the time of the shootings. "First is the major depression, major depressive disregard [sic]; secondly is the post traumatic stress disorder, chronic; third is dissociative disorder, and four is schizotypal personality disorder." Wilson testified that it was his considered opinion that appellant was in a dissociative [***4] state and could not distinguish right from wrong and could not refrain from his actions at the time of the homicides. 1 


1 Appellant had served in the armed forces and was briefly stationed in Vietnam from December 1972 through January 1973.

Drs. William H. Grant and Phillip J. Resnick, psychiatrists called as state witnesses, disagreed with Wilson's opinion that appellant was unable to distinguish right from wrong at the time of the shootings. However, they concurred in Wilson's conclusion that appellant was suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder. Resnick explained that this disorder "is manifested by sleep disturbance, startling easily during loud noises, and results from being subjected to a major stress."

At the conclusion of all evidence at the guilt phase, the trial court instructed the jury on the charges in the indictment and, upon request by the state and without objection by defense counsel, on the lesser included offense of murder. The trial court refused appellant's request for an instruction on the offense of voluntary manslaughter. The trial court also instructed the jury on the affirmative defense of insanity.

On April 4, 1986, the jury found the [***5] appellant guilty of two counts of aggravated murder, the multiple-murder and firearm specifications, and two counts of attempted murder and two additional firearm specifications. Sequestered until the penalty phase began on April 7, 1986, the jury recommended the imposition of the death penalty after one day of deliberation.

On April 17, 1986, the trial court followed the jury's recommendation. In addition to the imposition of the death penalty on both counts of aggravated murder, the trial court sentenced appellant to not less than ten and not more than twenty-five years on the two counts of attempted murder, with three years' actual incarceration on the firearm specifications.

The court of appeals affirmed the convictions and sentences on May 2, 1988. The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed as of right the judgment from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed defendant's aggravated murder convictions and death sentences. The jury also found defendant guilty of multiple-murder and firearm specifications, two counts of attempted murder, and two additional firearm specifications, and the trial court imposed additional sentences on those counts.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was a Vietnam veteran who suffered from post-traumatic stress syndrome. The State's doctors disputed whether he suffered from other disorders. Defendant's relationship with his neighbors was hostile. Defendant shot at his neighbors and their guests, killing two of them, after the neighbors verbally abused him for calling the police to complain about a party they were hosting. Affirming defendant's conviction, the court held inter alia that the trial court properly refused to give an instruction on voluntary manslaughter because the jury could not have found that the provocation was reasonably sufficient to have incited him into using deadly force. The court vacated both death sentences because the aggravating circumstances did not outweigh the mitigating factors beyond a reasonable doubt. The court found that five of the seven mitigating factors in Ohio Rev. Code § 2929.04(B) were present, including that one victim's return of fire provoked defendant to continue firing. The court also took into account defendant's care of his mother during high school, his voluntary military service, his love for his children, and the severe depression caused by his son's death.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions, vacated both death sentences, and remanded the matter to the trial court for resentencing.

 

16 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Thomas v. Kane


No. 88-1484


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 3d 164; 539 N.E.2d 1122; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 113


March 28, 1989, Submitted  
June 14, 1989, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] This cause was originally styled State, ex rel. Draper et al., v.. Kane et al. The action by petitioner Marvin L. Warner against respondent Judge Robert P. Ruehlman for a writ of prohibition was voluntarily dismissed in the court of appeals.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, No. C-880200.

Appellee, Lawrence A. Kane, Jr., brought various criminal actions against petitioner Marvin L. Warner in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County, case No. B-854622, as special prosecutor for the state. Kane was appointed by the Attorney General. On March 21, 1988, attorney Gerald L. Draper 1 filed a motion for leave to file an action in quo warranto in the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, proffering a complaint that challenged the constitutionality of the law under which Kane was appointed. The court of appeals overruled the motion, stating in part:

"In the record the petitioners have presented to us there is no indication that a demand (or a request) to proceed was made on either the attorney general or the county prosecutor. Similarly, there are no affidavits, depositions or other evidentiary materials which demonstrate any disability or conflict  [***2] of interest. The statute speaks of granting leave in permissive terms, and we hold that Draper has failed to establish a sufficient basis to convince us that it would be appropriate to exercise our discretion in this instance." (Footnote ommitted.)


1 Attorney Robin Thomas was substituted for Gerald L. Draper as the petitioner-appellant, effective March 13, 1989.

The cause is before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant attorney challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which overruled the attorney's motion for leave to file an action in quo warranto. The attorney sought to file a complaint alleging that the law under which appellee special prosecutor was appointed was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The attorney alleged that the special prosecutor had a disqualifying interest in a criminal case. The attorney filed a motion for leave to file an action in quo warranto proffering a complaint that challenged the constitutionality of the law under which the special prosecutor was appointed. The appellate court overruled the attorney's motion. Upon review, the court affirmed. The court held that the appellate court did not abuse its discretion when it overruled the attorney's motion. The court recognized that the appellate court had discretion to appoint an attorney of its choice to bring or prosecute an action on behalf of the state whenever the prosecuting attorney was absent, interested in the action, or disabled as set forth in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2733.07. The court noted that the appellate court did not accept the attorney's argument that the special prosecutor's disqualifying interest was self-evident. The court further noted that the attorney presented no evidence that the prosecuting attorney had a disqualifying interest. The court refused to address the attorney's arguments challenging the constitutionality of the law under which the special prosecutor was appointed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment that overruled the attorney's motion for leave to file an action in quo warranto.

 

17 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Bd. of Comm'rs v. City of Lebanon


No. 88-518


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 3d 188; 540 N.E.2d 242; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 108


March 29, 1989, Submitted  
June 14, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Warren County, No. CA86-09-061.

On April 10, 1986, the council of the appellee, city of Lebanon, enacted three ordinances, pursuant to R.C. 709.14, authorizing the annexation of three tracts of real estate contiguous to the city. Petitions for annexation were filed with the Board of Commissioners of Warren County ("board") the next day. On April 15, the council adopted three new ordinances authorizing, in effect, the filing of amended petitions, apparently in order to make technical changes reflecting the fact that each of the three tracts was solely owned by Warren County. 1 These amended petitions were filed the next day.


1 The trial court found that "one tract consists of 62.213 acres and is presently occupied by the Warren County Agricultural Society. The second tract consists of 103.132 acres upon which is located the Warren County Justice Center and the Common Pleas Courthouse. The third tract consists of 8.29 acres and is technically a part of the second tract, but separated from it by State Route 48."

Appellant board refused to take action upon the petitions and, instead, on May 6, 1986, filed the instant action seeking a [***2] declaratory judgment as to the proper procedure to follow in acting upon them. Named as defendants in this action were the appellee, appellant Warren County Agricultural Society ("Agricultural Society") and the Trustees of Turtlecreek Township. 2 The appellee city filed an answer and cross-petition, seeking, inter alia, a writ of mandamus directing the appellant board to approve the three amended petitions, as required by then R.C. 709.16. 3 Appellant Agricultural Society answered both pleadings, claiming an equitable interest in the Warren County fairgrounds property. The cause was submitted to the court upon the stipulations, exhibits and briefs of the parties.


2 The Trustees of Turtlecreek Township filed no responsive pleadings, and are not a party to this appeal.


3 At the time of the filing of the amended annexation petitions, R.C. 709.16 provided, in pertinent part:

"(B) If the only territory to be annexed is contiguous territory owned by the municipal corporation seeking annexation and if such territory is located entirely within the same county as the municipal corporation seeking annexation, or if the only territory to be annexed is contiguous territory owned by the county, upon receipt of the petition required by section 709.15 of the Revised Code, the board of county commissioners shall, by resolution, approve the annexation and make such adjustments of funds, unpaid taxes, claims, indebtedness, and other fiscal matters as the board determines to be proper. The annexation shall be complete upon the entry, pursuant to the board's resolution, of an order upon the journal of the board of county commissioners authorizing such annexation. Section 709.17 of the Revised Code does not apply to an annexation of territory described in this division." (Emphasis added.) (140 Ohio Laws, Part I, 102.)

 [***3] Prior to the rendering of judgment by the trial court, the General Assembly enacted H.B. No. 981, effective June 7, 1986, which amended R.C. 709.16, in pertinent part, as follows:

"(C) If the only territory to be annexed is contiguous territory owned by the county, upon receipt of the petition required by section 709.15 of the Revised Code, the board of county commissioners, by resolution, may disapprove the annexation, or may approve the annexation and make such adjustments of funds, unpaid taxes, claims, indebtedness, and other fiscal matters as the board determines to be proper. The annexation shall be complete upon the entry, pursuant to the board's resolution, of an order upon the journal of the board authorizing such annexation.

"(D) The board of county commissioners shall act upon a petition for annexation filed by a municipal corporation under this section within thirty days after receipt of the petition * * *." 4 (Emphasis added.) (141 Ohio Laws, Part III, 6158, 6162-6163.)


4 The amendments contained in subsection (C) were first added by S.B. No. 238, effective May 23, 1986, some five weeks after the filing of the amended annexation petitions. (141 Ohio Laws, Part I, 488, 492.)

 [***4] The trial court determined that these newly enacted provisions were "procedural" in nature, and thus could be applied retrospectively to the petitions filed here. The court found that appellant Agricultural Society had no ownership interest in the fairgrounds property, and rejected appellee's constitutional challenge to the amended statute. Finally, the court ordered that a writ of mandamus issue directing appellant board to proceed with the annexation petitions before it in accordance with R.C. 709.16, as effective June 7, 1986.

The court of appeals reversed in part, holding that retroactive application of H.B. No. 981 would deprive the city of a vested, substantive right to mandatory approval of its annexation petitions as provided under the former law, and was thus violative of the proscription against retroactive laws contained within Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution. 5 The court modified the writ of mandamus to reflect that the version of R.C. 709.16 existing on the date on which this action was filed was to be applied by appellant board.


5 Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution provides in part:

"The general assembly shall have no power to pass retroactive laws, or laws impairing the obligation of contracts * * *."

 [***5] The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, county board of commissioners and county agricultural society, sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Warren County (Ohio), which determined that the amended provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.16 could not applied to appellee city's amended petitions for the annexation of three tracts of land.


OVERVIEW: Pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.14, the city enacted ordinances authorizing the annexation of three tracts of land contiguous to the city. The city later filed amended petitions for annexation with the county board of commissioners. The county board of commissioners filed a declaratory judgment action seeking the proper procedure to follow in acting upon the city's amended petitions. The trial court determined the amended provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.16 were procedural and thus could be applied retroactively to the amended petitions. The court of appeals partially reversed the judgment because the amended provisions would violate the proscription against retroactive laws contained in Ohio Const. art. II, § 28. The county board of commissioners and the county agricultural society sought review. The court affirmed the judgment because (1) the amended provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.16 were not expressly made retrospective by the General Assembly, (2) Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2721.12 did not require that the attorney general be made a party to the action, and (3) the county agricultural society was not the owner of the land under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1711.31.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the determination that the amended provisions of the statute were not applicable to the city's amended annexation petitions.

 

18 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Port Clinton Fish Co.


No. 88-258


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 3d 93; 538 N.E.2d 1055; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 90


March 8, 1989, Submitted  
May 24, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County, No. L-87-148.

Appellant, Port Clinton Fish Company ("Port Clinton"), indisputably, is an Ohio corporation engaged in both retail and wholesale distribution of fish. On December 17, 1985, Ohio Division of Wildlife officers entered appellant's facility in Toledo and inspected seven boxes of walleye fillets.
