The boxes were labeled "Olmstead Foods," and were allegedly purchased from a Canadian company. Upon inspection, the officers determined that the boxes contained forty-two percent "undersized" walleye by weight. The fish were seized and appellant company was charged with possession of walleye "more than 10% undersize[d] by weight" in violation of R.C. 1533.63 and Ohio Adm. Code 1501:31-3-02(A).

After trial in the Toledo Municipal Court, appellant was found guilty and appealed that judgment to the court of appeals. The appellate court affirmed, holding that R.C. 1533.63 and Ohio Adm. Code 1501:31-3-02 do not represent an unconstitutional interference with or burden on interstate commerce. Further, the court of appeals ruled that enforcement of the regulations did not abridge appellant's right to contract.

The cause is now [***2] before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant fish company challenged a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio) that affirmed a trial court's decision that, upon a complaint by the State, found appellant guilty of possession of walleye of more than 10 percent undersized by weight, in violation Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.63 and Ohio Admin. Code § 1501:31-3-02(A).


OVERVIEW: The company was a commercial fishing operation. On appeal, the company claimed that Ohio Admin. Code § 1501:31-3-02(A), which criminalized the possession of undersize walleye, was violative of the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution. By virtue of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.63, which prohibited commercial fishing of walleye in Ohio waters, all such fish traded commercially in the State were required, by necessity, to be caught outside Ohio. The court ruled with a legitimate state purpose of protection and propagation of walleye in the State as its basis, and only minimal intrusion on the affected parties, Ohio Admin. Code § 1501:31-3-02 did not violate the Commerce Clause. Section 1501:31-3-02 was "evenhanded" in that it neither favored local enterprise nor facially discriminated against interstate commerce, it involved a legitimate state interest, and there were no less restrictive means of promoting the state interest. The court summarily rejected the company's claim that the regulation disrupted its "right to contract."


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

19 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Atwood Res. v. Public Utils. Com


No. 87-1727


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 3d 96; 538 N.E.2d 1049; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 89; 109 Oil & Gas Rep. 36


February 21, 1989, Submitted  
May 24, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, No. 86-2175-GA-CSS.

On November 17, 1986, Columbia Gas of Ohio, Inc. ("Columbia"), intervening appellee herein, 1 brought a complaint pursuant to R.C. 4905.26 against Atwood Resources, Inc. ("Atwood"), appellant herein. Columbia alleged that Atwood, a producer of natural gas operating in and around Newcomerstown, Ohio, had bypassed complainant's existing pipeline facilities and was making retail sales of natural gas through its own facilities to Simonds Cutting Tools ("Simonds"); had installed facilities and had made arrangements to make sales of natural gas to Kurz-Kasch, Inc. ("Kurz-Kasch"); and was soliciting other consumers concerning possible direct sales of natural gas.


1 Columbia, in its brief before this court, describes itself as a natural gas distribution company that currently provides retail gas service to more than one million customers in all or part of sixty-nine counties in Ohio, including the area in and around the village of Newcomerstown, and also provides gas transportation services to approximately eighteen hundred customers who have acquired their own supplies of natural gas. Columbia acknowledges it is a "natural gas company" and a "public utility" within the meaning of R.C. 4905.03 (A)(6) and 4905.02, and further acknowledges it is subject to the jurisdiction of the Public Utilities Commission.

 [***2] Columbia maintained that Atwood's activities constituted those of a public utility subject to the jurisdiction of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio ("commission"), appellee herein, but that it had failed to submit to regulation and to comply with the applicable laws. Columbia also alleged that Atwood's activities had displaced, or would displace, its sales to these consumers, causing Columbia lost revenues and injury to its remaining customers who will ultimately pay higher rates because of the displaced sales. Columbia requested the commission to find that Atwood is a public utility and a natural gas company under R.C. 4905.02 and 4905.03(A)(6), and to order Atwood to cease making or soliciting direct sales of natural gas to consumers through its own pipeline facilities in violation of law.

By an attorney-examiner's entry issued February 4, 1987, the commission found that reasonable grounds for complaint had been stated and set the matter for public hearing. The hearing was held, as rescheduled, on May 4, 1987.

On August 4, 1987, the commission issued a decision in which it concluded that the direct sales of natural gas to Simonds and to Kurz-Kasch constituted public  [***3] utility activities and that Atwood was a public utility and a natural gas company. It further concluded that by engaging in these activities without submitting to regulation, Atwood was causing injury to Columbia. The commission ordered Atwood, within a specified period of time, to either comply with the public utility regulations or cease its direct sales of natural gas to Simonds and Kurz-Kasch.

Atwood filed a timely application for rehearing, which was denied by entry issued September 15, 1987.

The cause is now before the court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a private supplier of natural gas, challenged the decision of appellee, the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, that ordered it to comply with regulations concerning natural gas suppliers or cease the sale of natural gas after a complaint was brought by intervening appellee, a competitor.


OVERVIEW: A competitor complained to the Commission that a private natural gas supplier, which was not regulated by the Commission, was selling natural gas. The Commission found that the supplier was a public utility subject to regulation and ordered the supplier to cease the sales or comply with state regulations. The supplier appealed and the court affirmed. The court held that the Commission was authorized under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.26 to hear actions brought by a competing public utility against a supplier whose activities should have been regulated as a public utility. The supplier's sales to two customers caused economic loss to the competitor, a regulated entity, and its consumers. Private contracts for the sale of natural gas were subject to Commission regulation because the product sold was subject to such regulation. The court found that the supplier's activities were sufficient to meet the definition of public utility because of the sizeable and recurring nature of the sales. Because the supplier engaged in business of an industry that was regulated, it should have known that it was subject to regulation as well.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the Commission's decision.

 

20 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Urbana ex rel. Newlin v. Downing


No. 88-30


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 3d 109; 539 N.E.2d 140; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 91


February 14, 1989, Submitted  
May 24, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Champaign County, No. 87-CA-03.

On December 3, 1985, the Director of Law of the city of Urbana brought an action for declaratory judgment in the Urbana Municipal Court pursuant to R.C. Chapter 2721, Civ. R. 57 and Section 133.014 1 of the Urbana City Code ("U.C.C."). Plaintiff was seeking a determination that five "male sophisticate" magazines sold by the defendants were obscene. The magazines challenged are the January 1986 editions of "Juggs," "Nugget," and "Velvet"; the December 1985 edition of "Oui"; and the March 1986 edition of "Big Boobs." The defendants waived a jury trial and after three days of hearings, the trial court determined that the magazines were obscene. The court of appeals affirmed that decision.


1 See Appendix.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff law director filed a declaratory judgment against defendant sellers. The law director asked for a declaration that five magazines were obscene. The Court of Appeals for Champaign County (Ohio) affirmed the municipal court's decision, which was that the magazines were obscene. The sellers appealed.


OVERVIEW: In disposing of preliminary matters on appeal, the court rejected the sellers' challenge to the municipal court's jurisdiction and their contention that the controversy was moot because the specific magazines had been withdrawn from circulation. This case was tried without a jury. The sellers argued that the municipal judge erred by admitting the opinion testimony of the law director's lay witnesses. The court found that the admission of this testimony did not constitute an abuse of discretion because Ohio R. Evid. 701 permitted opinion testimony of lay witnesses if was helpful. Next, the court analyzed the municipal obscenity ordinance as incorporating the U.S. Supreme Court's Miller test. With respect to the magazines at issue, the court noted that the sellers' expert had testified that that the difference between male sophisticate magazines and explicit magazines was that the latter depicts actual penetration while the former does not. The court held that the depiction of actual penetration was not required and that the industry practice of using black dots to obscure sexual contact did not preclude a finding that the patently offense prong of the Miller test was satisfied.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision that the magazines were legally obscene under the municipal ordinance and remanded the case to the municipal court for additional proceedings.

 

21 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Allenius v. Thomas


No. 87-1558


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 3d 131; 538 N.E.2d 93; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 64


January 10, 1989, Submitted  
May 10, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, No. 87AP-9.

Appellee, Lois Allenius, was a patient of appellant, Dr. Walter A. Thomas, periodically from 1968 through January 2, 1975. On January 2, 1975, Dr. Thomas took a Pap smear from the appellee. The results of the Pap smear indicated that Class III cells had been found which were suggestive, but not conclusive, of a malignancy. Dr. Thomas attempted to notify appellee by mail, but the letter was returned to his office as not deliverable as addressed. Appellee averred that Dr. Thomas made no further attempt to contact her about the laboratory results.

On January 29, 1980, appellee had another Pap smear performed by the other appellant herein, Dr. Lloyd Barnes. The laboratory results of this Pap smear showed Class IV cells which are strongly suggestive of malignancy. Dr. Barnes performed a fractional D & C and cervical cone biopsy on appellee on February 13, 1980. On March 7, 1980, Dr. Barnes explained to appellee the pathology report which stated that appellee had cancer in situ.

Appellee returned to Dr. Thomas on May 28, 1980, and requested that a repeat Pap smear be taken due to the result of the cone biopsy [***2] and D & C which had been performed by Dr. Barnes. This Pap smear showed Class I, normal cells being present. This office visit was the last time appellee saw Dr. Thomas in his professional capacity though she did visit his office in the spring of 1982 to see a copy of her records.

Appellee continued her treatment with Dr. Barnes and had repeat Pap smears taken on June 6, 1980, December 9, 1980, May 5, 1981, November 3, 1981 and May 28, 1982. The laboratories all reported that Class I, normal cells were present in the Pap smears.

Less than five months after Dr. Barnes took appellee's last Pap smear, appellee went to a non-party obstetrician/gynecologist. A Pap smear was taken on October 12, 1982, which was reported by the laboratory as showing Class III cells. On November 5, 1982, appellee underwent a fractional D & C, cervical conization and laparoscopy which led to the diagnosis that appellee had invasive carcinoma of the cervix. As a result of the pathology report, appellee had a hysterectomy on December 1, 1982.

On September 29, 1983, appellee sent Dr. Thomas a one-hundred-eighty-day notification letter pursuant to R.C. 2305.11(A), stating that appellee was considering [***3] a medical malpractice action against him. On March 23, 1984, Dr. Thomas stipulated an extension of the one-hundred-eighty-day letter, such extension being granted until June 27, 1984.

On or about June 15, 1984, a medical expert's opinion led appellee to believe that she had a cause of action against Dr. Barnes for medical malpractice.

Appellee filed her medical malpractice complaint against Dr. Thomas and Dr. Barnes on June 27, 1984. A motion for summary judgment was filed by appellants who claimed the action was time-barred by the statute of limitations set forth in R.C. 2305.11(A) and (B). Dr. Thomas raised the applicability of the four-year statute of repose of R.C. 2305.11(B) to the action filed against him.

The trial court held that R.C. 2305.11(B) did not bar the action against Dr. Thomas, on the basis of this court's reasoning in Deskins v.. Young (1986), 26 Ohio St. 3d 8, 26 OBR 7, 496 N.E.2d 897. However, the trial court found that the filing of the complaint against Dr. Thomas and Dr. Barnes was untimely under R.C. 2305.11(A) and granted appellants' motion for summary judgment.

Appellee appealed. Dr. Thomas cross-appealed as to the application of R.C. 2305.11(B)  [***4] to him. The court of appeals reversed the summary judgment as to both doctors on the basis that the complaint was not time-barred by R.C. 2305.11(A). That court found that the time began to run when "* * * the plaintiff is aware or should be aware of the event which caused the injury and aware of the nature of the injury as a legal wrong. * * *" Furthermore, the court of appeals affirmed the trial court's finding that R.C. 2305.11(B) did not bar appellee's action against Dr. Thomas.

This cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee patient brought a medical malpractice action against appellant physicians. The Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), denied summary judgment motions by both physicians. The physicians appealed.


OVERVIEW: The court addressed whether the patient's alleged malpractice cause of action against the physicians was timely filed pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(A). Specifically, the court applied a three-prong test for determining the accrual date of the resulting injury in applying § 2305.11(A). The court found that the "extent and seriousness of his condition" language of the test required that there be an occurrence of a cognizable event which did or should have led the patient to believe that the condition of which the patient complained was related to a medical procedure, treatment, or diagnosis previously rendered to the patient and where the cognizable event did or should have placed the patient on notice of the need to pursue his possible remedies. The court did not agree that the patient had to be aware of the full extent of the injury before there was a cognizable event. The court found that the cognizable event was when the patient learned she had invasive cancer and such should have led her to believe that follow-up treatment by the physicians, which only consisted of taking more tests, was negligently rendered.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed that part of the order denying one physician's summary judgment motion and remanded. The court reversed the denial of the other physician's motion for summary judgment.

 

22 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Rocky River v. State Employment Relations Bd.


No. 87-157


Supreme Court of Ohio


43 Ohio St. 3d 1; 539 N.E.2d 103; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 67; 131 L.R.R.M. 2952


February 8, 1989, Submitted  
May 10, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County, No. 51299.

ON RECONSIDERATION.

The facts of this case are undisputed. In 1983, Ohio enacted the Public Employees' Collective Bargaining Act, which is codified in R.C. Chapter 4117. The Act, which took effect on April 1, 1984, included provisions for the representation of public employees by "exclusive representatives." R.C. 4117.04 and 4117.05.

Appellee, Rocky River Firefighters Association, Local 695, is the exclusive representative of firefighters employed by appellant, the city of Rocky River. In 1984, appellant and appellee commenced negotiations for the first collectively bargained employment contract between appellant and appellee's members. When the parties failed to reach an agreement, they requested mediation assistance from appellee State Employment Relations Board ("SERB") pursuant to R.C. 4117.14(C)(2). 1 The mediation process failed to resolve the parties' disagreement on numerous issues, so the parties proceeded to the next step: submission of the issues to a fact-finding panel under R.C. 4117.14(C)(3). 2 The panel held a hearing and issued recommendations favoring appellant's positions on all disputed  [***2] issues except salary, on which appellee firefighters' proposal was recommended. Appellant exercised its option under R.C. 4117.14(C)(6) 3 to reject the panel's recommendation. This rejection triggered the conciliation requirements of R.C. 4117.14(D)(1). 4 After hearing testimony from the parties, the conciliator issued an order choosing appellee's final salary offer over the offer of appellant. Appellant, even before the conciliator issued any final order, refused to recognize the validity of any such order, and commenced the instant action seeking a declaration that R.C. 4117.14(I) violates the Ohio Constitution by mandating binding arbitration between a city and its safety forces in the event of a collective bargaining impasse. 5 The court of common pleas granted appellee's motion for summary judgment, upholding the constitutionality of R.C. 4117.14(I). The court of appeals, in a unanimous opinion, affirmed.


1 R.C. 4117.14(C)(2) provides:

"If, fifty days before the expiration date of the collective bargaining agreement, the parties are unable to reach an agreement, any party may request the state employment relations board to intervene. The request shall set forth the names and addresses of the parties, the issues involved, and, if applicable, the expiration date of any agreement.

"The board shall intervene and investigate the dispute to determine whether the parties have engaged in collective bargaining.

"If an impasse exists or forty-five days before the expiration date of the collective bargaining agreement if one exists, the board shall appoint a mediator to assist the parties in the collective bargaining process."


2 R.C. 4117.14(C)(3) states:

"If the mediator after assisting the parties advises the board that the parties have reached an impasse, or not later than thirty-one days prior to the expiration date of the agreement, the board shall appoint within one day a fact-finding panel of not more than three members who have been selected by the parties in accordance with rules established by the board, from a list of qualified persons maintained by the board."


3 R.C. 4117.14(C)(6) reads as follows:

"Not later than seven days after the findings and recommendations are sent, the legislative body, by a three-fifths vote of its total membership, and in the case of the public employee organization, the membership, by a three-fifths vote of the total membership, may reject the recommendations; if neither rejects the recommendations, the recommendations shall be deemed agreed upon as the final resolution of the issues submitted and a collective bargaining agreement shall be executed between the parties, including the fact-finding panel's recommendations, except as otherwise modified by the parties by mutual agreement. If either the legislative body or the public employee organization rejects the recommendations, the board shall publicize the findings of fact and recommendations of the fact-finding panel. The board shall adopt rules governing the procedures and methods for public employees to vote on the recommendations of the fact-finding panel."


4 R.C. 4117.14(D)(1) provides in pertinent part:

"Public employees, who are members of a police or fire department * * * shall submit the matter to a final offer settlement procedure pursuant to a board order issued forthwith to the parties to settle by a conciliator selected by the parties. The parties shall request from the board a list of five qualified conciliators and the parties shall select a single conciliator from the list by alternate striking of names. If the parties cannot agree upon a conciliator within five days after the board order, the board shall on the sixth day after its order appoint a conciliator from a list of qualified persons maintained by the board or shall request a list of qualified conciliators from the American arbitration association and appoint therefrom."


5 It is interesting to speculate as to what action appellant might have taken had the conciliator ruled in appellant's favor on the issue in question.

 [***3] Appellant appealed to this court and the case came before us pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record. The issues were extensively briefed and oral argument was held on March 8, 1988. On November 2, 1988, this court, in a four-to-three split decision, issued our opinion and judgment reversing the judgment of the court of appeals and entering final judgment for appellant. Rocky River v.. State Emp. Relations Bd. (1988), 39 Ohio St. 3d 196, 530 N.E. 2d 1 ("Rocky I"). A plethora of motions was filed for rehearing and/or clarification.

The motions for rehearing and/or clarification were submitted to the court on December 13, 1988. In an opinion, decided December 22, 1988 and published in the Ohio Official Reports Advance Sheets on January 23, 1989, the court issued a clarification of its decision in Rocky I and concluded by stating: "In all other respects, the motions for reconsideration [sic] 6 and clarification are overruled as they have raised no germane arguments that were not considered by the court in the disposition of appellant's appeal." Rocky River v.. State Emp. Relations Bd. (1988), 40 Ohio St. 3d 606, 533 N.E. 2d 270,  [***4] 271-272 ("Rocky II"). The vote of the court was again split, four to three.


6 The motions filed were for rehearing (not reconsideration) pursuant to Section 1, Rule IX of the Supreme Court Rules of Practice. Compare App. R. 26, which provides for an application for reconsideration.

Accordingly, there is no Supreme Court rule providing for a motion for reconsideration of any matter previously decided by the court. Conversely, neither is there any rule prohibiting the filing of such a motion.

It would seem, therefore, that consideration of any such motion is left to the sound discretion of the court and would be within the inherent powers of the court to entertain and



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a decision by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed a trial court decision upholding the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.14(I) regarding a statutorily-mandated bargaining procedure. The court reversed the appellate court in its original decision and in a later decision regarding a motion for clarification. Appellee firefighters filed a motion for reconsideration.


OVERVIEW: The city filed suit challenging the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.14(I) while the statutorily-mandated bargaining process with the firefighters was in process. The trial court upheld the validity of § 4117.14(I), which was affirmed by the appellate court, but reversed by the state's supreme court in its original decision and again in response to a motion for clarification. In response to a motion for reconsideration by the firefighters, the court held that: (1) the doctrine of stare decisis was less compelling regarding constitutional issues; (2) the city did not sustain its burden to show that § 4117.14(I) and the state's constitution were clearly incompatible; (3) § 4117.14(I) was not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power because it served an appropriate purpose, contained sufficient procedural standards and safeguards, and provided for effective judicial review; (4) the power of home rule was constitutionally limited; (5) Ohio Const. art. II, § 34 governed the case and made home rule inapplicable; (6) § 4117.14(I) was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted the firefighters' motion for reconsideration, reversed its two previous decisions, and upheld the constitutionality of the statute. The court also overruled an intervening decision that was inconsistent with this opinion.

 

23 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Bradley


No. 87-1985


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 3d 136; 538 N.E.2d 373; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 68


February 7, 1989, Submitted  
May 10, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Scioto County, No. 1583.

On February 10, 1984, the Scioto County Grand Jury returned an indictment against appellant, William J. Bradley, charging him with one count of aggravated murder, in violation of R.C. 2903.01(A). The indictment also contained two specifications which permitted the imposition of the death penalty. The specifications were that (1) pursuant to R.C. 2929.04(A)(4), the offense was committed while the offender was a prisoner in a detention facility; and that (2) pursuant to R.C. 2929.04(A)(5), prior to the offense at bar, the offender was convicted of an offense, an essential element of which was the purposeful killing of or attempt to kill another.

The charges now before us stem from an incident that occurred on February 2, 1984 at the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility in Lucasville. On that date, appellant allegedly approached Eric Bowling, a sixty-two-year-old civilian supervisor of the institution's sheet metal shop, and beat him about the head and face with a ten-gauge bar of sheet metal.

Appellant was arraigned in the Court of Common Pleas of Scioto County on March 2, 1984, at which time he entered a plea of not [***2] guilty. The court appointed two local attorneys, Stephen C. Rodeheffer and Joseph L. Hale, as counsel for appellant.

On March 27, 1984, the court ordered the Shawnee Forensic Center to conduct a mental evaluation of appellant for purposes of determining his competence to stand trial. The examiner, James R. Hagen, Ph.D., reported that though appellant was at times delusional, and had been diagnosed as paranoid schizophrenic, appellant was nevertheless competent to stand trial. Appellant subsequently requested an independent mental evaluation by an examiner of his own choosing. The court, at appellant's request, appointed Dr. Ronald Litvak, who confirmed the diagnosis of chronic paranoid schizophrenia and that appellant was nonetheless competent to stand trial.

Appellant, on January 29, 1985, filed a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity. The court thereupon ordered Shawnee Forensic Center to conduct an evaluation of appellant for purposes of determining his mental condition at the time of the offense. Appellant was evaluated by Dr. David Helm. Dr. Helm concluded that, although appellant was mentally ill, it could not be definitely stated that the offense was a result of [***3] appellant's mental illness.

The case proceeded to trial, with jury selection beginning on May 6, 1985. The lengthy selection process finally concluded on May 13, with the jury being taken to the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility to view the scene of the homicide.

When the trial resumed the following day, Howard McCoy, an inmate who worked in the sheet metal shop, was called to testify. McCoy testified that he was standing at Bowling's desk reading from a list of jobs and that Bowling was standing behind him. McCoy further testified that he heard a noise, whereupon he turned around and saw appellant hit Bowling with a steel bar. McCoy stated that appellant continued to hit Bowling, even after Bowling had fallen to the floor. Appellant then walked away and threw the steel bar into a pile of scrap metal.

John King, another inmate assigned to the sheet metal shop, also testified. King stated that he saw appellant "whacking away at something" with a piece of steel, but that he (King) could not tell what appellant was hitting because his view was obscured by filing cabinets. When King came out from behind the cabinets, he could see Bowling lying on the floor and appellant hitting [***4] Bowling. King summoned Corrections Sgt. Larry Smith, who found the bloody piece of steel lying twenty feet from the place of the attack.

After the incident, the area was closed off by prison officials and a strip search was conducted of all inmates in the sheet metal shop. According to Deputy Superintendent Bill Seth, this was routine prison procedure for prison incidents, designed to ensure that inmates did not possess any type of weapon that constituted a threat to institutional security.

As the strip search progressed, an inmate was found to have blood on his shorts and he was asked for an explanation. At that time, appellant approached the officers conducting the search and stated that this inmate "had nothing to do with this * * *." Appellant was ordered to sit down.

Appellant was chosen to be the next inmate searched. One of the officers conducting the search, Corrections Officer Richard Taylor, found blood on appellant's shirt and asked for an explanation. Appellant pointed to where Bowling's body had been and stated that it was the foreman's blood. Officer Taylor called the spot to the attention of Deputy Superintendent Seth, who repeated the questions to appellant [***5] and received the same answers. Officer Taylor then asked appellant, "[D]id you do it?" Appellant replied, "[Y]eah, I did it." Appellant was then handcuffed and taken to the institution's J-Block and the strip search of the inmates continued.

The incident was turned over to the State Highway Patrol for investigation. Sergeant Blaine Keckley testified that his examination of appellant revealed no bleeding wounds and that the blood on appellant's shirt was type "O," the same blood type as that of Bowling. State Highway Patrol District Investigator Ivan Teets interviewed appellant on the day of the incident and noticed what appeared to be speckles of blood on appellant's forehead. After removal and analysis, the speckles were determined to be blood. As part of the investigation, Teets compiled an extensive report. After a minor deletion, the investigative report was marked as an exhibit and introduced as evidence without objection at trial.

The prosecution also produced inmate James Patterson as a witness. Patterson had a relatively low I.Q. and was described as "mildly retarded." Appellant's counsel objected, alleging that Patterson had been judicially declared incompetent.  [***6] The trial judge took the step of questioning the witness in chambers to determine his competency as a witness. The trial judge believed Patterson to be competent to testify. Once on the witness stand, Patterson indicated that the day before the incident he heard appellant tell Bowling that "* * * I'm going to get you, old man." Patterson stated that appellant became angry and made this statement when Bowling told appellant he would have to do some work over.

After the state presented its case, appellant testified in his own defense. Appellant denied having harsh words with Bowling, denied striking Bowling, and stated that anyone who said otherwise was incorrect or lying. Appellant further denied or could not recall making certain inculpatory statements to the investigating officers. Appellant revealed on direct examination that he had an extensive record of prior convictions and incarceration. He admitted that he had been convicted of murder and that a significant portion of his incarceration had been served at the Lima State Hospital for the criminally insane. Following appellant's testimony, the defense rested its case.

Prior to the jury



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of conviction from the Court of Appeals for Scioto County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgment of conviction that found him guilty of first degree murder and sentenced him to death.


OVERVIEW: Defendant challenged the appellate court's affirmation of his judgment of conviction and death sentence on the grounds of ineffective assistance of counsel. The appellate court's judgment of conviction and death sentence against defendant was affirmed. The court held that the investigative report was admissible because appellant's trial counsel failed to object to its admission, thereby waiving any error. The court has held that the doctrine of waiver was applicable, even in capital cases. Further, the court held that defendant failed to demonstrate ineffective assistance of counsel because he failed to show a substantial violation of any of defense counsel's essential duties, and that he was prejudiced by counsel's ineffectiveness. Defendant failed to prove that there existed a reasonable probability that, were it not for counsel's errors, the result of the trial would have been different. In addition, the court held that the aggravating circumstances of the crime outweighed beyond a reasonable doubt, any mitigating factors, and that the sentence imposed was proportionate and appropriate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of conviction and death sentence because defendant failed to demonstrate ineffective assistance of counsel as he did not show counsel's substantial violation of any of his essential duties, and that he was prejudiced by counsel's ineffectiveness. The aggravating circumstances of the crime outweighed beyond a reasonable doubt, any mitigating factors, and the sentence imposed was proportionate and appropriate.

 

24 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


In re Order Requiring Fingerprinting of Juvenile


No. 88-5


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 3d 124; 537 N.E.2d 1286; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 55


February 7, 1989, Submitted  
May 3, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lake County, No. 12-027.

Pursuant to R.C. 2151.313, Judge Richard A. Hoose of the Lake County Court of Common Pleas, Juvenile Division, issued an order requiring the fingerprinting of a juvenile who was neither in custody nor under arrest. The Lake County Prosecutor made the request for fingerprinting of the juvenile as a result of an investigation conducted by the Madison Fire District. Prior to the issuance of the order, the juvenile court judge considered the affidavit and testimony of Captain Norm Chaffee of the Madison Fire District, as well as the testimony of another fire district officer, expressing their suspicion that the juvenile was involved in the placement and explosion of numerous homemade pipe bombs in the Madison, Ohio area including the local high school. In the original order permitting the fingerprinting, the juvenile court judge did not articulate a probable cause standard.

On May 29, 1986, Madison Township police arrived at the residence of the juvenile, appellant herein, to execute the fingerprinting order. Appellant refused to comply. Instead, appellant retained counsel who filed a motion to quash the order on June [***2] 2, 1986.

On June 4, 1986, the juvenile court issued an opinion holding that:

"* * * The Court finds that the proceedings herein have complied with the requirements of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution and Ohio Revised Code Section 2151.313. In addition to the affidavit filed by Norm Chaffee, Captain of the Madison Fire District, the Court heard his sworn testimony and that of Bob Johnson of the Madison Fire District on May 27, 1986 before granting its consent for the fingerprinting of the juvenile and issuing its order. The Court finds further that Ohio Revised Code Section 2151.313 does provide the Court with the authority to issue the fingerprint order herein albeit through language less dispositive than what the Court believes the statute was meant to provide. Nonetheless what infringement there may be on the juvenile's Fourth Amendment rights in [sic] minimal at best for the time of detention required at the police station for the sole purpose of obtaining his fingerprints and is outweighed by concerns for the safety of the community in investigating the detonation of a pipe bomb exploded at Madison High School and the pipe bomb discovered at 1877 [***3] Bennett Road in Madison.

"The Juvenile's Motion to Quash and/or Vacate is therefore denied."

Appellant appealed that decision to the court of appeals, which affirmed the decision of the juvenile court.

This cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant juvenile sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Lake County (Ohio), which affirmed the decision of the juvenile court denying the juvenile's motion to quash an order to obtain fingerprints.


OVERVIEW: A juvenile was under suspicion for his involvement in the placement and explosion of numerous homemade pipe bombs at a local high school. In the original order permitting his fingerprinting, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2151.313(A)(1), the juvenile court judge did not articulate a probable cause standard. The juvenile argued that his U.S. Const. amend. IV rights were violated. The court held that there was sufficient evidence before the juvenile court judge to find an articulable and specific basis in fact for suspecting that the juvenile was involved in criminal activity. Further, the fingerprinting of the juvenile was justified by substantial law enforcement interests in order to protect the public safety, and the intrusion was limited to the taking of the juvenile to the police station for the sole purpose of fingerprinting. The court held that there was no constitutional violation and that the juvenile court was correct in issuing an order compelling the juvenile to accompany an officer to the police station for the limited purpose of fingerprinting.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment upholding the order compelling the juvenile to submit to fingerprinting.

 

25 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Guinn


No. 88-21


Supreme Court of Ohio


42 Ohio St. 3d 92; 537 N.E.2d 656; 1989 Ohio LEXIS 41


February 8, 1989, Submitted  
April 26, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Clermont County, No. CA87-03-028.

Appellee, Prentice L. Guinn, was indicted on October 16, 1986, for engaging in pyramid sales in violation of R.C. 1333.92, with a specification that the compensation involved in the offense was in excess of $ 150. Following a bench trial, appellee was found guilty of proposing a pyramid sales scheme, was sentenced to six months' imprisonment, and fined $ 1,000.

The conviction was based solely on the testimony of an undercover police officer, who stated that he arrived at the residence of a Robert Anderson on the evening of October 7, 1986 and was introduced to the appellee. Appellee had several playing cards lying on a table in a pyramid formation, and he began to explain the "airplane" scheme at issue here: at the top was a "pilot"; the next two positions down were the "co-pilots"; the next four positions were the "crew"; and the last eight positions were "passengers". Appellee then explained that every time a participant joined, two more people had to join below him, until he reached the pilot's position. Fifteen hundred dollars was needed to join, and that money had to be turned in by the time the participant [***2] made "co-pilot". This money was given to the pilot. Thus, appellee explained, after the initial $ 1,500 was realized, the "pilot" would receive $ 10,500, and then "move off" so the next participant could collect.

After appellee explained this scheme three or four times, the meeting was called to order and appellee recited from two typed pages the rules of the program, including suggestions on how to withdraw and deposit the money involved without arousing the suspicion of the Internal Revenue Service. Appellee then broke the meeting down into smaller groups to form the individual "airplanes". The officer testified that he then signed up as a "passenger" on one of the pyramids, but stated that no money was exchanged at this meeting. The officer testified that, as explained by appellee, payments were to be arranged later by the "pilot". The officer had no further conversations with appellee that night.

After cross-examination of the officer, the state rested its case. Appellee filed a Crim. R. 29 motion for acquittal, which was overruled. Appellee then rested without presenting any testimony or evidence, and renewed his motion for acquittal. After a short recess, the court [***3] entered its judgment, finding appellee guilty as charged, and sentenced him to six months' imprisonment and a fine of $ 1,000.

The court of appeals reversed, holding that the evidence presented was insufficient to support appellee's conviction.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State challenged the order of the Court of Appeals for Clermont County (Ohio), which reversed the order of the trial court that convicted defendant for proposing a pyramid sales scheme in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.92, and which sentenced him to six months' imprisonment, and fined him $ 1,000.


OVERVIEW: An undercover officer observed defendant give instructions on how a pyramid sales scheme worked. The audience then broke into small groups for the actual solicitations. Defendant was arrested. The trial court convicted defendant and sentenced him. Defendant appealed, and the appellate court reversed. The State appealed. The court reversed and found the evidence was sufficient to support the conviction. Defendant had done more than explain the scheme he had offered it for the acceptance of the audience, went into detail on how much money was needed to join, how much would be returned, and how to withdraw and deposit funds to avoid the attention of the federal government, and supervised the solicitations. Defendant's speech had solicited the commission of an unlawful commercial transaction that was inherently misleading and deceptive, and therefore, was unprotected speech under U.S. Const. amend. I. Although speaking was involved, the right to prohibit unfair trade practices derived from what was being sold not how it was sold and the sales pitch that accompanied a solicitation to perform an illegal act had not made it lawful.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the appellate court, which had reversed the trial court order that convicted and sentenced defendant. The court reinstated the order of the trial court that convicted and sentenced defendant.

 

26 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Doersam v. Indus. Com. of Ohio


No. 88-51


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 3d 201; 533 N.E.2d 321; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 457


October 4, 1988, Submitted  
December 30, 1988, Decided *


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Granted February 22, 1989. * Reporter's Note: This cause was decided on December 30, 1988, but was released to the public on January 6, 1989, subsequent to the retirement of Justice Locher, who participated in the decision.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, No. 86AP-710.

On November 8, 1973, Robert J. Doersam suffered a myocardial infarction while in the course and scope of his employment with Wuellner & Theado, Inc. Subsequently, he filed a workers' compensation claim and was awarded benefits for the myocardial infarction and chronic ischemic heart disease. Doersam died on September 27, 1983, as a result of his allowed injuries. On February 12, 1985, Doersam's surviving spouse, appellee Betty Doersam, and their daughter, Teresa, filed an application for death benefits pursuant to R.C. 4123.59(B). On May 15, 1985, a district hearing officer determined that claimants were wholly dependent upon the decedent for support at the time of his death. Accordingly, the hearing officer calculated that they were entitled to a death benefit of $ 214 per week, a sum that was two thirds of $ 321, the statewide average weekly wage ("SAWW") for 1983 as determined pursuant to R.C. 4123.62.

Betty appealed, arguing that the SAWW used was the wrong amount. The district officer's ruling was affirmed by the regional board of review on December 5, 1985. The [***2] Industrial Commission, appellant herein, affirmed.

Thereafter, appellee initiated this action in the Court of Appeals for Franklin County seeking a writ of mandamus to change the amount awarded and to declare R.C. 4123.59(B) unconstitutional. The court of appeals referred the matter to a referee and adopted the findings of fact of the June 19, 1987 report and recommendation, but the court rejected the referee's conclusions of law. The court of appeals in its December 8, 1987 decision granted the requested writ and held that the classification of death benefits recipients set forth in R.C. 4123.59(B) had no rational basis and therefore violated the Equal Protection Clauses of the United States and Ohio Constitutions. The court of appeals increased the weekly benefit to one hundred percent of the SAWW.

This cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the Industrial Commission of Ohio, challenged a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which granted the request of appellee claimants, a widow and her daughter, for a writ of mandamus ordering the Commission to change the amount awarded to the claimants as death benefits and declared that the classification of death benefits recipients under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.59(B) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The decedent suffered a myocardial infarction in the course and scope of his employment and was awarded worker's compensation for the myocardial infarction and chronic ischemic heart disease. The decedent died as a result of his allowed injuries. The claimants applied for death benefits. Pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.59(B), a hearing officer calculated that they were entitled to a death benefit based on the statewide average weekly wage (SAWW). The decision was affirmed upon administrative review. The claimants appealed, arguing that the SAWW used was the wrong amount. The appeals court granted the requested writ of mandamus and held that the classification of death benefits recipients set forth in § 4123.59(B) had no rational basis and therefore was unconstitutional. The appeals court increased the weekly benefit to 100 percent of the SAWW. Because § 1.50 provided for partial invalidation of any statute found unconstitutional, the court affirmed that part of the judgment holding that the classification of claimants under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.59(B) was unconstitutional but reversed that portion of the judgment granting the claimants 100 percent of the SAWW.


OUTCOME: The judgment granting the writ of mandamus was affirmed with respect to the holding that the classification of claimants was unconstitutional but was reversed with respect to the decision granting the claimants 100 percent of the SAWW. The Commission's award was reinstated.

 

27 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Battin v. Bush


No. 87-1903


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 3d 236; 533 N.E.2d 301; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 461


October 26, 1988, Submitted  
December 30, 1988, Decided *


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: * Reporter's Note: This cause was decided on December 30, 1988, but was released to the public on January 6, 1989, subsequent to the retirement of Justice Locher, who participated in the decision.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County, No. 3728.

The facts giving rise to the within action begin with the election of Thomas R. Battin to the office of County Commissioner of Trumbull County on November 6, 1984. He took office on January 3, 1985 and was to serve a four-year term. On June 6, 1985, Battin was seriously injured in an automobile accident which left him incapacitated. It was undisputed at trial that at no time after the accident had Battin been able to, nor did he, resume his duties as a county commissioner.

On September 5, 1985, and pursuant to former R.C. 305.03, 1 a physician's certificate was filed with appellee Board of Trumbull County Commissioners, which stated that Battin had been absent because of injury. On February 14, 1986, appellee county auditor refused to give any further paychecks to Battin. Application for a writ of mandamus was filed on February 21, 1986 in the trial court to command the auditor to issue paychecks to Battin. After the auditor asserted that Battin lacked capacity to file the action because of mental incapacity, Karen S. Battin was appointed by the trial court as Battin's guardian ad litem. Also, the county [***2] prosecutor filed an action in quo warranto in this court, case No. 86-279, on February 25, 1986. Later, on April 30, 1986, the prosecutor filed an application to dismiss the action, which we granted on May 5, 1986.


1 Former R.C. 305.03 stated as follows:

"Such vacancy shall be filled in the manner provided by section 305.02 of the Revised Code.

"Whenever any county officer is absent from the county because of sickness or injury, he shall cause to be filed with the board of county commissioners a physician's certificate of his sickness or injury. If such certificate is not filed with the board within ten days after the expiration of the ninety consecutive days of absence from the county, his office shall be deemed vacant and the board shall declare a vacancy to exist in such office.

"This section shall not apply to a county officer while in the active military service of the United States."

The General Assembly then enacted emergency legislation which amended R.C. 305.03. 2 This measure was signed into law by the Governor on April 15, 1986 and was then effective. By letter dated April 15, the county prosecutor advised the auditor that Battin's office should be deemed  [***3] vacant and that he should be deleted from the payroll. Appellee Trumbull County Democratic Party Central Committee announced its intention to meet on April 24, 1986 for the express purpose of appointing someone to fill the vacancy.


2 The amended version of R.C. 305.03, effective April 15, 1986, states as follows:

"(A) Whenever any county officer fails to perform the duties of his office for ninety consecutive days, except in case of sickness or injury as provided in divisions (B) and (C) of this section, his office shall be deemed vacant.

"(B) Whenever any county officer is absent because of sickness or injury, he shall cause to be filed with the board of county commissioners a physician's certificate of his sickness or injury. If such certificate is not filed with the board within ten days after the expiration of ninety consecutive days of absence, his office shall be deemed vacant.

"(C) Whenever a county officer files a physician's certificate under division (B) of this section, but continues to be absent for an additional thirty days commencing immediately after the last day on which this certificate may be filed under division (B) of this section, his office shall be deemed vacant.

"Any vacancy declared under this section shall be filled in the manner provided by section 305.02 of the Revised Code.

"This section shall not apply to a county officer while in the active military service of the United States."

 [***4] The original complaint in mandamus was, on April 17, 1986, supplemented to substitute Karen Battin, guardian, as party plaintiff and to include requests for a declaratory judgment as well as injunctive relief. The declarations sought were that the amended statute was unconstitutional, or not applicable to Thomas Battin, and that the office he was elected to was not vacant. The trial court convened hearings upon the matter on April 18 and 21 before rendering judgment on April 24. The court found that the statute as amended was constitutional, was validly applied to declare the seat at issue vacant, and that the office had been vacated under such statute as of April 15, 1986. Also, the court found that the guardian ad litem had no standing to assert claims on behalf of Thomas Battin because the rights asserted were personal to him alone.

According to the parties, the county Democratic Party met on April 24, 1986, and the next day, its appointee, Christopher S. Lardis, was sworn in to the office declared vacant. On that date, Karen Battin filed an application for a writ of quo warranto in the court of appeals seeking ouster of Lardis from the office to which he was appointed.  [***5] This action was ultimately stayed pending appellate review of the trial court's determinations.

Karen Battin filed her appeal in the instant cause on May 15, 1986. On October 1, 1987, the court of appeals reversed the decision of the trial court. The court found that the sole remedy available in an action questioning the right of one to hold public office was one in quo warranto. Since this kind of action may be filed only in the court of appeals or the Supreme Court pursuant to R.C. 2733.03, 3 it was concluded that the trial court was without jurisdiction in the matter and the cause was remanded for dismissal of the supplemental complaint.


3 R.C. 2733.03 states, in pertinent part, as follows:

"An action in quo warranto can be brought only in the supreme court, or in the court of appeals of the county in which the defendant, or one of the defendants, resides or is found * * *."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, a county commissioner, sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County (Ohio), which found that it did not have subject matter jurisdiction over the commissioner's action' against appellees, a board of county commissioners and a county auditor, because the action sounded in quo warranto due tot he fact that its ultimate goal was a dealt with a person's right to hold a public office.


OVERVIEW: A commissioner was involved in an automobile accident and was incapacitated. The commissioner was not able to perform his duties since the accident. The state legislature amended Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 305.03, which set forth the process for declaring a public officer vacant following an injury to the elected official. A new commissioner was appointed. The commissioner's wife, as guardian ad litem for the commissioner, sought to oust the person who filled the "vacancy" of his office. The trial court found that it did not have jurisdiction to hear the action. The commissioner appealed. The court held that the § 305.03 contained no express provision that it applied retrospectively. The calculation of time to determine the vacancy of the commissioner's office began upon the effective date of the § 305.03. As of July 14, 1986, the commissioner had 10 days in which to file a physician's certificate which would explain his absence from the performance of his official duties for the immediately preceding 90 days. This he failed to do, and, accordingly, his office was deemed vacant as of July 14, 1986.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the order of the trial court and remanded the matter for further proceedings.

 

28 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Benner


No. 87-1614


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 3d 301; 533 N.E.2d 701; 535 N.E.2d 315; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 468


September 27, 1988, Submitted  
December 30, 1988, Decided *


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] * Reporter's Note: This cause was decided on December 30, 1988, but was released to the public on January 18, 1989, subsequent to the retirement of Justice Locher, who participated in the decision.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County, No. 12664.

On the night of August 6, 1985, Cynthia Sedgwick and three friends attended the George Thorogood concert at Blossom Music Center in Summit County. While she was in what was described as a "tipsy" condition, Sedgwick wandered away from her companions several times. Defendant-appellant, Glenn L. Benner II, also attended the concert accompanied by a group of friends, some of whom worked with him for Michael's Construction. One of the group with appellant, Anthony J. Hoehn, testified that he saw appellant talking with a girl who was "fairly drunk or high * * *."

When the concert ended, Hoehn and another member of appellant's group, Jeffrey Erhard, saw appellant walk through one of the music center's parking lots and into the adjoining woods accompanied by the girl with whom appellant had been talking earlier. According to Erhard, appellant "had his arm around her until he got to the parking lot, then he picked her [***2] up and carried her." Erhard testified that he and Hoehn followed appellant into the woods but could not find him. Both Hoehn and Erhard testified that they called out for appellant in the woods, but heard no response. Consequently, Hoehn and Erhard went home.

The next day, appellant told Robert L. Tyson, a co-worker at Michael's Construction, that "he killed a girl at Blossom last night. * * * He said he raped her and then choked her to death."

The day following the Thorogood concert, Sedgwick's purse was found in the woods surrounding the Blossom Music Center. Subsequently, on August 12, 1985, a Blossom parking lot attendant found Sedgwick's decomposed body in the woods. A Summit County deputy sheriff who was called to the scene shortly thereafter testified that a partial pack of Winston cigarettes was found near the body. Other testimony indicated that neither Sedgwick nor anyone in her group smoked Winston cigarettes. Robert Tyson testified, however, that appellant smoked Winstons. It was also testified that a knotted brassiere, a pair of socks tied together, and a tooth were found around Sedgwick's body.

On September 26, 1985, appellant and Robert Tyson entered the [***3] Akron home of Nancy Hale, which was located in a neighborhood where Michael's Construction had been working. Appellant grabbed Hale by surprise and proceeded to rape her orally, anally and vaginally. While appellant was raping Hale, Tyson was asking for money from her. Upon ceasing the rape, appellant began to choke Hale with his hands. At that time, Tyson somehow got appellant to let go of Hale's neck. Subsequently, appellant and Tyson left Hale's home. After he was apprehended by the Akron police, appellant confessed to raping Hale.

On the evening of November 19, 1985, Shelli Powell, a University of Akron student, was jogging along Howe Road in Tallmadge, Ohio. Suddenly, Powell was hit from behind and landed face down on the side of an embankment. She testified that her attacker told her to "shut up," not say anything and not look. The assailant then began to wrap tape around her head, covering her eyes. Powell stated that she was able to see her attacker's profile for around five seconds before he taped her eyes shut. At that time, the assailant dragged Powell into the woods, whereupon he took off her shirt, brassiere, and the tape around her eyes, and began to fondle [***4] her. The assailant then put his hand down her pants and stuck his fingers in her vagina. As he stood up and began to undo his pants, Powell tried to run away. However, the assailant pounced on her from behind and began to choke her with his hands. Powell then became dizzy and lost consciousness.

When Powell regained consciousness, she was lying naked in mud. She noticed that something was tied tightly around her neck and mouth, which impeded her breathing. She climbed up the embankment towards Howe Road and proceeded to a house nearby for help. Upon reaching the house, she was admitted by the occupants, who called the Tallmadge police. The officer responding to the call aided Powell and untied the knotted brassiere that was wound tightly around her neck. Subsequently, Powell identified the appellant as her attacker, both at trial and in an array of photographs.

Robert Tyson testified that he discussed the attack on Powell with the appellant after hearing a radio report that a "Tallmadge jogger was attacked and raped." Tyson further testified that appellant admitted he was the attacker, but denied he raped her "because he ran into complications."

On January 1, 1986, Trina [***5] Bowser, an acquaintance of appellant who lived in the same neighborhood, was visiting her friend, Cheryl Leek. Leek testified that Trina left her home at 9:45 p.m., stating that she wanted to go home because she was tired. Between 12:15 and 12:20 a.m., January 2, 1986, Lincoln Skeen, Jr. was driving home from work when he found Bowser's car on fire on the Akron Expressway. Skeen flagged down a truck to help put out the fire, and afterwards phoned Bowser's residence. After Bowser's parents arrived on the scene, the trunk of the car was opened wherein Bowser's corpse was found. Her ankles were bound with curtain tiebacks resembling those from appellant's new home on Butterbridge Road in Canal Fulton. In addition, Bowser's underpants and brassiere were tied around her neck, and her jeans were wrapped around her head.

A single set of footprints in the snow was found going away from Bowser's car to a point on Southwest Avenue, just north of Newton Street. Steven Weigand, who owned the Northeast Auto Shop at that location, testified that he had seen a pickup truck with a broken grille in his parking lot at midnight on January 2. He further stated that at 1:20 a.m. he noticed that [***6] the truck was gone. Appellant's truck was later identified by Weigand as the truck he had seen that night.

The Summit County Coroner testified that tests indicated the presence of spermatozoa in Bowser's anus and vagina. A criminalist employed by the Ohio Bureau of Criminal Identification and Investigation testified that appellant could have been the source of the sperm. It was also testified that fibers and a green paint chip were found on Bowser's coat, and that fibers were found on and around her corpse.

Shortly after the murder of Bowser, Robert Tyson phoned the Tallmadge police, and stated that he knew the perpetrator of the murders of Sedgwick and Bowser, and of the attack on Powell. After Tyson met with the coroner and several detectives, he told them of the Hale rape. On January 10, 1986, both Tyson and appellant were taken into custody by Akron police. That same day, appellant confessed to the Hale rape.

On January 12 and 14, 1986, police executed warrants to search appellant's residence on Broadview Road, his new home on Butterbridge Road, and his truck. The executing officers seized clothing, vacuum sweepings, dryer lint, carpet fiber samples, and two chips [***7] of green paint. On the clothing, in the dryer lint, and in the vacuum bag, blue bilobal acrylic fibers and green trilobal nylon fibers were found with the same characteristics as those fibers found on Bowser's body and coat. On some of the clothing, whit modacrylic fibers with the same characteristics as the fibers in Bowser's fake fur coat were also found.

Also seized at the Broadview residence were newspaper clippings about the Hale and Bowser crimes. Appellant's sister, however, testified that she had clipped the stories.

On January 21, 1986, appellant was indicted by the grand jury on twenty-two counts including the aggravated murders of Cynthia Sedgwick and Tina Bowser. For each aggravated murder, appellant was charged with felony murder ( R.C. 2903.01[B]), and with causing each death purposely and with prior calculation and design ( R.C. 2929.04[A][5]) and a felony murder specification ( R.C. 2929.04[A][7]). In addition, appellant was charged with two counts of attempted aggravated murder for the attack on Shelli Powell; two counts of attempted aggravated murder stemming from the Nancy [***8] Hale assault; six counts of rape; three counts of kidnapping; and one count each of aggravated burglary, felonious sexual penetration, gross sexual imposition, attempted rape, and aggravated arson.

On January 23, 1986, appellant entered pleas of not guilty to all the charges. After the trial court denied appellant's motion to sever the counts, appellant waived his right to trial by jury and elected to have his case tried by a three-judge panel.

Trial commenced on April 7, 1986. During the court of the trial, the plaintiff-appellee, state of Ohio, presented the testimony of thirty witnesses and proffered over one hundred exhibits. At the close of the state's case, the trial court granted appellant's Crim.R. 29 motion for acquittal with respect to the counts charging prior calculation and design in the Sedgwick murder and the Hale attempted murder.

Appellant was subsequently found guilty of all the remaining charges except for the second of the two counts of attempted aggravated murder stemming from the Hale assault, felonious sexual penetration in the Hale incident and aggravated arson in the Bowser death. Of importance to this appeal, appellant was convicted [***9] of the felony murder of Cynthia Sedgwick, both counts of the murder of Trina Bowser, and all the death specifications attached to those counts. As to the Bowser convictions, the prior calculation and design count was merged into the felony murder count. The court also merged the three course-of-conduct specifications of which appellant was convicted into a single aggravating circumstance.

After a mitigation hearing was held, the appellant was sentenced to death.

Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed the trial court's judgment of conviction and sentence. The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with four crimes, two of which involved the murder and sexual assault of the victims. The trial court refused to grant a severance, found defendant guilty, and imposed two death sentences. The Court of Appeals of Summit County (Ohio) affirmed the convictions and the death penalty, and defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: The prosecution tried defendant on four similar crimes and introduced gruesome photographs of the first victim's decomposing body. The evidence disclosed that a second murder victim also was strangled. The second victim was raped anally and vaginally and left in the trunk of a car with her ankles bound and her undergarments tied around her neck. Shortly after the murders, a witness gave the police information that linked defendant to the crimes. The police arrested defendant, and two police officers questioned him. Defendant did not invoke his Fifth Amendment rights until a later date. The court held that (1) the trial court did not abuse its discretion when it denied the severance because the evidence would have been admissible in separate trials, (2) the improper admission of evidence was harmless error in light of defendant's confession to one of the crimes, a victim's identification of defendant as her assailant, and a witness's testimony that he saw defendant rape one victim, and (3) the aggravating circumstances outweighed mitigating factors beyond a reasonable doubt, so the death sentences were appropriate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court and defendant's convictions and the death sentence.

 

29 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Johnson v. Administrator, Ohio Bureau of Employment Services


No. 87-1956


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 3d 365; 533 N.E.2d 757; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 488


November 1, 1988, Submitted  
December 30, 1988, Decided *


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: * Reporter's Note: This cause was decided on December 30, 1988, but was released to the public on January 27, 1989, subsequent to the retirement of Justice Locher, who participated in the decision.
 [***1] Rehearing Granted March 29, 1989.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Ashtabula County, No. 1322.

Appellee, Ashtabula County Medical Center ("ACMC"), operates a general hospital located in Ashtabula, Ohio. The Ohio Nurses Association ("ONA") is the exclusive bargaining representative of the registered nurses employed at the hospital. In July 1980, the ONA went on strike, and the ACMC responded by closing the facility, thereby laying off all remaining employees of the hospital.

Appellants are one hundred eighty-five 1 non-union employees who were laid off by the hospital and who subsequently filed timely applications for unemployment compensation. The Administrator of the Ohio Bureau of Employment Services ("OBES") denied their claims and, with certain exceptions, timely requests for reconsideration were made and the requests were certified as appeals to the Unemployment Compensation Board of Review ("board"). The appeals were consolidated by the board pursuant to Ohio Adm. Code 4146-7-02(E), and a hearing was held before a referee for and on behalf of the board on March 22, 1984. The board in nine separate opinions affirmed the denial of appellants' claims on October 16,  [***2] 1984.


1 There is evidently some confusion about how many appellants there are in this case. In their brief, appellants refer to themselves as "one hundred and eighty-four non-union affiliated individuals." ACMC, on the other hand, throughout its brief refers to "176 claimants." The court of common pleas characterized the appeal from the board's decisions as "taken on behalf of the 176 claimants," and, citing R.C. 4141.28(P), the court concluded that the appellants therein were "the 176 claimants." The court of appeals also viewed appellants as "[o]ne hundred seventy-six of the laid off employees."

From our review of the record we count, as does the administrator, one hundred eighty-five claimants. In its decision in In re Claim of McConnell (Oct. 16, 1984), No. 609558-M-BR, the board listed one hundred seventy-six individuals to whom the decision applies. The record also contains eight separate decisions by the board, each addressing an individual claim not included in the McConnell decision. The "Notice of Appeal and Class Action Complaint" filed in the court of common pleas listed forty-one claimants: thirty-two appealing from the McConnell decision; eight appealing from the board decision specifically addressing their claim; and one, Vera Valitsky, appealing from an earlier decision of the board dated April 10, 1984, dismissing her claim for failure to appear at the March 22, 1984 hearing. Thus, one hundred forty-four of the claimants affected by the McConnell decision were not individually listed as appellants.

 [***3] The board's rulings were appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Ashtabula County pursuant to R.C. 4141.28(O) and 4141.28(P). The single appeal, captioned "Notice of Appeal and Class Action Complaint," was filed by forty-one named appellants on their own behalf and purportedly on behalf of "all other[s] similarly situated." ACMC's motion to strike the appeal as to the appellants not listed was denied. The trial court granted appellants' motion for summary judgment on the merits, reversing and vacating the board's prior rulings. The court of appeals affirmed in part and reversed in part, modifying the trial court's order to apply only to the forty-one named appellants.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant claimants brought an action pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4141.28(O), (P), against appellee medical center, appellee board, and appellee agency, seeking review of the board's rulings affirming the denial of the claimants' requests for unemployment compensation. The Court of Common Pleas of Ashtabula County (Ohio) reversed and vacated the board's rulings. The court of appeals affirmed in part and reversed in part.


OVERVIEW: The claimants were non-union workers at a hospital operated by the medical center. In response to a strike by a nurses' union, the medical center closed the facility, thereby laying off all remaining employees of the hospital including the claimants. As a result, the claimants requested unemployment compensation. The agency denied their requests. On review, the board issued nine separate opinions affirming the denials. Forty-one claimants then successfully sought review before the trial court. On review of the trial court's entry of summary judgment in favor of the claimants, the court of appeals modified the trial court's order to apply to the 41 claimants only. On further review, the court affirmed the court of appeals because the trial court's jurisdiction was limited to the claims of the 41claimants who actually appealed the board's rulings.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals limiting the trial court's jurisdiction to the claimants who appealed the board's rulings.

 

30 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Posey


No. 87-1677


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 3d 420; 534 N.E.2d 61; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 484


September 21, 1988, Submitted  
December 30, 1988, Decided *


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: * Reporter's Note: This cause was decided on December 30, 1988, but was released to the public on January 30, 1989, subsequent to the retirement of Justice Locher, who participated in the decision.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, Nos. 86AP-1132, 86AP-1162 and 86AP-1163.

On May 7, 1986, Franklin County Deputy Sheriff Ernest Cook visited the premises of the Fraternal Order of Eagles ("FOE") Post 3261 in Reynoldsburg, Ohio. Prior to this visit Detective Cook had received information from an informant that gambling activities were being conducted at the Reynoldsburg Post. This informant was a member of the FOE. She had been a reliable source of information for Cook in the past, and on May 7, 1986, she accompanied Cook to the Reynoldsburg post.

The informant had her FOE credentials in hand and presented them to the doorkeeper, though the doorkeeper apparently never asked to see them. The informant was permitted to enter the premises, and Cook was allowed to accompany her as her guest. Once inside, Cook and the informant ordered drinks and observed the alleged gambling activity, which consisted of the use of electronic draw poker machines and instant win tickets. Cook himself engaged in these activities. As a result of his observations, Cook obtained a warrant to search the premises on May 9, 1986. A search pursuant to the warrant was conducted on [***2] that date.

On June 2, 1986, appellants, Jesse Posey, Sr., Fraternal Order of Eagles Post 3261, and Sharon Parker, were charged with violating R.C. 2915.02. Appellants each filed a motion to suppress the evidence. Appellants also each filed a motion to dismiss the charges on statutory and constitutional grounds. The trial court overruled the motions to suppress on December 12, 1986, finding that Cook's entry into the lodge was lawful and that anything he observed in plain view was admissible. However, the court did grant appellants' motions to dismiss the charges on two grounds: that the state could not demonstrate that the gambling was for profit; and that the statute's exemption from prosecution of certain charitable organizations, but not the FOE, denied the FOE equal protection of the laws. Both decisions were appealed to the court of appeals, which on July 28, 1987, affirmed the denial of the motions to suppress, but reversed the dismissals and remanded the cases for trial.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, fraternal organization and others, were charged with violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.02 for illegal gambling. The trial court overruled their motions to suppress the evidence but granted their motions to dismiss the charges. Both decisions were appealed to the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed denial of the motions to suppress but reversed the dismissals. A motion to certify the record was allowed.


OVERVIEW: An informant provided a detective with information that the fraternal organization was conducting gambling activities on its premises. The detective visited the premises as a guest of the informant who was a member of the fraternal organization. As a result of the detective's observations of the alleged gambling activity, he subsequently obtained a warrant to search the premises. A search pursuant to the warrant was conducted and evidence was seized. Thereafter, the fraternal organization and the others were charged with illegal gambling. On appeal, the court held that (1) such a nonprofit fraternal organization could be found guilty of gambling for profit in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.02; (2) application of § 2915.02 to the fraternal organization was consistent with the equal protection guarantees of the U.S. and Ohio Constitutions in light of certain exemptions from prosecution granted to other purely charitable institutions by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2915.02(D); and (3) the evidence seized was admissible notwithstanding that the seizure, while made pursuant to a warrant, was preceded by a warrantless entry into the premises because that entry was not deceptive.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals, affirming the denial of the motions to suppress and reversing the dismissals, was affirmed.

 

31 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Mitchell v. Lawson Milk Co.


No. 87-2099


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 3d 190; 532 N.E.2d 753; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 450


November 2, 1988, Submitted  
December 30, 1988, Decided *


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: * Reporter's Note: This cause was decided on December 30, 1988, but was released to the public on January 4, 1989, subsequent to the retirement of Justice Locher, who participated in the decision.


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]  

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County, No. CA 10483.

On January 16, 1985, Mary A. Mitchell was fatally shot during a robbery which occurred while she was working as a clerk in a Lawson Milk Company store. James L. Mitchell, administrator of her estate and appellee herein, filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County on August 14, 1986.
