He alleged that Lawson had committed an intentional tort by failing to provide adequate security or training in handling violent situations. Lawson responded with a motion to dismiss the complaint pursuant to Civ. R. 12(B)(6). 1 


1 Appellant also argued that the complaint was barred by R.C. 4121.80(A), effective August 22, 1986, which provides that actions which allege the commission of an intentional tort by an employer must be brought within one year of the employee's death or alleged injury. The court of common pleas held and the court of appeals affirmed that application to the cause herein of the statute of limitations contained in R.C. 4121.80(A) would be unconstitutional because appellee would be denied a reasonable time after the effective date of the statute in which to bring the claim. We need not decide the merits of this argument due to our decision that even if the complaint were timely filed, it must be dismissed pursuant to Civ. R. 12(B)(6).

 [***2] The trial court granted the motion, holding that the complaint failed to state a claim of intentional tort under the retroactive application of R.C. 4121.80(G)(1), or under the "substantial certainty" test of Blankenship v.. Cincinnati Milacron Chemicals (1982), 69 Ohio St. 2d 608, 23 O.O. 3d 504, 433 N.E. 2d 572, and Jones v.. VIP Development Co. (1984), 15 Ohio St. 3d 90, 15 OBR 246, 472 N.E. id 1046.

The court of appeals concluded that the statute, effective August 22, 1986, could not be given retroactive effect consistent with Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution. The court reversed the lower court's judgment on the basis that the complaint properly pled a claim of intentional tort under the standard set forth in Blankenship and Jones.

The cause is before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following the death of an employee during a robbery, appellee estate administrator brought suit against appellant employer. The trial court dismissed for failure to state a claim under the retroactive application of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4121.80(G)(1) and under a "substantial certainty" test. The Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio) reversed and held that a claim of intentional tort was properly pleaded. The employer appealed.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the court held that Ohio Const. art. II, § 28 precluded the retroactive application of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4121.80(G)(1) to intentional tort causes of action committed by employers arising prior to the statute's effective date. In order to establish an intentional tort, the estate administrator must have shown proof beyond that required to establish negligence and beyond that required to establish recklessness. The complaint concluded that the employer knew or should have known that its employees were subject to armed robberies and other violent acts. The court held that the intentional tort claim against the employer would be dismissed unless the complaint alleged facts showing that the employer specifically desired to injure the employee or knew that injury to the employee was certain or substantially certain to result from the employer's act and despite this knowledge, still proceeded. Given the facts pleaded in the complaint, the court concluded that it was not possible for the estate administrator to prove an intentional tort.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that the statute could not be given retroactive effect. The court reversed the judgment that the complaint properly pleaded a claim of intentional tort. The court reinstated the trial court's dismissal of the complaint.

 

32 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Gibney v. Toledo Bd. of Educ.


No. 87-2097


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 3d 152; 532 N.E.2d 1300; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 445


November 2, 1988, Submitted  
December 29, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County, No. L-86-221.

In August 1982, defendant Toledo Board of Education (hereinafter "the board") and appellant, Toledo Federation of Teachers (hereinafter "TFT"), entered into a collective bargaining agreement which contained an "[a]gency [s]hop" provision. This provision required that teaching employees either become members of TFT or, if membership was not desired, share in the financial support of TFT by paying a service fee not to exceed the amount of dues paid by members. Thus, each teacher was required to pay a "fair share" of collective bargaining costs.

Appellees are teachers employed by the board who are not members of TFT. These teachers opposed the requirement that they pay the service fees to TFT from the inception of the collective bargaining agreement. TFT filed an action to enforce payment. On August 15, 1983, the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of TFT. This decision was subsequently upheld on appeal. 1 The board notified the appellees on September 8, 1983, that it would deduct the fees from each of the appellees' payroll checks, to be paid to TFT on an installment basis.


1 See Toledo Federation of Teachers v.. Gibney (Feb. 3, 1984), Lucas App. No. L-83-303, unreported.

 [***2] On September 22, 1983, appellees filed an action challenging the service fees and procedures regulating the rebate of portions of such service fees used for political and ideological purposes as, inter alia, violative of Section 1983, Title 42, U.S. Code, and appellees' rights under the Constitution of the United States and Constitution of the state of Ohio. Appellees requested temporary and permanent injunctive relief, as well as damages and attorney fees. Thereafter, all service fees paid by appellees to TFT were placed in escrow pursuant to a court order filed on October 13, 1983. On April 1, 1984, R.C. Chapter 4117, the Public Employees' Collective Bargaining Act, became effective.

Trial commenced on August 29, 1985 to determine whether TFT's rebate procedure was constitutional. 2 Following the presentation of appellees' case, TFT rested without offering any evidence. On November 15, 1985, the trial court held that the procedures used by TFT to refund nonmember employee service fees and resolve disputes concerning the validity of the rebates were unconstitutional. TFT was enjoined from collecting service fees from appellees and the funds placed in escrow pursuant to [***3] the order of October 13, 1983 were ordered released to appellees with interest. The cause was continued for purposes of determining appellees' damages and several motions were subsequently filed by both sides. On June 19, 1986, 3 the trial court awarded attorney fees and expenses to the appellees pursuant to Section 1988, Title 42, U.S. Code.


2 The trial court admitted into evidence two separate rebate procedures utilized by TFT. One was the original rebate procedure and the other was a procedure that would have been utilized as of the date of trial.


3 As of April 25, 1986, TFT had not formally adopted a new rebate procedure.

On appeal, TFT did not contest the trial court's finding that the procedures for refunds and rebate disputes were unconstitutional. However, TFT did argue that the trial court erred in ordering the return to appellees of those funds placed in escrow after April 1, 1984 and in granting relief enjoining TFT from collecting service fees from appellees. TFT also appealed the award of attorney fees to appellees. The court of appeals affirmed the decision of the trial court in all respects.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance [***4] of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant union challenged a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which determined that the procedures used to refund appellee nonunion member employees service fees and resolve disputes concerning the validity of the rebates was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The nonunion members challenged the union's agency shop provision of the collective bargaining agreement which required each teacher to pay a fair share of collective bargaining costs regardless of union status. The nonunion members filed a 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 action against the union. The trial court held that the procedures used by the union to refund nonmember employee service fees and resolve disputes concerning the validity of the rebates were unconstitutional. The union was enjoined from collecting service fees from the nonmembers. On appeal the union argued that the trial court erred in granting relief to the nonmembers because appellees were required to exhaust administrative remedies contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.01 et seq., and specifically § 4117.09(C), before obtaining relief pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983. The court affirmed the judgment, holding that, unless otherwise provided by Congress, the exhaustion of state administrative remedies was not required prior to obtaining relief pursuant to § 1983 in state court. Further, the nonmembers were clearly prevailing parties which entitled them to recover attorney fees under § 1988.


OUTCOME: Judgment finding that the union's procedures to refund the nonunion members' service fees and its dispute resolution concerning the validity of the rebates were unconstitutional was affirmed.

 

33 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Denson


No. 86-1866


Supreme Court of Ohio


40 Ohio St. 3d 30; 531 N.E.2d 674; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 397


October 18, 1988, Submitted  
December 7, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, No. C-850311.

 

34 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Sowell


No. 86-1499


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 322; 530 N.E.2d 1294; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 375


May 3, 1988, Submitted  
November 16, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, No. C-830835.

On May 1, 1983, appellant, Billy Joe Sowell, visited the apartment of his friend, Calvert Graham, who lived down the hall from appellant in a Cincinnati apartment building. Appellant later left the apartment in the company of Pamela Jean Billups, who had been visiting Graham and his friend Donna Edwards. Appellant took Billups to dinner and, afterwards, they went to a hotel and rented a room. There was conflicting testimony as to what transpired there, but it is undisputed that appellant eventually passed out under the influence of marijuana and alcohol that he had consumed that evening. Appellant bought breakfast for Billups the following morning and went home.

Three days later, on May 4, appellant saw Billups as they passed each other in a store doorway. Neither person acknowledged the other. On his way home that evening, appellant claims he drank at least one double shot of vodka at each of five taverns. He then proceeded to Graham's apartment where he allegedly consumed more alcohol and a marijuana cigarette with Graham, Billups, and Edwards.

Appellant testified that he then fell asleep for a short [***2] time only to awaken and find $ 190 missing from his pocket. He became enraged when Graham, Billups, and Edwards claimed ignorance of the funds. Billups testified that appellant also accused her of stealing money from him on the night they were at the hotel. Graham subsequently ordered appellant to leave his apartment. Appellant then announced his intention to get his gun to shoot Billups, and he returned to his own apartment for several minutes, where he instructed his alleged common-law wife, Lenora Waugh, to bring him his .38 caliber pistol. He and Waugh then walked down the hall to Graham's apartment. Appellant told Waugh to knock on the door and identify herself as someone named "Portia."

Billups and Edwards testified that when Graham opened the door, appellant forced his way into the apartment. He then fired a shot into the ceiling and said that he intended to shoot Billups. Graham managed to calm appellant down somewhat and began escorting him to the door. At this time, appellant suddenly turned and shot Graham in the abdomen. As Graham fell, appellant fired another shot into Graham's head, killing him. Appellant claimed that he did not draw and shoot his gun until [***3] Graham threatened him with a knife.

Appellant then searched for Billups and found her hiding in a closet. He shot her three times and then put the gun to her head and pulled the trigger. However, the gun failed to fire because he had expended all its ammunition. Appellant returned to his apartment, ordered Waugh to hide the gun and give him some money, and then left the premises. As he left the building he threatened to shoot Edwards if she fled before he did. Appellant was subsequently arrested at a nearby tavern.

Appellant was indicted for aggravated murder with a death penalty specification pursuant to R.C. 2929.04(A)(5), that the killing of Graham was part of a course of conduct involving the purposeful killing of Graham and the attempt to kill Billups. He was also indicted for the attempted aggravated murder of Pam Billups. Appellant entered pleas of not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity, and was subsequently found competent to stand trial. He then waived his right to a jury trial.

A three-judge panel found appellant guilty as charged and sentenced him to death for the aggravated murder of Graham, and to a term of seven to twenty-five years for the attempted [***4] aggravated murder of Billups. The court of appeals affirmed the convictions and sentences with one judge dissenting only with respect to the court's approval of the death sentence.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.
State v. Sowell, 1986 Ohio App. LEXIS 7943 (Ohio Ct. App., Hamilton County, Feb. 20, 1986)



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision from Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed defendant's convictions for aggravated murder and attempted aggravated murder and which also affirmed the imposition of the death penalty.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, who was intoxicated, thought the victims stole his money and he shot them several times. He was convicted of aggravated murder and attempted aggravated murder and the trial court imposed the death penalty. The convictions and the sentence were affirmed, and defendant sought review. The court affirmed. It found that the appellate court erred when it failed to consider voluntary intoxication as a mitigating factor when it reviewed the death sentence but that the error was not prejudicial to defendant. Furthermore, the appellate court was not required to unanimously find that the aggravating circumstances outweighed the mitigating factors beyond a reasonable doubt and that the death sentence was appropriate. The trial court did not err when it admitted a victim impact statement in its sentencing determination because the panel did not affirmatively rely on the evidence. The trial court did not err when it weighed the aggravating circumstances and mitigating factors in its sentencing determination. The trial court did not err when it failed to specifically find that defendant killed prior calculation and design and when it failed to acquit defendant of aggravated murder.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's aggravated murder and attempted aggravated murder convictions and affirmed the imposition of the death penalty.

 

35 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Van Hook


No. 87-1159


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 256; 530 N.E.2d 883; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 365


June 14, 1988, Submitted  
November 9, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, No. C-850565.

It was established at trial that on the evening of February 18, 1985, Robert Van Hook, appellant herein, went to a downtown Cincinnati establishment called the Subway Bar. There, he approached David Self. The two engaged in conversation while consuming alcoholic beverages for approximately two to three hours. As they left together, Self stopped briefly to explain to the bartender that he and appellant were planning to go to Self's apartment.

At the apartment, appellant lured Self into a vulnerable position and, with no provocation, attacked him. Initially, appellant strangled Self into a state of unconsciousness. He then took a paring knife from the victim's kitchen and stabbed the victim behind the right ear, aiming the thrust upward toward the brain, accompanied by a blade-twisting movement. Appellant then stabbed the victim's neck in numerous places, each stab wound accompanied by cutting motions. Several of these wounds penetrated over halfway through the neck and apparently represented appellant's efforts to decapitate the victim. Appellant then made an incision on the victim's body from the abdomen [***2] up to and over the sternum. The victim's abdominal cavity was opened so that his liver was visible. Appellant then stabbed upward a number of times, penetrating the liver and eventually penetrating the abdominal wall into the heart in three places. He placed a small bottle which had contained amyl nitrate, its cap, a cigarette butt and the paring knife into the victim's abdominal cavity.

Appellant then searched much of the apartment including a chest of drawers and a jewelry box. There was evidence that particular items of jewelry were taken, including specific testimony that the victim's gold chain necklace, which he had worn into the bar earlier that evening, was missing. Thereafter, appellant looked into the victim's refrigerator for food, but not seeing anything that "[he] liked," he prepared his departure from the apartment. Such preparation included smearing his bloody fingerprints, and turning up the volume on the stereo system.

After leaving the apartment, appellant went to the home of Dr. Robert Hoy, a family friend. There, under the guise of recovering from a fight with his stepfather, appellant borrowed money and ate a large meal. He then left and eventually arrived [***3] in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. There, he evaded detection until April 1, 1985, when, pursuant to information given by appellant's family, he was arrested by the Oakland Park police.

Subsequently, appellant was indicted for the offenses of aggravated murder in violation of R.C. 2903.01 and aggravated robbery in violation of R.C. 2911.01. A specification was also contained in the indictment that appellant committed the aggravated murder during the course of an aggravated robbery and that he was the principal offender. R.C. 2929.04(A)(7). Appellant pled not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity.

Appellant waived his right to a trial by jury, electing to be tried instead by a three-judge panel. Appellant was found guilty of both charges as well as the aggravating circumstances specified. Following the sentencing phase, the three-judge panel, for the reasons set forth in its opinion filed pursuant to R.C. 2929.03(F), imposed the sentence of death upon appellant for the crime of aggravated murder and also imposed a concurrent indefinite term of ten to twenty-five years for the crime of aggravated robbery. The court of appeals, having performed its statutory independent analysis [***4] of the record and the proportionality of the sentence, affirmed the sentence in all particulars.

The cause is before this court pursuant to an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which upheld defendant's conviction for the offenses of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery.


OVERVIEW: After the police discovered a victim brutally murdered in his apartment, defendant was indicted for the offenses of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery. Defendant was found guilty of both charges as well as the aggravating circumstances and was sentenced to death. The court of appeals upheld the sentence and on appeal, the conviction and sentence were affirmed. Defendant's confession to the police, which included an admission to the killing and the robbery, was properly admitted because the record demonstrated that defendant himself reinitiated his own interrogation. Further, the evidence establishing deadly force and a deadly weapon constituted evidence that the victim had been robbed as well as murdered and, accordingly, was sufficient to firmly establish the corpus delicti predicate for admission of the confession. Finally, the trial court was justified in refusing to find the existence of mitigating factors under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(B)(3), given defendant's failure to establish mental disease, the finding that defendant was not impaired in his ability to distinguish right from wrong, and the scant evidence offered in mitigation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for aggravated murder and aggravated robbery because defendant's confession was properly admitted, a predicate for admission of the confession was established, and defendant was not entitled to consideration of mitigating factors.

 

36 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


City of Middletown v. McGee


No. 87-1656


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 284; 530 N.E.2d 902; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 358


June 8, 1988, Submitted  
November 9, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Warren County, No. CA86-07-050.

The subject of this appeal is the legality of the proposed annexation by the city of Franklin of two sections of Cincinnati-Dayton Road in Warren County. The first section of roadway (hereinafter "the northern territory") connects two areas of the city of Franklin. The second section (hereinafter "the southern territory") runs parallel to the boundary of the city of Franklin for about eighteen hundred feet and then continues outward into Franklin Township. These two sections of the county highway's right-of-way total 3.8 miles in length and are eighty feet wide at all points. (See appended map.)

[SEE ILLUSTRATION IN ORIGINAL]

On August 5, 1985, the Franklin City Council adopted Ordinance 1985-19, which authorized proceedings to annex the territory in question. A petition for annexation was filed with the Board of County Commissioners for Warren County (hereinafter "the board"). On November 5, 1985, the electors of the unincorporated areas of Franklin Township approved the issue. Following a public hearing on January 30, 1986, the board adopted Resolution 86-63, thereby approving the petition for annexation.

 [***2] Thereafter, the city of Middletown, Donald Easterly, Byron R. Strassburger and Sue Strassburger, appellants herein, sought an injunction under R.C. 709.07 to prevent the annexation. The Court of Common Pleas of Warren County held a hearing on the merits and denied the injunction on July 28, 1986.

The court of appeals found that appellants had standing to challenge the proposed annexation, but affirmed the trial court's denial of the injunction.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, city of Middletown and Middletown residents, sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Warren County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgment that denied their request for an injunction to prevent the annexation proposed by appellees, city of Franklin and Franklin residents.


OVERVIEW: The city of Franklin and the Franklin residents had adopted a resolution for the annexation into the city of Middletown. The city of Middletown and the Middletown residents opposed the annexation by filing an injunction to prevent the annexation. The trial court denied the request for an injunction, and the appellate court affirmed the denial. On appeal, the court held that the city of Middletown and the Middletown residents had proven by clear and convincing evidence their right to an injunction under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 709.07. One of the Middletown residents' legal interest in his property within the territory to be annexed could be adversely affected because he did not have a desire to have his property located within the city of Franklin. The city of Middletown's legal rights could be adversely affected by the annexation because its right under a contract with Warren County to service and maintain water located within a portion of the subject territory could be impaired. The court concluded that the city of Franklin had erred to the prejudice of the city of Middletown and the Middletown residents when it found the annexation was good for the territory at issue.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment that affirmed the trial court's denial of the request for an injunction of the city of Middletown and the Middletown residents to prevent the annexation proposed by the city of Franklin and the Franklin residents. The court remanded the matter to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

37 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Rocky River v. State Employment Relations Bd.


No. 87-157


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 196; 530 N.E.2d 1; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 347; 129 L.R.R.M. 2975


March 8, 1988, Submitted  
November 2, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Rehearing Granted February 10, 1989.


PRIOR HISTORY: APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County, No. 51299.

In 1983 the General Assembly adopted new R.C. Chapter 4117, the Ohio Public Employees' Collective Bargaining Act, which established the procedures for the representation of public employees by labor unions. R.C. 4117.14(D)(1), in particular, provides for dispute settlement between the exclusive representative of public safety employees and a public employer. After the exclusive representative and the public employer have failed to reach an agreement and have engaged in fact-finding, the dispute is to be submitted to a conciliator, in effect an arbitrator, for final offer binding arbitration. R.C. 4117.14(I) mandates that the issuance of a final offer settlement award be binding upon the parties to the dispute.

After this section of the Act became effective in 1984, appellant, the city of Rocky River, recognized the Rocky River Firefighters (IAFF), Local 695 ("the union") as the exclusive representative of fire fighters in the city and bargained with it with respect to wages, hours, and other terms and conditions of employment. Following an impasse over the issue of wages,  [***2] the city and the union participated in fact-finding, the first stage of the dispute-resolution process. The city rejected the fact-finder's report, triggering the binding final offer arbitration provision of the Act's dispute-resolution "conciliation" mechanism. The city agreed to proceed with the conciliation process, but stated in advance that it would not be bound by the "binding mandate," whether favorable or unfavorable, because of the constitutional infirmities of R.C. 4117.14(I). The conciliator issued an award on February 21, 1985, adopting the union's position, which became a "binding mandate" under the Act. Subsequently, on March 14, 1985, the city and the union reached an agreement providing for wages and wage adjustments during this litigation and, if appropriate, upon the conclusion thereof.

Prior to the conciliator's award, however, on February 6, 1985, Rocky River filed a declaratory judgment action seeking a judgment that R.C. 4117.14(I) violates the Ohio Constitution by mandating binding arbitration for collective bargaining disputes between the exclusive representative of safety employees and municipal employers. Appellees, the State Employment Relations Board [***3] ("SERB"), and the Rocky River Firefighters (IAFF), Local 695 filed motions for summary judgment seeking to uphold the constitutionality of R.C. 4117.14(I).

Rocky River responded with its cross-motion for summary judgment challenging the constitutionality of R.C. 4117.14(I) as a violation of the city's home-rule powers and as an unlawful delegation of legislative power. The trial court granted appellees' motions and denied the city's cross-motion. The court of appeals affirmed the trial court's decision.

The case is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellees, the State Employment Relations Board and the local firefighters union filed a motion for summary judgment against appellant city seeking to uphold the constitutionality of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.14(I). The city responded by filing a cross-motion for summary judgment challenging the constitutionality of § 4117.14(I). The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County upheld the constitutionality of the statute and the city appealed.


OVERVIEW: The issue of first impression presented in this case was whether Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.14(I), which mandated binding arbitration for collective bargaining disputes between the exclusive representatives of municipal safety forces and a municipal employer, was unconstitutional to the extent that it violated the city's power. Appellant city challenged § 4117.14(I) as a violation of its power of local self-government, usurping its power to set the wages of its safety forces. Appellees, the state employment relations board and the local firefighters union, maintained that § 4117.14(I) was enacted by the General Assembly for the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the state and applicable to municipalities. The state employment relations board and the local firefighters union further argued that § 4117.14(I) manifested a statewide concern for the integrity of the collective bargaining process in the public sector. The court held that § 4117.14(I) was unconstitutional to the extent that it violated a municipality's right to exercise power of local self-government and because it interfered with the municipality's power to determine municipal safety employee compensation.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment.

 

38 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Twinsburg v. State Employment Relations Bd.


No. 86-1947


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 226; 530 N.E.2d 26; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 395; 129 L.R.R.M. 2995


March 8, 1988, Submitted  
November 2, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County, No. 12509.

Plaintiff-appellant, city of Twinsburg, is a "home-rule" charter municipality under Sections 3 and 7, Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution. 1 Defendant-appellee, State Employment Relations Board ("SERB"), is a state agency created by the General Assembly, inter alia, to administer and enforce R.C. Chapter 4117, the Public Employees' Collective Bargaining Act.


1 Section 3, Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution provides:

"Municipalities shall have authority to exercise all powers of local self-government and to adopt and enforce within their limits such local police, sanitary and other similar regulations, as are not in conflict with general laws."

Section 7, Article XVIII provides:

"Any municipality may frame and adopt or amend a charter for its government and may, subject to the provisions of section 3 of this article, exercise thereunder all powers of local self-government."

Under various provisions of the Twinsburg City Charter and Twinsburg Codified Ordinances, the Mayor and City Council of Twinsburg have the power to determine and establish the wages and terms of employment of all municipal employees.

 [***2] On April 1, 1984, the effective date of R.C. Chapter 4117, intervening defendant-appellee, Northern Ohio Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, filed a petition with SERB pursuant to R.C. 4117.05 in order to be recognized as the bargaining agent for Twinsburg police officers.

Subsequently, Twinsburg commenced this action in the court of common pleas seeking a declaration that R.C. Chapter 4117 is unconstitutional in its entirety as it relates to Twinsburg, by virtue of Sections 3 and 7, Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution. In addition, Twinsburg sought to enjoin SERB from any further action relating to Twinsburg.

The trial court held that R.C. Chapter 4117 is constitutional and that it is applicable to Twinsburg. On appeal, the court of appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of the judgment from the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio) affirming the decision of the trial court, which held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 4117 was constitutional. The city contended that the statute was unconstitutional in its entirety as it related to the city, by virtue of Ohio Const. art. XVIII, §§ 3, 7.


OVERVIEW: The city was a "home-rule" charter municipality under Ohio Const. art. XVIII, §§ 3, 7. Appellee, the State Employment Relations Board (SERB), was a state agency created to administer and enforce Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 4117, the Public Employees' Collective Bargaining Act (Act). On the effective date of the Act, intervening defendant-appellee union filed a petition with SERB pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.05 in order to be recognized as the bargaining agent for the city police. The court had earlier held that the provision for mandatory binding arbitration of collective bargaining disputes over municipal safety-employee benefits and wages, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.14(I), was unconstitutional. However, with the exception of its arguments concerning the Act's mandatory binding arbitration provisions, the city had not met the burden of overcoming this presumption of constitutionality of the Act. In affirming the court of appeals in part, the court held that the city's constitutionally protected right to determine the compensation of its employees was not irreconcilable with those portions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 4117 that were left intact after the court's prior ruling.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals except where it conflicted with the court's prior holding that the statute in question was unconstitutional in so far as it violated a municipality's right to exercise the powers of local self-government, and (2) unlawfully delegated municipal legislative authority to set wages and salaries for municipal safety employees.

 

39 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Jacobs v. Teledyne, Inc.


No. 87-1297


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 168; 529 N.E.2d 1255; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 338


May 18, 1988, Submitted  
October 26, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Allen County, Nos. 1-86-17 and 1-86-18.

Appellant, Jimmie Jacobs, was employed as a foundry worker by appellee, Teledyne, Inc. (hereinafter "Teledyne"), from 1943 until 1983. In August 1972, appellant filed a workers' compensation claim alleging that he had contracted the occupational disease of silicosis as a result of exposure to silica dust in the course of his employment.

On November 7, 1973, following a hearing on the claim, a deputy administrator of the Industrial Commission rendered a decision which stated:

"The Administrator finds that although proof of record shows that the claimant has contracted the disease of silicosis the same has not caused total disability within eight (8) years after his last injurious exposure; it is, therefore found that under the provisions of O.R.C. 4123.68 no benefits or compensation can be paid at this time in this claim.

"Claim uncertified."

The decision was also stamped with the words: "Bureau of Workmen's Compensation APPROVED CLAIM." This decision was not appealed by any party and no further proceedings were held on this matter at that time.

In January 1984, appellant filed a new claim and again [***2] alleged that he had contracted silicosis in the course of his employment. The new claim made specific reference to and incorporated the application filed in August 1972. A district hearing officer considered appellant's 1984 claim for benefits and construed it to be an application to reactivate the 1972 claim. 1 The hearing officer denied the new claim and stated in part:

"Claim OD-21497-22 is disallowed as a new claim as the record is clear that the claimant has a previous claim for the same condition with the same employer and that that claim is OD-9957-22. Hence, claimant's application filed in claim OD-21497-22 is to be deemed as an application to reactivate the claim in OD-9957-22. As such, the application must be denied in that more than six years has elapsed in claim OD-9957-22 and there has been no payment of compensation so as to continue the jurisdiction of the Industrial Commission under 4123.52 of the Ohio Revised Code. The findings of the Deputy Administrator as previously cited is [sic] a finding as to the claimant's right topparticipate [sic] in that it does find that the claimant has contracted the condition of silicosis in the course of and arising  [***3] out of his employment. That finding is also a finding as to the claim-ant's [sic] extent of disability in that is [sic] is found that the claimant has not suffered total disability within eight years of the last injurious exposure. In that claimant's right to participate was determined as of 11-7-73, at least, and in that more than six years has elapsed without the payment of compensation for the condition of silicosis, Claim OD 9957-22 is no longer a claim within the continuing jurisdiction of the Industrial Commission of Ohio * * *.

"As a point of clarification OD-21497-22 is not a newly compensable claim for the reason that the claimant had a pre-existing condition specifically allowed in the prior claim. While it is a general rule that there is some exception to the rule of Miller vs mead [sic] conderning [sic] dust cases, the instant claim is not within those exceptions because the present conditionawas [sic] specifically recognized in a previous claim."


1 Appellant's August 1972 claim was designated as claim OD-9957-22. The 1984 claim was designated as claim OD-21497-22.

This decision was affirmed by the regional board of review and the [***4] Industrial Commission refused appellant's further appeal.

Subsequently, appellant filed two separate appeals in the court of common pleas pursuant to R.C. 4123.519. One appeal involved the original 1972 claim and the other involved the 1984 claim. These claims were consolidated by the trial court. The trial court granted summary judgment on both claims in favor of Teledyne on March 27, 1986. On appeal, the court of appeals affirmed the trial court's decision on the basis that appellant's claims were barred under the doctrine of res judicata.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant worker's 1972 workers' compensation claim for silicosis was allowed but nothing was paid because he was not disabled. He refiled in 1984 after becoming disabled but the claim was denied by appellee Industrial Commission because more than six years had passed since the 1972 filing. When summary judgment was granted to appellee employer on review and affirmed by the Court of Appeals for Allen County (Ohio), the worker appealed.


OVERVIEW: A worker's 1972 claim resulted in his silicosis being recognized. However, no compensation was paid because he was not disabled. His 1984 claim, made when he became disabled, was deemed a reactivation of the old claim. Because more than six years had passed, the claim was found to be no longer viable. After being denied administrative relief, the worker appealed the 1972 and 1984 orders, but the trial court ruled for the employer and the commission. The worker appealed and the court reversed and remanded. It rejected the argument that res judicata barred the claim. Finding that the worker had filed the 1972 claim only to avoid a statute of limitations issue, the court found that the earlier claim had served no purpose because the worker was not disabled when he filed it and thus could not receive any compensation. However, he was totally disabled when he filed the 1984 claim. This factual difference alone was significant enough to prevent res judicata from applying to bar the claim, and the court so ruled. The court also found that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.52 was not applicable to an occupational disease like silicosis, as it was not an "injury" within the meaning of the statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed lower court orders holding that the worker's claims were barred by res judicata and remanded to the commission for further proceedings on the worker's 1984 claim for compensation.

 

40 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Williams v. Iannucci


No. 88-1662


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 292; 530 N.E.2d 869; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 420


October 19, 1988, Submitted  
October 20, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

IN MANDAMUS.

Relators filed this complaint in mandamus on September 21, 1988, alleging that they are registered voters of Trumbull County and members of official committees proposing to initiate virtually identical "ordinances" in the city of Warren and Warren Township pursuant to R.C. 731.28 et seq. Respondents are the Warren City Auditor and Board of Elections of Trumbull County. The proposals would generally forbid municipal or township assistance to state authorities in the construction of penal institutions in the respective areas, subject to criminal penalties and citizen suits for injunctive relief at public expense.

The municipal petitions were filed with the city auditor, as required by R.C. 731.28, on August 12, 1988, with sufficient signatures under the statute. However, the auditor did not certify the petition to the respondent board of elections after ten days, as required by R.C. 731.28, because of alleged "defects rendering the petition insufficient and invalid." The relators request this court to issue a peremptory or alternative writ of mandamus compelling the auditor to submit the text of the proposed ordinance to the board of elections and compelling  [***2] the board of elections to submit it to the electorate on November 8, 1988.

Relators further allege that they filed the township petitions with the "Auditor of Warren Township," who certified the text to the board of elections, that the petitions were "determined to contain" sufficient signatures under R.C. 731.28, that they are in substantial compliance with applicable laws, and that the board has refused to submit the proposed ordinance at the forthcoming election of November 8, 1988. The board expressly admits only that the "township clerk" delivered the petitions to it and that it refused to submit the proposal to a vote. By failing to deny the allegation, the board admits that the township petitions were determined to contain sufficient signatures. Relators request a peremptory or alternative writ compelling the board to submit the proposed ordinance to the township electorate.

The board of elections has filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed in part and denied in part.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent election board filed a motion to dismiss a complaint in mandamus filed by relators, registered voters and official committee members. Relators filed a mandamus action to compel respondent city auditor to submit the text of a proposed ordinance to the board and to compel the board to submit the ordinance to the electorate. Relators further requested that the board submit another proposed ordinance to the township electorate.


OVERVIEW: Relators proposed to initiate identical ordinances forbidding municipal or township assistance to state authorities in the construction of penal institutions. The municipal petitions were filed with the city auditor with sufficient signatures under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 731.28. However, the city auditor did not certify the petitions because of alleged defects. Relators filed the township petitions with the township auditor who certified the text to the board. However, the board failed to submit the proposed ordinance at the forthcoming election. In response, relators requested a writ compelling the board to submit the proposed ordinances to the municipal and township electorates. The board filed a motion to dismiss the relators' complaint. Upon review, the court issued a limited writ in relators' favor. The court agreed that the city auditor exceeded his authority by refusing to certify the text of the municipal proposal. The court noted that the city auditor did not have the authority to pronounce judgment on the legality of a proposed ordinance. However, the court found that relators failed to prove that the board had a clear duty to place the proposed ordinances on the ballot.


OUTCOME: The court issued a limited writ of mandamus ordering the city auditor to certify the text of the proposed municipal ordinance to the election board. and ordering the election board to review the sufficiency and validity of the petitions proposing the municipal ordinance.

 

41 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Bedford


No. 86-1976


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 122; 529 N.E.2d 913; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 318


June 9, 1988, Submitted  
October 12, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, No. C-840850.

On May 17, 1984, Daniel Lee Bedford, appellant herein, was indicted on two counts of aggravated murder pursuant to R.C. 2903.01(A). Both counts alleged that Bedford purposely and with prior calculation and design caused the death of another. Each count was accompanied by the specification that the murder was committed as part of a course of conduct involving the purposeful killing of two or more persons. R.C. 2929.04(A)(5).

At approximately 2:30 a.m. on Tuesday, April 24, 1984, Bedford telephoned the apartment shared by his ex-girlfriend, Gwen Toepfert, and Jo Ann Funk. Bedford asked to speak with Toepfert. Funk refused to awaken Toepfert, although she reluctantly told Bedford that both Toepfert and her boyfriend, John Smith, were at the apartment.

It seems Bedford had attempted to speak with Toepfert because he had been hoping for some time to rekindle a prior romance. On the prior Saturday, he came to the apartment to deliver a plant to Toepfert but discovered her new boyfriend there. Bedford became very upset and departed after giving the plant to Toepfert.

Later that Tuesday morning, Jo Ann Funk was [***2] awakened by gunshots and screams. Toepfert ran into Funk's bedroom, crying that she had been shot. After Funk attempted to phone for help, Bedford entered the room and shot Toepfert as she lay on the floor. 1 Bedford did not shoot Funk, although she heard the .38 caliber revolver click after Bedford shot her roommate.


1 It is not entirely clear how Bedford gained access to the apartment. Bedford told an examining psychologist that he had hidden in the laundry room of the apartment building to avoid being seen prior to gaining entrance to the apartment.

Bedford left the bedroom and Funk followed him into the living room. She saw Bedford with a shotgun. He was looking behind the open front door and yelling, "Come out, mother-fucker." Outside the building, Smith's body lay on the landing of the front steps.

Funk ran to the bathroom and slammed the door. During that time, she heard a loud shot fired. Bedford then left the apartment. Upon coming out of the bathroom, Funk noticed that Toepfert had sustained a shotgun blast to the lower abdomen, in the pelvic region.

Bedford fled to Tennessee. While there, he visited an acquaintance from his boyhood days, Jimmy Joe Pennington.  [***3] Later that same Tuesday evening, Pennington asked why Bedford looked troubled and Bedford replied that he had killed two people. Pennington told a store clerk to phone the police and, although Bedford guessed that Pennington had turned him in, Bedford waited for the arrival of the authorities.

Upon arriving, a deputy sheriff asked Bedford if the police could help him. He replied that he had killed two people in Cincinnati earlier in the day. Appellant was frisked, given his Miranda rights, and taken to jail. Bedford again received his Miranda rights, signed a waiver, and gave police an inculpatory statement. He later gave Cincinnati authorities a similar inculpatory statement.

At trial, Bedford attempted to establish that he was extremely upset and depressed due to the break-up with his girlfriend and that he was intoxicated when he went to her apartment. 2 His statement indicated that he shot Smith after Smith wrestled away the shotgun and that he would not have killed either victim if Smith had not wrestled the shotgun from him.


2 There was no evidence corroborating Bedford's intoxication claim. Funk testified to the effect that he did not seem intoxicated either on the telephone or when he was at the apartment. Pennington testified that, while Bedford appeared very tired, Bedford did not seem to be intoxicated. Finally, the police testified that Bedford did not appear intoxicated. There was testimony that Bedford made the early morning call from a bar.

 [***4] A jury convicted Bedford on one count of aggravated murder (Toepfert) with a specification and one count of murder (Smith). This same jury, after hearing the evidence of mitigating factors, recommended that defendant be sentenced to death. The trial court, in its separate findings of fact and opinion, concurred and sentenced Bedford to death. After conducting an independent review, the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County affirmed the conviction and death sentence.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.
Ohio v. Bedford, 1986 Ohio App. LEXIS 8608 (Ohio Ct. App., Oct. 8, 1986)



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a decision of the Hamilton County Court of Appeals (Ohio) by which his conviction for aggravated murder and murder and sentence to death were affirmed. Defendant claimed that he was prejudiced by prosecutorial misconduct, that he was denied an impartial jury, and that the death penalty was improperly imposed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant entered the apartment of the first victim, his ex-girlfriend, where she was with the second victim, her current boyfriend. The first victim's roommate was awakened by the sound of gunshots and screams and observed defendant shoot the first victim and pursue the second victim. Defendant had learned that the victims were together in the apartment when he telephoned earlier on the day of the homicides. The trial court dismissed two jurors for cause because they indicated that they could not impose the death penalty. Defendant claimed that he was intoxicated and under stress when he shot the victims. On appeal, the court affirmed defendant's conviction and sentence, finding first that the trial court properly dismissed the jurors for cause because they could not have properly fulfilled their obligations as jurors. The court determined that the death penalty was properly imposed, reasoning that defendant's emotional stress, personal problems, and hardships in life did not mitigate the circumstances of the murders. The court noted that there was no evidence that defendant was unable to distinguish right from wrong or that the victims induced or facilitated the crimes.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for murder and aggravated murder as well as his sentence of death.

 

42 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Johnston


Nos. 86-1547, 86-1548


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 48; 529 N.E.2d 898; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 316


May 1, 1988, Submitted  
October 5, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Rehearing denied by State v. Johnston, 40 Ohio St. 3d 707, 534 N.E.2d 850, 1988 Ohio LEXIS 887 (1988)


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Hocking County, Nos. 412 and 425.

At approximately 4:00 p.m. on October 4, 1982, Margaret Annette Cooper, a.k.a. Margaret Annette Johnston, and Todd Leroy Schultz, her fiancee, left the Schultz family home in Logan, Ohio. They did not return.

On October 14, 1982, two nude and decomposing human torsos were discovered in the Hocking River near the city's edge. Two days later, the arms, legs, and heads of Annette and Todd were found buried in a cornfield adjacent to the river.

The victims had been shot several times with a .22 caliber weapon and dismembered with a sharp instrument. Expert testimony established that the victims had been killed on or about October 4. Various kinds of circumstantial evidence linked Annette's stepfather, Dale N. Johnston, to the crime.

On September 29, 1983, an indictment was issued charging Dale N. Johnston, appellee herein, with two counts of aggravated murder in violation of R.C. 2903.01. The indictment contained death penalty specifications charging that the murders were a part of a course of conduct involving the purposeful killing of two or more persons, as provided in R.C. 2929.04(A)(2).

Appellee waived [***2] his right to a jury trial, and the case was tried before a three-judge panel. After hearing the evidence, the panel found appellee guilty of all charges and specifications on January 31, 1984. Following a mitigation hearing, the panel sentenced appellee to death on March 27, 1984.

On July 6, 1984, appellee filed a motion for a new trial pursuant to Crim. R. 33(A)(6), citing newly discovered evidence. The panel considered all the exhibits, affidavits, memoranda and briefs submitted, and denied the motion for a new trial on October 25, 1984.

On August 6, 1986, the court of appeals unanimously reversed appellee's conviction and remanded the case for a new trial. In case No. 412 (Supreme Court No. 86-1547), the appellate court found that the trial court had erred in admitting the testimony of a witness who had been hypnotized and in issuing an opinion without findings and reasons for its conclusion at the sentencing phase. In case No. 425 (Supreme Court No. 86-1548), the appellate court held that evidence material to appellee's guilt or innocence had been improperly withheld by the state.

The causes are now before this court pursuant to the allowance of motions to certify the  [***3] record. The causes have been consolidated for purposes of review and disposition by this court.
State v. Johnston, 1986 Ohio App. LEXIS 8178 (Ohio Ct. App., Hocking County, Aug. 6, 1986)
State v. Johnston, 1986 Ohio App. LEXIS 8159 (Ohio Ct. App., Hocking County, Aug. 6, 1986)



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Hocking County (Ohio), which reversed appellee's conviction and death sentence for two counts of aggravated murder in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01. The court of appeals remanded for a new trial.


OVERVIEW: Appellee was convicted of two counts of aggravated murder in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01 and sentenced to death. The court of appeals reversed appellee's conviction and remanded for a new trial, ruling that the trial court had erred in admitting the testimony of a witness who had been hypnotized. The court of appeals held that evidence material to appellee's guilt or innocence had been improperly withheld by state. On appeal, the court affirmed the court of appeals' judgment remanding the case for a new trial. The court ruled that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in allowing the witness to testify about matters he recalled under hypnosis. The court concluded that there was reasonable probability that the outcome of the trial would have been different had some of the evidence been disclosed to the defense.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' ruling to remand the cause for a new trial. The court ruled that there was a reasonable probability that the outcome of the trial would have been different had some of the evidence been disclosed to the defense.

 

43 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Esparza


No. 86-1689


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 8; 529 N.E.2d 192; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 313


May 23, 1988, Submitted  
October 5, 1988, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Rehearing denied by State v. Esparza, 39 Ohio St. 3d 725, 534 N.E.2d 359, 1988 Ohio LEXIS 1649 (1988)
Writ of certiorari denied Esparza v. Ohio, 490 U.S. 1012, 109 S. Ct. 1657, 104 L. Ed. 2d 171, 1989 U.S. LEXIS 1678, 57 U.S.L.W. 3654 (1989)


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County, No. L-84-225.

At approximately 9:30 p.m. on February 12, 1983, a man entered the Island Variety Carryout in Toledo, Ohio, wearing a green ski mask and a dark blue jacket. The victim, Melanie Gerschultz, and James Barrailloux, both store employees, were the only other persons present and were standing in the back of the store as the man entered. The man approached the pair, pointed a small black handgun at them and ordered one of them to open the cash register at the front of the store. Gerschultz complied and walked towards the cash register. As she opened the register, Barrailloux crouched down and left the store through the rear door, entering the attached home of the store owner, Evelyn Krieger. While he was alerting Krieger of the robbery, they heard a gunshot. Barrailloux and Krieger re-entered the store to find Gerschultz lying on the floor with a fatal gunshot wound in her neck. The cash register was open and approximately $ 110 was missing. A small round hole was found in the sheet of clear Plexiglas located to the side of the cash register, through which the bullet had apparently passed.

On October 13, 1983, the [***2] appellant, Gregory Esparza, was indicted on the following two counts: (1) aggravated murder while in the commission of an aggravated robbery, to which a firearm specification and a specification of committing the aggravated murder while committing aggravated robbery were attached; and (2) aggravated robbery, to which a firearm specification was attached. Appellant pleaded not guilty to each count and specification.

The jury was impaneled on May 4, 1984. At trial, appellant's sister and a fellow inmate, Albert Richardson, testified that appellant had independently told each of them that he had robbed the carryout and had shot a woman. The jury returned verdicts of guilty on both counts and all specifications charged.

Appellant requested a presentence investigation and a mental examination, pursuant to R.C. 2929.03(D)(1), which were granted. However, his contemporaneous request for appointment of an independent psychologist to perform the examination, pursuant to R.C. 2929.024, was denied. The jury, following the hearing on mitigation, recommended that appellant be sentenced to death. The trial court accepted the jury's recommendation and additionally sentenced appellant to serve [***3] seven to twenty-five years' imprisonment for aggravated robbery, plus three years on the firearm specification. The court of appeals affirmed the conviction and sentence.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.
State v. Esparza, 1986 Ohio App. LEXIS 7956 (Ohio Ct. App., Aug. 22, 1986)



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with aggravated murder while in the commission of an aggravated robbery and aggravated robbery; firearm specifications were attached to both charges. The Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio) denied defendant's request for appointment of an independent psychologist, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.024. Defendant was convicted and sentenced to death. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the trial court erred in denying his request under § 2929.024 for an independent psychologist to perform his mental examination. The court held that the trial court did not err because defendant was not entitled to the psychologist of his own choosing under § 2929.024. Moreover, the trial court properly determined that such an examination was not reasonably necessary for the proper representation of defendant at the sentencing hearing. Next, the court held that defendant was not entitled to complain of the submission to the jury of a presentence investigation report because he had requested the report, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.03(D)(1). The court held that defendant was not denied his right to place all relevant evidence before the sentencing jury because the letter to his former foster family, which defendant used to illustrate ties to the community and which was written three weeks prior to trial, lacked trustworthiness. The State did not unconstitutionally exercise its preemptory challenges as jurors who had some reservations about the death penalty were not an "identifiable group" for the purposes of an Equal Protection challenge.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions and sentences for aggravated murder while in the commission of an aggravated robbery and aggravated robbery.

 

44 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Henderson


No. 87-447


Supreme Court of Ohio


39 Ohio St. 3d 24; 528 N.E.2d 1237; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 305


June 13, 1988, Submitted  
September 28, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, No. C-850557.

Our review of this case is statutorily mandated because a sentence of death was imposed upon appellant, Jerome Henderson, for his conviction of the aggravated murder of Mary Acoff.

Around 10:45 p.m., March 2, 1985, Acoff left her basement-level apartment at 1944 Highland Avenue in Cincinnati and went to the apartment of her boyfriend, James Martin, who lived in the same building. Martin and Acoff engaged in sexual intercourse. Acoff left around midnight and returned to her apartment.

Tony Nixon, who lived in the apartment above Acoff, testified that around 4:50 a.m. on March 3, 1985, he heard sounds "like a commotion" coming from below. After Nixon stepped into the hallway of the building to await his ride to work he heard a downstairs door open. However, he did not see anyone downstairs.

Cheryl Turner testified that as she drove toward the building about 6:00 a.m. to pick up Nixon, she saw appellant standing on the street a little way up from the building. She stated that appellant was wearing a dark, knee-length coat.

Delrick Johnson testified that as he approached the Highland Avenue area around 5:30 [***2] a.m., he saw appellant, whom he knew from school. Johnson honked his horn at appellant, who responded by pulling his coat up around his ears. Johnson stated that appellant was wearing a long leather coat with a shorter coat underneath.

About 4:15 p.m., March 3, 1985, ten-year-old Joann Acoff, Mary Acoff's daughter, and Sandra Simmons, a neighbor, found Acoff's body on the living room floor of the apartment. The front door was unlatched and a kitchen window was closed but unlocked.

The police found latent fingerprints, mud on the kitchen and living room floors, and bloodstains on the outside kitchen windowsill. A bloodstained rock and fallen leaf were found on the ground outside the kitchen window. The ground beneath the kitchen window was muddy.

Acoff died as a result of hemorrhage due to multiple stab, incised and blunt injuries to the head, chest, neck and upper extremities. In addition to at least four fatal stab wounds, Acoff had been cut with the point of a sharp knife numerous times and her throat had been slashed at least thirteen times. Acoff's left hand had been cut and was wrapped in a towel.

Acoff's body was found nude, lying face up with legs spread apart.  [***3] Semen was found in her vagina. The deputy coroner testified that the general pattern of bloodstains over the upper torso indicated that Acoff was killed while she was lying in a horizontal position.

The front door of the apartment building was kept locked. To gain entry without a key, one had to ring the doorbell of an apartment and have the occupant open the front door. On the day of the murder, Acoff's doorbell was not working.

Apparently nothing was stolen from the apartment: Acoff's purse was undisturbed, a gold chain was found lying in a pool of blood on the floor and the stereo and television set were in place.

Upon learning of appellant's presence in the neighborhood, police called him and he went to the police station to be interviewed. Appellant denied being in the vicinity of Acoff's apartment at the time of the murder. He was permitted to leave the police station.

Shortly thereafter, police were told that a latent fingerprint lifted from the kitchen wall of Acoff's apartment had been identified as appellant's. Police arrested appellant and informed him of the fingerprint, but appellant insisted that he had never been inside Acoff's apartment and that he did not [***4] know her.

Police searched appellant's residence pursuant to a warrant and seized a damp pair of gym shoes, a long black leather coat, a short black leather jacket, and an eight-inch paring knife discovered inside the pocket of the jacket. The soles of the shoes contained human blood but in an insufficient amount to determine its type. A bloody shoeprint from the floor of Acoff's apartment was consistent with the characteristics of the soles of the seized gym shoes. Bloodstains found on the coat were consistent with Acoff's blood type (type AB) and inconsistent with appellant's (type O). A piece of unidentifiable human tissue was discovered on the long coat. Semen stains, consistent with a type O secretor, were also found on the coat.

The rock found outside the kitchen window was stained with type AB blood and the fallen leaf with human blood, type unknown.

Appellant was charged with two counts of aggravated murder with specifications that: (1) appellant, as the principal offender, purposely caused Acoff's death while committing or attempting to commit aggravated burglary; and (2) appellant, as the principal offender, purposely caused Acoff's death while committing or attempting [***5] to commit rape. The third and fourth counts charged appellant with aggravated burglary and rape.

Appellant pled not guilty. The jury found appellant guilty of both counts of aggravated murder and the accompanying specifications. The jury also found appellant guilty of aggravated burglary and not guilty of rape but guilty of attempted rape. The jury recommended a penalty of death; the trial court followed the recommendation and imposed a death sentence. The court further sentenced appellant on counts three and four to consecutive terms of imprisonment.

The court of appeals affirmed the convictions and sentence of death.

The cause is before us upon an appeal as of right.
State v. Henderson, 1987 Ohio App. LEXIS 5519 (Ohio Ct. App., Hamilton County, Jan. 14, 1987)



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed defendant's convictions for two counts of aggravated murder, one count of aggravated burglary, and one count of attempted rape.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant contended that aggravated burglary and aggravated murder were allied offenses of similar import pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2941.25, and thus, that the aggravated burglary could not be the basis for elevating the aggravated murder to the narrow class of murders subject to the death penalty. The court affirmed defendant's convictions and held that the capital sentencing scheme did not violate the Ohio or U.S. Constitutions because the sentencing scheme constitutionally narrowed the class of persons eligible for the death penalty. The death penalty was imposed for felony murder only when defendant was the principal offender or when the murder was premeditated. The aggravated murder and aggravated burglary were not merely incidental to each other, thus the aggravated burglary could be the basis for elevating the aggravated murder to felony murder.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's convictions.

 

45 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Davis


No. 86-1171


Supreme Court of Ohio


38 Ohio St. 3d 361; 528 N.E.2d 925; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 299



September 14, 1988, Decided; As amended


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Butler County, No. CA84-06-071.

At approximately 7:40 p.m. on December 12, 1983, officers of the Hamilton Police Department arrived at the scene of a shooting at American Legion Post 520 (hereinafter "the Legion") in Hamilton, Ohio. Lying on the pavement approximately six feet outside the front door of the Legion was the deceased victim, Suzette Butler. An autopsy performed the following day by the county coroner revealed that Butler had died as a result of multiple gunshot wounds to the left side of her head. One of the entrance wounds suggested that the muzzle of the murder weapon was within four to twenty inches of the victim's head at the time the weapon was fired.

On the day of the shooting, Butler met her friend, Mona Aldridge, at the Legion sometime between 5:00 p.m. and 6:30 p.m. Appellant, Von Clark "Red" Davis, arrived shortly thereafter, and eventually sat at a table with Butler and Aldridge. Apparently, appellant and Butler had cohabited for several months, but had recently separated. After a brief period of time, appellant and Butler arose from the table and walked out the front door. Prior to leaving, Butler told Aldridge [***2] that she would be "right back" and asked Aldridge to watch her jacket, cigarettes and drink. Several minutes later, a concerned Aldridge went to the front door of the Legion to look for Butler. Aldridge opened the door slightly and discovered appellant pointing a gun at Butler's head. Aldridge panicked and went back inside the bar. Momentarily, others followed her into the bar saying that someone had been shot.

The shooting was witnessed by Reginald Denmark and Cozette Massey. the couple had been on a walk observing Christmas lights. As they were walking, they saw a man and a woman talking in front of the Legion. The man and woman did not appear to be arguing. Two shots rang out. As the woman (later identified as Butler) fell, another shot was fired. Finally, "* * * after she was down, he bent down and shot her in the head * * *." Both Massey and Denmark ultimately identified appellant as the person who shot Butler.

It was later established that on the day of Butler's murder, appellant had sought out Mark "Poppa" Lovette to "do him a favor" in exchange for sixty dollars. Along with a third party, Wade Coleman, a.k.a. Hank Stokes, appellant drove Lovette to a pawn shop [***3] and gave him money to purchase a handgun. Lovette purchased a Raven P.25 semi-automatic handgun and gave it to appellant. Appellant again gave money to Lovette and had him purchase shells for the gun at a K Mart store. Lovette was then dropped off. Appellant subsequently discovered that the K Mart shells did not fit the weapon. Lovette was picked up again, the shells were returned to K Mart, and appellant drove Lovette to a local gun shop. Lovette purchased a box of PMC .25 automatic shells and gave them to appellant. Appellant then loaded the gun in the presence of Lovette and Coleman and placed the gun under the driver's seat of his car. 1 Late that afternoon, Lovette and Coleman were dropped off separately.


1 Four "spent" PMC manufactured shells were found at the murder scene. The murder weapon was never recovered. However, a criminalist testified at trial that the bullets removed from Butler's head had been fired from a handgun manufactured by Raven or Astra arms companies.

Following the murder, appellant was arrested and an indictment was filed against him on January 6, 1984. Count one of the indictment charged appellant with the aggravated murder of Butler  [***4] in violation of R.C. 2903.01 (A), 2 with the specification of having a firearm while committing the offense. See R.C. 2929.71. Count one also contained a specification of the aggravating circumstance that prior to this offense appellant had been convicted of an offense an essential element of which was the purposeful killing of, or attempt to kill, another. See R.C. 2929.04(A)(5). 3 In count two, it was alleged that appellant did knowingly acquire, have, carry or use a firearm having previously been convicted of felonies of violence, i.e., shooting with intent to wound on April 10, 1970, and murder in the second degree on April 20, 1971, in violation of R.C. 2923.13(A)(2). 4 


2 R.C. 2903.01(A) provides:

"(A) No person shall purposely, and with prior calculation and design, cause the death of another."


3 R.C. 2929.04(A) provides in part:

"Imposition of the death penalty for aggravated murder is precluded, unless one or more of the following is specified in the indictment or count in the indictment pursuant to section 2941.14 of the Revised Code and proved beyond a reasonable doubt:

"* * *

"(5) Prior to the offense at bar, the offender was convicted of an offense an essential element of which was the purposeful killing of or attempt to kill another, or the offense at bar was part of a course of conduct involving the purposeful killing of or attempt to kill two or more persons by the offender."


4 R.C. 2923.13(A) provides in part:

"Unless relieved from disability as provided in section 2923.14 of the Revised Code, no person shall knowingly acquire, have, carry, or use any firearm or dangerous ordinance, if any of the following apply:

"* * *

"(2) Such person is under indictment for or has been convicted of any felony of violence, or has been adjudged a juvenile delinquent for commission of any such felony[.]"

 [***5] Appellant waived his right to a jury trial. The trial began on May 9, 1984, before a three-judge panel. 5 Appellant was convicted by the panel on both counts of the indictment and of both specifications to count one. Following the penalty phase of the trial, appellant was sentenced to death. The court of appeals affirmed both the conviction and the sentence.


5 Appellant testified on his own behalf and claimed that he had given the gun to a person from Lexington, Kentucky, by the name of Silky Carr, in exchange for some dental equipment. Appellant also testified that he left "Carr" and Butler talking in front of the Legion on the night of the murder. A "Silky Carr" has never been located.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Butler County (Ohio), which affirmed defendant's conviction for aggravated murder under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01(A) with specifications and for knowingly acquiring, having, carrying, or using a firearm having previously been convicted of felonies of violence in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.13(A)(2). The lower court also affirmed defendant's death sentence.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the trial court erred in refusing to sever the two charges contained in the indictment and that the trial court erred in imposing his death sentence. In affirming defendant's conviction, the court held that the evidence of clearly revealed that the crimes charged in the indictment arose from the same act or transaction. Thus, the trial court's refusal to sever the charges was proper. Moreover, the evidence of guilt is so overwhelming that it may be concluded beyond a reasonable doubt that any introduction of defendant's prior convictions did not contribute to the finding of guilt. However, the court reversed defendant's death sentence after concluding that the trial court improperly weighed non-statutory aggravating circumstances outside of those listed in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(A) against the mitigating factors in sentencing. The aggravating circumstances that could have been considered in imposing the death penalty were limited to those specifically enumerated in § 2929.04(A). Thus, defendant was entitled to resentencing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court with regard to defendant's conviction, but reversed the judgment of the lower court as to defendant's death sentence and remanded the cause for resentencing.

 

46 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. DePew


No. 87-1334


Supreme Court of Ohio


38 Ohio St. 3d 275; 528 N.E.2d 542; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 293



August 31, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Butler County, No. CA85-07-075.

Late in the evening of November 23, 1984, Tony Jones returned from work to find his home in flames. In the course of battling the blaze, firefighters discovered three bodies inside the house. They were subsequently identified as those of Tony Jones' wife, Theresa, age twenty-seven, their daughter, Aubrey, seven, and Theresa's sister, Elizabeth Burton, twelve. Autopsies revealed that Theresa had died from at least fourteen stab wounds, that Aubrey had perished as the result of twenty-one stab wounds, and that Elizabeth had died from a combination of five stab wounds, burns and carbon monoxide poisoning.

On April 3, 1985, Detective Sergeant Rick Sizemore questioned Deborah Sowers about the homicides. During the course of the interview, Sowers implicated defendant-appellant, Rhett DePew. Based on this information, Sizemore and Detective Joe Rooks located appellant and arrested him on an outstanding, unrelated warrant. Appellant was taken to the prosecuting attorney's office in Hamilton, where he was questioned for several hours about the murders. Appellant eventually confessed to the crimes, giving the following [***2] account.

On the evening of the murders, appellant and his girlfriend, Deborah Sowers, drove to the Joneses' residence to "get some money." Appellant was armed with a large knife. Once he believed the house to be empty, he approached it alone, entered through a back door, and began searching the house. As he approached a bedroom, he was confronted by the victims, who began screaming. He "freaked out" and "just started swinging" with his knife, stabbing the three repeatedly. He then set fire to some clothing in Theresa's closet. Before leaving, he discovered a baby crying in a back bedroom. He wrapped the child in a blanket and left her on the porch of the house next door. Sowers then picked appellant up and they went home.

Appellant was indicted on three counts of aggravated murder in violation of R.C. 2903.01(B). Each murder count contained the following death penalty specifications: the offense was committed while the offender was committing aggravated burglary ( R.C. 2929.04[A][7]), the offense was committed while the offender was committing aggravated arson ( R.C. 2929.04[A][7]), and the offense was part of a course of conduct involving the purposeful killing of two or [***3] more persons ( R.C. 2929.04[A][5]). Appellant pleaded not guilty to all counts.

Before trial, appellant moved to suppress his confession. He also filed a motion in limine to prevent Sowers from testifying against him on the basis that she was his common-law wife. These motions, after a hearing, were denied.

Jury trial commenced on June 17, 1985. Appellant offered no evidence. The jury returned a verdict of guilty on all counts and on the accompanying specifications.

During the penalty phase, appellant presented twenty witnesses and his own unsworn statement.
