The union had earlier appealed the trial court's judgment of February 12, whereby the court extended the original temporary  [***5] restraining order by fourteen days.

The court of appeals consolidated the two cases and issued a decision on March 18, 1987. The appellate court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that R.C. 4117.16(A) is unconstitutional as a violation of the doctrine of separation of powers. Specifically, the court of appeals held that the statute improperly grants SERB the power to terminate the jurisdiction of the trial court by finding no clear and present danger to the public health or safety; and that the statute impermissibly reduces the trial court to an agent of SERB by forcing the court to accept SERB's finding and act, or refrain from acting, solely in accordance with that finding. The appellate court found that the offending portion of the statute was severable, and held that the trial court's resumption of jurisdiction under the remaining language of R.C. 4117.16(A) was consistent with the intentions of the legislature. However, the appellate court reversed the lower court's finding that the strike posed a clear and present danger to the public health and safety, on the basis that there was no evidence properly before the court from which that determination could have been made.  [***6] No hearing had been held on this issue, nor was there any stipulation by the parties that the transcript of the hearing before SERB could be reviewed by the trial court. The cause was remanded to the lower court for an evidentiary hearing or other appropriate action to afford the parties the opportunity to offer testimony.

Both SERB and the union appealed the judgment of the court of appeals, which judgment found R.C. 4117.16(A) unconstitutional, to this court. (Case No. 87-655.)

While that appeal was pending, the trial court, upon remand, again found that the strike posed a clear and present danger to the public health and safety. 1 That finding was based on the evidence adduced at the prior probable cause hearing held by the trial court and at the hearing before SERB, the parties having stipulated to the admission of such evidence into the record. 2 Based upon this finding, the court held that the temporary restraining order previously issued should be continued for sixty days "as provided in Section 4117.16(A)." Upon appeal by the union, the court of appeals affirmed this judgment. An appeal of the court of appeals' judgment was taken to this


1 The record does not disclose why the trial court deemed itself authorized to resume jurisdiction while an appeal of the case was pending in this court.


2 The stipulation does not appear in the record filed in this court, but the parties to this appeal agree that such a stipulation was made.



DISPOSITION: Judgments reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff transit authority filed a petition in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County (Ohio) seeking to enjoin a transit workers' strike. The trial court granted the injunction and upon appeal by defendant union, Court of Appeals reversed. The transit authority sought review.


OVERVIEW: The union asserted that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.16(A) violated the doctrine of separation of powers. The court held that (1) the legislature, not the State Employment Relations Board (SERB), controlled the court's jurisdiction, (2) the legislature had authority to condition the court's jurisdiction on a finding of an administrative agency, (3) by proceeding to entertain the transit authority's motion for injunctive relief after SERB issued a finding that the strike did not pose a clear and present danger to the public health or safety, the trial court attempted to exert jurisdiction that had been withheld by the legislature, (4) under express terms of the statute, the court had jurisdiction to issue orders to enjoin the strike, (5) the only limitation on the court's exercise of injunctive powers is that no injunction could be issued for longer than 60 days.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court decision which had found that the trial court did not have jurisdiction to grant an injunction to the transit authority.

 

61 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Ohio Ass'n of Pub. Sch. Employees v. Twinsburg


No. 87-165


Supreme Court of Ohio


36 Ohio St. 3d 180; 522 N.E.2d 532; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 107



April 27, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

On March 1, 1983, the Twinsburg City Council (hereinafter "council") enacted Ordinance No. 13-1983, which limits the constituency to be served by the city's civil service commission by excluding the Twinsburg City School District, a multi-city district, and its employees from the services provided by the commission. The council passed the ordinance because "the Twinsburg City School District * * * has refused to appropriate and pay its share of the cost of the Civil Service Commission of the City of Twinsburg * * * as permitted in Section 124.54 1 of the Ohio Revised Code." Plaintiffs-appellees, Ohio Association of Public School Employees, Chapter No. 471 ("OAPSE") and two of its members, then filed a complaint, later amended, in the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County, seeking both injunctive and declaratory relief to prevent the city from enforcing, and proceeding in accord with the provisions of, the ordinance.


1 R.C. 124.54 provides:

"Where [a] municipal civil service commission serves a city school district whose territory is located in more than one city, the board of education of such district shall, by resolution, appropriate each year, to be paid into the treasury of the municipal civil service commission's city, an amount sufficient to meet the portion of the board of education's cost of civil service administration. The amount shall be mutually agreed to by the school board and the commission or if agreement cannot be reached, it shall be determined by the ratio of the number of employees of such board in the classified service to the entire number of employees in the classified service in all political divisions served by the commission.

"Where a municipal civil service commission serves a city school district whose territory is not located in more than one city, the board of education of such district may appropriate such an amount to be paid to the city's treasury."

 [***2] The trial court found for the appellees, ruling that the ordinance was in direct conflict with the general laws of the state. Therefore, the court concluded that the ordinance "must yield to the overriding law of statewide concern." Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio). The lower court affirmed that a local ordinance excluding the city school district from the constituency to be served by the city's civil service commission was in direct conflict with and must yield to state law. The lower court also affirmed an injunction sought by appellee school employees union to prevent enforcement of the ordinance by the city.


OVERVIEW: A city enacted a local ordinance to limit the constituency to be served by the city's civil service commission by excluding the city school district and its employees. The council passed the ordinance because the school district refused to appropriate and pay its share of the cost of the civil service commission. The public school employees union sought and was granted an injunction to prevent the city from enforcing the ordinance. The city sought review, and the lower court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that the ordinance must yield to the overriding state law, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.011(A). The city sought further review. On review, the court concluded that under Ohio Const. art. XVIII, §§ 3 and 7, municipal ordinances enacted under the power of local self-government prevailed over state statutes, except for ordinances enacted pursuant to a city's police powers. The ordinance in issue concerned the jurisdiction of the city's civil service commission and was not adopted pursuant to the city's police powers. Therefore, the ordinance superseded the state statute. The lower court erred in concluding that the issue was one of statewide concern.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower court.

 

62 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. 1981 Dodge Ram Van


No. 86-1151


Supreme Court of Ohio


36 Ohio St. 3d 168; 522 N.E.2d 524; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 100



April 27, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Butler County.

This case involves an appeal of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Butler County, which reversed a decision of the court of common pleas on the ground that former R.C. 4549.07 was vague and unconstitutional as applied to Charles R. Pierson, appellee.

On November 7, 1983, Detective Rick Sizemore of the Butler County Sheriff's Department had occasion to be at the Pierson residence. With Pierson's permission, Sizemore inspected a 1981 Dodge Ram Van which was parked in Pierson's driveway. Sizemore observed that the Vehicle Identification Number ("VIN") plate located on the van's dashboard was bent and appeared to have been tampered with. Sizemore advised Pierson that he was leaving the premises to seek a warrant to search the van and asked Pierson not to move the vehicle. As Sizemore left the Pierson residence, he observed Pierson enter the van, drive through an adjoining field and fence at the rear of his property and park the van at a neighbor's house.

The vehicle was then impounded by police and a search warrant obtained. An inspection of the van showed that the confidential VIN, located on the frame of the [***2] vehicle underneath the passenger side, contained a partial VIN that did not correspond with the VIN plate attached to the dashboard. In addition, the federal inspection sticker and the manufacturer's sticker, both of which would have shown the vehicle's VIN, had been removed from the van.

Using the VIN shown on the dashboard plate, Sizemore, after a title search, located a wrecked van in a junk yard in Spiceland, Indiana. The wrecked van's VIN plate had been removed, but the confidential VIN found on that vehicle corresponded to the VIN plate attached to the van seized from Pierson.

The state of Ohio, pursuant to R.C. 2933.41, filed an application in the Court of Common Pleas of Butler County for an order of forfeiture and disposition of the van seized from Pierson. On May 9, 1985, the trial court issued its decision which concluded that Pierson could not lawfully possess the van in question because the VIN had been removed, defaced or otherwise obliterated for the purpose of concealing and destroying the vehicle's true identity, a violation of R.C. 4549.07. The trial court ordered the van forfeited to the Butler County Police Department to be used solely for the performance [***3] of departmental duties. Pierson filed a timely notice of appeal.

On May 19, 1986, the court of appeals issued its decision, which, sua sponte, held that R.C. 4549.07 was vague and unconstitutional as applied to Pierson. The court of appeals reversed the trial court's decision and ordered the state to return the van to Pierson.

The court of appeals, finding its decision as to the constitutionality of R.C. 4549.07 to be in conflict with the decisions by the Court of Appeals for Scioto County in In re Disposition of a 1976/1977 Brown Ford F150 Pick-up Truck (July 7, 1983), No. 1403, unreported, and the Court of Appeals for Summit County in Son's Harley Davidson Sales & Service, Inc. v. Akron et al. (July 29, 1981), No. 10146, unreported, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State sought an order of forfeiture of a van seized from appellee owner. The trial court ordered the van forfeited because the vehicle identification number had been removed for the purpose of concealing the vehicle's true identity, a violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4549.07. The Court of Appeals for Butler County (Ohio) reversed on the ground that § 4549.07 was vague and unconstitutional as applied to the owner. The State appealed.


OVERVIEW: The court held that the lower court abused its discretion by sua sponte considering the constitutionality of § 4549.07. The court noted that although the lower court could have considered the constitutionality issue sua sponte, it should have given the parties notice of its intention and an opportunity to brief the issue. The lower court also abused its discretion by refusing to consider the issues raised by the owner's appeal. Under Ohio R. App. P. 12(A), all errors assigned and briefed in the court of appeals had to be passed upon by the appellate court, stating the reasons for its decision.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment and remanded to the lower court for compliance with the requirements of Rule 12(A).

 

63 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Taylor v. Acad. Iron & Metal Co.


No. 87-127


Supreme Court of Ohio


36 Ohio St. 3d 149; 522 N.E.2d 464; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 93



April 13, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Luke Scargill and Bobby Lee Taylor were employees of Apex International Alloys, Inc., a metal manufacturing concern that is now known as Alumax, Inc., the appellee herein. On August 25, 1981, as aluminum scrap was being fed into a crusher machine at Alumax, an explosion occurred which resulted in Taylor's death and serious injury to Scargill. A personal injury and wrongful death suit was filed in the Cuyahoga County Court of Common Pleas by plaintiffs Scargill and Henry Taylor, administrator of the estate of his son, Bobby Taylor, against appellant, Academy Iron & Metal Company, a Cleveland scrap dealer. The suit alleged that Academy Iron sold dangerous and defective aluminum scrap to Scargill's and Taylor's employer and sought damages from the scrap dealer on theories of products liability. Academy Iron denied the allegations.

Academy Iron filed an amended answer and brought a third-party complaint against Alumax, alleging that Bobby Taylor's death and Scargill's injuries were the result of "intentional" tortious acts by Alumax. The third-party complaint sought indemnification from Alumax to Academy [***2] Iron. Academy Iron then moved for leave to amend its third-party complaint to allege a claim for contribution. The trial court dismissed the third-party complaint, apparently, in part, on the grounds that Academy Iron had no standing to bring a third-party action against Alumax under Ohio workers' compensation law, implicitly disposing of the claim for contribution.

Thereafter, Academy Iron settled the claims of Taylor and Scargill, but it appealed the dismissal of the third-party complaint. The court of appeals affirmed the dismissal, holding that the third-party complaint was precluded by R.C. 4121.80.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.
Taylor v. Academy Iron & Metal Co., 1986 Ohio App. LEXIS 9144 (Ohio Ct. App., Cuyahoga County, Nov. 20, 1986)



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant scrap metal dealer challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's dismissal of its third-party complaint for indemnification against appellee employer.


OVERVIEW: The scrap metal dealer was named as a defendant in a personal injury and wrongful death action arising out of injuries to two employees of the employer. The scrap metal dealer filed a complaint for indemnification against the employer. The trial court dismissed the complaint and denied the scrap metal dealer's motion for leave to amend the complaint to include a cause of action for contribution. The intermediate appellate court affirmed the trial court's judgment. The court affirmed the lower courts' judgments. It held that the scrap metal dealer did not have standing to bring an indemnification claim against the employer, who was acting in compliance with the Ohio workers' compensation law, for damages suffered by the employees in the course of or arising out of their employment. The court further held that relief from common-law liability under the Ohio Workers' Compensation Act extended to cases in which a third-party tortfeasor, having paid damages to an employee or his estate, sought indemnity from the employer on the ground that the liability of the employer was primary or active and the liability of the third-party tortfeasor was secondary or passive.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the lower courts' judgments, which dismissed the scrap metal dealer's complaint for indemnification against the employer and denied its motion for leave to amend the complaint to add a cause of action for contribution.

 

64 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Van Fossen v. Babcock & Wilcox Co.


No. 87-624


Supreme Court of Ohio


36 Ohio St. 3d 100; 522 N.E.2d 489; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 91



April 13, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

On February 21, 1983, appellee Robert Van Fossen, an employee of appellant, Babcock & Wilcox, a McDermott Company, was working on a gear-driven positioner manufactured by Aronson Machine Company. A set of steps had been welded to the rear of the machine, leading up to a platform on which Van Fossen was working. After working approximately one hour, Van Fossen, while backing down these steps, slipped and fell backwards. He incurred serious injuries. Based upon his injuries, Van Fossen applied for and apparently received workers' compensation benefits.

The subject steps had been welded onto the platform in 1968 by David K. Bailey, a fellow employee of Van Fossen. Bailey designed the steps and he installed them both for his own convenience and the convenience of others, at a time when he was assigned to use the machine. He stated that he had never had any problem in the use of the steps, and that there had never been any expressions of concern about the steps from federal safety inspectors.

On February 20, 1985, Van Fossen and his wife brought a tort action and an action for loss of consortium against Babcock [***2] & Wilcox. On February 25, 1986, Babcock & Wilcox filed a motion for summary judgment. In response, the Van Fossens averred, in effect, that the employer knew of the installation of the steps, knew that the steps were dangerous in that other employees had fallen from such steps, and yet continued to allow the use of the steps by its employees. This, concluded the Van Fossens, constituted an intentional tort as enunciated by this court in Blankenship v.. Cincinnati Milacron Chemicals, Inc. (1982), 69 Ohio St. 2d 608, 23 O.O. 3d 504, 433 N.E. 2d 572, and as further defined in Jones v.. VIP Development Co. (1984), 15 Ohio St. 3d 90, 15 OBR 246, 472 N.E. 2d 1046, at paragraph one of the syllabus, to be "an act committed with the intent to injure another, or committed with the belief that such injury is substantially certain to occur."

After considering the motion for summary judgment, the trial court granted the motion in favor of Babcock & Wilcox. In the court's view, reasonable minds could not conclude that the employer knew to a substantial certainty that an accident would occur from the use of the steps.

The Van Fossens filed a notice of appeal with the trial [***3] court on July 1, 1986. Thereafter, Babcock & Wilcox filed a cross-assignment of error in defense of its summary judgment. Therein, Babcock & Wilcox suggested as an alternative argument that even if issues of fact were presented which were relevant in light of prior case law, the judgment of the trial court should yet be affirmed on the basis of R.C. 4121.80, which became effective on August 22, 1986, i.e., while the appeal was pending.

On February 11, 1987, the court of appeals reversed the grant of summary judgment, finding that there was a justiciable issue of "substantial certainty of proximate harm," and remanded the cause to the trial court for further proceedings. The court also concluded that R.C. 4121.80 was inapplicable "to cases pending on appeal."

The court of appeals, finding its decision to be in conflict with the decision rendered by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County in Taylor v.. Academy Iron & Metal Co. (Dec. 1, 1986), No. 51305, unreported, appeal pending in No. 87-127, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's grant of summary judgment, finding that there was a justiciable issue of substantial certainty of proximate harm to appellee employee, and which remanded the employee's intentional tort action to the trial court for further proceedings.


OVERVIEW: The employee slipped and fell when backing off steps that were welded to a machine that he was operating. The employee contended that the employer knew to a substantial certainty that an accident would occur from the use of the steps. The employer argued that a recent amendment to the Workers' Compensation Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4121.80(H), which placed more stringent conditions upon all employer-employee intentional tort actions, applied retrospectively to the action, which was pending in the court of appeals on the effective date of the amendment. The court agreed that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4121.80(H) applied because a final judgment by the court of appeals was not entered when the statute became effective. Further, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4121.80(H) contained a clear legislative intent of retrospective application. However, because the statute imposed a more difficult statutory restriction upon the employee's ability to bring the instant action, its retrospective application was banned by the Ohio Const. art. II, § 28. The court also held that the employer's mere knowledge of a risk was not intent and did not support the intentional tort action.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the court of appeals and reinstated the summary judgment in favor of the employer. There was no evidence that the employer knew with a substantial certainty that the steps would cause injuries to the employee.

 

65 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Cleveland Gear Co. v. Limbach


No. 86-1553


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 3d 229; 520 N.E.2d 188; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 58



March 9, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

On September 1, 1980, Dyna Cure Precoated Steel, Inc. ("Dyna Cure"), a wholly owned subsidiary of Vesper Corporation, purchased the Cleveland Gear Division of Eaton Corporation. Prior to that date Dyna Cure was not qualified to do business in Ohio and did not engage in business in Ohio. This transaction involved the purchase of the assets of an entire manufacturing plant from Eaton which was located in Cuyahoga County, Ohio. Dyna Cure purchased all the inventories of finished goods, partially finished goods, and raw materials.

For its 1981 personal property tax return, Dyna Cure reported the average monthly value of its manufacturing inventory on hand as of the last day of each of the four calendar months of September through December 1980, and divided that sum by twelve. The appellee Tax Commissioner audited this return and recomputed the average monthly value by dividing the sum by four, the number of months that Dyna Cure conducted business in Ohio as a manufacturer in 1980.

For its 1981 return, Eaton reported the average monthly value of inventory for the tax year by totalling month-end inventories for the eight months it held inventory [***2] at this plant, and divided that sum by twelve, the number of months that Eaton conducted business in Ohio as a manufacturer during 1980. Eaton apparently continued in business in Ohio at another location in 1980 after its sale of the Cleveland Gear Division to Dyna Cure.

The average monthly value of the inventory of Dyna Cure increased from $ 2,752,371, as reported in the return, to $ 8,257,114 after audit by appellee. The tax increased from $ 67,722 to $ 203,166.

Dyna Cure changed its name to Cleveland Gear Company, hereinafter "appellant," on or about February 1, 1982.

The Board of Tax appeals ("BTA") held that the statutes and prior case law directed that the inventory be valued in the manner in which appellee had determined it. The BTA further declined to comment upon the constitutional implications in the application of the challenged statute ( R.C. 5711.16) because appellant had not challenged the statute at the first available opportunity, i.e., during the proceedings before appellee, citing Bd. of Edn. of South-Western City Schools v.. Kinney (1986), 24 Ohio St. 3d 184, 24 OBR 414, 494 N.E. 2d 1109. The BTA thus affirmed the assessment.

The cause is now  [***3] before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed an assessment by appellee Tax Commissioner. The Commissioner audited the taxpayer's return and recomputed the average monthly value of its manufacturing inventory, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5711.16, which increased the value of the inventory and the tax due.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer, which had not done business in Ohio previously, bought the inventory of an Ohio manufacturer in September. For its Ohio personal property tax return, the taxpayer reported the average monthly value of its manufacturing inventory on hand as of the last day of each of the four calendar months of September through December, and divided that sum by 12. The Commissioner audited the return and recomputed the average monthly value by dividing the sum by four, the number of months that the taxpayer had conducted business in Ohio as a manufacturer. The taxpayer argued that the valuation method of § 5711.16 denied it equal protection of the laws because the corporation that it bought the inventory from was permitted to divide the total monthly inventories, which it held for eight months, by the 12 months that it was in business. The court affirmed. The court held that the taxpayer was paying the tax upon a correct valuation of its inventory; the selling corporation was paying a tax based upon inventory it no longer held. The taxpayer had not been denied equal protection of the law because it had not been unlawfully discriminated against.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision.

 

66 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Collett v. Cogar


No. 87-711


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 3d 114; 518 N.E.2d 1202; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 30



February 10, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Athens County.

On September 23, 1974, appellee Vickie Collett gave birth out of wedlock to a daughter, appellee Brandie Rochelle Collett (nee Bartlett). 1 No father was listed on Brandie's original birth certificate.


1 Vickie's surname was Bartlett at the time of Brandie's birth.

On September 26, 1977, Vickie married Charles Collett. When Brandie began school, Vickie and Charles decided to have Brandie's surname changed from Bartlett to Collett. They accomplished this by filing a duly notarized declaration of paternity with the Ohio Department of Health in July 1979. In the declaration, Charles acknowledged that he was the natural father of Brandie. Brandie was subsequently issued a new birth certificate indicating her surname to be Collett and listing Charles as her father. Vickie and Charles subsequently dissolved their marriage.

On October 30, 1984, Vickie filed an action under R.C. Chapter 3111 in the Athens County Court of Common Pleas, Juvenile Division, to determine the paternity of Brandie. Vickie filed the action both on her own behalf and as next friend of her minor daughter, Brandie. The complaint alleges that appellant,  [***2] Darrell Cogar, is the father of Brandie, and asks that the court issue a judgment (1) establishing that Darrell is Brandie's father, (2) ordering him to pay $ 200 a month in child support and all her medical, dental and optical expenses until she reaches age eighteen, (3) ordering him to maintain a $ 10,000 life insurance contract for her benefit, and (4) granting Vickie $ 15,000 to recompense her for her pregnancy, confinement, and the support and necessaries she has furnished to Brandie.

In addition to an answer and a counterclaim, Darrell filed a third-party complaint on December 3, 1984, in which he claims he has reason to believe that either Randy Jackson or Charles Collett is the father of Brandie. While being deposed, Vickie stated that Brandie was conceived between December 1973 and January 1974, at which time she had engaged in sexual intercourse with Darrell and Randy, but not with Charles.

Randy and Darrell filed motions for summary judgment, which the trial court granted in a decision journalized on December 13, 1985. The court of appeals reversed and remanded the cause for proceedings under R.C. Chapter 3111. 

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance [***3] of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant alleged father sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Athens County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's grant of summary judgment to him in an action by appellees, a mother and her daughter, seeking a declaration of paternity and other relief. The court of appeals remanded the matter for proceedings under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. ch. 3111.


OVERVIEW: The mother gave birth to an out-of-wedlock child. No father was listed on the daughter's original birth certificate. The mother married third party defendant former husband, who filed a notarized declaration of paternity with the state health department. A new birth certificate was issued listing him as the child's father. The marriage was dissolved, and appellees filed an action against the alleged father under ch. 311 to determine paternity. Appellees also sought child support and reimbursement for support the mother had furnished to the daughter. The alleged father filed a third party complaint against the former husband and another individual. He was granted summary judgment, which was reversed on appeal. In affirming on appeal, the court held that the declaration of paternity signed by the former husband was not a final judgment. Thus, the doctrine of res judicata did not operate to bar the action under ch. 3111. Because no judgment was ever rendered on the issue of paternity, no retroactivity problem existed with respect to appellees' action under ch. 3111. The court of appeals correctly reversed the trial court's judgment and remanded for a determination of paternity.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' judgment, which reversed the grant of summary judgment to the alleged father in an action by the mother and her daughter for a declaration of paternity and other relief and remanded the matter for a determination on the merits.

 

67 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Avon Lake City School Dist. v. Limbach


Nos. 86-1117, 86-2038


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 3d 118; 518 N.E.2d 1190; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 31



February 10, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]  

APPEALS from the Board of Tax Appeals.

These cases, consolidated sua sponte, involve appeals by appellants, Avon Lake City School District and Fort Frye Local School District, of public utility tax assessments made by appellee Tax Commissioner against appellee Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company and appellee Ohio Power Company, respectively.

Appellants listed several errors in their notices of appeal to the Board of Tax Appeals ("BTA"). The two chief contentions were that the commissioner had undervalued the personal property of the utility companies and that the resulting apportionment of the taxable value thereof to appellants was incorrect. Second, appellants asserted that the commissioner's rule, Ohio Adm. Code 5703-25-01, 1 was invalid as it was improperly promulgated and is injurious to appellants. Also named as appellees were all the eighty-eight county auditors, none of whom has filed any documents in response to the appeals to the BTA or to this court.


1 Repealed effective October 20, 1986.

In each case, the BTA bifurcated the appeal: one part dealing with the valuation of the subject property and one part dealing with the validity of the commissioner's [***2] rule. As to the former, the BTA dismissed the appeals brought pursuant to R.C. 5717.02, ruling that appellants did not have standing to file an appeal, and, as to the latter, the BTA retained jurisdiction of the appeals to await hearing for a review of the validity of the rule. The BTA dismissed the utility companies as parties to the appeals brought pursuant to R.C. 5703.14. Appellants appeal that portion of the orders which dismisses the appeals concerning the valuation of the utility companies, naming the commissioner, the utility companies, and the eighty-eight county auditors as appellees.

The cause is now before this court upon appeals as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decisions affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant school districts sought review of public utility assessments made by appellee Tax Commissioner against appellee power companies. The Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) dismissed the appeals brought pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5717.02 ruling that the school districts did not have standing to file an appeal. The school districts appealed the dismissal.


OVERVIEW: The school districts contended that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5717.02 conferred jurisdiction upon the board to hear their appeal from the valuation of personal property, and apportionment of the taxable value thereof, of a utility company. The school districts also argued that the dismissals by the board deprived them of their right to due process of law under the Ohio and federal Constitutions. The court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5727.23 did not require that the school districts received notice of the apportioned values and assessments. Thus, because they were not required to be notified by law of the final determination of the commissioner, they were not within that class of persons authorized to appeal her determinations. The court held that the term "any person interested therein" as used in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5727.10 meant a person interested in the public utility and not a person interested in the assessment. Finally, the court held that a school district was a political subdivision created by the General Assembly, and it could not assert any constitutional protections regarding due course of law or due process of law against the State, its creator.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decisions.

 

68 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Jurcisin v. Cuyahoga County Bd. of Elections


No. 86-1727


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 3d 137; 519 N.E.2d 347; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 26



February 10, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

In response to an increasing number of citizen complaints involving allegations of police misconduct, the Cleveland City Council passed an emergency ordinance, Ordinance No. 1397-84, on September 5, 1984, to place a proposed city charter amendment on the ballot at the November 6, 1984 election. The preamble to the ordinance stated that the ordinance was "an emergency measure providing for the immediate preservation of the public peace, property, health, and safety in that it must be certified to the election authorities immediately in order for the question to appear at a special election to be held on November 6, 1984 * * *." Section 5 of the ordinance declared that it was to be effective immediately upon passage.

The purpose of the charter amendment was to establish a police review board and to create the Office of Professional Standards within the office of the Director of Public Safety. The new office would have an administrator who would assist the police review board. The review board would "receive, cause investigation of, and recommend resolution of complaints" filed with it alleging police misconduct. The board [***2] would also be authorized to adopt rules and procedures for the processing of complaints. These rules and regulations, however, would be subject to the approval of the Director of Public Safety.

Under the charter amendment, the administrator of the Office of Professional Standards would be authorized to cause investigation of complaints filed with the board and to report the results of these investigations to the board. The police review board would then decide that the complaint warranted no further action, or that the complaint should be resolved by the Director of Public Safety. The board could alternatively decide that disciplinary action is warranted and make such a recommendation to the chief of police. With one exception described below, if the chief decided to initiate charges against a police officer (suspend the officer) and if the review board concurred, the existing disciplinary procedure would apply and the matter would go before the Director of Public Safety for hearing and "judgment." If the police review board did not agree with the chief's decision, then the board itself could initiate disciplinary action against the police officer. However, all charges initiated [***3] by the board would be certified to the Director of Public Safety, who is required to hold a hearing and render judgment. As is presently the case, the Director of Public Safety could decide that no discipline is warranted, or he could suspend, reduce in rank, or dismiss the officer.

The charter amendment would modify existing provisions of the charter to provide that all decisions by the chiefs of police and fire to suspend a police officer or firefighter for ten days or less would be final and, therefore, not reviewable by the Director of Public Safety. The Director of Public Safety could employ hearing officers to conduct disciplinary hearings on his behalf, but all authority to make disciplinary decisions would be retained by the director.

Finally, the charter amendment would clearly state that the city civil service commission would entertain appeals by suspended employees in the city's classified civil service only if the suspensions are for more than ten days. Suspensions of ten days or less are not appealable to the civil service commission under the existing provisions of the charter.

The ordinance, with the proposed charter amendments, was introduced and read for the [***4] first time at the city council's meeting on June 4, 1984. Subsequently, the public safety, legislation, and finance committees of council held public hearings on the ordinance. The ordinance was read again at the September 5 meeting. Council then voted fifteen to zero to suspend the rule requiring the ordinance to be read on three separate days. The ordinance was then read a third time and was passed by a vote of fifteen to zero.

The clerk of council forwarded a certified copy of the ordinance to the Cuyahoga County Board of Elections on September 7, 1984. The clerk later sent a proposed ballot title summarizing the charter amendment question to the board of elections on September 17, 1984. On October 5, 1984, the board of elections evidently approved the ballot summary language and adopted a resolution placing the proposed charter amendment on the next ballot. The ballot title language 1 was subsequently approved by the Secretary of State, and the charter amendment was adopted by the voters of the city of Cleveland on November 6, 1984.


1 The text of the ballot title and summary states:

"PROPOSED CHARTER AMENDMENT

"CITY OF CLEVELAND

"A Majority Affirmative Vote is Necessary for Passage

"Shall the Charter of the City of Cleveland be amended by enacting new sections 115-1, 115-2, 115-3, and 115-4, to create an Office of Professional Standards to investigate complaints of police misconduct and a Police Review Board appointed by the Mayor with approval of Council with power to hold hearings on such complaints, initiate disciplinary action against police officers, and cause investigation of incidents involving the use of deadly force by policemen, and by amending existing sections 116, 119, 121, and 126 of the Charter to create the new positions of three Deputy Chiefs of Police and eleven Commanders of Police in the unclassified service, to permit the Chiefs of Police and Fire to suspend members of the police and fire forces for not to exceed 10 days, to provide for hearing officers to conduct police and fire disciplinary hearings on behalf of the executive head of the police and fire forces, to provide that persons in the classified service who are suspended for more than 10 days may appeal to the Civil Service Commission, and to place members of the auxiliary police force in the unclassified service?"

 [***5] Prior to the election, appellants, Paul Jurcisin and the Cleveland Police Patrolmen's Association ("CPPA") and Joseph Musarra and the Fraternal Order of Police, Lodge 8 ("FOP"), sought an injunction in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court against the submission of the proposed charter amendment to the voters. Appellants further sought equitable relief to prevent the implementation of the charter amendment. The trial court refused to cancel the election on the proposed charter amendment. The court, however, did grant the appellants' alternative request and restrained the board of elections from certifying the results of the election on the amendment to the Secretary of State pending a final determination on the merits of appellants' claims.

In its memorandum opinion, the trial court held that the council had enacted the ordinance in conformity with all applicable charter requirements and that the ballot title of the amendment conformed to law. The court, however, declared the unofficial election results null and void, enjoined certification of the election results by the board of elections, and enjoined the amendment from becoming part of the charter, ruling that, under R.C. 4117.10(A),  [***6] it would



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant police officer and police associations sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) reversing a trial court decision and holding that an ordinance and charter amendment establishing a police review board and creating an office of professional standards to review complaints alleging police misconduct was properly enacted as an emergency measure.


OVERVIEW: Appellant police officer and police associations filed suit against appellee county board of elections seeking an injunction against the submission of a proposed charter amendment to the voters. The charter amendment proposed the establishment of a police review board and created an office of professional standards to review complaints alleging police misconduct. The court affirmed the appellate court's decision and concluded that that the charter amendment was properly enacted as an emergency measure. The court concluded that the council followed lawful procedures in passing the ordinance as an emergency measure. The court held that the proposed charter amendment establishing a police review board to investigate charges of police misconduct and recommend disciplinary actions upon a finding of misconduct did not conflict with provisions of a collective bargaining agreement between appellants and the municipality concerning wages, hours, and other conditions of employment. Finally, the court held that the ballot title and summary properly described the substance of the proposed charter amendment under standards found in the city charter, state statutes, and decision of the court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment reversing a trial court decision and holding that an ordinance establishing a police review board and creating an office of professional standards to review complaints alleging police misconduct was properly enacted as an emergency measure. The court concluded the charter amendment did not conflict with provisions of a collective bargaining agreement.

 

69 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Ratner v. Stark County Bd. of Revision


No. 86-1126


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 3d 26; 517 N.E.2d 915; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 12



January 13, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]

APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

This case is again before this court after remand in Ratner v.. Stark Cty. Bd. of Revision (1986), 23 Ohio St. 3d 59, 23 OBR 192, 491 N.E. 2d 680 ("Ratner I").

James Ratner, Trustee for Forest City Enterprises, Inc. ("taxpayer"), purchased the Mellett Mall in Stark County on September 30, 1981. The taxpayer paid a total of $ 500,000 in cash, signed a $ 6,000,000 note at the closing, and assumed four mortgages totalling $ 6,040,500 with interest rates ranging from 5 3/4 percent to 9 percent. This total amount, $ 12,540,500, was stated by the BTA to be reflective of the true value of the property in its earlier decision of April 15, 1985, where it determined that the fair market value of the property was $ 12,530,000. Upon appeal, this court reversed and remanded this decision and directed the board to consider, at least, independent appraisal evidence which adjusts the sale price to reflect the price paid for the property and the price paid for the favorable financing. The tax lien date under review in this case is January 1, 1981, nine months prior to the date of sale.

Upon remand, the BTA determined that the fair market value [***2] of the property was $ 10,500,000, approximating the conclusions of the witnesses provided by the taxpayer. The board of revision et al., appellants, have appealed.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant county board of revision sought review of a decision by the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which determined the fair value of appellee taxpayer's property to be $ 10,500,000.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer purchased property for $ 500,000 in cash, a $ 6,000,000 note at the closing, and the assumption of four mortgages totaling $ 6,040,500, for a total amount of $ 12,540,500. The tax court held that the fair market value of the property was $ 12,530,000. On appeal, the court reversed and remanded, directing the tax court to consider independent appraisal evidence that adjusted the sale price to reflect the price paid for the property and the price paid for the favorable financing. On remand, the tax court said that the fair market value of the property was $ 10,500,000. The county board of revision sought review and the court affirmed. The court noted, as it had in its earlier ruling, that the sale price paid for property in an arm's length transaction was the best, but not the only, evidence of the property's fair market value. The court said that the tax court was justified in taking other appraisals into consideration and that the price paid by the taxpayer for favorable financing was properly taken into account. The court also said that the tax court's determination of the property's fair market value would not be disturbed unless it was unreasonable or unlawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the tax court's appraisal of the taxpayer's property contrary to that urged by the county board of revision.

 

70 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Wright v. Oliver


No. 87-298


Supreme Court of Ohio


35 Ohio St. 3d 10; 517 N.E.2d 883; 1988 Ohio LEXIS 21



January 6, 1988, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1]  

APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Appellant Leatha Wright (hereinafter "Wright") is the mother of appellant Andrea Wright (hereinafter "Andrea"). Andrea was born on June 1, 1978. In January 1980, Wright brought a paternity action under Ohio's old "bastardy" law against appellee, Danny Oliver (hereinafter "Oliver"), based on allegations that Oliver was Andrea's father. The complaint was dismissed in July 1981.

Wright refiled the action on July 1, 1985. The action was filed pursuant to the new Parentage Act set out in Ohio R.C. Chapter 3111. Wright requested a judgment that Oliver was Andrea's father. Andrea was also a plaintiff in the refiled action.

Oliver denied Wright's allegations and requested summary judgment on the grounds of laches. He contended laches was appropriate because Wright delayed refiling the action four years. Oliver claimed the four-year delay caused his case to be materially prejudiced. The basis of his claim of material prejudice was that three of his supporting witnesses were no longer available and that he incurred substantial obligations which he would not have undertaken but for the delay.

A referee of the juvenile court [***2] denied Oliver's summary judgment motion on September 26, 1985. On October 29, 1985, the trial court found laches applicable and dismissed the case. The court of appeals affirmed the trial court.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant mother sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgment that found laches was applicable to appellant's claim against appellee, alleged father, and dismissed the paternity action.


OVERVIEW: Appellant mother challenged the appellate court's judgment, which affirmed the trial court's judgment that found appellant's action against appellee, alleged father, was barred by the doctrine of laches, and her paternity action against him was dismissed. The trial court's judgment was reversed and the cause remanded. The court held that laches could be applicable in parentage actions filed prior to the expiration of the statute of limitations, but only if appellee could show material prejudice. The unavailability of witnesses and incurrence of obligations did not materially prejudice appellee. The unavailable witnesses would not have commented on their observations that the parties did not engage in sexual intercourse during the probable time of the child's conception absent 24-hour a day contact.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's decree that appellant mother's paternity claim against appellee, alleged father, was barred by the doctrine of laches, and dismissed because the unavailability of witnesses and incurrence of obligations did not materially prejudice appellee.

 

71 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Stambaugh


No. 86-2068


Supreme Court of Ohio


34 Ohio St. 3d 34; 517 N.E.2d 526; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 446



December 16, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

Appellee, Nathan N. Stambaugh, was operating a motor vehicle on October 18, 1985, when he was stopped by an Ohio State Highway Patrol Trooper and cited for driving with an expired driving license in violation of R.C. 4507.02. Appellee entered a plea of guilty in Maumee Municipal Court and subsequently was fined and assessed costs. Stambaugh was ordered to furnish proof of financial responsibility pursuant to R.C. 4509.101. Appellee filed a motion for relief from judgment, post-conviction relief or, in the alternative, for stay of imposition of sentence -- directed at the court's order requiring proof of financial responsibility. The motion was denied, except as to the stay of imposition of sentence pending appeal.

The appellee appealed to the court of appeals, which held R.C. 4509.101 was unconstitutional in toto. Specifically, the court held that sections (B)(1), (B)(2)(b), and (B)(3)(a), when read in conjunction with each other, granted appellate powers to the Registrar of Motor Vehicles. The court further determined R.C. 4509.101(D) conferred judicial powers upon the registrar. Accordingly, the judgment of the [***2] trial court was reversed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part, reversed in part and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State sought review of the decision from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which reversed the judgment of the trial court and held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101 was unconstitutional. The trial court had denied appellee motorist's motion for relief from judgment, post-conviction relief or, in the alternative, for stay of imposition of sentence directed at the order requiring proof of financial responsibility.


OVERVIEW: The State argued that the appellate court had erred in finding Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101(B)(1), (B)(2)(b) unconstitutional. The appellate court had held that the sections, when read in conjunction with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101(B)(3)(a), were unconstitutional because their cumulative effect was to give the registrar authority to review judicial determinations. The court, after applying the rules of construction to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101, and after a careful reading of the statute, concluded that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101(B)(1), (B)(2)(b) were constitutional and valid. The appellate court erred when it found that the section was unconstitutional in that it gave an administrative officer authority to review a court's determination. The Bureau of Motor Vehicles was not empowered with appellate review under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101(B)(2)(b). The court further found that the statute was not in direct conflict with the Ohio Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court reversed that portion of the judgment of the appellate court, which found the traffic statutes unconstitutional. The court affirmed the remainder of the judgment. The court remanded the case.

 

72 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Dreger v. Public Employees Retirement System


No. 86-1919


Supreme Court of Ohio


34 Ohio St. 3d 17; 516 N.E.2d 214; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 436



December 9, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

From January 1950 to July 1967, appellee, Robert Dreger, was employed as a volunteer member of the North Ridgeville, Ohio, Fire Department. In June 1959, he became an employee of the town's street department. At this time, he began contributing to the Public Employees Retirement System ("PERS"), pursuant to R.C. 145.03. He continued to contribute to PERS until August 1967, at which point he ceased work for the street department and became a full-time employee of the fire department. He then became a contributing member of the Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund ("PFDPF"), pursuant to R.C. 742.01(B) and 742.31.

In October 1967, PERS notified Dreger that, according to the provisions of R.C. 145.02, as then effective, he was ineligible to maintain membership in PERS. When PERS terminated his membership, however, Dreger did not seek a refund of his accumulated contributions. He continued to contribute to PFDPF until his retirement in August 1982 as Chief of the North Ridgeville Fire Department.

In January 1975, Dreger was informed by the retirement supervisor of PFDPF that he could receive service credit [***2] for his work as a volunteer fireman from 1950 to 1967. However, on June 30, 1975, the board of trustees of PFDPF passed a resolution stating that service credit would only be given for full-time service. This resolution was subsequently promulgated as Ohio Adm. Code 742-5-01, effective January 1, 1977. In March 1978, PFDPF notified Dreger of this change and denied him credit for his part-time service as a volunteer fireman.

In February 1982, Dreger applied to PERS for a retirement allowance. PERS denied his application in March 1982, stating he was ineligible for benefits under R.C. 145.02, and sent him a refund check for his accumulated contributions pursuant to R.C. 145.40.

In June 1982, PFDPF informed Dreger that he was ineligible for service credit for his years with the street department, since his service at the time was covered by PERS. Dreger then applied for and accepted retirement from PFDPF, pursuant to R.C. 742.37(C)(1).

In September 1983, Dreger filed suit against PERS, PFDPF and others. The Franklin County Court of Common Pleas granted Dreger's motion for summary judgment on January 7, 1986. The trial court ordered PERS to accept return of Dreger's accumulated [***3] contributions and to issue him a retirement allowance, having found R.C. 145.02 to be unconstitutional on its face. The trial court also ordered PFDPF to give Dreger service credit for his years of service as a volunteer fireman.

The court of appeals affirmed in part and reversed in part. It upheld the trial court's finding that Dreger's membership was improperly terminated by PERS, although it did not reach the constitutional issue. It reversed the lower court on the issue of service credit, however, holding that Dreger has a right to purchase service credit from PERS, rather than receive it from PFDPF, for his years of service as a volunteer fireman.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the Public Employees Retirement System (PERS), sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which held that appellee fireman's membership was improperly terminated by PERS and that he had a right to purchase service credit from PERS, rather than receive it from the Police and Firemen's Disability and Pension Fund (PFDPF).


OVERVIEW: The fireman began contributing to PERS while working for the town's street department and serving as a volunteer fireman. When he ceased working for the street department and became a full-time fireman, he became a contributing member of PFDPF. PERS notified the fireman that he was ineligible to maintain membership in PERS. PFDPF denied the fireman credit for his part-time service as a volunteer fireman. The court initially held that the action was not barred by the six-year statute of limitations of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.07 because the cause of action did not accrue until PERS denied his application for a retirement allowance. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 145.02 did not require the termination of the pre-existing membership in PERS of a person who began contributing to PFDPF. Instead, the statute was only intended to exclude the initial membership in PERS of a person who was contributing to PFDPF. Thus, PERS improperly terminated the fireman's pre-existing membership. Finally, any right the fireman had for service credit for his work as a volunteer fireman had to be established under the guidelines of PERS because PFDPF had no authority beyond that which was conferred by statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

73 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Vargo v. Travelers Ins. Co.


No. 87-216


Supreme Court of Ohio


34 Ohio St. 3d 27; 516 N.E.2d 226; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 438



December 9, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Jefferson County.

On March 4, 1983, at approximately 6:00 p.m., decedent Louis Vargo was southbound on I-77 in Stark County, Ohio, when the vehicle he was operating swerved off the roadway into the median strip. The car continued its southerly course within the median strip for approximately fifty to seventy-five yards, then swerved abruptly back to the right, crossing both southbound lanes of I-77, climbing an embankment, crashing through a wire fence and proceeding in a straight line through a cornfield until striking a tree approximately nine hundred to thirteen hundred feet from the roadway. 1 The decedent received cardiopulmonary resuscitation at the scene. The resuscitation efforts were unsuccessful.


1 The speed at impact was estimated to be approximately thirty miles per hour.

Florence Vargo, the decedent's widow and appellee herein, sought thereafter to obtain insurance proceeds under a policy of insurance issued to decedent's employer, Youghiogheny & Ohio Coal Company, and pursuant to which decedent was an insured. The policy was issued by Travelers Insurance Company, appellant herein. Appellant denied coverage on the [***2] basis that the decedent had suffered his heart attack prior to the collision with the tree, and that its policy provided coverage only if the insured sustained bodily injury or death through accidental means directly and independently of all other causes. 2 


2 The policy contained the following provisions:

"* * *

"If an insured Employee or an insured Employee's Dependent while covered under this Part shall sustain bodily injury not hereinafter excepted effected directly and independently of all other causes through accidental means, and if such injury shall result within Three Hundred Sixty-five days of the date of accident, in any One of the losses enumerated below, the Company will pay, subject to the provisions and limitations hereinafter contained and the Indemnity Limits set forth below, the sum set opposite such loss.

"* * *

"Exclusions: -- The insurance under this Part shall not cover any loss

"(1) caused or contributed to by bodily or mental infirmity, disease or infection (except pus-forming infection which shall occur through an accidental cut or wound), even though the proximate and precipitating cause of the loss is accidental bodily injury."

Appellee [***3] thereupon filed the instant suit to compel payment of the insurance proceeds pursuant to the insurance contract. At trial, appellee utilized a medical expert in an attempt to establish that the decedent fell asleep at the wheel, woke up when the car left the roadway, then "froze" out of panic and suffered a heart attack as a result of the adrenaline surge. Conversely, appellant utilized three medical experts, the chief deputy coroner who performed the autopsy on decedent, a pathologist, and a cardiologist, who all testified that the heart attack was, without the involvement of external factors, caused by the decedent's degenerative heart disease. To further support its position, appellant introduced the coroner's report and death certificate which both reflect that the cause of death was "acute massive myocardial infarction due to or as a consequence of atherosclerotic heart disease."

The jury returned a unanimous verdict for appellant and the trial court entered judgment upon the verdict. Upon appeal, the court of appeals vacated the trial court's judgment and remanded the cause for a new trial on the basis that R.C. 313.19 was unconstitutional and deprived a party of due process [***4] by compelling the jury to accept, as a matter of law, the coroner's opinion as to the manner and mode of death, thus, in effect, directing the verdict for appellant herein. Additionally, the court of appeals reversed on the basis that the trial court erred by permitting one of appellant's medical experts to testify both to matters beyond the scope of his expertise and to testify with the aid of irrelevant, prejudicial statistical evidence.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant insurance company sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Jefferson County (Ohio), which reversed the judgment of the trial court that rendered a jury verdict favorable to the insurance company in appellee, wife of decedent's, action for payment of accidental death insurance coverage on decedent.


OVERVIEW: The decedent drove across a highway median and struck a tree. The coroner's report stated that the decedent died of a heart attack. At trial, a jury verdict was awarded to the insurance company. On appeal, the lower court reversed, and held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 313.19 was unconstitutional and deprived the wife of due process by compelling the jury to accept, as a matter of law, the coroner's opinion as to the manner and mode of death; thus, in effect, directing the verdict for the insurance company. The court disagreed, reversed the judgment of the lower court, and reinstated the verdict of the trial court. The court held that § 313.19 did not mandate a jury verdict for the insurance company, but created in the coroner's report and death certificate a non-binding, rebuttable presumption of the decedent's cause of death in the absence of competent, credible evidence to the contrary. The court held that § 313.19 did not violate due process because the wife had the opportunity, through medical testimony, to rebut the coroner's report that the decedent died a non-accidental death.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower court, reinstated the judgment of the trial court in favor of the insurance company, and held that the coroner's report, pursuant to statutory law, did not direct a verdict for the insurance company in its claim that the decedent died by non-accidental means, and that his wife was not entitled to his accidental death coverage. The court held that the coroner's report created a rebuttable presumption.

 

74 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Lyle Constr., Inc. v. Ohio Dep't of Natural Resources, Div. of Reclamation


No. 86-1753


Supreme Court of Ohio


34 Ohio St. 3d 22; 516 N.E.2d 209; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 437



December 9, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Vinton County.

On July 19, 1983, an inspector from the Ohio Department of Natural Resources, Division of Reclamation, appellee herein, issued a notice of violation ("NOV") No. 3918 to Lyle Construction, Inc., appellant herein, for failing to timely reclaim a portion of its coal mining permit area, in violation of R.C. 1513.16(H)(1) and (3) and Ohio Adm. Code 1501:13-7-06(A). A deadline for compliance with NOV No. 3918, requiring complete reclamation, was set for October 13, 1983. The compliance deadline was later extended to October 17, 1983 and then extended again to November 17, 1983. In addition to extending the compliance deadlines, appellee simultaneously reduced the compliance requirements from complete reclamation to "complet[ing] all physical work necessary to establish a successful cover of permanent vegetation." At no time during the period July 19, 1983 to November 22, 1983, the date noncompliance was determined, did appellant appeal either NOV No. 3918, pursuant to R.C. 1513.13(A)(1), or request extensions of the compliance deadline contained therein, pursuant to Ohio Adm. Code 1501:13-14-02(B)(3) and (5).

On April 3, 1984,  [***2] appellant remained non noncompliant with NOV No. 3918, and appellee, pursuant to R.C. 1513.02(F)(1), issued proposed civil penalty assessment No. 2832, in the amount of $ 400, and active final civil penalty assessment No. 2832, in the amount of $ 22,900. 1 Appellant did not appeal either assessment, 2 and continued to remain noncompliant with NOV No. 3918. On December 7, 1984, appellee issued final civil penalty assessment No. 2832 in the amount of $ 229,150. 3 Subsequently, on December 20, 1984, appellant sought, pursuant to R.C. 1513.02(F)(3), an informal assessment conference to review the amount of the assessment in final civil penalty assessment No. 2832. The conference officer affirmed, without modification, the amount of assessment No. 2832.


1 Active final civil penalty assessment No. 2832 is comprised of the $ 400 proposed civil penalty and an additional assessment of $ 750, the minimum daily assessment permitted by R.C. 1513.02(F)(4), for each of the first thirty days of noncompliance with NOV No. 3918.


2 Review was available pursuant to R.C. 1513.02(F)(3), 1513.13 and Ohio Adm. Code 1501:13-14-03.


3 Final civil penalty assessment No. 2832 includes the April 3, 1984 assessment of $ 22,900 plus an additional $ 750 a day penalty, purportedly for each day of noncompliance from December 22, 1983 through October 19, 1984.

 [***3] Appellant therein timely perfected its appeal to the Reclamation Board of Review, yet failed to prepay the penalty amount as required by R.C. 1513.02(F)(3). In lieu of payment, appellant attached an affidavit of insolvency to its notice of appeal. The Reclamation Board of Review thereupon sua sponte dismissed, pursuant to R.C. 1513.02(F)(3), 4 appellant's appeal on the basis of lack of jurisdiction. Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed the dismissal of appellant's appeal on the basis that the statutory scheme of R.C. Chapter 1513, and specifically the penalty prepayment provision in R.C. 1513.02(F)(3), did not violate appellant's right to either due process of law or equal protection of the laws.


4 R.C. 1513.02(F)(3), at the time of the decision of the Reclamation Board of Review, provided in part: "* * * At the time the petition for review of the proposed assessment is filed with the secretary of the reclamation board of review, the person shall forward the amount of the penalty to the secretary of the reclamation board of review for placement in an escrow account. * * * Failure to forward the money to the secretary of the reclamation board of review within thirty days after the chief informs the operator of the proposed amount of the penalty shall result in a waiver of all legal rights to contest the violation or the amount of the penalty.

 [***4] The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, an insolvent coal mine operator, appealed from an order of the Court of Appeals of Vinton County (Ohio), confirming a ruling by the Reclamation Board of Review, dismissing the operator's appeal from a violation notice that was issued by appellee natural resources department. The operator challenged the Board's dismissal of its appeal for failure to prepay a civil penalty under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1513.02(F)(3).


OVERVIEW: The natural resources department issued a notice of violation to the insolvent coal mine operator for its failure to timely reclaim a portion of its coal mining permit area, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1513.16(H)(1), (3) and the Ohio Admin. Code § 1501:13-7-06(A). The company remained noncompliant and a civil penalty was assessed against it by the department. The company appealed to the Board, but failed to prepay the penalty as required by § 1513.02(F)(3). The company claimed that it was insolvent. The Board dismissed the appeal for lack of jurisdiction. The appellate court confirmed the ruling of the Board on the grounds that the operator's due process and equal protection rights were not violated. The court affirmed the order of the appellate court. The court held that the jurisdictionally required penalty prepayment provision set forth in § 1513.02(F)(3) did not deny the operator due process or equal protection of the laws. The legislature may rationally require the prepayment of penalty assessments and, therefore, insure the collection of penalties and compliance with the State of Ohio's scheme of coal mine reclamation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed an order that was entered by the appellate court which confirmed a ruling by the review board that dismissed the insolvent coal mine operator's appeal from a decision of the natural resources department, assessing a civil penalty against the operator.

 

75 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Lunsford v. Mussio


No. 87-1068


Supreme Court of Ohio


33 Ohio St. 3d 64; 514 N.E.2d 869; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 414



October 28, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

 

76 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Gaines v. Preterm-Cleveland, Inc.


No. 86-1881


Supreme Court of Ohio


33 Ohio St. 3d 54; 514 N.E.2d 709; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 410



October 21, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On April 30, 1980, plaintiff-appellant, Evelyn Y. Gaines, went to defendant-appellee, Preterm-Cleveland, Inc., a health care facility, for the dual purpose of having her pregnancy terminated and her intrauterine device ("IUD") removed. The pertinent medical records indicate that the abortion was successfully completed. The IUD was not recovered, apparently because it could not be located, although the records reflect an estimate by the physician of its possible location.

In her complaint, and in the evidence presented to the trial court, appellant alleged that agents or employees of appellee "negligently failed to remove the IUD" as requested by appellant. Moreover, appellant alleged that she "was told by employees or agents of * * * [appellee] Preterm that the IUD had been removed." (Emphasis added.) The complaint further stated that "[i]n reliance on the misrepresentations of the employees or agents of * * * [appellee] Preterm as alleged above, * * * [appellant] did not seek further medical attention in order to remove the IUD." Appellant alleged that "[a]s a result of * * * [appellee]  [***2] Preterm's negligence in failing to remove the IUD and misrepresenting to * * * [appellant] that the IUD had been removed, * * * [appellant] suffered great physical pain and emotional distress, underwent an operation to remove the IUD, received medical attention and will continue to receive medical attention the rest of her natural life, will suffer great pain of body and mind for the rest of her natural life, and was permanently scarred." Appellant asserted that she did not discover that the IUD remained in her body until she underwent a tubal ligation on October 18, 1983, nearly three and one-half years after the Preterm procedure. At that time, appellant's new physician discovered that the IUD had not been removed, but had perforated appellant's uterus and become embedded in her left ligament. On October 16, 1984, appellant notified appellee pursuant to the second paragraph of R.C. 2305.11(A) (the one-hundred-eighty-day notice) that she was considering instituting an action stemming from professional services rendered to her. On April 11, 1985, appellant filed suit.

Appellee moved for summary judgment on June 12, 1985, arguing that appellant's action was barred by the four-year [***3] statute of repose for medical malpractice suits embodied in R.C. 2305.11(B). The trial court granted the motion and entered judgment for appellee.

The court of appeals affirmed, holding that appellant's medical malpractice action was time-barred under R.C. 2305.11(B), since her complaint was filed more than four years after the act or omission constituting the alleged malpractice occurred. The court rejected appellant's argument that her allegations stated an independent cause of action in fraud and that such action was timely filed under R.C. 2305.09, the statute of limitations for fraud. The appellate court reasoned that the "gist" of appellant's allegations was medical malpractice and that the statute of limitations for fraud does not apply.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.
GAINES v. PRETERM CLEVELAND, 1986 Ohio App. LEXIS 8669 (Ohio Ct. App., Cuyahoga County, Oct. 9, 1986)



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant patient challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's grant of summary judgment to appellee healthcare facility on the basis that her medical malpractice action was barred by the four-year statute of repose embodied in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(B).


OVERVIEW: The court first discussed the patient's contention that the allegations in her complaint stated a cause of action in fraud, separate from any claim of malpractice. The court identified the elements of an action in fraud, found that the patient's allegations satisfied these elements, and found that a jury question was clearly generated under the allegations made by the patient. The court also found that the patient's complaint was timely filed under the statute of limitations, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.09, applicable to such a fraud action. The court then noted that Ohio's statute of repose, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(B), had been declared unconstitutional as to some but not all medical malpractice litigants. The court then compared the operation of § 2305.11(B) to the court's interpretation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(A) and determined that § 2305.11(A) provided for a minimum one-year period in which medical malpractice litigants could pursue their claims. The court found that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(B) was unconstitutional as applied to litigants who, following discovery, did not have the time provided by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(A) to file their actions.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals was reversed and the cause was remanded to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

77 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Shkurti v. Withrow


No. 87-1314


Supreme Court of Ohio


32 Ohio St. 3d 424; 513 N.E.2d 1332; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 402



September 21, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Under the Federal Unemployment Tax Act, Section 3301 et seq., Title 26, U.S. Code, the federal government levies an excise tax on the payroll of employers for unemployment compensation. However, employers who pay into an approved state program are granted credits of up to ninety percent of the federal tax. Ohio operates such an approved program under R.C. Chapter 4141, in support of which Ohio employers pay "contributions."

Federal law, Section 1321 et seq., Title 42, U.S. Code, also provides for advances of federal funds to state programs. Generally, these advances are repayable with interest. Section 1322(b), Title 42, U.S. Code. When advances are not repaid within a certain time, the credits available under the federal tax are reduced and, accordingly, the employers in a state with outstanding advances pay a higher effective federal tax rate. Section 3302(c)(2), Title 26, U.S. Code.

Ohio has had outstanding advances since 1980. Because of these outstanding advances, the effective federal tax rate on Ohio employers had increased each year, beginning in 1982, due to reduction in the state credits to offset the tax. Moreover, the state [***2] has paid interest on the advances, from the General Fund each year, beginning in 1982.

As part of Am. Sub. H.B. No. 171, effective July 1, 1987, the General Assembly enacted R.C. 4141.251 and 4141.48. R.C. 4141.48 directs the Treasurer of the state of Ohio to issue bonds on and after October 1, 1987, to repay outstanding advances made by the federal government to the Ohio unemployment compensation program, to pay interest on advances, and to reimburse the General Fund for interest paid since July 1, 1987. The bonds are to be issued upon the determination of the Director of Budget and Management that they would be "cost-effective." ( R.C. 4141.48[B].)
