Specifically, defendant argued that the trial court erred in instructing the jury that one who lawfully entered premises became a trespasser subject to conviction for burglary by virtue of the commission of the felony on the premises. The court held that under the circumstances of the case, even assuming lawful initial entry, the jury was justified in inferring from the evidence that defendant's privilege to remain in the home terminated the moment he commenced the assault. Defendant also argued that the death penalty was disproportionately severe compared to penalties imposed in similar cases in the county. The court held that the proportionality review was satisfied by a review of those cases already decided by the reviewing court in which the death penalty had been imposed, but not those cases in which the death penalty could have been sought.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals, which had affirmed defendant's convictions and death sentence.

 

90 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. McDonald


No. 86-1376


Supreme Court of Ohio


31 Ohio St. 3d 47; 509 N.E.2d 57; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 291; 31 Ohio B. Rep. 155



June 10, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Jefferson County.

On February 25, 1985, the Jefferson County Grand Jury returned indictments against the several defendants, Michael P. McDonald, Joseph A. DiAlbert, John N. Hribar, Nicholas Kolakis and James B. Connor. The one count common to all the defendants was possession of criminal tools in violation of R.C. 2923.24. Defendant Hribar filed a motion to dismiss this count, asserting that the criminal tools statute is unconstitutional. Following a hearing on this motion, the trial court ruled that R.C. 2923.24 is unconstitutional and dismissed the count in the indictment. Based on this order, the same count against each of the other four defendants was dismissed. The state appealed and the court of appeals consolidated the cases and affirmed the judgment.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State challenged a decision from the Court of Appeals for Jefferson County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's dismissal of the charges against defendants for possession of criminal tools in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2923.24, on the ground that the statute was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were indicted for possession of criminal tools in violation of § 2923.24. The trial court dismissed the charges on the ground that the statute was unconstitutional because it was vague and impermissibly overbroad. The appellate court affirmed. On appeal, the court stated that § 2323.24 was not void for vagueness because the conduct prohibited by the statute did not lend itself to concise, specific wording. The court stated that because the statute included a scienter requirement the general assembly had required both control of the article and the specific intention to use the article to commit a crime. The court stated that that provided sufficient notice to persons of ordinary intelligence to the prohibited conduct. The court stated that the statute was not impermissibly overbroad because the mere possession of an article or devise was not the prohibited conduct.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded the dismissal of the charges against defendants for possession of criminal tools.

 

91 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Walker v. Glenwood Corp.


No. 86-1102


Supreme Court of Ohio


30 Ohio St. 3d 601; 509 N.E.2d 57; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 297



May 6, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Delaware County.

 

92 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Franchise Developers, Inc. v. Cincinnati


No. 86-513


Supreme Court of Ohio


30 Ohio St. 3d 28; 505 N.E.2d 966; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 257; 30 Ohio B. Rep. 33



April 8, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Under Chapter 34 of the Cincinnati Municipal Code ("CMC"), the city council of defendant-appellant city of Cincinnati is empowered to create "environmental quality districts" ("EQD's") to "* * * assist the development of land and structures to be compatible with the environment and to protect the quality of the urban environment in those locations where the characteristics of the environment are of significant public value and are vulnerable to damage by development permitted under conventional zoning and building regulations." CMC Section 3400.2. Such additional zoning regulation in this context is more commonly known as "overlay" zoning.

The record indicates that during 1975, the defendant-appellant Clifton Town Meeting (a neighborhood group) successfully opposed the development of a "Burger Chef" restaurant on Ludlow Avenue in the city of Cincinnati on the basis that such a restaurant would have a destabilizing effect on the Ludlow Avenue business district.

On September 27, 1978, Cincinnati City Council adopted Ordinance No. 398-1978 which created an environmental quality-urban design zone district ("EQ-UD") over [***2] the existing zone district in the vicinity of Clifton and Ludlow Avenues in the city of Cincinnati. Incorporated within this ordinance was a Development Guidelines Report ("DGR") which provided in guideline III A 2:

"New businesses should contribute to the desired mix of commercial activities; franchise type establishments are acceptable provided that they are primarily pedestrian and not automobile oriented." (Emphasis added.)

In 1982, plaintiff-appellee Alvin Lipson purchased a theatre located at 320 Ludlow Avenue within the subject EQ-UD. In 1984, the theatre was leased to plaintiff-appellee Franchise Developers, Inc. ("FDI"). Early in 1984, FDI applied for a building permit to remodel the theatre for use as a "Wendy's" restaurant.

As part of the building permit application process, defendant-appellant James R. Krusling, Director of Buildings and Inspections for the city of Cincinnati, served as hearing examiner and conducted a hearing with respect to FDI's application. As a result of the hearing, Krusling recommended approval of the application over the strong objections raised by Clifton Town Meeting. Subsequently, Clifton Town Meeting appealed Krusling's decision [***3] to Cincinnati City Council pursuant to CMC Section 3405.3.

A hearing was held by city council with respect to FDI's application, whereupon council reversed Krusling's decision and directed that the permit application be denied. In so doing, the council adopted separate findings of fact and conclusions of law. 1 


1 Some of the conclusions of law adopted by Cincinnati City Council were the following:

"1. The proposed fast food restaurant at 320 Ludlow Avenue would be a valid use of the property under the B-2 Community Business District Regulations, Chapter 21, of the Zoning Code. Pursuant to the provisions of § 102.5 of the Zoning Code, such property may, however, be subject to additional regulations.

"2. The subject address is part of an Environmental Quality District, created by Ordinance 398-1978 of the Council of the City of Cincinnati, and thus subject to the provisions of Chapter 34 of the Zoning Code, the provisions of which, pursuant to § 3401.1, prevail over any conflict with the B-2 underlying zone regulations.

"3. There is a substantial City interest in protecting the stability of neighborhoods and neighborhood business districts, and Ordinance No. 398-1978 is a valid exercise of the legislative authority of the Council of the City of Cincinnati.

"4. The Council may validly provide for land use regulations in ordinances establishing Environmental Quality District Regulations, pursuant to the provisions of Zoning Code § 3400.2.

"5. The phrase 'fast food restaurant' is not defined in any provision of the Zoning Code. It must be defined in accordance with the ordinary and usual meaning of the phrase, as well as by the usage given such phrase by the public and the industry involved.

"6. The provision of the Clifton Community Plan (as approved by the Planning Commission and adopted as part of the Coordinated City Plan) to the effect that fast food restaurants are not appropriate along Ludlow Avenue is a valid expression of the mutual desire of the Clifton neighborhood and the City of Cincinnati.

"7. Inasmuch as the proposed use fails to contribute to the desired mix of commercial activity on Ludlow Avenue, for the reason set forth above, it fails to comply with the provisions of Ordinance No. 398-1978, and is not a permitted use under the Zoning Code of the City of Cincinnati."

 [***4] The matter was then appealed by FDI and Lipson to the court of common pleas, where they sought a declaratory judgment against the city, Krusling and Clifton Town Meeting that Ordinance No. 398-1978 and its incorporated DGR are unconstitutional. Upon motions for summary judgment filed by all the parties, the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the defendants, thereby affirming the decision of city council to deny the permit application.

Upon further appeal, the court of appeals reversed and reinstated the decision of the hearing examiner that granted the permit application. The appellate court narrowed the issue to whether DGR III A 2 is a constitutionally acceptable expression of governmental judgment upon which city council was entitled to rely, when it addressed the merits of FDI's application in light of the overlay zoning regulations contained in CMC Chapter 34. The court of appeals opined that the regulation of land use apart from the underlying provisions of the zoning code is clearly prohibited, and that any regulatory action taken in connection with the creation of an environmental quality district is confined to only the physical or aesthetic aspects of [***5] property development. The appellate court held that DGR III A 2, standing alone, cannot withstand constitutional scrutiny due to the inherent vagueness of its terms.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) that reversed the trial court's decision to grant summary judgment in favor of appellee corporation and affirmed the denial of appellee's permit application to build a fast food restaurant.


OVERVIEW: The lower trial court granted summary judgment in favor of appellee corporation but the lower appellate court reversed the decision. The lower appellate court first reviewed the constitutionality of the municipal zoning provision and found it too vague. The court disagreed because it found the lower appellate court did not give it the presumption of validity that it deserved. The court found the ordinance was not unconstitutionally vague because such an argument is inherently deficient in a zoning case. The court also found the lower appellate court erred in finding that land use regulations were clearly prohibited in the instant overlay zoning scheme because the court found the overlay zoning scheme presented constituted a proper exercise of the city's zoning authority in its attempt to preserve and protect the character of certain neighborhoods that the city deems important, in order to promote the overall quality of life within the city's boundaries. The court therefore reversed the lower appellate court decision.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the lower appellate court that reversed the lower trial court's decision to grant summary judgment in favor of appellee corporation and affirmed the denial of appellee's permit application to build a fast food restaurant.

 

93 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Schmidt


No. 86-263


Supreme Court of Ohio


29 Ohio St. 3d 32; 505 N.E.2d 627; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 240; 29 Ohio B. Rep. 383



March 25, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Columbiana County.

On October 12, 1984, Roger M. Stiller, Superintendent of the Columbiana Exempted Village School District, filed two complaints charging defendant-appellants, Richard and Pamela Schmidt, with failing to send their daughter, Sara, a minor of compulsory school age, to a school or special education program conforming to the minimum standards established by the State Board of Education, in violation of R.C. 3321.04 and 3321.38(A). Each complaint contained twenty counts, alleging that appellants failed to send Sara to a school on twenty successive school days between September 17 and October 12, 1984.

Richard and Pamela Schmidt are "born-again Christians," and believe that it is their undelegable duty as parents to educate Sara themselves. Appellants undertook to teach Sara at home with assistance from a correspondence curriculum they obtained from Winchester Christian Academy, a private, non-chartered school located in Columbus. Appellants enrolled Sara as a student at Winchester Christian Academy, but she has never attended classes there.

Upon becoming aware that Sara was of compulsory school age but was not attending [***2] a school, Superintendent Stiller informed appellants that they were required by Ohio law to obtain his approval for their home education program. Appellants did not seek Stiller's approval because they felt that their religious beliefs not only required them to educate Sara themselves, but also forbade them from seeking Stiller's permission to do so.

The matter came to trial on February 28, 1985, before the Columbiana County Court of Common Pleas, Juvenile Division, and on April 8, 1985. the court entered judgment finding both appellants guilty as charged. the court of appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants challenged the order of the Court of Appeals for Columbiana County (Ohio), which affirmed the order of the trial court that convicted defendants under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3321.04 and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3321.38(A) for failing to send their minor daughter to school or to obtain permission from the school district superintendent to home school the child.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were the parents of a minor child. For religious reasons, the parents home schooled the child and refused to request permission for home schooling from the superintendent. The superintendent brought charges. The trial court convicted defendants, and they appealed. The appellate court affirmed, and defendants appealed. The court affirmed. The approval requirement of § 3321.04(A)(2) had not violated defendants' rights under the First Amendment because although defendants' religious beliefs appeared sincere, defendants had failed to demonstrate that the approval requirement infringed upon their right to the free exercise of religion. Without the application by defendants and without a proposal to the superintendent, there was no way to balance defendants' rights against the State's interest. The delegation of authority to the superintendent was not improper because the superintendent was given an intelligible principle for guidance and desirable flexibility to accommodate home education programs in § 3321.04(A)(2), and any arbitrary and capricious refusal was subject to appeal. Finally, the approval requirement of § 3321.04(A)(2) was not vague.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order of the appellate court, which had affirmed defendants' convictions.

 

94 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


South Euclid Fraternal Order of Police, Lodge 80 v. D'Amico


No. 86-864


Supreme Court of Ohio


29 Ohio St. 3d 50; 505 N.E.2d 268; 1987 Ohio LEXIS 243; 29 Ohio B. Rep. 398



March 25, 1987, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Since 1973, the city of South Euclid, Ohio has passed several ordinances for the purpose of regulating the sick-leave benefits of the police and fire fighters employed by the municipality. Also since 1973, the instant appellants, the South Euclid Fraternal Order of Police, Lodge 80, and the South Euclid Fire Fighters Association, Local 1065, have on several occasions judicially attacked these attempts by the city to limit their sick-leave benefits.

In 1981, the city passed Ordinance No. 49-80. Appellants' declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of that ordinance resulted in a judgment in favor of the appellees, the city of South Euclid and its mayor (hereinafter collectively termed "the city"). On appeal, the court of appeals on November 7, 1983 reversed the trial court's judgment, holding that Ordinance No. 49-80 was unconstitutional 1 because the city could not abridge rights granted to the appellants by R.C. 124.38. 2 The court of appeals remanded the cause to the trial court and directed it to enter final judgment in favor of appellants. 3 South Euclid Fraternal Order of Police v. [***2] . D'Amico (1983), 13 Ohio App. 3d 46, 13 OBR 49, 468 N.E. 2d 735. The trial court entered judgment accordingly on May 4, 1984.


1 The principal provision that the appellate court found objectionable sought to prohibit sick-leave benefits for injuries incurred by police and fire fighters during outside employment.


2 R.C. 124.38 provides that county, municipal and other specified employees are entitled to certain amounts of paid sick leave, and sets forth the procedure for the use of sick leave.


3 The court of appeals' mandate failed to include a specific reference to appellant South Euclid Fire Fighters Association, Local 1065. However, pursuant to the appellate court's remand, the trial court's entry refers to the fire fighters association.

On December 26, 1984, the city passed Ordinance No. 29-84, again for the purpose of regulating the sick-leave benefits. The instant cause began with a motion filed by appellants in February 1985 wherein they requested that the trial court hold the city in contempt, arguing that the enactment of Ordinance No. 29-84 was in contravention of the previous entry of the trial court of May 4, 1984. On May 20, 1985, the trial court denied [***3] the motion, ruling that the city had committed no act in violation of previous court orders. The court of appeals affirmed the trial court's ruling, concluding that neither its order of November 7, 1983 nor the trial court's order of May 4, 1984 did anything other than to declare Ordinance No. 49-80 invalid, and thus there was no order that the city could have violated. 4 


4 We note that William J. Brown, in his capacity as Attorney General of the state of Ohio, was a party to the original declaratory judgment action in the trial court, and that appellants' motion for contempt was filed under the same case number as that action. William J. Brown was succeeded as Attorney General by Anthony J. Celebrezze, Jr. However, the motion for contempt that generated the instant appeal was not directed to the Attorney General.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a police association and a fire fighters' association, sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed a trial court judgment denying their motion for contempt against appellees, the City of South Euclid, Ohio, and the Mayor of the City, based on the City passing a new ordinance to regulate appellants' sick leave benefits after a previous ordinance had been declared unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The City passed an ordinance regulating appellants' sick leave benefits, which the trial court upheld, but the appellate court declared it unconstitutional and directed the trial court to enter final judgment in favor of appellants. A few years later, the City passed another ordinance for the purpose of regulating sick-leave benefits, and appellants filed a motion for contempt, which the trial court denied, ruling that the City had committed no act in violation of previous orders. The appellate court affirmed the judgment. On appeal, the court found that there was no court order of record affirmatively directing how the City was to proceed in regard to ordinances regulating appellants' sick-leave benefits. Consequently, the court held that in a declaratory judgment action contesting the constitutionality of an ordinance, an entry granting judgment to the plaintiffs without expressly directing the defendants to do, or refrain from doing, a particular thing or things, could not be the basis of finding the defendants in contempt upon the enactment of subsequent legislation, allegedly containing the same or similar infirmities.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals, which affirmed the trial court's ruling denying appellants' motion for contempt.

 

95 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Ridgley, Inc. v. Board of Zoning Appeals


No. 86-260


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 3d 357; 503 N.E.2d 1036; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 859; 28 Ohio B. Rep. 420; 65 A.L.R.4th 541



December 30, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Medina County.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in part and reversed in part. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Medina County (Ohio) reversing the common pleas court, which held that appellee, zoning board of a city, did not have the authority to regulate the retail sale of alcoholic beverages within that municipality.


OVERVIEW: The issue presented in the common pleas court was whether the city was preempted by operation of state law from regulating, pursuant to the authority of local zoning ordinances, the retail sale of alcoholic beverages within the city. In affirming that part of the judgment of the court of appeals, which reversed the common pleas court, the court noted that Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3, known as the home rule provision, provided that municipalities shall have authority to exercise all powers of local self-government and to adopt and enforce within their limits such local police, sanitary and other similar regulations, as are not in conflict with general laws.A municipal zoning ordinance was valid unless it conflicted with the dictates of a state statute. Because, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4303.292(A)(2)(a), a liquor permit could not validly be issued, under state law, in contravention of local zoning ordinances, municipal zoning ordinances limiting the retail sales of alcoholic beverages within the municipal corporate boundaries were not in conflict with state liquor laws providing for the issuance of liquor permits. It was improper to remand the questions not raised on appeal.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed that part of the decision of the court of appeals that reversed the judgment of the common pleas court. The court reversed that part of the court of appeals' decision, which remanded the cause to the common pleas court. The court entered final judgment for the zoning board.

 

96 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Rogers


No. 84-784


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 3d 427; 504 N.E.2d 52; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 867; 28 Ohio B. Rep. 480



December 30, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] ON REMAND from the Supreme Court of the United States.

Appellant was convicted of the strangulation murder of seven-year-old Lisa Bates, whose body was discovered in appellant's closet. See State v.. Rogers (1985), 17 Ohio St. 3d 174. The jury found the existence of two statutory aggravating circumstances, i.e., that the offense was committed in the course of a kidnapping and in the course of a rape. R.C. 2929.04(A)(7).

Thereafter, the penalty phase of the trial was conducted as required by R.C. 2929.03. The jury returned a finding that the aggravating circumstances outweighed the mitigating factors, beyond any reasonable doubt. The trial court then imposed the sentence of death. Both the court of appeals and the Ohio Supreme Court affirmed the verdict and the sentence. Each court independently determined that the aggravating factors outweighed the factors in mitigation. State v.. Rogers, supra. 

Subsequently, the United States Supreme Court decided the case of Caldwell v.. Mississippi (1985), 472 U.S. 320. On December 2, 1985, the United States Supreme Court vacated this court's judgment in State v.. Rogers, supra, and remanded [***2] the case for further consideration in light of Caldwell v.. Mississippi, supra. ( Rogers v.. Ohio [1985], U.S., 88 L.Ed. 2d 452.)



DISPOSITION: Judgment reaffirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following vacation of the earlier conviction and imposition of the death penalty upon defendant by the United States Supreme Court, the case was remanded for further consideration.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted and sentenced to death. His conviction and sentence were upheld throughout state appeals. The United States Supreme Court vacated defendant's sentence and remanded for further consideration. The court reaffirmed. The court found that defendant's case was distinguished from Caldwell v. Mississippi because Ohio had no sentencing jury and the power to impose the death penalty resided in the trial court under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.03(D)(3). The prosecutor's comments in defendant's case were not improper because they accurately stated that the jury only recommended whether or not to impose the death penalty. The court noted that the appellate courts in Ohio were required to weigh the mitigating factors against aggravated circumstances to evaluate whether the imposition of the death penalty was appropriate under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.05. Therefore, they made an original determination. Defense counsel had made brash and inappropriate references to the death penalty and had argued the merits. The State had merely made a measured response that accurately reflected the law. Therefore, defendant was not entitled to relief.


OUTCOME: The court reaffirmed.

 

97 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Glenn


No. 85-877


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 3d 451; 504 N.E.2d 701; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 870; 28 Ohio B. Rep. 501



December 30, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Portage County.

John Glenn, appellant, was convicted of the aggravated murder of Mahoning County Reserve Deputy Sheriff John Litch, Jr. Litch was killed while transporting a prisoner, Robert Glenn, who was also appellant's half-brother, from the prison to a hospital for treatment of Robert's leg which was in a cast. While en route, the deputy's squad car was stopped at a downtown traffic light. At that time, appellant's vehicle struck him from behind. The deputy left the squad car and walked toward the other vehicle. As he approached the door, he was shot at close range and killed with a twelve-gauge shotgun. The prisoner then left the squad car and entered the other vehicle. Both men immediately departed in the auto driven by appellant.

The crime was committed in downtown Youngstown, Ohio, and was witnessed by two firemen. It was shown at trial that appellant had access to the information concerning the scheduled medical treatment of his half-brother. Appellant's girlfriend testified that appellant admitted to her that he killed the officer. Also, appellant had been observed earlier in the day driving the vehicle used in the [***2] escape.

Appellant was indicted for escape and aggravated murder with a specification, pursuant to R.C. 2929.04(A)(6), that the victim was a peace officer. The jury found appellant guilty, after which the jury was released until the beginning of the sentencing phase of the trial.

After the sentencing phase presentations, the jury recommended the death penalty. The trial court then determined that the aggravating circumstances outweighed any mitigating factors beyond a reasonable doubt. It thereafter adopted the jury's recommendation and sentenced appellant to death. The court of appeals, after independently reweighing all the evidence, mitigating factors, and aggravating circumstances, as well as determining appellant's other assignments of error, affirmed both the verdict and the sentence.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed the decision of the Court of Appeals for Portage County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's finding that he was guilty of aggravated murder of a peace officer and which affirmed his death sentence.


OVERVIEW: A county reserve deputy sheriff was transporting a prisoner from the prison to a hospital for treatment. While en route, defendant hit the deputy's car from behind in an attempt to free the prisoner. As the deputy approached defendant's vehicle, he was shot at close range and killed. Defendant was convicted of aggravated murder of a peace officer under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(A)(6). The trial court sentenced defendant to death. The court of appeals affirmed. On further review by the court, the court concluded that the victim was acting as a peace officer under § 2929.04(A)(6). There was no error in allowing witness testimony regarding defendant's prior incarcerations because there was no evidence that the information was given with a motive to harm defendant's case. There was substantial, probative evidence from which the jury could decide beyond a reasonable doubt that defendant was guilty. Witnesses observed defendant driving the vehicle used in the incident, and there were also witnesses at the scene of the crime. Moreover, the prisoner's overalls were found in defendant's car. The court also concluded that the sentence was not excessive or disproportionate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment convicting defendant for aggravated murder and sentencing him to death.

 

98 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


New Energy Co. v. Limbach


No. 86-784


Supreme Court of Ohio


1986 Ohio LEXIS 771



December 26, 1986, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [*1] Rehearing Granted January 21, 1987


PRIOR HISTORY: Appeal from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Plaintiff-appellant, New Energy Company of Indiana, manufactures ethanol and is engaged in commerce among the states. Ethanol is a 199 proof alcohol which is mixed with gasoline in a 10/90 ratio to form a blend called gasohol. Plaintiff's manufacturing facility is located in South Bend, Indiana. Ethanol produced by New Energy has been marketed in Ohio at a rate of approximately one million gallons per month.

Effective January 1, 1985 the Ohio General Assembly amended R.C. 5735.145(B) to provide that any fuel otherwise eligible for a tax credit shall not contain ethanol produced outside Ohio unless the state of origin provides a similar tax credit, exemption or refund for similar fuel containing ethanol produced in Ohio. Indiana does not provide any such credit, exemption or refund for Ohio-produced ethanol.

Plaintiff brought this action to challenge the constitutionality of R.C. 5735.145(B), seeking declaratory and injunctive relief. Plaintiff contended, inter alia, that the statute violates the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution by placing an undue burden [*2] on interstate commerce. Plaintiff alleged that the statute effectively barred it from marketing its ethanol in Ohio, since the unavailability of a tax credit for plaintiff's ethanol renders the product economically undesirable to Ohio dealers.

The trial court held that R.C. 5735.145(B) is constitutional, finding no significant burden on interstate commerce.

The court of appeals affirmed. In holding that the statute does not violate the Commerce Clause, the court reasoned that it has neither a discriminatory purpose nor a discriminatory effect. It gives no benefit to Ohio ethanol producers that is not equally available to an out-of-state producer as long as that state provides incentives to all ethanol producers, including Ohio, on an equal basis. The court stressed that the statute effectuates the legitimate state purpose of encouraging the production of an environmentally benigh fuel additive as a replacement for lead, a notorious pollutant. The statute does not constitute an outright ban on plaintiff's ethanol in Ohio, nor does it preclude plaintiff from doing business in Ohio. It gives no direct competitive advantage to Ohio producers. It does not tax the use or sale of ethanol [*3] differently depending on whether it was produced in our out of Ohio. In sum, the statute does not impermissibly impose an oppressive burden on the industry and business of other states in order to enhance the vitality of domestic commerce.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant manufacturer challenged a decision from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's determination that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5735.145(B), which limited tax credits for fuel containing out-of-state ethanol, did not violate the Commerce Clause.


OVERVIEW: The manufacturer, which was located in Indiana, produced and sold ethanol. It challenged § 5735.145(B), which limited the tax credit eligibility for fuel containing ethanol produced outside of Ohio. The trial court determined that § 5735.145(B) did not impose an undue burden on interstate commerce. After the decision was affirmed, the manufacturer sought review. In reversing, the court determined that the manufacturer had standing to challenge the statute, despite the fact that it did not pay taxes in Ohio. The manufacturer was asserting its right to engage in interstate commerce. Moreover, the statute had an adverse competitive impact on its business. The court held that § 5735.145(B) was unconstitutional. The statute presented local business with a direct commercial advantage. The statute made it impossible for the manufacturer to makes sales in Ohio. Ohio's interest in encouraging the use of ethanol was outweighed by the burden that the statute imposed on interstate commerce. In addition, the essential attribute of even-handed treatment was not present in § 5735.145(B). Finally, the forced reciprocity portion of the statute also violated the Commerce Clause.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's decision, which determined that a statute limiting tax credits for fuel containing out-of-state ethanol did not violate the Commerce Clause.

 

99 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


South Euclid v. Jemison


No. 85-1911


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 3d 157; 503 N.E.2d 136; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 816; 28 Ohio B. Rep. 250



December 26, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Defendant-appellee, Jeffrey Jemison, was arrested and charged with speeding in violation of an ordinance of plaintiff-appellant, city of South Euclid. On November 21, 1984, defendant appeared before the South Euclid Municipal Court and was found guilty as charged.

The court, as part of the sentencing procedure under R.C. 4509.101, required defendant to provide proof that he was "financially responsible" at the time he committed the speeding violation. Since defendant was unable to make such a showing, the trial court suspended his driver's license and impounded his certificate of registration and registration plates under the procedure delineated in R.C. 4509.101.

Upon appeal, the court of appeals reversed and remanded, holding that R.C. 4509.101 violates Section 1, Article IV of the Ohio Constitution, and is in direct conflict with the constitutional doctrine of separation of powers. The appellate court reasoned that two provisions of the statute ( R.C. 4509.101[B][3][a] and [D]) are unconstitutional because they confer appellate powers of review to the Registrar of Motor Vehicles subsequent to a court-ordered [***2] license suspension. The court further held another section ( R.C. 4509.101[B][2][b]) to be constitutionally infirm on the grounds that it requires the court and its clerk to act as agents of the Registrar of Motor Vehicles.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The City of South Euclid challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4509.101(B)(3)(a), (D), and Ohio Rev. Code § 4509.101(B)(2)(b) were unconstitutional under the doctrine of separation of powers.


OVERVIEW: After violating an ordinance prohibiting speeding, the trial court required the driver to provide proof that he was "financially responsible" at the time of the violation. When the driver was unable to make such a showing, the trial court suspended his driver's license and impounded his certificate of registration and registration plates pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101. The court of appeals reversed, holding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4509.101(B)(3)(a), (D) were unconstitutional because they conferred appellate powers of review to the Registrar of Motor Vehicles subsequent to a court-ordered license suspension, and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101(B)(2)(b) was unconstitutional because it required the court and its clerk to act as agents of the Registrar of Motor Vehicles. On appeal, the court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals as to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 4509.101(B)(3)(a), (D). The court reversed the judgment as to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4509.101(B)(2)(b), holding that the provision was not unconstitutional because it merely promoted cooperation between the clerk of courts and the Registrar of Motor Vehicle in enforcing the financial responsibility law.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court, with the exception that the court found that the provision that promoted cooperation between clerk of courts and the Registrar of Motor Vehicle in enforcing the financial responsibility law was not unconstitutional.

 

100 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State Personnel Bd. of Review v. Bay Village Civil Service Com.


No. 86-388


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 3d 214; 503 N.E.2d 518; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 825; 28 Ohio B. Rep. 298



December 26, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

Appellant, State Personnel Board of Review, hereinafter "board," had received separate requests to investigate the civil service commissions of the cities of Bay Village, Cleveland and Lyndhurst because of alleged failures to comply with the duties imposed by law upon them. When the cities responded to the board's inquiry into these allegations by contending that the board had no jurisdiction to investigate the action of charter municipalities' civil service commissions, the board filed this declaratory judgment action. The trial court found that the board lacked authority to investigate the civil service commissions of these charter municipalities or to investigate the Bay Village Civil Service Commission with respect to city school district employees. The court of appeals affirmed on the basis that the establishment and regulation of municipal civil service commissions are purely matters of local self-government as to which charter provisions prevail over conflicting state statutes. 

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant State Personnel Board of Review (board) filed an action seeking a declaration that it had the authority to investigate respondent civil service commissions. The appellate court (Ohio) affirmed the trial court's decision that the board lacked authority to investigate the civil service commission with respect to city school district employees. The board challenged the appellate court's decision.


OVERVIEW: The court held that the sole issue before it was whether a state agency had investigative and removal authority over a municipal civil service commission when the charter of the municipality provided for local investigation, notice and hearing prior to removal of its commissioners. The court held that the state agency did not have such authority. The court found that the municipalities' charter provisions regulating the procedures for selection and removal of their civil service commissioners, were sufficiently confined to the internal affairs of these municipalities as to be immune from conflicting state regulations under the Home Rule Amendment. Moreover, the court held that the General Assembly had the authority to enact such laws, applicable to the cities, only where and to the extent that such laws would not restrict the exercise by such cities of their powers of local self-government. However, the court did not find Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.40(A) to be unconstitutional as violative of Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's decision entering judgment against the board.

 

101 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Mominee v. Scherbarth


Nos. 85-688 and 85-1039


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 3d 270; 503 N.E.2d 717; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 833; 28 Ohio B. Rep. 346



December 22, 1986, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: The case of Ream v.. MacPherson, case No. 85-1237, which was previously consolidated with case No. 85-688, is decided today by separate entry. See infra at 304.


PRIOR HISTORY: CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The plaintiffs 1 in these appeals, consolidated sua sponte, challenge the constitutionality of the medical malpractice statute of limitations, R.C. 2305.11(B), 2 as it applies to minors. While the statutes of limitations applicable to other claims by a minor are tolled until the child reaches the age of majority, see R.C. 2305.16, 3 any minor with a claim for medical malpractice is subject to the same limitations period as an adult. In each of the suits below, plaintiffs filed a malpractice claim after the expiration of the "adult" limitations period, but before the injured minor had reached age eighteen. All the trial courts ruled that plaintiffs were barred from suing by R.C. 2305.11. The courts therefore summarily disposed of the cases, either by entering a summary judgment for defendants or by dismissing the complaint pursuant to Civ. R. 12(B)(6).  [***2]


1 To avoid the confusion caused by the consolidated appeal, the parties will be referred to by their designations at the trial level.


2 R.C. 2305.11 provides in pertinent part: "(A) An action for * * * malpractice, including an action for malpractice against a physician, podiatrist, hospital, or dentist, * * * shall be brought within one year after the cause thereof accrued * * *. "If a written notice, prior to the expiration of time contained in this division, is given to any person in a medical claim that an individual is presently considering bringing an action against that person relating to professional services provided to that individual, then an action by that individual against that person may be commenced at any time within one hundred eighty days after that notice is given. "(B) In no event shall any medical claim against a physician, podiatrist, or a hospital or a dental claim against a dentist be brought more than four years after the act or omission constituting the alleged malpractice occurred. The limitations in this section for filing such a malpractice action against a physician, podiatrist, hospital or dentist apply to all persons regardless of legal disability and notwithstanding section 2305.16 of the Revised Code, provided that a minor who has not attained his tenth birthday shall have until his fourteenth birthday in which to file an action for malpractice against a physician or hospital." (Emphasis added.) We held the emphasized language unconstitutional in Schwan v.. Riverside Methodist Hospital (1983), 6 Ohio St. 3d 300. See discussion infra.


3 R.C. 2305.16 provides in pertinent part: "Unless otherwise specially provided in sections 2305.04 to 2305.14, inclusive, and sections 1302.98 and 1304.29 of the Revised Code, if a person entitled to bring any action mentioned in such sections, unless for penalty or forfeiture, is, at the time the cause of action accrues, within the age of minority, of sound mind, or imprisoned, such person may bring it within the respective times limited by such sections, after such disability is removed. * * *"

 [***3] All the cases were appealed to the court of appeals. In the first three of these cases, Mominee v.. Scherbarth, Gregory v.. Armstrong and Jordan v.. Maumee Valley Hospital, the Court of Appeals for Lucas County, in a consolidated opinion, reversed the trial courts' judgments. The appellate court held that R.C. 2305.11 is unconstitutional as applied to minors because it violates the due course of law provision of the Ohio Constitution, Section 16, Article I. In the remaining case, Wainstein v.. University Hospitals, the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County affirmed the lower court's dismissal.

The cause is now before this court upon the certifications of conflict between the courts of appeals.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed in case No. 85-688. 

Judgment reversed in case No. 85-1039. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Review was granted by the court upon the certification of conflicts between the courts of appeals. Plaintiff minors commenced malpractice actions against defendant health care providers. The Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio) held that the applicable statute of limitations, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(B), was unconstitutional. The Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County reached a contrary conclusion.


OVERVIEW: Under § 2305.11(B), a medical malpractice claim had to be brought within one year from the date that the cause of action accrued, or within four years from the date of the alleged malpractice. Furthermore, only the claims of minors under the age of 10 were tolled and then only until they reached the age of 14, at which time they had to file their action. That court held that § 2305.11(B) was unconstitutional with regard to minors. Under Ohio law, a legislative enactment was valid for purposes of due process if it bore a real and substantial relation to the public health, safety, morals or general welfare of the public and was not unreasonable or arbitrary. Moreover, the scope of due process included access to the courts for all injured persons. Given that minors lacked standing to sue prior to the age of majority, § 2305.11(B) effectively prevented such access. The mere fact that a parent was permitted to sue in behalf of a minor child was not sufficient. In that regard, the court noted that it was unrealistic to expect that children would willingly seek redress against their parents for their failure to timely commence malpractice actions in their behalf.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County. The judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County was reversed. The cases were remanded to the respective trial courts for further proceedings in accordance with the court's opinion.

 

102 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Moss v. Ulmer


No. 86-125


Supreme Court of Ohio


27 Ohio St. 3d 37; 500 N.E.2d 1376; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 780; 27 Ohio B. Rep. 452



November 26, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On February 1, 1984, appellees, Nannie O. Moss and George W. Kelley, obtained a judgment against Lewis Ulmer, Sr., d.b.a. Lou Ulmer Realty, and Helen Ulmer, his wife (hereinafter "Ulmer"). The judgment was in the amount of $ 3,105.40 in compensatory damages and $ 10,000 in punitive damages. Appellees were unable to collect this judgment from Ulmer, and therefore, on August 1, 1984, they filed application for an order directing payment out of the Ohio Real Estate Recovery Special Account (hereinafter "special account") in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County pursuant to R.C. 4735.12.

The parties reached a compromise settlement regarding the compensatory damages portion of appellees' judgment and, on December 10, 1984, the trial court journalized two entries, one of which ordered appellant, Charles Santer, Superintendent of the Ohio Division of Real Estate, to pay appellees the sum of $ 2,505.40, plus interest from the special account, which represented the balance of compensatory damages due. The other entry ordered the superintendent to pay appellees the sum of $ 10,000, plus interest, from the special account [***2] which represented the punitive damages portion of the judgment against Ulmer.

The superintendent appealed the trial court's order, challenging the award of punitive damages from the special account.

The court of appeals affirmed the trial court and finding its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Fayette County in Bailey v.. Gilbert (1985), 27 Ohio App.3d 11, certified the record of the cause to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a real estate agent and a realty company, sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which awarded compensatory and punitive damages in favor of appellee clients. Because the clients were unable to collect the judgment from the agent, they filed an application for an order directing payment out of the Ohio Real Estate Recovery Special Account for all damages, which the trial court allowed.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, appellants argued that the trial court acted improperly in allowing the clients to recover punitive damages from the special account. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4735.12 previously prohibited the payment of punitive damages from the special account; however, § 4735.12 was amended to preclude the payment of punitive damages from the special account. This amendment occurred after the clients filed their action, but before they attempted to collect on the judgment from the agent. The clients asserted that applying the amendment to bar the payment of punitive damages would have constituted an unconstitutionally retroactive application of the law in violation of Ohio Const. art. II, § 28. The court held that the amendment applied to the action, precluding the payment of the punitive damages award from the special account. The claim against the special account did not arise when the action was filed, but after the first judgment was obtained and the clients' efforts at collection of that judgment were unsuccessful.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and remanded the matter to the trial court with instructions to amend the judgment to preclude the payment of punitive damages.

 

103 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Meadows


No. 86-233


Supreme Court of Ohio


28 Ohio St. 3d 43; 28 Ohio St. 3d 354; 503 N.E.2d 697; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 793; 28 Ohio B. Rep. 146



October 7, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Appellee, John Meadows, resided in a Cincinnati hotel. On October 23, 1984, police officers executed a search warrant and found in appellee's room a picture and various magazines which depicted children engaged in sexual activity. Meadows was then arrested and charged with pandering sexually oriented matter involving a minor in violation of R.C. 2907.322(A)(5). 1 


1 Ohio's statute prohibiting pandering sexually oriented material involving a minor, R.C. 2907.322, which became effective on September 27, 1984, provides as follows: "(A) No person, with knowledge of the character of the material or performance involved, shall do any of the following: "(1) Create, reproduce, or publish any material that shows a minor participating or engaging in sexual activity, masturbation, or bestiality; "(2) Exhibit or advertise for sale or dissemination, sell, disseminate, or display any material that shows a minor participating or engaging in sexual activity, masturbation, or bestiality; "(3) Create, direct, or produce a performance that shows a minor participating or engaging in sexual activity, masturbation, or bestiality; "(4) Advertise for presentation, present, or participate in presenting a performance that shows a minor participating or engaging in sexual activity, masturbation, or bestiality; "(5) Possess or control any material that shows a minor participating or engaging in sexual activity, masturbation, or bestiality; "(6) Bring or cause to be brought into this state any material that shows a minor participating or engaging in sexual activity, masturbation, or bestiality. "(B) This section does not apply to any material or performance that is sold, disseminated, displayed, possessed, controlled, brought or caused to be brought into this state, or presented for a bona fide medical, scientific, educational, religious, governmental, judicial, or other proper purpose, by or to a physician, psychologist, sociologist, scientist, teacher, person pursuing bona fide studies or research, librarian, clergyman, prosecutor, judge, or other person having a proper interest in the material or performance. "(C) Whoever violates this section is guilty of pandering sexually oriented matter involving a minor. Violation of division (A)(1), (2), (3), (4), or (6) of this section is a felony of the second degree. Violation of division (A)(5) of this section is a misdemeanor of the first degree. If the offender previously has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to a violation of division (A)(5) of this section, pandering sexually oriented matter involving a minor is a felony of the fourth degree." (Emphasis added to challenged provisions.)

 [***2] Appellee first raised a constitutional challenge to the statute before the trial court in a motion to dismiss. Appellee contended that the statute, to the extent division (A)(5) thereof punishes the mere private possession of sexually oriented material involving a minor participating or engaging in sexual activity, masturbation, or bestiality, was unconstitutional under the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the federal Constitution. The trial court denied appellee's motion to dismiss. Thereafter, Meadows was found guilty on his plea of no contest.

On appeal, the court of appeals, in a split decision, reversed. The majority of the three-judge panel reasoned that, upon the authority of Stanley v.. Georgia (1969), 394 U.S. 557, the state could not constitutionally criminalize the mere private possession of obscene matter. Concluding that child pornography fell unequivocally within the Stanley holding, the appeals court stated it was bound to follow the Supreme Court's mandate and discharged Meadows. 2 


2 A contrary result was reached by the Franklin County Municipal Court in in State v.. Stover (1985), 25 OBR 349. In upholding the constitutionality of this statutory scheme, the Stover court found that "the State of Ohio has a compelling interest in the protection of children from the pernicious effects of being solicited or procured, abused or exploited for purposes of child pornography and that by imposing sanctions on the possession of these materials, even in the privacy of one's home, the state is using a reasonable means to protect that interest. The state's compelling interest in the protection of its children overrides defendant's right of privacy and to possess child pornography." Id. at 351.

 [***3] The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought review of the order of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County, Ohio that reversed appellee pornography possessor's conviction and held that the state could not constitutionally criminalize the mere private possession of obscene matter containing child pornography.


OVERVIEW: Appellee pornography possessor was convicted under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.322, for illegally possessing materials containing child pornography. On appeal of his conviction, the appellate court held that the state could not constitutionally criminalize the mere private possession of obscene matter containing child pornography, and the statute that appellee was convicted under was unconstitutional. The state appealed, and the court reversed the judgment. On appeal, the court held that the state had a legitimate interest in attempting to ban such materials, and that the value of permitting possession of photographic reproductions of children engaged in lewd sexual conduct was exceedingly modest, if not de minimis. The court concluded that the competing public policy and constitutional concerns tilted decidedly in favor of sustaining the statute. Finally, the court held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann § 2907.322(A)(5), which prohibited the knowing possession or control of material which showed a minor participating or engaging in sexual activity, masturbation, or bestiality, did not violate U.S. Const. amend. I.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate judgment in favor of appellee pornography possessor, because the statute banning the private possession of child pornography materials was not violative of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution.

 

104 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Kettering v. State Employment Relations Bd.


No. 85-1459


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 3d 50; 496 N.E.2d 983; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 747; 26 Ohio B. Rep. 42



August 20, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

This appeal arises from a complaint filed by the city of Kettering on April 23, 1984, seeking a declaratory judgment that R.C. 4117.01(F)(2) is unconstitutional. 

In 1970, Kettering adopted Resolution No. 2017-70, setting forth its collective bargaining policy regarding municipal employees. That resolution, later codified as Ordinance No. 3106-84, excluded from collective bargaining units all supervisory employees or those who formulate personnel policy. Pursuant to the resolution the city has, since 1970, declined to recognize or bargain with any employee organization representing police sergeants, lieutenants or captains.

On April 1, 1984 Ohio's new Public Employees Collective Bargaining Act, R.C. 4117.01 et seq., became effective. As pertinent to this appeal, R.C. 4117.01(C)(10) excludes supervisors from the Act's coverage. However, R.C. 4117.01(F)(2) specifically provides as follows:

"With respect to members of a police or fire department, no person shall be deemed a supervisor except the chief of the department or those individuals who, in the absence of the chief, are authorized to exercise the authority [***2] and perform the duties of the chief of the department * * *."

Also on April 1, 1984, Teamsters Local No. 740 filed a petition with the State Employment Relations Board pursuant to R.C. 4117.07 seeking certification as the exclusive bargaining representative of Kettering's police sergeants, lieutenants and captains. Shortly thereafter, Kettering filed its complaint requesting the declaratory judgment and seeking an injunction to prevent recognition of and collective bargaining with representatives of its police command officers.

The parties filed motions for summary judgment in October 1984. The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the appellees on the basis that the General Assembly's exercise of its police power on a matter of statewide concern in enacting R.C. Chapter 4117 prevailed over the city's ordinance. This determination was affirmed by the court of appeals.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city challenged the judgement Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which affirmed the summary judgment granted appellee union in the city's lawsuit seeking to declare Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.01(F)(2), which exempted all police and fire supervisors (with the exception of department chiefs or acting chiefs) from the state's Public Employees Collective Bargaining Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.01 et seq., unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The city contended that the management of its police department was a power of local self-government with which the state could not interfere pursuant to Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3, that membership in a union would lead to divided loyalty among police command officers, reducing the city's ability to control and manage the department, and that it should be free to exclude police command officers from the Public Employees Bargaining Act (Act), Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.01 et seq., in the name of municipal home rule powers. The city's position was rejected by the court who concluded that the city failed to overcome the presumption of the Act's constitutionality because the city failed to demonstrate that requiring it to bargain collectively with its police command officers would work an unconstitutional interference with its local self-government power to manage its police department. Further, the state general assembly, after experiencing public employee labor strife with one city, properly exercised its constitutional police power to promote the general safety and welfare in enacting the measure, to which the city's police powers were subordinated.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment below.

 

105 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


East Ohio Gas Co. v. Limbach


No. 85-1706


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 3d 63; 498 N.E.2d 453; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 748; 26 Ohio B. Rep. 54



August 20, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

The instant appeal arises from a complaint filed by appellant, East Ohio Gas Company, seeking a declaratory judgment that Sections 6 and 29 of Am. Sub. H.B. No. 100 were unconstitutionally retroactive in violation of Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution. 

Prior to the enactment of Am. Sub. H.B. No. 100, East Ohio Gas was operating under an order of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio dated August 4, 1982 authorizing a 12.57 percent rate of return. East Ohio Gas was also subject to the statutory annual excise tax on gross receipts imposed upon public utilities pursuant to R.C. 5727.38. At the time the rate order became final, the excise tax rate was 3.85 percent. R.C. 4909.161, which provided that the payment of an increased tax levy could be recovered in the utility's rates, was also effective.

Am. Sub. H.B. No. 100 became effective February 24, 1983. (140 Ohio Laws, Part I, 1855.) Section 6 of that bill increased the annual excise tax rate to 4.35 percent for the 1983 tax year which, for natural gas companies, encompassed the period from May 1, 1982 to April 30, 1983. 1 Section 29 of the bill further [***2] provided that notwithstanding R.C. 4909.161, payment of the increased excise tax could not be recovered by a public utility. 2 


1 Section 6 of Am. Sub. H.B. No. 100 provides in pertinent part: "Notwithstanding section 5727.38 of the Revised Code, the rate of tax to be charged on the annual excise tax statements required to be filed on or before the first day of August of 1983, shall be four and thirty-five hundredths per cent of the gross receipts. The amount of tax shall not be less than ten dollars in any case." (140 Ohio Laws, Part I, at 1925.)


2 Section 29 of Am. Sub. H.B. No. 100 provides as follows: "Notwithstanding section 4909.161 of the Revised Code, the increased excise tax levy imposed by the amendments made by Section 6 of this act shall not be recoverable by a public utility in its rates." (140 Ohio Laws, Part I, at 1936.)

East Ohio Gas contended that as a result of the enactment of the bill, its tax liability for the 1983 tax year was increased by nearly $ 6.5 million which could not be recovered [***3] in its rates but rather was exacted from the utility's owners, thus reducing its rate of return.

The trial court found in favor of the company, ordered the appellees, Tax Commissioner et al., to make refund to the company and entered judgment as follows:

"1. Insofar as it increased the rate of the tax imposed upon plaintiff's taxable gross receipts actually received prior to February 24, 1983, Section 6 of House Bill [sic] 100 is unconstitutional as a retroactive law in violation of Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution. 

"2. Insofar as it suspends the operation of Ohio Rev. Code § 4909.161 as applied to the plaintiff for its 1983 excise tax liability, Section 29 of House Bill [sic] No. 100 is void as a retroactive law in violation of Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution."

The court of appeals reversed. It held that Section 6 of the bill was not unconstitutionally retroactive because the twelve-month period for ascertaining gross receipts had not closed at the time the tax increase became effective. The appellate court also reasoned that Section 29 did not retroactively suspend operation of R.C. 4909.161 because the section affected [***4] only payments of an increased levy made after the effective date of the bill.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of appellant's motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant gas company sought review of an order from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which, in an action for declaratory to declare that Am. Sub. H.B. 100, § 6, 29 (Ohio 1983) were unconstitutionally retroactive in violation of Ohio Const. art. II, § 28, reversed the trial court and held that § 6 was not unconstitutionally retroactive and that § 29 did not retroactively suspend operation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4904.161.


OVERVIEW: The gas company claimed that in calculating its expenses as part of the ratemaking process, it reasonably relied to its detriment on the assurance contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4909.161 that it could recover any increased tax liability. The gas company contended that pursuant to Ohio Const. art. II, § 28, the general assembly was estopped from retroactively altering the law upon which the company relied at the time its rate of return was fixed. On appeal the court held that where an excise tax on the privilege of doing business was measured by the gross receipts from the operation of a business for an annual period, the tax rate could constitutionally be increased at a time prior to the end of that annual period. The court noted that the gas company's excise tax liability was calculable and payable only after its tax year had concluded. It was not until an accounting year was closed that a taxpayer was closed that a taxpayer was entitled to consider that its income or gross receipts was finally its own.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

106 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Scott


No. 85-1209


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 3d 92; 497 N.E.2d 55; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 753; 26 Ohio B. Rep. 79



August 20, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On May 6, 1983, Vinnie M. Prince, owner and operator of the V & E Delicatessen at East 86 Street and Quincy Avenue in Cleveland, was shot and killed during an attempted armed robbery of her establishment. An autopsy later revealed that the victim died from a gunshot wound of the chest. Octavia Hickman, a nearby resident, testified that while walking back to her home after shopping at the Sav-more Market, she noticed a greenish-blue Cadillac without a rear license plate pull up across from her house. She observed two black males inside the car; one behind the wheel and the other in the back seat. She later observed another black male come over a nearby fence and dive through the open window of the Cadillac. The car then drove away.

Another witness near the delicatessen when the incident occurred was Clifford Roberson. Roberson was heading toward the store with a female companion when a shot was heard from inside the store. He immediately grabbed his friend and pushed her up against the wall of the building, in an apparent effort to protect her. When he heard a screen door slam, he turned around and saw two black males [***2] running from the store. Roberson testified that the taller man was about five feet eleven inches tall wearing "some type of rag around his head" and was holding a long-barreled pistol.

Upon opening the store's door, Roberson observed Prince lying "almost to the door as if she was trying to chase them or something." Roberson proceeded to flag down a nearby police car and informed the officers therein of the situation.

Another witness to this incident, Solomon Smith, testified he saw "two men run across the street, and run down to the corner of Mr. Cooper's house, and turn through the alley, and jump the fence." He described these assailants as two black males, one 5'10 1/2" tall, the other "a little shorter." Smith did not observe anything in either of the suspects' hands.

Sometime after this incident, Detective Robert Moore received a telephone call from Ricky Tramble and a meeting between them was arranged. As a result, Moore began looking for the Cadillac used in the crime, and several suspects. Tramble testified at trial that he informed the detective that on the day Vinnie Prince was killed, he was with Edward O'Neal, Michael Streeter, Danny Jones and appellant, Jay D.  [***3] Scott, at O'Neal's girlfriend's house "[t]o get high." Tramble stated that he had overheard appellant say, "Well, I did what I had to do. She shouldn't have made me move like that. Fuck it. It's over with." Later that day, appellant told Tramble, "[t]hese niggers don't know what they're doing. * * * [T]hey get to crying about this and crying about that. This is what I do." Appellant professed to be "a stick-up man." Tramble related that O'Neal had informed him the next day of their involvement in the V & E Delicatessen incident, including the shooting of Prince.

Pursuant to this information, Danny Jones was subsequently apprehended and arrested. Jones' automobile, an older model, blue, turquoise bottom Cadillac with a white top and no license plate, but with a thirty-day tag, was also confiscated at this time. Jones signed a typewritten statement wherein he related to the police that he and Edward O'Neal, Michael Streeter, and Jay D. Scott were driving around looking for a place to rob. After selecting the V & E Delicatessen as a target, appellant requested "front money" in order to fabricate a purchase and wanted someone to go into the store with him. O'Neal finally [***4] agreed to accompany appellant into the store. At this time appellant was observed armed with a .38 caliber pistol that looked like a police revolver and O'Neal was armed with a .25 caliber automatic handgun. Jones then pulled his car around the corner. O'Neal and Scott got out of the car and Jones and Streeter waited for them there. Later, appellant and O'Neal came running through a yard and climbed over a fence. O'Neal ran to the car and got in and appellant dove into the car through a window. Jones was told to "pull off." Later, Jones asked O'Neal what had happened and was told "that J.D. shot her * * * cause she went for her shit (her gun)." When Jones asked appellant if he had killed her, appellant replied, "naw she was still standing up when he ran out the door." At trial, Jones repudiated that part of his typewritten statement wherein he acknowledged their intent to rob the V & E Delicatessen. Instead, Jones contended that appellant and O'Neal had gone into the store to get cold beer.

The police subsequently apprehended Edward O'Neal who also gave a typewritten statement to the police. Therein, O'Neal stated that he, Danny Jones, Michael Streeter, and appellant were [***5] driving around in Jones' Cadillac. They stopped in front of the V & E Delicatessen because appellant told them that he wanted to get some bologna and crackers. O'Neal followed appellant into the store. Appellant asked for bologna and crackers and when the old woman minding the store prepared them, appellant pulled out a pistol. Appellant told the woman to "freeze" and when the woman began to "holler" and "yell" appellant fired a single shot at the decedent, striking her. O'Neal related that he was momentarily stunned by this occurrence and it wasn't until appellant grabbed him and pulled him out of the store that he began to run. They jumped a fence and ran to the car. O'Neal stated that he did not observe the victim reach for a weapon.

At trial, O'Neal's testimony differed from this statement in that it was he who ordered the bologna and crackers at the store. In addition, O'Neal asserted that he was unarmed throughout this ordeal and that Michael Streeter had the .25 caliber weapon in his possession while waiting in the car. Lastly, O'Neal confirmed that he had talked with Ricky Tramble about what had transpired at the V & E Delicatessen.

Barbara Campbell, a trace-evidence [***6] analyst with the Cuyahoga County Coroner's office, testified that pursuant to the Walker Nitrate Test, the muzzle of the gun which killed Vinnie Prince was estimated to have been twelve inches from her body when it was fired. She further testified that a trace metal test conducted on the victim's hands indicated that she did not handle or fire a weapon prior to her death. However, Detective David Hicks testified that Prince had a fully loaded .38 caliber revolver on her person when she was found.

On May 17, 1983, the grand jury charged appellant with aggravated murder with an aggravated robbery specification and a firearm specification and aggravated robbery. Also charged in the same indictments were co-defendants Danny Jones, Edward O'Neal and Michael Streeter.

On November 10, 1983, appellant was apprehended in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania by Detective James Svekric of the Cleveland Police Department. During the trip back to Cleveland, appellant inquired who was using his name in connection with a homicide and robbery. Up to this point, the arresting officers had informed appellant that he was wanted in connection with a homicide, but made no mention of the fact that appellant [***7] was also charged with aggravated robbery. Appellant maintained that he had been in Reading, Pennsylvania when the incident occurred.

On November 23, 1983, appellant entered a plea of not guilty at his arraignment March 23, 1984, after a trial by jury, appellant was found guilty as to all counts and specifications. On March 28, 1984, the jury recommended the sentence of death. On April 4, 1984, Judge Joseph McManamon accepted the jury's recommendation and ordered that appellant be put to death on July 11, 1984.

Appellant filed a timely appeal to the court of appeals on May 4, 1984. On June 3, 1985, the appellate court affirmed the trial court's judgment of conviction and sentence.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The trial court convicted defendant of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery. As a result, the trial court imposed the death sentence. On appeal, the Court of Appeals of Cuyahoga County (Ohio) affirmed the conviction and sentence. The appeal followed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant shot victim, the owner and operator of a neighborhood delicatessen, during the course of a robbery. The trial court convicted defendant of aggravated murder and aggravated robbery and imposed the death sentence. On review, the intermediate appellate court affirmed the judgments of conviction and sentence. Defendant filed an appeal. In affirming, the court found no error in the trial court's refusal to declare a mistrial as a result of the trial judge's allegedly prejudicial comments. The court explained that the remark at issue, when analyzed in light of the circumstances under which it was made, did not cast an aspersion upon defendant's innocence. Additionally, the court held that the trial court did not err in excluding prospective jurors who expressed some opposition to the imposition of the death penalty. The court found no error in the court's jury instructions, or in the trial court's refusal to administer the jury instruction requested by defense counsel on the credibility of testimony of addict-informers, informer co-defendants, and accomplices. The court found that the evidence was sufficient to support the judgments of conviction, as well as the death penalty.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction.

 

107 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Deskins v. Young


No. 85-1778


Supreme Court of Ohio


26 Ohio St. 3d 8; 496 N.E.2d 897; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 744; 26 Ohio B. Rep. 7



August 13, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This appeal arises from a medical malpractice claim filed by appellant, Jean H. Deskins, against appellee, Robert E. S. Young, M.D. The complaint alleged that on or about June 22, 1971, appellant underwent an operation, performed by appellee, to remove her gallbladder. Twelve years later, on or about June 3, 1983, appellant underwent a second surgery. At this time it was discovered that the first surgery was not complete. A remant of appellant's gallbladder was removed. Appellant averred in response to appellee's motion for summary judgment that she could not have discovered and did not discover that the first surgery was incomplete until she was so advised on the date of her second surgery. Appellee admits to receiving timely written notice from appellant that she was contemplating an action against him, thus extending the statute of limitations by one-hundred-eighty days pursuant to R.C. 2305.11(A). Appellant filed her claim against appellee on November 21, 1984.

The trial court granted summary judgment to appellee on the ground that appellant's action was time-barred by the four-year limitation period [***2] contained in R.C. 2305.11(B). The court of appeals affirmed the application of the four-year bar to appellant's claim and further held that the statute was not unconstitutional. 

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant patient challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County, which affirmed the trial court which granted summary judgment to appellee doctor on the ground that patient's action was time-barred by the limitation period contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(B). Patient had surgery to remove her gallbladder and 12 years later had another surgery where she was notified that part of her gallbladder had been left.


OVERVIEW: Patient underwent surgery for the removal of her gallbladder and 12 years discovered that a portion of her gallbladder had been left behind during the surgery to remove that organ. The court held that the alleged malpractice and injury reasonably remained undiscovered more than four years after the act or omission constituting the alleged malpractice occurred.
