The court held that § 2305.11(B) would not operate to bar patient's claim because it would totally eliminate patient's substantive right in her cause of action without affording her a reasonable time within which to enforce that right. The court held that patient was afforded a reasonable time within which to bring her claim, one year after the discovery of the alleged malpractice. The court held that patient's claim was thus timely filed in accordance with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(A).


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded for further proceedings, holding that patient was entitled to a one year period after discovery of the alleged malpractice to file a claim, which patient did.

 

108 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Egan v. National Distillers & Chemical Corp.


No. 85-699


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 3d 176; 495 N.E.2d 904; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 718; 25 Ohio B. Rep. 243



July 30, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Appellee Leroy F. Egan was employed by appellant National Distillers & Chemical Corporation, d.b.a. Emery Industries ("National Distillers"), at its chemical manufacturing and processing plant in Cincinnati, Ohio. A chemical explosion occurred on February 18, 1982 at the plant and appellee was severely injured. Four days later an application for workers' compensation benefits was filed on behalf of Egan. The application was not contested by appellant which, as a self-insured employer, had paid the maximum workers' compensation benefits together with medical expenses. In March 1983, appellee sought additional benefits for, inter alia, post-traumatic neurosis. These benefits were also awarded.

Approximately one year after the explosion, Leroy and Catherine S. Egan, appellees herein, filed a nine-count complaint against appellant. The complaint essentially claims that Leroy's injuries resulted from intentional tort(s) committed by National Distillers. 1 


1 We note that neither the sufficiency of the allegations contained in the complaint nor the question of whether National Distiller's acts constituted an intentional tort is before this court. Rather, solely at issue in this review is whether the appellate court correctly reversed the trial court's grant of summary judgment.

 [***2] Thereafter, the trial court granted appellant's motion for summary judgment. The trial court recognized that a complying employer is not entitled to the immunity of R.C. 4123.74 if an employee's injury is caused by the employer's intentional conduct. However, the motion for summary judgment was nevertheless granted in favor of National Distillers. The trial court essentially reasoned that under the doctrine of election of remedies, Leroy's receipt of workers' compensation payments estopped him from also maintaining a civil suit.

On appeal, the court of appeals, relying on the decision in Jones v.. VIP Development Co. (1984), 15 Ohio St. 3d 90, reversed the trial court and remanded the cause for further proceedings. The appellate court reasoned that the "doctrine of estoppel" was not applicable to an employee's common-law action for damages against his employer for an intentional tort. The court of appeals also observed that "[i]t is immaterial whether the workers' compensation benefits are sought before, after or concurrently with the suit for common law damages."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION:  [***3] Judgment affirmed and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employer sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which overturned a grant of summary judgment in its favor in appellee employee's personal injury suit.


OVERVIEW: Employee had been severely injured in a chemical explosion at employer's plant. He applied for and received workers' compensation benefits. One year later, employee and his wife filed the instant suit, alleging that the injuries resulted from intentional torts committed by employer. The reviewing court found that the employer was not entitled to summary judgment. The reviewing court found that employer's argument that it was entitled to set off the amount of the workers' compensation award from any damages award was not ripe for review because no damages had yet been awarded. Additionally, employee was not precluded from filing the instant suit under the doctrine of estoppel. The reviewing court concluded that the receipt of workers' compensation benefits did not preclude an employee or his representative from pursuing a common-law action for damages against his employer for an intentional tort.


OUTCOME: The judgment was affirmed and the cause was remanded.

 

109 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Kalain v. Smith


No. 85-1417


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 3d 157; 495 N.E.2d 572; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 713; 25 Ohio B. Rep. 201



July 30, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

On April 2, 1980, appellee, Emilia Kalain, was a passenger in a van driven by her husband which was heading west on a two-lane highway. Appellant, Phyllis K. Smith, was driving a car that was heading in the same direction, in front of the Kalains' van. A truck separated Smith's car and the van. Kalain's husband began to pass the truck without sounding his horn to signal this intention. At the same time, Smith allegedly activated her turn signal, slowed down and began to make a left turn. The van and Smith's car collided.

Kalain filed suit against Smith in the Court of Common Pleas of Summit County. The case was later transferred to Montgomery County and was tried before a jury. The jury returned a $ 75,000 verdict for Kalain. Smith did not appeal from the verdict.

Subsequently, Kalain filed a motion under R.C. 1343.03(C) for prejudgment interest, alleging that Smith had failed to make a good faith effort to settle the case. At a hearing on this motion, Kalain's counsel testified that prior to trial he contacted Smith's counsel and proposed to settle the case for $ 70,000. This offer was later reduced to [***2] $ 65,000. Kalain's counsel testified that, although he advised Smith's counsel that Kalain was prepared to present testimony by an independent witness and by a State Highway Patrol officer that would substantiate Smith's liability, Smith's counsel responded that his client refused to pay "one single dime." During trial, Kalain's counsel offered to settle the case for $ 60,000. This offer was also rejected.

Kalain complained that Smith's counsel had never disclosed that he had authority from his client's insurer to settle the case for $ 2,500. In response, Smith's counsel and Harold Herrington, a claims superintendent from Smith's insurer, stated that the settlement authority was "contingent," i.e., Smith's counsel was not required to offer $ 2,500 as "nuisance" value unless Kalain's counsel substantially reduced the $ 70,000 settlement offer. Smith's counsel and the claims superintendent also testified that they believed Smith was neither negligent nor liable. Their assessment was supported by the following facts: (1) Mr. Kalain had attempted to pass two vehicles at one time; (2) he had failed to sound his horn as required by R.C. 4511.27; (3) the passengers in Smith's car [***3] would testify that her turn signal had been on for an "appreciable period of time"; and (4) Kalain's primary witness had stated in a statement to an insurance company that she had not noticed whether Smith's turn signal had been activated.

The trial judge granted the motion for prejudgment interest and assessed $ 24,801 against Smith, representing interest dating back to the day of the accident. Smith appealed, alleging that the court had erred as a matter of law in awarding prejudgment interest and that R.C. 1343.03(C) unconstitutionally deprived her of her right to a jury trial.

The court of appeals affirmed, holding the statute to be constitutional and the award justified. The court of appeals, finding its judgment to be in conflict with that of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County in Ware v.. Richey (1983), 14 Ohio App. 3d 3, with that of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County in Blitz v.. Art Iron, Inc. (Nov. 16, 1984), No. L-84-069, unreported, and with that of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County in Huffman v.. Hair Surgeon, Inc. (Aug. 22, 1984), No. C-830818, unreported, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final [***4] determination on the following issues:

(1) Whether R.C. 1343.03(C) can be retroactively applied to causes of action accruing before July 5, 1982.

(2) Whether a "good faith effort to settle" means the absence of bad faith.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: After appellee victim was awarded prejudgment interest under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1343.03(C) on a jury award in a personal injury action against appellant driver, the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio) affirmed, holding that § 1343.03(C) was constitutional and the award justified. The record of the case was then certified for review and determination on the question whether a good faith effort to settle meant the absence of bad faith.


OVERVIEW: The victim was injured when the driver's car collided with the van in which the victim was a passenger. A trial court jury awarded damages to the victim in her action against the driver, and no appeal was taken. The victim than filed a motion for prejudgment interest pursuant to § 1343.03(C), claiming that the driver failed to make a good faith effort to settle. The trial judge granted the motion, and the court of appeals affirmed. Subsequently, because of a conflict among the appellate courts, the court of appeals certified the case for review. The court held that because the driver had a reasonable good faith belief that he had no liability, he had no duty to make a monetary settlement offer pursuant to § 1343.03(C). Further, the record reflected that the driver cooperated fully in discovery and did not attempt to unnecessarily delay any of the proceedings. Thus, the trial court abused its discretion when it awarded prejudgment interest to the victim. Also, because the standard for a "good faith effort to settle" did not require parties in all cases to make monetary settlement offers, § 1343.03(C) did not infringe upon the driver's right to a jury trial.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals that affirmed a trial court order awarding the victim prejudgment interest.

 

110 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Middletown v. Ferguson


No. 85-996


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 3d 71; 495 N.E.2d 380; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 698; 25 Ohio B. Rep. 125



July 23, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Butler County.

This cause concerns a dispute arising from the Manchester Road project in the city of Middletown ("city"), appellee herein. As early as 1963, the city first considered the widening and improvement of Manchester Road as part of its master plan for development. The city intended to upgrade the road from two lanes to a four-lane divided highway. Appellants herein are abutting property owners who opposed the Manchester Road project.

In 1975, the Ohio-Kentucky-Indiana Regional Counsel of Governments, an organization responsible for distributing federal highway improvement funds, resolved that federal monies would be allocated to improve Manchester Road.

The city's next step was to pass the necessary legislation. In May 1977, the city commissioners passed emergency Resolution No. R77-19, officially instructing the administration to proceed with the Manchester Road project. Detailed plans for the road improvement project were drawn up and presented to the Ohio Department of Transportation ("ODOT"), which acted as contracting authority for the actual work and served as a conduit for federal funds.

ODOT did approve the project [***2] and thereafter, on May 2, 1978, the city commissioners passed emergency Ordinance No. 078-93 directing the city manager to enter into contracts with ODOT for the improvement project. The ordinance set forth the parties' contractual obligations. A certified copy of the ordinance was signed by a city representative on May 12, 1978 and by ODOT on June 2, 1978. As provided by the ordinance, the city agreed to bear the full cost of the project, less federal funds received, and to maintain the road after completion of the project. ODOT was to supervise construction of the improvement. The full text of this ordinance was published in the Middletown Journal.

At the time of passage of Ordinance No. 078-93, the estimated construction cost was $ 1,185,000. The city expected federal funds to cover about seventy percent of the costs of the project, while it would bear the remaining thirty percent. It has been stipulated by both parties to the instant case that "[f]rom the inception of the Project, the City planned to finance most of its share of the cost by special assessments to the benefiting owners of * * * private property bounding or abutting Manchester Road * * *."

On May 8,  [***3] 1979, pursuant to the passage of Ordinance No. 079-19, two public hearings on the road improvement project were held. It is stipulated that owners of twenty-seven of the affected properties, including all of the appellants herein, attended one or another of the hearings. Appellants and other citizens expressed safety concerns about increased traffic on Manchester Road and concerns about the proposed assessments. City officials explained the assessment process and responded to the safety concerns. The city then typed Summary Minutes and Recommendations from the meetings and mailed it to all affected property owners.

On January 20, 1981, the city commission adopted emergency Resolution No. R81-03, declaring the necessity to improve Manchester Road and stating that bonds should be issued in anticipation of the collection of assessments levied on affected property owners. A copy of this resolution was published in the Middletown Journal.

After enactment of the resolution, the city's director of public service prepared estimated assessments. Notice of the adoption of Resolution No. R81-03 and the estimated assessments were sent to all affected property owners. Five owners filed [***4] objections, which were resolved by the Assessment Equalization Board.

In March 1981, the city commission passed emergency Ordinance No. 081-44, stating its determination to proceed with the project and to levy the special assessments to pay the city's portion of the project's cost.

On June 9, 1981, several affected property owners filed with the clerk of the city commission a verified copy of an ordinance which they intended to make the subject of an initiative petition to be placed on the November ballot. The text of the proposed ordinance called for the repeal of "any and all further legislation" adopted by the city commissioners having reference to the widening and improvement of Manchester Road. The proposed ordinance also sought repeal of any and all commitments of the city of Middletown to the Manchester Road project.

While signatures for the initiative petition were being collected, on June 23, 1981, the city commission passed emergency Resolution No. R81-41 approving final plans for the project and appropriating approximately $ 330,000 from its general fund representing the city's share of the project cost. This sum was paid to ODOT by the city and a formal contract [***5] between the parties was executed concurrently with the passage of the resolution.

Pursuant to the contract, ODOT apparently let bids for the construction phase of the project. On July 27, 1981, ODOT awarded a contract for the construction to SK Construction Company. Construction on the project commenced.

Meanwhile, on July 24, 1981, the Butler County Board of Elections validated sufficient signatures to have the initiative ordinance placed on the November ballot. At the November 3, 1981 general election, the voters approved the initiative ordinance, thus repealing "any and all" Manchester Road enabling legislation and any and all commitments of the city to the project. At the time of passage of the initiative ordinance, construction on the road widening and improvement was nearly sixty percent complete.

Although the effect of the initiative ordinance would have been to halt further construction on the project, the city believed the ordinance to be an unconstitutional impairment of an obligation of a contract and allowed construction to continue. The project was completed by July 1, 1982.

On June 7, 1983, in conformance with previously passed enabling legislation, the city [***6] commission enacted ordinances levying the special assessments and providing for the issuance of bonds by the city to pay for its portion of the construction costs. The bonds were to be retired by funds generated from the anticipated collection of assessments.

At that point, the salability of the bonds became an issue in light of the initiative ordinance and its possible effect on the prerequisite enabling legislation for the levying of the assessments. The city then brought a bond validation action, pursuant to R.C. 133.71 et seq., to establish its authority to issue the bonds and to establish that all of its previous resolutions and ordinances relating to the Manchester Road project were lawful and enforceable. Appellants, Judy F. Sticklen, James L. Deger, Mary S. Rice and Frederick H. Cranford, owners of property affected by the project, became named defendants to the action in an attempt to block assessments against their properties.

At trial, the city contended that the entire initiative ordinance was void ab initio as an unconstitutional impairment of the city's contractual obligations with ODOT for construction of the project. Appellants claimed that the city [***7] had no standing to sue. Appellants also argued that in the event that the portion of the initiative ordinance purporting to halt construction on the project was unconstitutional, that portion of the ordinance repealing assessments could be severed off and given full force and effect.

The trial court held (1) that the city had special statutory standing to bring its suit; (2) that the initiative's repeal of the assessment ordinance did not impair the city's contractual obligations; (3) that the primary aim of the initiative ordinance, to halt construction of the project, would have been an unconstitutional impairment of an obligation of a contract had construction been stopped; and (4) that the portion of the ordinance pertaining to assessments could not properly be severed from the portion of the ordinance halting construction. Therefore, the trial court decided that the entire initiative ordinance was unconstitutional and thus void. In its judgment entry of April 10, 1984, the trial court held that the city had the authority to issue its bonds and that all proceedings taken by the city in connection with the Manchester Road project were lawful and valid.

The court of appeals [***8] affirmed. It reasoned that the initiative ordinance did impair the city's then-existing contractual obligations with ODOT on the effective date of its passage by the voters and that the ordinance was therefore void ab initio.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff city filed a motion to certify the record from the Butler County Court of Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed the finding that plaintiff had the authority to issue its bonds and that all proceedings taken by plaintiff in connection with a road improvement project were lawful and valid. The order also declared the initiative ordinance brought by defendant landowners was void ab initio.


OVERVIEW: The city started a road improvement project and the landowners affected by the improvement placed an on the voter ballot repealing any and all legislation enabling the project. The initiative ordinance passed on election day. The city then brought a bond validation action to establish its authority to issue the bonds and to establish that all of its previous resolutions and ordinances regarding the project were lawful and enforceable. The appellate court affirmed an order finding that the city had the authority to issue its bonds and all proceedings regarding the project were lawful and valid and that the initiative ordinance was void ab initio. The city filed a motion to certify the record. On review, the court held that (1) the city had standing to sue under Ohio Rev. Code § 133.71(B); (2) as one of the effects of the initiative ordinance was to repeal all legislation necessary for the city to levy assessments it amounted to substantial impairment of the city's contractual rights under U.S. Const. art. I, § 10; and (3) there was not sufficient justification for the ordinance to survive challenge under the Contract Clause. The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order from the appellate court.

 

111 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


J.C. Penney Co. v. Limbach


No. 85-1830


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 3d 46; 495 N.E.2d 1; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 692; 25 Ohio B. Rep. 71



July 16, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

J.C. Penney Co., Inc. (hereinafter "J.C. Penney" or "Penney"), appellant and cross-appellee, is a Delaware corporation engaged in retail sales in the state of Ohio and the United States through its retail sales and catalog sales divisions. One of the distribution centers for the catalog division is located in Columbus, Ohio.

The Tax Commissioner, appellee and cross-appellant, made assessments for sales or use taxes on various equipment owned and used by J.C. Penney in its retail operation.

J.C. Penney appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals which affirmed the order of the commissioner in all respects, except for that part of the order relating to teletype terminals.

J.C. Penney has appealed the decision and the commissioner has cross-appealed on the issue of the terminals, as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed in part, reversed in part and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation sought review of the decision by the Board of Tax Appeals relating to the tax assessment of various pieces of equipment.


OVERVIEW: The tax commissioner made assessments for sales or use taxes on various equipment owned and used by a corporation its retail operation. The corporation appealed to the board which affirmed the order of the commissioner in all respects, except for the part of the order relating to teletype terminals. Both parties sought review. On review, the court held that the teletype terminals were not merely preparatory equipment used prior to the actual retail sale. The court found that they were exempt from tax under the applicable statute. The court noted that the record fully supported the board's reversal of the commissioner's assessment. The court opined that the board's finding was supported by the record and was thus not unreasonable or unlawful. The court affirmed the holding that the purchases of the equipment used in the order filling process were not entitled to an exemption as equipment used in the consummation of a retail sale under the statute. The court held that the board erred in its determination that no installation exemption applied to the use tax and further, the court remanded for a determination on that issue.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded the matter.

 

112 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Board of Education v. Kinney


No. 85-1585


Supreme Court of Ohio


24 Ohio St. 3d 184; 494 N.E.2d 1109; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 669; 24 Ohio B. Rep. 414



July 2, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

Section 2, Article XII of the Ohio Constitution provides that statutes may be enacted exempting public property from taxation if the property is used exclusively for any public purpose. R.C. 5709.01 states that all real property in Ohio is subject to taxation unless expressly exempted therefrom. R.C. 5709.08 states that "* * * public property used exclusively for a public purpose shall be exempt from taxation." This case requires us to apply R.C. 5709.08, and to review the tax-exempt status of a publicly owned and managed golf course, a small portion of which is used with the intention of generating profit for private concerns.

In 1971, the city of Columbus acquired a 196.5 acre parcel known as the Bolton Field Golf Course, and it has enjoyed tax-exempt status since that date. The course, which is managed by the city Parks & Recreation Division, includes a clubhouse containing a large maintenance area, lobby, snack shop, pro-shop and an efficiency apartment. The snack shop is leased to a private concessioner for twenty-two percent of its gross sales.

The course pro is a city employee who is paid a small salary, and who [***2] draws the balance of his income from the sale of pro-shop merchandise. The efficiency apartment is rented for $ 80 per month to a non-city employee. The course is open to the general public. In 1980, standard green fees were $ 4.50 per eighteen holes, while junior and senior golfers received reduced rates. The course operates on a break-even budget, but lost about $ 3,400 in 1980. The loss was subsidized by the city.

On December 31, 1980, appellant, the Board of Education of the South-Western City Schools, filed a complaint with the then Commissioner of Tax Equalization challenging the tax-exempt status of several properties owned by the city of Columbus, including the Bolton Field Golf Course. The case was assigned to an attorney examiner and on May 19, 1982, he recommended that the golf course retain its tax-exempt status. 1 The school board objected to the recommendation and on July 28, 1982, the commissioner denied the complaint. In 1985, the Board of Tax Appeals agreed with the attorney examiner's recommendation and affirmed the order of the commissioner.


1 The tax-exempt status of the other properties is not before the court.

 [***3] The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of education sought review of the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which affirmed the order of appellee tax commissioner that the golf course should retain its tax-exempt status.


OVERVIEW: The board of education argued that the golf course's tax-exempt status violated the equal protection guarantee of the state and federal constitutions and that the golf course was not entitled to tax-exempt status because it was not used exclusively for a public purpose. The court affirmed the decision of the board and found that the equal protection issue was not properly before the court since it was not raised or considered in the prior proceedings. The court reasoned that one who challenged the constitutional application of legislation to particular facts was required to raise that challenge at the first available opportunity during the proceedings before the administrative agency. The court also found that the renting of an apartment at the golf course did not violate the exclusivity requirement of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5709.08 because the apartment was rented to insure someone was available in the evenings to deter vandalism. The court found that the operation of the pro-shop or the snack-shop did not violate § 5709.08 because the record did not reveal the extent of sales and therefore, did not render the board's determination unreasonable or unlawful.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the board.

 

113 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Pizza v. Sunset Fireworks Co.


Nos. 85-1134, 85-1269


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 3d 1; 494 N.E.2d 1115; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 676; 25 Ohio B. Rep. 1



July 2, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

Appellant Sunset Fireworks Company, Inc. ("Sunset") is a corporation organized and existing under the laws of Ohio and is engaged in the business of selling fireworks at two locations. Its principal place of business is at 1800 Commerce Road in Holland, Ohio, and a warehouse and distribution center is at 10224 State Route 2, Curtice, Lucas County, Ohio. The method and manner of appellant's sales are said to be in violation of R.C. 3473.32 and 3743.41.

The pertinent facts of the instant case are as follows.

Appellant sold fireworks to various individuals at retail at both locations. If the buyer had an Ohio residence, such individual was required to sign an affidavit that the goods would be shipped directly out of state and would not be used in the state of Ohio. A similar affidavit was not required for purchasers who were out-of-state residents; all retail purchasers were required to certify that the goods would be used in accordance with the laws of the state of destination. The fireworks were given to the purchaser for transportation and were not shipped by [***2] appellant. On June 13, 14 and 16, 1983, Lucas County deputy sheriffs made certain purchases of fireworks from appellant at both locations. On June 18 and 19, 1983, deputy sheriffs also stopped various motor vehicles improperly transporting fireworks from appellant's location in Curtice.

On June 21, 1983, the Lucas County Prosecutor and Sheriff, appellees, filed a complaint seeking a permanent injunction against appellants, Sunset Fireworks Co., Inc. and its president, Anthony Cicerella (case No. CV83-1501). On May 1, 1984, appellants filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings (treated as a motion to dismiss). On May 25, 1984, Sunset filed a complaint seeking a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief against appellees, together with motions for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction (case No. CV84-1361). Upon the trial court's denial of the motion for a temporary restraining order, Sunset voluntarily dismissed the count for injunctive relief on May 29, 1984.

Both complaints were consolidated for a trial on the merits on May 29, 1984. At trial, appellees established that appellants' principal place of business did not possess a license to sell fireworks [***3] at wholesale. Appellees also presented evidence demonstrating the various injuries sustained by people in the community as a result of playing with fireworks.

On June 1, 1984, the trial court in case No. CV83-1501 denied appellants' motion to dismiss, found that a public nuisance existed and issued a permanent injunction against appellants. A declaratory judgment was entered accordingly in case No. CV84-1361. Appellants filed a timely notice of appeal to the Court of Appeals for Lucas County on June 4, 1984. On May 31, 1985, the appellate court affirmed the trial court's judgments. On July 23, 1985, appellants filed a notice of appeal in this court (case No. 85-1134). On July 22, 1985, the appellate court, finding the decision in the case sub judice to be in conflict with the decision of the Court of Appeals for Clermont County in Van Camp v.. Riley (1984), 16 Ohio App. 3d 457, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination (case No. 85-1269).

On November 13, 1985, these cases were consolidated as they involved identical facts, issues and arguments.



DISPOSITION: Judgment as modified affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant seller challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgments. The trial court denied the seller's motion to dismiss, found that a public nuisance existed, and issued a permanent injunction against the seller. Appellee county prosecutor brought an action alleging that the seller's sale of fireworks was in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 3473.32, 3743.41.


OVERVIEW: The court found that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3743.33 permitted the retail sales of fireworks shipped directly out of state by a seller that was licensed by the Ohio Department of Industrial Relations as a wholesaler or manufacturer. The court also found that a seller could sell fireworks to a wholesaler, which would ship the fireworks out of state, that exhibited a wholesale permit or was known to have a wholesale permit issued pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3743.321. Therefore, the court found that any subterfuge between the seller and buyers by signing papers and affidavits that they were wholesalers when in fact they were not should be restrained. The court found that the seller did not ship the fireworks directly out of state but delegated the task to the purchaser of the fireworks, which was impermissible. The court found that the seller's sales in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3743.33 constituted a public nuisance, but any sales transactions within the permissive scope of that section could not be declared a public nuisance. The court found that the existence of a criminal sanction did not bar a civil action seeking the enjoinment of the nuisance.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the lower court as modified.

 

114 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Hayes


No. 86-65


Supreme Court of Ohio


25 Ohio St. 3d 173; 495 N.E.2d 578; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 717; 25 Ohio B. Rep. 214



June 30, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Appellee, Melvin Hayes, was indicted by the Hamilton County Grand Jury on September 27, 1984. The indictment specifically charged that appellee "engaged in sexual conduct with Crystal Ellison, a person who was not Melvin Hayes' spouse at the time and at the time the said Melvin Hayes was the guardian or the custodian or the stepparent or a person standing in the place of a parent to Crystal Ellison, in violation of Section 2907.03 of the Revised Code * * *." R.C. 2907.03(A)(5) provides in pertinent part:

"(A) No person shall engage in sexual conduct with another, not the spouse of the offender, when any of the following apply:

"* * *

"(5) The offender is the other person's natural or adoptive parent, or a stepparent, or guardian, custodian or person in loco parentis."

On October 10, 1984, appellee requested a bill of particulars pursuant to Crim. R. 7(E). Appellant responded with a bill which stated in pertinent part: "* * * Furthermore, at the time of the aforementioned sexual conduct, the defendant was a person standing in the place of a parent to Crystal Ellison." Appellant alleged that Crystal Ellison's parents [***2] died and that she moved in with her aunt. The aunt then married appellee, and he moved into the aunt's house. Thus, it was appellant's theory that at the time of the sexual conduct, appellee was standing in the place of a parent living in the household. Accordingly, appellant continued to proceed solely on the "in loco parentis" portion of R.C. 2907.03(A)(5).

On November 29, 1984, appellee filed a motion to dismiss, alleging that the portion of R.C. 2907.03(A)(5) which contains the phrase "in loco parentis" was unconstitutionally vague. On December 21, 1984, in a hearing on the motion, the trial court agreed with appellee that the statute, at least in its use of the Latin phrase "in loco parentis," was unconstitutionally vague. The trial court refused to dismiss the indictment, however, since appellee might also qualify as the guardian, custodian or stepparent of the alleged victim. On January 22, 1985, at a continuance of the hearing, appellant essentially argued that by refusing to dismiss the entire indictment, the court had effectively prevented appellant from proceeding to trial. The court, however, set a trial date for February 25, 1985 and entered the following ruling:

 [***3] "This matter having come on for hearing by this Court on the Motion of the defendant to Dismiss the Indictment and Bill of Particulars and the Court being fully advised in the matter does hereby grant said motion only to the extent that it finds:

"The portion of O.R.C. 2907.03(A)(5) which uses the Latin words 'loco parentis' is in violation of the mandates of the Constitution of the Constitution of the United States [sic] and the Constitution of the State of Ohio as being void for vagueness and is therefore unconstitutional. 

"In all other respects, said motion is denied."

Appellant then appealed this ruling to the court of appeals. The court of appeals held that there was no final order from which appellant could appeal and, consequently, dismissed the appeal for want of jurisdiction.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State appealed the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which, for want of jurisdiction, dismissed its appeal of an order granting a motion to dismiss a portion of the indictment that charged defendant with violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.03.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was indicted for violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.03 because he allegedly engaged in sexual conduct with a girl of whom defendant was the guardian, custodian, stepparent, or a person standing in the place of the girl's parent. Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the indictment, alleging that the portion of § 2907.03(A)(5) that contained the phrase "in loco parentis" was unconstitutionally vague. The trial court agreed and dismissed the part of the indictment that included that particular language. However, the trial court refused to dismiss the remaining portions of the indictment. The State appealed the order insofar as it granted a portion of defendant's motion to dismiss. The court of appeals dismissed the appeal for want of jurisdiction because it held that there was no final order from which the State could appeal. The State appealed, and the court reversed the court of appeals' judgment. The court held that the court of appeals did have jurisdiction to hear the State's appeal. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.67(A) allowed the State a direct appeal whenever the trial court granted a motion to dismiss all, or any part of, an indictment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded.

 

115 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Fondessy Enterprises, Inc. v. Oregon


No. 85-395


Supreme Court of Ohio


23 Ohio St. 3d 213; 492 N.E.2d 797; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 631; 23 Ohio B. Rep. 372; 16 ELR 20871



May 7, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

Appellee, Fondessy Enterprises, Inc., owns and operates a hazardous waste landfill facility within the city of Oregon with a permit issued by the Ohio Hazardous Waste Facility Board under the authority of R.C. Chapter 3734. Appellee's landfill facility is regulated by the Director of Environmental Protection under R.C. Chapter 3734 and the rules and regulations adopted thereunder.

Appellee acquired the site and operated it as a hazardous waste landfill by virtue of the permit from the Ohio Hazardous Waste Facility Board issued prior to January 23, 1984, when the appellant, city of Oregon, through its elected council adopted Ordinance No. 12-1984.

Under this ordinance, a "permit fee" was imposed upon all hazardous waste landfills located within the city's borders "for the purpose not to generate revenue, but for the sole purpose of generating sufficient funds in order to protect the environmental safety, health and welfare of its citizens."

The ordinance required the landfill operators to keep complete and accurate records and manifests on forms provided by the city, showing the amount, type and volume of hazardous [***2] waste disposed within the facility each day, and to remit monthly the "permit fee" and file the forms with the city's clerk auditor.

Appellee thereafter filed a complaint for declaratory judgment in the common pleas court seeking to have the ordinance declared invalid. Appellee also sought injunctive relief. In its complaint, Fondessy alleged that the regulation of hazardous waste facilities in the state was preempted as a matter of law to the exclusion of all political subdivisions. The trial court bifurcated the matter for hearing, reserving until later appellee's claim that the ordinance violated the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Constitutions of the United States and the state of Ohio.

After the hearing, the trial court held that R.C. 3734.05(D)(3) precluded the operation of Ordinance No. 12-1984 and entered judgment for appellee. Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed.

This cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio) affirming a trial court ruling that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3734.05 precluded the operation of an ordinance enacted by appellant. Appellee landfill owner filed a complaint for declaratory judgment seeking to have the ordinance declared invalid. The ordinance imposed a permit fee upon all hazardous waste landfills located within the city's borders.


OVERVIEW: Appellee landfill owner challenged an ordinance enacted by appellant city that imposed a permit fee upon all hazardous waste landfills located within the city's borders. The trial court and lower appellate court determined that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3734.05(D)(3) expressly preempted appellant from enacting the ordinance. The supreme court first found that the power of the municipality to enact local police regulations was derived directly from Ohio Const. art. XVIII, § 3 and that the statute could not nullify the police power granted by the constitution. Furthermore, the court held that absent any conflict between an ordinance and statute, the state and municipality had concurrent authority under their respective police powers to enforce their respective directives within the corporate limits of the city. In reversing the lower courts, the supreme court held that the ordinance did not conflict with the statute because the ordinance did not allow anything that the statute prohibited nor did it prohibit anything permitted by the statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals declaring invalid an ordinance enacted by appellant city and challenged by appellee landfill owner. The court held that appellant had the authority to enforce monitoring of hazardous waste facilities located inside the corporate limits of the city.

 

116 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Ewing v. Lindley


No. 85-1303


Supreme Court of Ohio


23 Ohio St. 3d 222; 492 N.E.2d 435; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 632; 23 Ohio B. Rep. 380



May 7, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

This appeal arises as a result of an appeal by appellants, Charles W. and Charlotte A. Ewing, concerning two sales tax assessments totalling over $ 78,000. the assessments were issued to appellants' company, Ewing Lumber Company, Inc., for unpaid sales tax to the state for various periods commencing January 1977 and ending December 31, 1979. Appellants were officers and employees of Ewing Lumber Company. The company's corporate assets were seized and sold in September 1980, and the company became insolvent.

Accordingly, the Tax Commissioner of Ohio, appellee, relying upon R.C. 5739.33, levied the assessments against appellants personally in their capacity as officers of the corporation charged with preparing and filing the company's tax returns, and ultimately remitting the sales tax payment to the state.

Following appellants' petition for reassessment, the Tax Commissioner issued a final determination, affirming the assessments against appellants. Upon appeal, the Board of Tax Appeals issued its decision and order, affirming the final determination of the Tax Commissioner.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as [***2] a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayers sought review of a decision of the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio) (board), which affirmed the final determination of appellee Tax Commissioner of Ohio (commissioner) levying two tax assessments against the taxpayers personally in their capacity as corporate officers charged with preparing and filing the company's tax returns, and ultimately remitting the sales tax payment to the state.


OVERVIEW: The commissioner, relying upon Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5739.33, levied sales tax assessments against taxpayers, and following the taxpayers' petition for reassessment, the commissioner issued a final determination affirming the assessments against them. Upon appeal, the board issued its decision and order, affirming the commissioner's final determination. The taxpayers appealed to the court as a matter of right, challenging the constitutionality of §5739.33, and claiming that the commissioner failed to establish that the taxpayers were the responsible corporate officers for purposes of § 5739.33. The court affirmed the board's decision, holding that both propositions lacked merit. The fact that a federal provision contained an element which the state statute did not was an insufficient reason to declare § 5739.33 unconstitutional, and the court specifically found that the provisions of § 5739.33 were compatible with federal and state constitutional provisions. Section 5739.33 was not void for vagueness, not overbroad, and did not create an unconstitutional presumption. In addition, the taxpayers had admitted that they were officers that would be liable under the statute.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the board's order affirming the commissioner's final determination that the taxpayers were responsible for the sales tax assessments against them.

 

117 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Rohdes


No. 85-1167


Supreme Court of Ohio


23 Ohio St. 3d 225; 492 N.E.2d 430; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 633; 23 Ohio B. Rep. 382



May 7, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Allen County.

On March 1, 1984, appellee, Fred D. Rohdes, Jr., killed Paul E. Boysel, Jr., with one shot to the head from a handgun, outside appellee's house where he lived with Tamara A. Korb. That day, Korb arranged a ride home with Boysel, her supervisor at work. An argument erupted after the two entered the residence and appellee ordered Boysel to leave. According to appellee's testimony at trial, he picked up a .38 caliber handgun from a gun rack on the wall and displayed it for the purpose of causing Paul to believe that he would use the gun on him if he "had to." Boysel left the house, followed by appellee, where the argument continued, and moments later the gun was discharged from a distance of about ten feet. Appellee testified that he slipped in the snow or tripped over some other object in his house slippers, and the resultant shooting was an accident.

After appellee telephoned for help, Michael DeVita, the first patrolman to arrive on the scene, approached the appellee's residence from the front and walked around it until he came upon an open side door. Appellee and Korb approached the door from the inside [***2] of the house, and led the officer to the victim's body, approximately twenty feet away. Appellee told the officer he had shot the victim and that it was an accident, and requested to re-enter the house to get another pair of shoes. Two additional officers arrived, arrested appellee, and transported him to the Lima Police Station. Lieutenant John J. Griesdorn arrived and, after questioning DeVita as to his knowledge of other victims in the house, entered the house with other officers. One of those officers saw a gun lodged between the cushions of the living room couch, and seized the weapon.

Appellee was indicted for murder with a firearm specification. Based upon the evidence adduced at trial, the state requested that jury instructions be given on voluntary manslaughter, which request was overruled, and on involuntary manslaughter based on the underlying offense of aggravated menacing, which request was granted. The trial court also overruled appellee's request for an instruction on negligent homicide.

The jury was thus instructed as to murder and involuntary manslaughter by aggravated menacing and the firearm specification. It returned a verdict of not guilty of murder [***3] but guilty of the involuntary manslaughter and firearm specification. The court of appeals reversed on two grounds: (1) involuntary manslaughter by aggravated menacing is not a lesser included offense of murder and thus appellee was found guilty of a crime not charged; and (2) conclusory statements of Korb were unlawfully admitted into evidence to appellee's prejudice.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion and cross-motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State appealed, and defendant cross-appealed, from a decision of the Court of Appeals for Allen County (Ohio), which reversed defendant's conviction for involuntary manslaughter, with a firearm specification. The court of appeals reversed on the grounds that involuntary manslaughter by aggravated menacing was not a lesser included offense of murder, and that a witness's conclusory statements were unlawfully admitted into evidence.


OVERVIEW: Defendant shot and killed a man following an argument. He alleged that he displayed a gun to cause the man to believe that he would use it if he had to, but that he fired it accidentally. Defendant was indicted for murder and was convicted in the trial court of involuntary manslaughter by aggravated menacing. The court of appeals reversed. On further review, the court reversed and reinstated the trial court's judgment. The court held that the jury was properly instructed on involuntary manslaughter because it was a lesser included offense of murder, in that is was a crime of a lesser degree, the intent element of murder was not required to prove it, and the jury reasonably found on the evidence that the murder could not have been committed without also committing involuntary manslaughter by way of aggravated menacing. The court also held that testimony as to a witness's statements containing her appraisal of the incident was admissible because as the sole witness her view of the events was relevant, its probative value was not outweighed by its prejudicial effect, and, pursuant to Ohio R. Evid. 704, it was not inadmissible solely because it embraced an ultimate issue.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals and reinstated the conviction and sentence entered by the trial court.

 

118 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Shriners' Hospital for Crippled Children v. Hester


No. 85-743


Supreme Court of Ohio


23 Ohio St. 3d 198; 492 N.E.2d 153; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 628; 23 Ohio B. Rep. 359



April 30, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Butler County.

On January 31, 1980, Myrtle R. Davis executed a will in which she made specific bequests of $ 10,000 to a niece, $ 5,000 to a half-brother, $ 10,000 to the "Burns Institute, Cincinnati Unit" of the Shriners' Hospital for Crippled Children, $ 5,000 to the Salvation Army, $ 5,000 to the Fairfield Church of God, and $ 10,000 to the Twin Wells Indian School. Davis' will also made a residual bequest dividing the remainder of her estate equally between the "Burns Institute, Cincinnati Unit" of the Shriners' Hospital for Crippled Children and the Twin Wells Indian School.

On July 25, 1980, Davis executed a new will, expressly revoking her previous will but altering the terms of that will only by reducing the bequest to her niece from $ 10,000 to $ 5,000 and by appointing a new executor. All other bequests in the will of July 25, 1980 were identical to those in Davis' previous will of January 31, 1980.

On November 9, 1980, less than four months after the execution of her last will, Davis died. Davis' will was admitted to probate in Butler County; but, prior to the completion of probate, the plaintiff-appellee herein,  [***2] Shriners' Hospital for Crippled Children ("Shriners"), filed a complaint for declaratory judgment in the Court of Common Pleas of Butler County. Stephen M. Hester (the executor of Davis' estate), the named charitable beneficiaries under Davis' will, Davis' grandchildren (her heirs-at-law), and the Attorney General of Ohio were joined as parties to the Shriners' action, which sought a judgment declaring that R.C. 2107.06, Ohio's mortmain statute, was unconstitutional or otherwise inapplicable to Davis' beneficiaries. The matter was transferred to the probate division of the common pleas court and an evidentiary hearing was held.

On January 23, 1984, judgment was entered whereby the trial court upheld the constitutionality of R.C. 2107.06, found that R.C. 2107.06 was applicable to Davis' last will, and refused to adopt the doctrine of dependent relative revocation, which would have enabled the court to revive the terms of Davis' prior will of January 31, 1980. The trial court ordered that, pursuant to R.C. 2107.06, the charitable bequests in Davis' last will "are to be honored to the extent that they do not exceed twenty-five [percent] (25%) of the value of the net probate estate.  [***3] That portion of the charitable bequests * * * which exceed[s] twenty-five [percent] (25%) of the value of the net probate estate, shall be distributed in accordance with intestate succession to the five grandchildren of the deceased, * * * in equal shares."

Shriners appealed to the Court of Appeals for Butler County; and, on March 18, 1985, the appellate court reversed the judgment of the trial court. The court of appeals held that the trial court erred in refusing to adopt the doctrine of dependent relative revocation, but it expressly refused to address Shriners' challenge to the constitutionality of R.C. 2107.06. T

he cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The cause was before the court pursuant to a motion to certify the record. The Court of Appeals for Butler County (Ohio) had reversed the trial court's judgment, which found that Ohio Rev. Code § 2107.06 was constitutional and was applicable to the decedent's last will. Further, the trial court refused to adopt the doctrine of dependent relative revocation in appellee charitable organization's declaratory judgment action.


OVERVIEW: The decedent executed a will in which she made specific bequests to some relatives and the charitable organizations. Thereafter, the decedent executed a new will, expressly revoking her previous will but altering the terms of that will only by reducing the bequest to her niece from $ 10,000 to $ 5,000 and by appointing a new executor. All other bequests in the will were identical to those in the previous will. The decedent then died, and the will was admitted to probate, but, prior to the completion of probate, one of the charitable organization filed a declaratory judgment action seeking a judgment declaring that § 2107.06, Ohio's mortmain statute, was unconstitutional or otherwise inapplicable to the decedent's beneficiaries. The trial upheld the constitutionality of the statute, and the appellate court reversed. The court affirmed. The court held that § 2107.06 was not rationally related to the accomplishment of its objective of protecting a testator's issue from disinheritance, as a result of the testator's unsound judgment or the undue influence of third parties upon the testator.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's decision.

 

119 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Williams


No. 85-7


Supreme Court of Ohio


23 Ohio St. 3d 16; 490 N.E.2d 906; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 597; 23 Ohio B. Rep. 13



March 26, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On January 21, 1983, the body of Leoma Chmielewski, a seventy-six-year-old woman, was discovered lying face down on the floor of her home. An autopsy revealed that the decedent had suffered multiple blunt force injuries to the head and neck, as well as a single gunshot wound fired from close range (approximately two feet or less) into the victim's face.

Witnesses established that the decedent was last seen between 10:00 and 10:30 p.m. the evening of the 20th, standing in her doorway talking with appellant, Lewis Williams. Between 10:30 and 11:00, the victim's neighbors heard a sound from her house like a door slamming. Appellant was arrested on January 22, 1983 and admitted being in the house the night of the murder, but denied perpetrating the offenses for which he was indicted.

The evidence produced at appellant's trial established the following sequence of events. Early in the evening of January 20, 1983, appellant and two acquaintances, Brent Nicholson and Tyrone Robinson, visited and had dinner with appellant's cousin, Kevin Samuels. Samuels lives across the street from the victim's house and had known [***2] her for several years. Prior to the night of the incident in question, appellant had stayed with Samuels and had known the victim.

On the evening of the 20th, Robinson and appellant left the Samuels residence, at approximately 9:00 p.m., to go to the store. Only Robinson returned a half-hour later, indicating appellant was still at the store. At trial, however, Robinson testified that appellant was in fact at Chmielewski's house, where he had apparently been invited in. The remarks to the contrary were merely to dissuade appellant's brother, Mark, who had arrived at the Samuels residence, from looking for appellant. Robinson eventually told Mark where appellant was, and the two of them went over to Chmielewski's house where Mark prevailed upon his brother to return some money. Mark left and Robinson went back to Samuels' house. Samuels sent Robinson back over to ask appellant to return to the Samuels residence. Appellant's responses were to tell Robinson he was not ready to leave and to call Samuels and tell him to mind his own business.

Samuels, Nicholson, and Robinson were driving down the Samuels driveway around 10:30 p.m. when Samuels saw appellant and Chmielewski at [***3] her door. They honked the horn, but appellant motioned for the car to proceed without him. When Nicholson and Samuels returned, a little over an hour later, Nicholson went across the street to find that the door was open and Chmielewski's body was on the floor. Nicholson returned to the Samuels residence, whereupon Samuels called appellant's mother's home, then the police.

When the police arrived, at approximately 1:00 a.m., January 21, 1983, they found not only the body, but also several coins scattered near the doorway, numerous bank envelopes throughout the house and down to the street corner, decedent's purse with its contents emptied on the bedroom closet shelf, decedent's false teeth on the floor next to the body, and the phone off the hook. A subsequent police investigation revealed an imprint on the hem of the nightgown decedent was wearing which matched a portion of a shoe appellant was wearing the day of his arrest. Appellant's jacket sleeve cuff also contained a trace of lead powder.

In addition to the above evidence, the state presented two witnesses who were former cellmates of appellant while he was confined to the Cuyahoga County Jail pending trial. Michael [***4] Anderson and Navarro Brooks each testified that appellant had told them he had murdered the decedent. Specifically, Anderson testified that appellant had said he "stuck the gun in her mouth" to get her "to shut up." Brooks testified that appellant was worried about blood on his shoes apparently from rolling decedent's body over with his foot. After this testimony, the state rested, as did the appellant, without presenting any evidence.

The jury found appellant guilty of aggravated murder in violation of R.C. 2903.01, and the accompanying specification under R.C. 2929.04(A)(7) of having committed the aggravated murder in the course of committing an aggravated robbery, for which the death penalty could be imposed. The jury also found appellant guilty of aggravated robbery in violation of R.C. 2911.01, as well as the firearm specification contained in R.C. 2929.71.

On October 13, 1983, the sentencing phase of the trial commenced. Appellant presented three witnesses, his father, sister, and a friend, in addition to making an unsworn statement on his own behalf. The evidence in mitigation was essentially: that appellant was relatively young (twenty-four); that he came from a broken [***5] home; that he loved his mother more than himself, but that she rejected him; and that he elected to pursue a life of crime in order to compensate for a lack of love during his childhood. After more than twenty-three hours of deliberation, the jury returned a verdict, finding beyond a reasonable doubt that the aggravating circumstances outweighed the factors offered in mitigation, and sentencing appellant to death. This conviction and sentence were affirmed by both the trial court and the court of appeals, after each made an independent determination that the aggravating circumstances outweighed the mitigating factors.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed his conviction of aggravated murder in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01, and the imposition of the death sentence under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(A)(7), for having committed the aggravated murder in the course of an aggravated robbery.


OVERVIEW: The court affirmed defendant's conviction and the imposition of the death penalty. Defendant raised numerous assignments of error, all of which the court found to be without merit. The court ruled that there was sufficient evidence of record by which a jury could find defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt and to support the imposition of the death sentence. The court stated that the aggravating circumstance was the commission of a senselessly cruel aggravated murder in the course of an aggravated robbery, and defendant had failed to produce any evidence of the mitigating factors listed in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2929.04(B). The court also stated that the trial court did not err in finding defendant competent to stand trial, because defendant failed to produce any evidence to rebut the presumption, contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2945.37(A), that a criminal defendant was competent. Finally, the court ruled that the trial court did not err in instructing the jury that its recommendation of the death penalty was not binding on the court. However, the court urged against the future use of this instruction in capital cases.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the defendant's conviction and sentence.

 

120 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Zone v. Cleveland


No. 85-775


Supreme Court of Ohio


23 Ohio St. 3d 1; 490 N.E.2d 600; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 594; 23 Ohio B. Rep. 1



March 26, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This action was commenced in the court of appeals as a complaint for a writ of mandamus. Appellants, John Zone et al., alleged that they are or were members of the skilled crafts and as such are or were members of the Cleveland Building and Construction Trades Council. They further alleged that they acted as foremen, assistant foremen, leadmen or general foremen while employed by the appellee city of Cleveland (hereinafter the "city"). Appellants brought their action on behalf of themselves and all skilled tradesmen who acted similarly.

Essentially, appellants alleged that the city and other city officials violated Section 191 of the Charter of the city of Cleveland and Ordinance No. 2356-48 by failing and refusing to pay the prevailing rate of wage scales for foreman as negotiated between the Cleveland Building and Construction Trades Council and the Local Building Trades Employers Association.

Appellants alleged that they are or were foremen for the city, and were not paid the prevailing rate mandated by such ordinance. The appellant's prayer sought an order requiring adoption of an ordinance providing for the [***2] payment of wage entitlement benefits to the building and construction foremen, assistant foremen, leadmen and general foremen from December 20, 1948, who have not been paid the prevailing rate of pay. (The prevailing rate ordinance was adopted by the city civil service commission on December 20, 1948.)

Appellees moved to dismiss the appellants' complaint pursuant to Civ. R. 12(B)(6) and moved for summary judgment pursuant to Civ. R. 56(B). In support of their motions, the appellees submitted the affidavit of the city's civil service commission Secretary and member, Irene R. Morrow. In her affidavit, Morrow stated she had reviewed the records of the commission with respect to the named appellants, and she stated they disclosed that none of said persons had ever been appointed to the classification of "foreman" at any time, save one appellant whose appointment as a steamfitter-foreman in 1965 and 1971 does not appear relevant to the disposition herein.

In response to the foregoing motions, affidavits of all appellants were submitted in support of their respective service "acting" as foreman. Further, the collective bargaining agreements of each named appellant's appropriate union [***3] were submitted demonstrating the prevailing rate of pay for foreman.

The court of appeals granted appellees' motion for summary judgment finding there to be no genuine issues of fact and appellees to be entitled to judgment as a matter of law. The court cited State, ex rel. Gibbons, v.. Cleveland (1984), 9 Ohio St. 3d 216, in support of its judgment.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city employees challenged a summary judgment from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which was entered for appellees, a city and city officials, in the city employees' action for a writ of mandamus regarding appellees' alleged failure to pay the prevailing rate of wage scales for foremen.


OVERVIEW: The city employees instituted an action against appellees for a writ of mandamus to required the adoption of an ordinance providing for the payment of wage entitlement benefits to alleged foremen who had not been paid the prevailing rate of pay. The lower court granted appellees' motion for summary judgment. The city employees contended on appeal that they were entitled to back pay under Cleveland, Ohio, Charter § 191 and Cleveland, Ohio, Ordinance No. 2356-48 (December 1948) because de facto appointments to foreman positions had occurred. The court affirmed the summary judgment against the city employees. The court concluded that the city employees' claims for back pay were barred because they had not been formally appointed foremen as provided by the city's civil service commission. The court determined that the city employees were on notice that supervisors that assigned them to perform tasks outside the classifications to which they been formally appointed lacked authority to create different classifications or to make appointments.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the summary judgment in favor of the city and the city officials in the city employees' mandamus action concerning the alleged failure to pay the prevailing rate of wage scales.

 

121 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Wilmoth


Nos. 85-72, 85-73


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 251; 490 N.E.2d 1236; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 586; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 427



March 19, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Lorain County.

On February 8, 1983, appellant, Howard D. Wilmoth, was indicted on one count of receiving stolen property in violation of R.C. 2913.51, and one count of possession of criminal tools in violation of R.C. 2923.24. On the same date, appellant, Bernard H. Wilmoth, was indicted on eight counts of receiving stolen property in violation of R.C. 2913.51, one count of possession of criminal tools in violation of R.C. 2923.24, and one count of concealing the identity of a motor vehicle in violation of R.C. 4549.07.

On May 16, 1983, the appellants timely filed motions to suppress the evidence. On June 28, 1984, the trial court granted the motions.

The facts contained in the record provide that when the police became aware of possible criminal activity at the shop at 732 Idaho Avenue in Lorain, they established a round-the-clock surveillance. On the morning of December 21, 1982, two vehicles, which were believed to have been stolen, were observed being driven into the shop. At that point, the police sought a search warrant. A warrant was obtained and Lorain police officers conducted a search of the shop. Numerous items were [***2] seized from the shop, the surrounding area, and vehicles located in or about the shop, resulting in the charges filed against the appellants.

The search was conducted pursuant to a search warrant issued by a Lorain County common pleas judge. It is the procedure in obtaining the warrant which is the focus in this appeal. The warrant was issued on the basis of oral statements given to the magistrate by Sergeant Jack D. Daniel and Patrolman Thomas M. DeNicola of the Lorain Police Department. The oral statements were being recorded as the officers testified before the magistrate. Their recorded statements, later transcribed, provided information concerning stolen motor vehicles being delivered to a "chop shop."

Probable cause is not an issue on appeal. However, a brief summary of the officers' testimony is necessary. Sergeant Daniel testified concerning the background information which led to the surveillance. He stated that the Cleveland Police Department alerted the Lorain County Sheriff's office that stolen vehicles were being transported to a shop at 732 Idaho Avenue. The Cleveland police obtained this information from David Hill, who admitted stealing the cars for Bernard [***3] Wilmoth. The Lorain police then began a surveillance of this address. At the same time, they learned that this shop was being rented by John Wilmoth.

Daniel then testified in detail concerning information the police obtained from four informants. The various informants had described the activities of the appellants and the activities of the shop. Daniel informed the magistrate that based on the information received from these four informants, the police set up a twenty-four hour surveillance. Their surveillance revealed that cars were being driven into the shop but were never seen exiting the shop. They also observed trucks entering and exiting. Daniel submitted police reports which detailed the activity observed during the surveillance.

DeNicola then testified concerning the activity he observed the morning of December 21, 1982. He claimed two new cars were brought into the shop. A computer registration check revealed that both cars were stolen vehicles.

After receiving the testimony of Daniel and DeNicola, the magistrate swore them in and then proceeded to issue the search warrant. The testimony of the December 21, 1982 hearing was subsequently transcribed. On January [***4] 3, 1983, the issuing magistrate and both of the officers certified that the transcript was an accurate record of the December 21, 1982 hearing.

However, the warrant in question was not issued on the basis of written affidavits but on the oral statements of the two officers and their submitted police reports. The state argued that the reason the affidavits were prepared in this manner was because all the intelligence gathered prior to the search showed the operation at 732 Idaho Avenue, Lorain, Ohio, to be a "chop shop" for cars that are immediately (in less than one hour) and completely dismantled with all identifying characteristics destroyed. In other words, the loss and/or destruction of the evidence was imminent. Later testimony revealed that one of the two stolen cars seen entering the shop on December 21, 1982 was completely dismantled with the identifying marks destroyed by the time the police entered with the warrant and the other car was in the state of partial disassembly. The completely disassembled vehicle was on its way down the highway in the back of a panel truck.

In addition, the transcript of the police officers' oral statements revealed they were not sworn [***5] in prior to giving their statements. However, they were sworn in twice. The first time the tape recorder was not on. The second time the tape was running and the following exchange occurred:

"[Prosecutor:] Hang on, swear them in again Judge, we * * *.

"[Judge:] Oh, I see * * *.

"[Prosecutor:] Didn't get that on the tape.

"[Judge:] Alright, please stand and raise your right hands, do you solemnly swear that the testimony you are about to give on to enable you to obtain a search warrant is the truth so help you God?

"[Patrolman DeNicola]: I do.

"[Sergeant Daniel]: I do." (Emphasis added.)

The trial court subsequently ruled that the evidence seized during the search should be suppressed for two reasons. First, the police failed to submit a written affidavit to obtain the warrant, as required by Crim. R. 41(C). Second, the officers did not testify under oath, as required by the United States Constitution and the Ohio Constitution.

On appeal, the court of appeals reversed the decision of the trial court. The appellate court found that failure to provide a written affidavit did not require suppression of evidence; that the error of the magistrate in [***6] giving the oath did not invalidate the search warrant; and even if the search warrant were invalid, the avowed purpose of the exclusionary rule would not be served by suppression of the evidence because the search warrant was executed in good faith by the police officers.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants were indicted for receiving stolen property, possessing criminal tools, and concealing the identity of a motor vehicle in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2913.51, 2923.24, and 4549.07 arising from their operation of a chop shop. The Court of Appeals for Lorain County (Ohio) reversed the order granting their motion to suppressed evidence found during a search of the chop shop. Defendants brought a motion for leave to appeal.


OVERVIEW: Defendants argued that the search warrant was defective and required the suppression of any evidence obtained during the search. Specifically, defendants argued that Fed. R. Crim. P. 41(C) required a warrant to be based on written affidavits and this one was based on oral statements, and that the police officers, when making their oral statements, did not do so under oath as required by the United States Constitution and the Ohio Constitution. The court held that these defects did not warrant the suppression of the evidence. The court found that the violation was an unintentional technical violation and not a violation of constitutional magnitude. The court concluded that there had been no prejudice to defendants and that the oral affidavit complied with the spirit of Rule 41. The court determined that the failure of the magistrate to use the proper verb tense in administering the oath did not require a finding that the oath was constitutionally infirm. The court noted that everyone made every effort to do the right thing under a very hurried time frame to circumvent the destruction of stolen motor vehicles and gather the evidence necessary to arrest defendants.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

122 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Jackson


No. 85-227


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 281; 490 N.E.2d 893; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 589; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 452



March 19, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On the evening of July 27, 1983, appellant, Eddie Jackson, walked into the Fifth District Police Station in Cleveland and informed Officer Patrick Wood that he had shot someone. The victim, Malvin L. Young, died of a gunshot wound to the chest. The killing had occurred some time after 7:00 that evening.

Appellant was indicted for the aggravated murder of Young in violation of R.C. 2903.01. The indictment also contained a gun specification. Appellant pleaded not guilty and at trial raised the affirmative defense of self-defense.

The testimony at trial, as to events leading up to the shooting, was conflicting. It can fairly be said that appellant and the victim were the closest of friends. The victim had free access to come and go as he pleased from appellant's apartment. There was testimony from two witnesses that appellant and the victim had been involved in a homosexual relationship. The state's witness, Delora Kilpatrick, also testified that she had lived with the victim for three and one-half years and bore his child. Kilpatrick stated that appellant was jealous of her because she interfered with his relationship [***2] with the victim.

On the evening of the shooting, appellant and a group of friends were gathered in his apartment when the victim arrived. An argument ensued and the victim hit appellant who fell into the lap of one of his guests. Appellant's nephew escorted the victim out of appellant's apartment. The victim returned and a struggle ensued. Appellant, the victim, and the nephew ended up in the yard outside appellant's apartment. After this second struggle, the victim was again restrained and the fight broken up. At this point appellant stepped inside his apartment and immediately returned with a gun. As the victim began to walk up the porch stairs toward the outside doorway of appellant's apartment, appellant fatally shot him. The deputy coroner, Marilee H. Frazer, testified that at the time of death, the victim's blood-alcohol content was .11 percent and that traces of cocaine were found in his urine.

At trial, appellant told the jury that he feared the victim was going to kill him and shot only in self-defense. Appellant also argued that the state could not constitutionally place upon him the burden of proving self-defense and submitted the following proposed jury instruction:

 [***3] "The burden of going forward with the evidence of self-defense is upon the defendant. The burden of proving the absence of self-defense is upon the prosecution. The prosecution must prove beyond a reasonable doubt the absence of the elements of self-defense.

"If the prosecution fails to satisfy you that beyond a reasonable doubt Defendant did not act in self-defense, you must acquit Defendant of the charge against him.

"If you are satisfied that beyond a reasonable doubt Defendant did not act in self-defense, the affirmative defense of self-defense is not available to Defendant."

Appellant also submitted the following proposed special jury instruction relative to his duty to retreat before killing in self-defense:
