"The doctrine followed in Ohio is that if a person is assailed without fault, and in a place where he has a right to be, and put in reasonably apparent danger of losing his life or receiving great bodily harm, he need not retreat, but may stand his ground, repel force by force, and if, in the reasonable exercise of his right of self-defense, he kills his assailant, he is justified. Consequently, there is no duty to retreat where the assault is violent and produces [***4] imminent danger of death or great bodily harm to the person attacked. Whether or not the person attacked could safely have retreated from the violent attack, he is not obliged to do so, even if it was within the power of the person attacked to retreat."

The trial court overruled both of appellant's proposed instructions. Appellant later noted his objections thereto. The court instead gave general instructions on self-defense in accordance with Ohio law and charged the jury, inter alia, that appellant was required to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that he acted in self-defense. The trial court's general instruction on the elements of self-defense stated that the defendant must show: (1) that he was not at fault in giving rise to the affray, (2) that he had a bona fide belief that he was in imminent danger of death or great bodily harm and that his only means of escape from danger was the use of such force, and (3) that he did not violate any duty to retreat or avoid the danger.

The jury found appellant guilty of the lesser included offense of murder and he was sentenced to the statutory term of fifteen years to life with a three-year consecutive term by reason [***5] of the gun specification.

On appeal, appellant renewed his contention that the state of Ohio could not, consistent with due process, require him to meet the burden of proving self-defense by a preponderance of the evidence. Appellant also assigned as error the trial court's refusal to submit his proposed special instruction on the duty to retreat to the jury.

The court of appeals found appellant's assignments of error not well-taken and affirmed his conviction.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's judgment of conviction against defendant for murder and his sentence of 15-years to life in prison.


OVERVIEW: Defendant appealed the appellate court's affirmance of the judgment of conviction against defendant for murder, rejecting his claims of self-defense. The appellate court's judgment was affirmed. The court held where the state was required to prove beyond a reasonable doubt every element of a crime as defined by statute, defendant was required to prove, by a preponderance of the evidence, the affirmative defense of self-defense. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2901.05. As long as the prosecution was required to prove the elements of a crime, there was no additional constitutional requirement to prove the absence of self-defense. The Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, U.S. Const. amend. XIV, was not offended by placing the burden of going forward with the affirmative defense of self-defense on the accused pursuant to § 2901.05. Further, the court held that the failure to give the special instruction on the duty to retreat neither affected defendant's substantial rights nor contributed to his conviction. Ohio R. Crim. P. 52(A). As demonstrated by the evidence, the jury simply rejected defendant's theory of self-defense.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment of conviction against defendant because due process was not offended by placing the burden of going forward with the affirmative defense of self-defense on defendant.

 

123 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Fricker v. Stokes


No. 85-1177


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 202; 490 N.E.2d 577; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 576; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 354



March 12, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamiltion County.

This appeal concerns the constitutionality of a strip search. The plaintiff's evidence is summarized as follows.

On June 9, 1982, DeAnna L. Fricker, plaintiff-appellee, was driving home from work to study for college examinations scheduled for the next morning. A Cincinnati police officer stopped her for speeding. (Fricker admitted at trial of the instant cause that she had been speeding.) The officer ran a computer check and discovered that a capias warrant had been issued in Fricker's name for failure to appear in court on a charge of driving while under the influence. When the officer informed Fricker of the outstanding capias, she denied ever having received a citation and insisted that a mistake had been made. Indeed, although the capias warrant was facially accurate, DeAnna Fricker had not committed the underlying offense; rather, Fricker's sister Katherine had been arrested and falsely gave her name as DeAnna Fricker. The underlying charge against Fricker was eventually dismissed. The officer transported Fricker to the precinct where he verified and reverified the capias. No search of Fricker of [***2] any kind was made at the precinct.

Fricker telephoned her mother from the precinct, but bond arrangements were not made. Then, another officer transported Fricker to the Community Correctional Institute ("C.C.I.") where Fricker was to be held until she could appear before the Hamilton County Municipal Court. Upon arrival at C.C.I., the transporting officer delivered Fricker to the matrons and told them that Fricker had been "no problem" and had been "cooperative." When Fricker heard the gates slam shut behind her, she began to plead with the matron, insisting on her innocence. Having never been incarcerated before, Fricker became increasingly frightened.

A C.C.I. matron told Fricker to remove her jewelry. Concerned that her jewelry might be stolen or lost, Fricker asked repeatedly why it was being taken. The matron provided no explanation. Reluctantly, Fricker complied with the demand. Then the matron told Fricker to remove the bobby pins from her hair. The matron apparently became irritated because Fricker so slowly complied with her requests, so the matron "started ripping the bobby pins" out of Fricker's hair.

Fricker, who could see lit cigarettes and smoke coming [***3] out of jail cells, reached to get a cigarette from her purse which was on a counter. The matron slammed her hand on top of Fricker's and said, "[N]o." Fricker, frustrated, "threw" her purse and it fell off the counter.

Next, matrons took each of Fricker's arms and escorted her to a cell. Fricker began cursing. She told the matrons that she had final exams in the morning and that she needed to leave. Once Fricker was in the cell, a matron called Fricker a "bitch" and shoved her so that her head hit a concrete wall, hard enough to stun Fricker and to affect her vision. Fricker crawled over to a cot and sat down.

The matron then ordered Fricker to take off her clothes; Fricker refused. The matron offered no explanation; she told Fricker that if she did not remove her clothes, her clothes would be forcibly removed. Fricker became afraid that if she failed to comply she would be harmed. Determined to retain her dignity, Fricker took off her clothing one piece at a time, waiting to be ordered to take off each article including her brassiere, underpants, and rubber thongs. Finally, the matron grabbed Fricker's reading glasses from her face, and told her to stand up and squat.  [***4] The matron glanced at Fricker, then left. Fricker testified that she "felt raped" by the search process.

At no time did any of the officers or matrons ask Fricker whether she was carrying weapons, drugs, or other contraband. Fricker never saw anyone search her small purse, and no one searched Fricker's clothing either before or after it was removed. Nor did the matrons search the clothing of a detainee on a drug charge who was later placed in the cell with Fricker.

As the result of Fricker's behavior at C.C.I., she was charged with disorderly conduct, to which she pled innocent; she was later found guilty.

Fricker filed a complaint for damages for false imprisonment in the court of common pleas, alleging violation of her constitutional rights. At trial, in addition to the testimony outlined above, Fricker introduced evidence as to her damages. At the close of plaintiff's evidence, the trial court granted defendant's motion for a directed verdict. The court of appeals reversed and remanded the cause for trial, finding that the strip search was unconstitutionally conducted in light of Bell v.. Wolfish (1979), 441 U.S. 520.

This cause is now before this court pursuant [***5] to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sheriff sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed a directed verdict entered in his favor in appellee college student's action alleging false imprisonment and violation of her constitutional rights. The appellate court remanded the case for trial, finding that a strip search of the student was unconstitutionally conducted.


OVERVIEW: The student was stopped for speeding and taken to a correctional facility because a capias warrant had been issued in her name. The student had not committed the other offense; rather, her sister had been arrested and falsely gave her name. At the facility the student asserted her innocence and, after a dispute with the matrons, she was strip-searched. She was later found guilty of disorderly conduct. She sued the sheriff, and the trial court directed a verdict for him. The appellate court reversed, holding that the trial court did not properly employ a required balancing test because the directed verdict was granted at the close of the student's evidence, and there was no evidence of facility's security interests. On appeal, the court affirmed the appellate court. Evidence that the student was never asked if she was concealing contraband, was never patted down, her clothes were never searched, and that the search was visual only and incomplete showed that the facility had no apparent legitimate and substantial institutional justification. Reasonable minds could have easily found that the strip search was performed as policy or to humiliate her for her protestations of innocence.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the reversal of the sheriff's directed verdict and remanded for trial.

 

124 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Personal Serv. Ins. Co. v. Mamone


No. 84-1875


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 107; 489 N.E.2d 785; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 563; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 189



February 19, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Coshocton County.

On September 26, 1978, appellee, Personal Service Insurance Co. ("PSI"), issued a surety bond on behalf of a strip mining permit holder who had been granted the permit pursuant to R.C. 1513.08. The permit holder, Mack Mining, Inc., commenced its strip mining operations, but defaulted on its obligation to reclaim the strip mined land as required under R.C. 1513.16. In March 1981, the Division of Reclamation notified PSI of Mack's default and demanded that PSI pay the bond or reclaim the land. As a result of the default, PSI elected to perform the reclamation itself instead of making payments under the bond.

Relevant to this action, the General Assembly enacted R.C. 1513.02(F)(1), effective September 1, 1981, which provides in part:

"A person who violates a permit condition or any other provision of Chapter 1513 of the Revised Code may be assessed a civil penalty by the chief * * *."

On May 23, 1983, appellant, Larry W. Mamone, Chief of the Division of Reclamation, Ohio Department of Natural Resources, issued "Proposed Civil Penalty Assessment Number 1523" to PSI for committing a violation of the reclamation performance [***2] standards by allowing a sediment pond to fill beyond the legally permissible limit.

On August 24, 1983, PSI filed a motion before the Reclamation Board of Review ("board of review") to dismiss the proposed civil penalty. Shortly thereafter, appellant filed a memorandum in opposition to PSI's motion. After a hearing, the board of review vacated the proposed civil penalty assessment on two grounds: (1) the assessment was an invalid retroactive application of law which, in effect, changes the terms of the surety's contract; and (2) the assessment is inconsistent with law.

Upon appeal the court of appeals affirmed, holding that the proposed civil penalty assessment was an unconstitutional impairment of the surety contract in violation of Section 10, Article I of the United States Constitution and Section 28, Article II of the Ohio Constitution. 

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals for Coshocton County (Ohio) affirmed the board of review's decision, which vacated a civil penalty assessment against appellee surety proposed by appellant Chief of the Ohio Division of Reclamation because (1) the assessment was an invalid retroactive application of law which, in effect, changed the terms of the surety's contract; and (2) the assessment was inconsistent with law. The chief sought further review.


OVERVIEW: The surety issued a bond to a strip mining permit holder. When the permit holder defaulted on its obligation to reclaim strip-mined land, the chief demanded that the surety pay the bond or reclaim the land. The surety elected to perform the reclamation. The chief proposed a civil penalty assessment against the surety for committing a violation of the reclamation performance standards by allowing a sediment pond to fill beyond the legally permissible limit. The board of review vacated the proposed civil penalty. The lower court affirmed, finding that the proposed civil penalty was an unconstitutional impairment of the surety contract. The chief appealed. The court reversed and remanded, holding that the proposed civil penalty did not unconstitutionally impair the surety contract because it merely sought to penalize the surety for violation of reclamation standards.Under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1513.02(F)(1), the surety was a "person" subject to a civil penalty assessment. Nor did the prohibition against retroactive laws apply to a sanction levied for a present violation of an existing law.Also, the enforcement techniques afforded the chief were cumulative and not mutually exclusive.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded the lower court's affirmance of the board's decision that vacated a civil penalty assessment against the surety proposed by the chief.

 

125 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Awan


No. 85-459


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 120; 489 N.E.2d 277; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 566; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 199



February 19, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Wayne County.

On May 9, 1984, appellant, Mohammed S. Awan, was involved in a collision while traveling eastbound on U.S. Route 30 when a vehicle driven by William Scholz attempted to cross such route. Scholz contended that he did not see appellant's vehicle approaching because its headlights were not in operation. The collision occurred between 8:40 p.m. and 8:45 p.m. on a day when sunset had been at 8:30 p.m. Appellant received a traffic citation charging him with operation of a motor vehicle without headlights at a "time when there were unfavorable atmospheric conditions," in violation of R.C. 4513.03. Appellant pled not guilty to this charge and the matter proceeded to trial.

The trial court found appellant guilty and fined him thirty-five dollars plus court costs. The court of appeals affirmed the conviction, refusing to address a constitutional issue which appellant had not raised in the trial court. The court of appeals, finding its decision to be in conflict with the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County in Lakewood v.. All Structures, Inc. (1983), 13 Ohio App. 3d 115, which had held in effect that a claim [***2] which concerns the constitutionality of legislation is never waived, certified the record of the case to this court for final review and determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Wayne County (Ohio), which affirmed his misdemeanor conviction for the operation of a motor vehicle without headlights at a time when there were unfavorable atmospheric conditions in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4513.03.


OVERVIEW: After defendant was involved in a motor vehicle collision, he received a traffic citation charging him with the operation of a motor vehicle without headlights at a time when there were unfavorable atmospheric conditions, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4513.03. The trial court found defendant guilty of the misdemeanor offense. The court of appeals affirmed his conviction and refused to address a constitutional attack on § 4513.03 because defendant failed to raise the issue on the trial court level. The supreme court affirmed defendant's conviction because it was not against the manifest weight of the evidence, and defendant failed to argue that the statute was constitutionally defective at the trial court level.


OUTCOME: Defendant's misdemeanor conviction was affirmed as it was not against the manifest weight of the evidence. Defendant failed to argue that the statute was constitutionally defective at the trial court level.

 

126 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Buell


No. 85-712


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 124; 489 N.E.2d 795; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 567; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 203



February 19, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County. On Saturday afternoon, July 17, 1982, eleven-year-old Krista Lee Harrison and a schoolmate collected aluminum cans in a ballpark 1 across the street from Krista's home. Krista was kidnapped from that park in broad daylight and was never seen alive again.


1 Marshallville Park in Marshallville, Ohio.

The schoolmate, Roy Wilson, testified that while they were picking up cans, a maroon-colored van with bubble-type side windows entered the park. The van, which had white-lettered tires, was positioned to face the road. The sole occupant, a man with dark brown curly-hair, a long mustache and a big nose, got out. He walked over to the park bleachers and sat down near Krista's ten-speed bike. A few minutes later, Wilson saw Krista talking to the stranger. Wilson testified that he saw the man reach inside Krista's blouse several times and each time she would knock his hand away. When Krista got on her bike to leave, the man felt under her blouse again [***2] and whispered something into her ear. Krista began to cry, got off her bike and got into the van. She sat on the carpeted floor between two black seats. As the van drove off, Wilson rode Krista's bike from the park and alerted Krista's family. Her parents called the police.

Six days later, in a remote area of Holmes County, Ohio, Krista's body was found beside a shed on Township Road 464. An autopsy revealed that Krista had been viciously sexually assaulted by the thrusting of a rigid object against the inlet of her vagina and then strangled to death. Her feet were bound with a large piece of plastic and tape. Her hair and clothing showed the presence of orange carpet fibers.

During a search of the scene and surrounding area, several articles of clothing were found, including a man's pair of paint-spotted blue jeans and two gloves. The gloves showed the presence of orange carpet fibers. While police investigated on Township Road the next day, a George Dawson turned over to them a shirt, with a "Mike's Place" label, which he said he took from the road on July 23, 1982.

Evidence was also collected the next day along Fair Road in Wayne County, Ohio. This included a clump [***3] of hair, a blanket, a green garbage bag with tape on it, and two pieces of cardboard box with the shipping label sprayed over with black paint. Further investigation revealed that the shipping label read "Sears." There were orange carpet fibers on the blanket, the cardboard pieces and on hairs found on the blanket.

Daniel Cappy, a laboratory supervisor at the Bureau of Criminal Identification and Investigation ("BCI") in London, Ohio compared the carpet fibers removed from the evidence collected on Township and Fair Roads. The orange synthetic fibers matched in color, shape and material content. Comparisons were also made of hair removed from the evidence and a hair sample from Krista. The hairs matched in color, texture and microscopic characteristics.

In October 1982, investigation and testing by the police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation ("FBI") disclosed that the plastic found around Krista's feet and the cardboard pieces were packing materials used for van seats sold by Sears, Roebuck & Company. On or about November 3, 1982, the name of the appellant surfaced in a search through the records of purchasers of these seats. Receipts showed that the appellant purchased [***4] two of these seats just sixteen or seventeen days before Krista's abduction.

No other evidence linked the appellant with the murder until mid-October 1983 when he was arrested and charged with other crimes. Police executed search warrants at appellant's residence and removed, among other things, a roll of orange-colored carpeting, cans of blue and tan paint, interior and exterior paint samples, a newspaper article with Krista's picture in it dated August 9, 1983, a plaid shirt containing a "Mike's Place" label, black spray paint and a 1978 maroon Dodge van.

Independent testing by the BCI and FBI determined that carpet fibers from the van matched fibers found on Krista's clothes. The fibers on the blanket matched fibers from the appellant's van and residence. The paint samples were compared to the paint spots on the jeans. These tests determined the blue and tan paint samples matched those on the spotted jeans.

Arnold Seawell, director of technical services for the carpet division of J.P. Stevens Company, identified the orange-colored carpet taken from appellant's home and van. Seawell testified that only twelve thousand fifteen square yards of the carpeting were ever produced [***5] and of that only seventy-four yards were ever sent to Northern Ohio.

William Kaskey, the manager of the loan adjustment department of Centran Bank of Akron, testified that appellant had purchased the van on October 22, 1980 in a stripped condition. The van had round or oval bubble-shaped side windows and was burgundy in color. Kaskey also testified that although work to the van's exterior had been contemplated, it was still unpainted when he saw it again in 1983.

The appellant's nephew, Ralph Ross, Jr., lived with him from February through July 1982. Ross testified that during those months appellant installed orange-colored carpet in his van like that in his home, and two new black seats. Appellant also replaced the bubble windows with sliding square ones.

Two of appellant's neighbors, Jeff Withrow and Carl A. Calvert, also testified regarding changes to the van, Calvert stating that appellant made drastic changes within days after Krista's death. These neighbors described the vehicle as a maroon-colored Dodge van with white-lettered tires.

Finally, Warren Walfish, appellant's supervisor, testified that on the day Krista was kidnapped, appellant took three and one-half [***6] hours leave from work in the afternoon.

Appellant was indicted on November 15, 1983 and charged with two counts of aggravated murder, with specifications, 2 three counts of kidnapping, 3 and three counts of felonious sexual penetration. 4 To avoid potential prejudicial pretrial publicity, the Court of Common Pleas of Wayne County granted appellant's motion for change of venue on March 1, 1984. A trial was held in the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, ending April 4, 1984 with a jury verdict of guilty on all eight counts including the death penalty specifications.


2 R.C. 2903.01(A) with specification R.C. 2929.04(A)(7); and R.C. 2903.01(B) with specification R.C. 2929.04(A)(7).


3 R.C. 2905.01(A)(2), 2905.01(A)(3) and 2905.01(A)(4).


4 R.C. 2907.12(A)(1), 2907.12(A)(3) and 2907.12(B).

During the sentencing phase, the jury recommended the death penalty upon finding beyond a reasonable doubt that the aggravating circumstances contained in the specifications to Courts I and II outweighed any [***7] mitigating factors. The trial court adopted the jury's recommendation and sentenced the appellant accordingly.

The court of appeals affirmed the conviction and sentence. The cause is now before this court on an appeal as a matter of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed as a matter of right from a decision of the Court of Appeals of Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed defendant's conviction on two counts of aggravated murder, with specifications, three counts of kidnapping, and three counts of felonious sexual penetration, and affirmed the jury's recommendation of the death penalty.


OVERVIEW: The trial court convicted defendant on two counts of aggravated murder, three counts of kidnapping, and three counts of felonious sexual penetration, and sentenced defendant to death. The court below affirmed the trial court's judgment. On appeal, the court held that the trial court's decision not to allow an expert to testify as to the variables which affected typical eyewitness identification did not constitute an abuse of discretion. There was no showing that the witness suffered from a mental or physical impairment which affected the witness' ability to observe or recall events. Further, the court held that it was convinced that even if the hearsay testimony were to be eliminated from consideration, sufficient evidence would remain to constitute overwhelming proof of the defendant's guilt. The court found that the death sentence imposed was appropriate in light of the existence of the aggravating circumstances and the absence of any factors in mitigation of the crime. The sentence was neither excessive nor disproportionate to the penalty imposed in similar cases. The court was convinced that defendant received objective, impartial, and unbiased review on appeal.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the court below.

 

127 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Keefe v. Eyrich


No. 85-1680


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 164; 489 N.E.2d 259; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 571; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 252



January 31, 1986 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

John W. Keefe, the relator, is a judge presently serving in the First District Court of Appeals. Because of the impending expiration of his term, Judge Keefe, on October 2, 1985, filed a declaration of candidacy and a petition to have his name placed on the Democratic primary election ballot for May 6. The Hamilton County Board of Elections, a respondent herein, refused to certify Judge Keefe's name for the reelection. Respondents admit that Judge Keefe's petition was proper as to form and bore the requisite number of signatures. Their refusal to submit Judge Keefe's name to the voters is based solely on the fact that Judge Keefe was born on April 24, 1915, making him seventy years old, and that he therefore will be unable to qualify for office under Section 6(C), Article IV of the Ohio Constitution. That provision states in part: "No person shall be elected or appointed to any judicial office if on or before the day when he shall assume the office and enter upon the discharge of its duties he shall have attained the age of seventy years. * * *"

Judge Keefe instituted the present action in mandamus, naming the Hamilton County Board of Elections, its [***2] members, and Sherrod Brown, Secretary of State, as respondents. In his complaint he alleges, inter alia, that Section 6(C), Article IV of the Ohio Constitution, on its face and as applied to him, contravenes the Constitution of the United States and also is in conflict with other provisions of the Constitution of Ohio.

Respondents filed two motions to dismiss. We overruled both motions on December 18, 1985, and we now consider this dispute on its merits.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator judge instituted an action in mandamus against respondents, the county board of elections, its members, and the secretary of state, seeking to compel respondents to place the judge's name on a primary election ballot. The court overruled two motions to dismiss and considered the dispute over the judge's eligibility for reelection on its merits.


OVERVIEW: Because of the impending expiration of his term, the judge filed a declaration of candidacy and a petition to have his name placed on the primary election ballot. The county board of elections refused to submit his name to the voters because the judge was 70 years old and therefore did not qualify for office under Ohio Const. art. IV, § 6(C). The judge asserted that § 6(C) violated the United States Constitution. The court held that under the rational basis standard § 6(C) was not invalid in view of the fact that there was no fundamental right to be a candidate for public office. The court could not find that the reasons given for mandatory retirement of judges were so irrational that they did not correspond with legitimate interests of the people of the state. Consequently, the court concluded that the judge could not establish a clear legal right to the relief he sought. It followed, then, that there was no duty whatsoever to certify his name for placement on the primary election ballot.


OUTCOME: The court denied the judge's petition for a writ of mandamus to allow him to run for reelection.

 

128 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Schwartz v. McAtee


No. 85-604


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 14; 488 N.E.2d 479; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 544; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 12



January 29, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Tuscarawas County.

Appellees, Dale and Thelma Schwartz, owned and operated Shel-Mar Estates, a mobile home park in New Philadelphia, Ohio. In July 1983, appellant, Kirk McAtee, moved into the park and received a copy of the park regulations. One of the regulations prohibited possession by tenants of large-size dogs. Appellant acquired a German shepherd dog and by notice dated May 2, 1984, Mrs. Schwartz notified appellant to have the dog removed from the park. Appellant did not comply and on May 11, 1984, Mrs. Schwartz wrote to appellant advising him that his oral lease would be terminated as of June 20, 1984 and that appellant should remove his mobile home and all personal property from the park on or before that date.

On July 12, 1984, appellant, having not moved from the park, received from appellees a "Notice To Leave The Premises." The notice stated:

"You are hereby notified that on or before July 15, 1984 you are to cause your mobile home to be moved from the premises * * *.

"* * *

"Grounds: Holding over after termination of thirty (30) day oral lease. Said termination being effective June 20, 1984, as provided for with [***2] 30 days notice in letter from owner's [sic] to tenant dated May 11, 1984. * * *" (Emphasis added.)

Appellant remained in the park and on July 18, 1984, appellees filed a two-count complaint pursuant to R.C. Chapter 1923 (which deals with forcible entry and detainer actions) in the Municipal Court of New Philadelphia. In the first count of the complaint, appellees alleged that appellant "entered into a possession of * * * [the premises at Shel-Mar Estates] at a rental of Seventy-Six Dollars ($ 76.00) per month payable on the 1st day of each calendar month in advance; that on the 11th day of May, 1984, * * * [Shel-Mar Estates] served upon Defendant a 30 day notice to vacate the premises; that on the 12th day of July, 1984, * * * [Shel-Mar Estates] duly served upon * * * [appellant] as required by law a written notice to leave the premises within 3 days of said service.

"* * *

"Therefore, * * * [appellant] now is unlawfully and forcibly detaining possession of said premises from * * * [Shel-Mar Estates] as a holdover tenant under Ohio Revised Code Sections 1923.02(A)(1), 3733.091(A)(3)."

In the second count of the complaint, appellees sought to recover damages [***3] resulting from appellant's actions. Appellees prayed for judgment which would restore the subject matter premises to their possession and for damages.

The case went to trial on August 24, 1984. At the conclusion of the trial, Shel-Mar's attorney moved to amend the complaint "* * * to add * * * that * * * [appellant] has been requested to vacate the premises * * * for park rule violations." The record does not reflect that the trial court ever ruled on this motion. On September 17, 1984, the municipal court ruled in favor of Shel-Mar and against appellant. The court said:

"* * * The plain meaning of Section 3733.091(A)(3) provides for a mobile home park operator to seek restitution of premises in forcible entry and detainer utilizing Chapter 1923, Ohio Revised Code, when a tenant is 'holding over his term.' * * *

"* * *

"In this case it is clear that * * * [Shel-Mar has] complied with the provisions of Ohio law in notifying * * * [appellant] of * * * [its] intent to terminate the month-to-month tenancy. There is no defect in notice and, as a consequence, the first claim of * * * [Shel-Mar] must be granted."

Upon appeal, the court of appeals held that appellees [***4] could successfully maintain an action in forcible entry and detainer even though their complaint failed to allege appellant had defaulted in the payment of his rent or breached the terms of his rental agreement. The court finding its decision to be in conflict with the decision of the Court of Appeals for Lucas County in Ward v.. Allen (July 2, 1981), No. L-80-388, unreported, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee landlords filed a forcible detainer action against appellant tenant after the tenant had failed to vacate the mobile home park owned by the landlords. The Court of Appeals for Tuscarawas County (Ohio) affirmed the grant of a forcible detainer against the tenant.


OVERVIEW: The tenant had neither defaulted in payments of rent nor breached the terms of his oral rental agreement. The landlords terminated the lease because the tenant had violated a park rule regarding owning a dog and the tenant refused to leave. The landlords unilaterally terminated the lease nine days after giving the tenant a citation notice, which stated the tenant had two days to remove the dog. The court reversed the judgment. In so doing, the court held that (1) because the landlords failed to follow the procedure mandated by Ohio Rev. Code § 3733.13, which provided that the tenant must have at least 30 days to remedy the noncompliance, they did not cause the tenant to become a holdover tenant, and (2) because there was no allegation in the landlords' complaint that the tenant defaulted in the payment of rent or breached a term of his rental agreement, the complaint failed to state a claim upon which relief could be granted.


OUTCOME: The judgment was reversed, and the complaint was dismissed for failure to state a claim.

 

129 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Dayton Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 44 v. State Employment Relations Bd.


No. 85-314


Supreme Court of Ohio


22 Ohio St. 3d 1; 488 N.E.2d 181; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 542; 22 Ohio B. Rep. 1; 124 L.R.R.M. 2649



January 16, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

On April 12, 1972, the City Commission of Dayton, Ohio passed an ordinance dealing with public-sector collective bargaining. The ordinance provided that certain categories of employees, including "supervisory employees," could not participate in the collective bargaining process. It further provided that the city manager was responsible for "* * * determining the appropriate representation unit * * *." On December 29, 1972, the city manager determined that all Dayton Police Department sergeants, lieutenants and captains and all lieutenants, captains and district chiefs of the Dayton Fire Department were "supervisory employees" within the meaning of the ordinance and excluded them from the bargaining unit represented by the Dayton Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 44 ("FOP") and the International Association of Fire Fighters.

The FOP then filed a lawsuit in the Court of Common Pleas of Montgomery County challenging the validity of the ordinance and seeking a judicial determination of its rights. On July 22, 1976, the court declared that the ordinance was valid in all respects, that police sergeants, lieutenants and captains were "supervisory employees" within [***2] the meaning of the ordinance, and that the city manager had properly excluded them from the FOP representation unit. 1 On May 16, 1978, the court of appeals affirmed. 2 


1 FOP v.. Dayton (C.P. 1976), 92 L.R.R.M. 3559, 3566.


2 FOP v.. Dayton (1978), 60 Ohio App. 2d 259 [14 O.O.3d 238].

In 1983, Ohio enacted the Public Employees Collective Bargaining Act, which is codified in R.C. Chapter 4117. The Act, which took effect on April 1, 1984, created the State Employment Relations Board ("SERB") ( R.C. 4117.02[A]) and provided that the SERB would be responsible for determining whether proposed employee bargaining units qualify as a bargaining unit under the terms of the Act ( R.C. 4117.06). In addition, the Act broadly defines "public employer," R.C. 4117.01(B), and "public employee," R.C. 4117.01(C), but states that "supervisors" do not have collective bargaining rights under the Act, R.C. 4117.01(C)(10) and 4117.03.

 R.C. 4117.01(F) defines "supervisor":

"'Supervisor' means any individual [***3] who has authority, in the interest of the public employer, to hire, transfer, suspend, lay off, recall, promote, discharge, assign, reward, or discipline other public employees; to responsibly direct them; to adjust their grievances; or to effectively recommend such action, if the exercise of that authority is not of a merely routine or clerical nature but requires the use of independent judgment * * *."

The broad sweep of this definition is substantially narrowed by R.C. 4117.01(F)(2):

"With respect to members of a police or fire department, no person shall be deemed a supervisor except the chief of the department or those individuals who, in the absence of the chief, are authorized to exercise the authority and perform the duties of the chief of the department. Where prior to June 1, 1982, a public employer pursuant to a judicial decision rendered in litigation to which the public employer was a party, has declined to engage in collective bargaining with members of a police or fire department on the basis that such members are supervisors, those members of a police or fire department do not have the rights specified in Chapter 4117 of the Revised Code for the purposes of future [***4] collective bargaining. * * *"

The second sentence of R.C. 4117.01(F)(2) is the so-called "Dayton Amendment," and is the subject of this lawsuit.

On or about April 4, 1984, the FOP filed a Request for Voluntary Recognition as a bargaining unit with the SERB. A copy of the request was served on the city of Dayton. The request described the proposed bargaining unit as, "[s]worn supervisors of [the] Dayton Police Department holding the ranks of Sergeant, Lieutenant and Captain." The request was assigned case No. 84-VR-04-0231. By a letter dated May 29, 1984, the Mayor of Dayton wrote to the SERB, stating in part:

"As you are well aware, supervisors in Dayton's city government are treated differently, under state law, than supervisors in uniformed services in other communities. * * *

"The so-called 'Dayton Amendment' to the new State Collective Bargaining Law is thought, by some, to be unconstitutional in that Dayton's uniformed supervisors are addressed differently than those in all other Ohio cities.

"We are seeking direction and decision from the members of the State Employment Relations Board. * * *

"* * * [I]t would only seem fair if supervisory employees around [***5] the state were treated as are Dayton's employees, or, in the alternative, Dayton's employees were treated as all others -- in other words, the law should probably apply one way or the other, equally across the state of Ohio.

"We are, therefore, requesting that this case be used as a vehicle for obtaining a formal, legal opinion as to the constitutionality of the 'Dayton Amendment' to the State Collective Bargaining Law."

On May 31, 1984, the city of Dayton filed a motion to dismiss the FOP Request for Voluntary Recognition on the ground that the bargaining unit proposed by the FOP consisted of persons who are not "public employees" under the Act and thus "* * * do not have the rights specified in Chapter 4117. of the Revised Code for purposes of collective bargaining, because prior to June 1, 1982 * * * [the city] declined to engage in collective bargaining with such [police department] members pursuant to judicial decisions in litigation to which the * * * [city] was a party."

On June 14, 1984, a SERB hearing officer issued a proposed order recommending that the city's motion to dismiss be granted. He noted that Dayton's Mayor had requested that the board determine the [***6] constitutionality of the "Dayton Amendment," but concluded that since the SERB was an administrative agency, and not a court, it had no authority to make such a determination. He went on to find that Dayton Police Department sergeants, lieutenants and captains did not have the right to engage in collective bargaining, "* * * in that they were determined to be supervisors under the terms of * * * [the relevant Dayton ordinance] pursuant to a judicial decision rendered in litigation to which the public employer was a party prior to June 1, 1982."

The FOP filed exceptions to the proposed order with the entire board. On November 21, 1984, the board issued an opinion in effect accepting the hearing officer's recommendations. The board found that the "* * * [Dayton Amendment] was intended to apply, and does apply, exclusively to the Dayton Police Department" (emphasis added), and that "[i]t is conceivable * * * that the uniquely exclusive specificity of the 'judicial decision' exemption offends the equal protection provisions of the Ohio Constitution and the equal protection clause in the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution." (Footnotes omitted.) The board [***7] concluded that since it was a part of the executive branch of government, it had no authority to declare the "Dayton Amendment" unconstitutional, and that such a determination could only be made by the judiciary.

On February 25, 1985, relator, the FOP, filed a complaint in this court seeking a writ of mandamus to require the SERB to reinstate case No. 84-VR-04-0231, and to rule on it in accordance with the law. Relator further requested this court to declare the "Dayton Amendment" unconstitutional. The city of Dayton and the SERB were named as respondents.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator union, the fraternal order of police, sought a writ of mandamus seeking to have respondent, the State Employment Relations Board, reinstate the union's request for voluntary recognition as a bargaining unit with the Board, and to declare as unconstitutional, an amendment to an ordinance passed by respondent city, in connection with the Public Employees Collective Bargaining Act (Act), codified in Ohio Revised Code Ch. 4117.


OVERVIEW: The city passed an ordinance, which provided that certain supervisory employees could not participate in the collective bargaining process. All police and fire department sergeants, lieutenants, and captains were supervisory employees and were excluded from the bargaining unit. The union filed a request for recognition as a bargaining unit with the Board. The Board granted the city's motion to dismiss, and the union sought a writ of mandamus. The court issued the mandamus and determined that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4117.01(F)(2) violated Ohio Const. art. II, § 26, in that the provision did not have a uniform operation throughout the state. The second sentence of § 4117.01(F)(2) was null and void because it offended the equal protection guarantees of Ohio Const. art. I, § 2 and the Fourteenth Amendment because the classification contained therein had no rational relationship to the legitimate governmental purposes of the Act. The union had a clear legal right to have its request for recognition considered by the Board and the Board was under a clear legal duty to consider the request in accordance with the law. Finally, the union had no adequate remedy at law.


OUTCOME: The court issued the writ of mandamus and declared the amendment to the ordinance was unconstitutional.

 

130 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Martin


No. 85-114


Supreme Court of Ohio


21 Ohio St. 3d 91; 488 N.E.2d 166; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 535; 21 Ohio B. Rep. 386



January 15, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On the morning of July 21, 1983, appellant, Earline Martin, shot to death her husband, sixty-eight-year-old Walter C. Martin, Sr., after an argument over grocery money. Appellant was arrested and charged with aggravated murder pursuant to R.C. 2903.01.

Appellant pleaded not guilty and, at trial, raised the affirmative defense of self-defense. Appellant took the stand and testified she feared for her life because the victim had struck her just prior to the fatal shooting. In closing argument, the prosecutor characterized appellant's testimony as a sham, amounting to a lie.

Appellant requested and received jury instructions on self-defense. At the close of evidence and argument, the trial judge instructed the jury on the offense of aggravated murder and the lesser-included offenses of murder and voluntary manslaughter. The trial court instructed the jury that it should not consider any lesser-included offense if the jury first found that the state had proved beyond a reasonable doubt all of the elements of the offense of aggravated murder. The trial court's charge included the following:

"Basically speaking,  [***2] look at the aggravated murder first. If you find the Defendant not guilty, then you go to murder. In the event that you deliberate as to murder, and making a good faith effort, you are unable to reach a verdict, then you go to the next step, the same thing, going on to voluntary manslaughter."

The jury found appellant guilty of aggravated murder with a gun specification, and the court sentenced her to life and a three-year term of imprisonment. On appeal, appellant claimed five assignments of error. First, appellant contended that the state unconstitutionally imposed upon her the burden of proving self-defense and that this, in effect, required her to prove her innocence. Second and third, appellant claimed she was denied due process of law when the trial court instructed the jury not to consider the lesser-included offenses unless and until it had reached a conclusion regarding the aggravated murder offense. Appellant further claimed that the verdict of guilty was against the manifest weight of the evidence. Finally, appellant claimed substantial prejudicial error in the prosecutor's closing remarks.

The court of appeals found these assignments of error not well-taken and [***3] affirmed appellant's conviction.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed an order of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed her conviction for aggravated murder in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.01. At trial she had asserted self-defense. On appeal, she contended that because self-defense negated the mens rea of aggravated murder, requiring her to prove self-defense compelled her to prove her innocence by disproving criminal intent.


OVERVIEW: Defendant shot to death her 68-year-old husband. At trial, she asserted self-defense, testifying that she feared for her life because the victim had struck her just prior to the fatal shooting. The jury found her guilty. On appeal, she claimed that because it was constitutionally impermissible to require her to prove her innocence, once she produced evidence of self-defense, the prosecution had to disprove it beyond a reasonable doubt. The court disagreed and affirmed, holding that § 2901.05 required the prosecution to prove beyond a reasonable doubt every element of a homicide offense as defined by statute, and the statute did not require defendant to disprove any essential element of the offense. Thus, she had to prove self-defense by a preponderance of the evidence. Self-defense involved facts peculiarly within her knowledge. The burden of proving it by a preponderance of the evidence did not require her to prove her innocence by disproving an element of the charged offense. Also, there was sufficient evidence to support the verdict. The husband had been visibly weakened as the result of a heart attack and stroke, which he suffered two months prior to the killing.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment, convicting defendant of aggravated murder.

 

131 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Williams


No. 84-1945


Supreme Court of Ohio


21 Ohio St. 3d 33; 487 N.E.2d 560; 1986 Ohio LEXIS 519; 21 Ohio B. Rep. 320



January 2, 1986, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

This appeal arises from the court of appeals' reversal of the conviction of Hank Williams, appellee, on two counts of rape. The court of appeals remanded the case to allow certain testimonial evidence proffered by appellee to be admitted at trial.

The events which led to the indictment of appellee occurred on September 27, 1983. Tracy Washington, the alleged victim, testified at trial that on the day in question she was raped by appellee after refusing to pay money on a claimed debt.

At a pretrial hearing held pursuant to R.C. 2907.02(E), appellee admitted the sexual intercourse with the alleged victim on the date in question, but claimed it was consensual. He testified as to having had numerous prior sexual encounters with the alleged victim. Further, appellee testified that the alleged victim was a prostitute, and that he was her "pimp."

At the pretrial hearing, defense witness James Hart testified on direct examination as to the alleged victim's reputation in the community as a prostitute. The trial judge ruled that this evidence would be inadmissible at trial, pursuant to R.C. 2907.02.

At trial, Ms. Washington [***2] testified on direct examination that she had not had sex with appellee prior to September 27, 1983, and that she did not have sex with men because she was "gay." During cross-examination by the defense, the following colloquy took place:

"Q. [Defense attorney] All right, and you consider yourself as a person who likes females, rather than males, in your sexual orientation, which is towards other females; is that correct?

"A. [Ms. Washington] That's correct.

"Q. All right. You offer this as a basis for the proposition that you would therefore not voluntarily have sex or intercourse or other sexual relations with a male person; is that the reason you offer it?

"A. That is right." (Bracketed material added.) Later, during the trial, defense witness John Fleming, Jr. attempted to testify on direct examination as to his prior sexual relations with the alleged victim. This evidence was objected to by the state, the appellant herein, and stricken from the record.

Appellee then proffered the pretrial testimony of James Hart as to the reputation of the alleged victim, as well as the testimony of Fleming, concerning his prior sexual activity with her and her reputation as [***3] a prostitute.

Appellee was convicted on the two counts of rape and sentenced to two concurrent terms of ten to twenty-five years' imprisonment.

On appeal, the court of appeals reversed. The case was remanded in order that the testimony of defense witnesses Hart and Fleming be admitted into evidence.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought review from an order of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed a conviction of appellee for two counts of rape and which remanded the case to allow certain testimonial evidence proffered by appellee to be admitted at trial. The state contended that evidence that the victim had a reputation in the community as a prostitute was inadmissible, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.02.


OVERVIEW: The state charged appellee with two counts of rape, and during a pretrial hearing, the trial court ruled that various evidence and testimony concerning the victim's reputation in the community as a prostitute was inadmissible, under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.02(D). Appellee was convicted of two counts of rape and sought review. The appellate court reversed the convictions and remanded to the trial court for the admission of the evidence. The state sought review of that order, and the court affirmed the appellate court's ruling, holding that the evidence sought to be admitted was probative of the contested issue in this case as to whether the victim had consented, which related to a direct element of the crime. The court found that the probative value of the testimony outweighed any interest the state had in exclusion. Further, that exclusion of the evidence was a violation of appellee's U.S. Const. amend. VI right of confrontation. The court also held that Ohio R. Evid. 608(B) did not preclude admissibility of the proffered evidence because it was offered for more than mere impeachment of credibility.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's reversal of appellee's convictions for rape and the remand for admission of certain evidence as to the victim's reputation in the community as a prostitute. The court held that appellee's interest in offering probative evidence to negate an element of the offense by showing the victim's consent outweighed the purposes of the rape shield law.

 

132 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


In re Appeal in Morrison Single County Ditch No. 1330


No. 84-1817


Supreme Court of Ohio


20 Ohio St. 3d 13; 484 N.E.2d 699; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 534; 20 Ohio B. Rep. 84



October 30, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Seneca County.

This appeal arises from a decision of the court of appeals approving a final schedule of assessments made by the board of county commissioners for a ditch improvement.

In 1975, this ditch improvement was petitioned by landowners in the Morrison Ditch watershed area of Seneca County. At the time of the petition, that portion of the ditch upon the lands of Floyd and Rita Meyers, appellants herein, was virtually obliterated and had been cultivated and planted.

The Seneca County Engineer calculated the assessments for the ditch improvement, applying the so-called "Preble County" formula, 1 and submitted his report to the Board of County Commissioners of Seneca County, appellees herein, in January 1981. Many of the landowners, including appellants, hired a private excavator to make improvements in an effort to reduce the assessments.


1 The "Preble County" formula is a complex and detailed series of calculations involving numerous factors and was first published by the County Engineer of Preble County. Yost, Rational Determination of County Ditch Assessments, Ohio County Engineers News (Nov. 1979). In the instant case, the elements used in the calculations of this formula were adapted to the peculiarities of Seneca County in determining appellants' assessments.

 [***2] These landowners appealed to the Court of Common Pleas of Seneca County which ordered the county engineer to make a second assessment taking into account the excavation work. The excavations, however, proved insufficient and the second schedule of assessments was not significantly lower than the first. Appellees then approved the new assessments.

The appellants, who owned approximately ten percent of the affected acreage, were assessed approximately thirty-six percent of the total project cost. They again appealed to the common pleas court, claiming their assessments were unconstitutionally disproportionate to the benefits which they received. Appellants also contended that the formula used to calculate the assessments did not properly determine benefits as required by R.C. 6131.15 and 6131.01.

After a trial de novo, the court entered its findings of fact and conclusions of law approving the assessments and specifically approving the "Preble County" formula as a reasonable method of determining benefits.

On appeal, appellants again attacked the formula used to calculate assessments and again claimed that their assessments were unconstitutionally disproportionate to [***3] the benefits received. Appellants also contended that the trial court erred in placing the burden of proof upon them at the trial de novo. Appellees argued that the formula used to calculate the assessments was valid and that appellants' assessments were not disproportionate. Appellees further argued that the burden of proof was properly upon appellants.

The court of appeals affirmed the judgment of the trial court, reasoning that the factors used in the "Preble County" formula were consistent with "benefits" as defined by R.C. 6131.15 and 6131.01. The court of appeals further held that appellants had not sustained their burden of proof in showing disproportionate assessments, as their lands had most needed the ditch improvement and received the greatest benefits thereby.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant landowners challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Seneca County (Ohio), which approved a final schedule of assessments made by appellee board of county commissioners (board) for a ditch improvement.


OVERVIEW: The landowners and others petitioned a ditch improvement. The county engineer calculated the assessments for the improvement, applying the so-called "Preble County" formula. After a second assessment was made, the board approved the assessments. The landowners, who owned approximately 10 percent of the affected acreage, were assessed 36 percent of the project cost. They appealed to the trial court, claiming their assessments were unconstitutionally disproportionate to the benefits that they received and that the formula used to calculate the assessments did not properly determine benefits as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 6131.15, 6131.01. The trial court approved the assessments and the formula used. The court of appeals affirmed the judgment. The landowners appealed, but the court affirmed and found that the use of the "Preble County" formula gave a rational and justifiable basis to the calculation of the assessments and demonstrated an assessment in which the landowners' greater need was proportionate to their greater benefits from the improvement. The burden was properly upon the landowners to demonstrate the unlawfulness of the assessments.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed.

 

133 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Mapes


No. 84-1885


Supreme Court of Ohio


19 Ohio St. 3d 108; 484 N.E.2d 140; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 518; 19 Ohio B. Rep. 318



August 9, 1985, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: Writ of certiorari denied Mapes v. Ohio, 476 U.S. 1178, 106 S. Ct. 2905, 90 L. Ed. 2d 991, 1986 U.S. LEXIS 1729, 54 U.S.L.W. 3810 (1986)
Post-conviction relief granted at, Remanded by State v. Mapes, 2006 Ohio 294, 2006 Ohio App. LEXIS 251 (Ohio Ct. App., Cuyahoga County, Jan. 26, 2006)


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On January 30, 1983 at approximately 7:50 a.m., appellant, David Mapes, and Rodney Newton entered Chap's Bar located on Prospect Avenue in Cleveland, Ohio. The bar was closed, but one of its owners, John Allen, and four employees were present. Allen, Ronald Rucci and Michael Williams were seated at the bar. John Hovekamp and David Yun were off to the side in a section of the bar known as the "pit area," asleep. A sixth man, Frank Kuhn, was upstairs in the building.

Mapes and Newton gained entrance through the rear of the building and, upon encountering the three men at the bar, Mapes aimed a sawed-off shotgun he was carrying at Rucci's head and instructed all three to put their hands on the bar. Allen began to make some gesture with his hands and Mapes shot him in the face. Allen fell to the floor, mortally wounded. At the sound of the shot, Rucci dove to the floor. Mapes ordered Williams to lie on the floor and then searched the men on the floor, including Allen, for money. Newton went first behind the bar to the cash register, and then proceeded to the video machines. While en route to the video machines,  [***2] Newton spotted Yun and Hovekamp in the "pit area" and notified Mapes of their presence. Mapes ordered Rucci and Williams to crawl to the "pit area" and stood guard over the four there while Newton broke into the video games with a crowbar.

Mapes and Newton next proceeded to the back of the building where the safe was located and the liquor was stored. The two were not able to open the safe as Allen had been the only one present who knew the combination. The four men then heard a door slam and, after determining it was safe, called the police. Allen was dead when the police arrived at 8:10 a.m. The police found no one at the scene but found a broken window by the parking lot of the Town House Apartments and a garage door held open by a wooden block.

Michael Reese, upon hearing the news accounts of the murder and robbery, notified a Cleveland detective that Mapes had approached him and had attempted to recruit him for the robbery of Chap's Bar. Reese gave the police a formal written statement to this effect on February 5, 1983. On February 6, the police showed a photo array to John Hovekamp. He selected photos of three individuals whom he thought resembled the gunman. This [***3] group included a photo of appellant. On the next day, a warrant for appellant's arrest and a warrant to search his apartment were obtained. This search, conducted on February 8, 1983, revealed, among other things, a crowbar. Appellant was arrested and, when questioned, he told the police that he had merely prepared an entrance to the bar, but that Newton and a man named Red had committed the robbery. On February 11, 1983, a lineup was held at which Hovekamp positively identified appellant as the man carrying the shotgun within the premises where the robbery and murder occurred.

Newton was arrested on March 4, 1983 in Akron and was interviewed by Cleveland police on March 7. He gave a full written statement to police recounting the events at the bar consistent with the accounts of the bar employees and the police investigation. This written statement was introduced at trial and Newton testified at trial. Newton also indicated that appellant had returned to his own apartment and dropped unused shells down a drainpipe and arranged to dispose of the gun. After obtaining a warrant, the police found a shell in the hole indicated by Newton. The shell was the same type that was [***4] used to kill Allen.

Rucci positively identified appellant during trial as the man who shot Allen with the sawed-off shotgun. Hayward Chambers testified at trial that appellant had admitted to him that he had robbed Chaps and killed Allen. Appellant's wife and a neighbor, Christine Alexander, both testified that appellant owned a sawed-off shotgun.

Appellant was indicted for two counts of aggravated murder under R.C. 2903.01(B). One count charged that the murder occurred during the course of an aggravated robbery. The other count charged that the murder occurred during the course of an aggravated burglary. Each of these counts had four identical specifications as follows: Under R.C. 2929.04(A)(7), one death-penalty specification alleging the offense occurred in the course of an aggravated robbery; under R.C. 2929.04(A)(7), one death-penalty specification alleging the offense occurred in the course of an aggravated burglary; under R.C. 2929.04(A)(5), one death-penalty specification alleging a prior murder conviction; and, under R.C. 2941.141, one firearm specification. In addition to the death-penalty charges, Counts Three, Four and Five each charged aggravated robbery under [***5] R.C. 2911.01, and Count Six charged aggravated burglary under R.C. 2911.11.

The jury returned a verdict finding appellant guilty of both counts of aggravated murder under R.C. 2903.01(B), but not guilty of the death-penalty specifications charged under R.C. 2929.04(A)(7). Appellant was found guilty of the firearm specification as well as Counts Four, Five and Six. Appellant was found not guilty of Count Three.

The issue of whether appellant was guilty of the prior murder specification under R.C. 2929.04(A)(5) was tried separately to the court. The court received into evidence an indictment from Passaic County, New Jersey, charging appellant with murder. Also received was a judgment of conviction entered upon appellant's plea of non vult. The court found appellant guilty of the prior murder specification under R.C. 2929.04(A)(5).

At the sentencing phase of trial, appellant made a statement on his own behalf, but presented no other witnesses. The jury returned a recommendation that the death penalty be imposed. The trial court sentenced appellant to death on the two counts of aggravated murder and to terms of imprisonment on Counts Four, Five and Six, to run consecutively.

 [***6] The court of appeals merged the conviction for aggravated murder with specifications under Count Two of the indictment with the conviction under Count One because only one homicide occurred. The court of appeals affirmed the judgment of conviction and the various sentences imposed by the trial court.

This cause is now before the court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, citing U.S. Const. amend. V, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2929.04, 2929.05, Ohio R. Crim. P. 11, Ohio R. Evid. 410, appealed a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) affirming a trial court judgment convicting defendant of aggravated murder, aggravated robbery, aggravated burglary, and a firearm specification, and sentencing him to death, for robbing a bar and fatally shooting its owner.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued on appeal that his foreign state conviction on a non vult plea was inadmissible to prove a prior murder specification, that the "death-qualification" of each juror should have been made separately, and that he was denied his right to remain silent by the prosecutor's comment on his unsworn statement during the sentencing phase. The court affirmed the judgment. The court held that admission of a conviction entered upon a no contest plea to prove a prior murder specification was not precluded by Ohio R. Crim. P. 11 or Ohio R. Evid. 410. The court stated that the determination of whether voir dire in a capital case should be conducted in sequestration was a matter of discretion within the province of the trial judge. The court observed that because the jury had to determine the weight attributed to defendant's unsworn oral statement, the state could dispute the weight of that statement without violating defendant's Fifth Amendment rights. The court concluded that the mitigating factors did not outweigh the aggravating circumstances and that the sentence of capital punishment was neither excessive nor disproportionate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals affirming the judgment of the trial court convicting and sentencing defendant for aggravated murder, aggravated robbery, aggravated burglary, and a firearm specification.

 

134 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Calhoun


No. 84-1569


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 3d 373; 481 N.E.2d 624; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 450; 18 Ohio B. Rep. 429



August 7, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.

Appellee, William E. Calhoun, was indicted on one count of voluntary manslaughter in violation of former R.C. 2903.03. 1 Appellee entered a plea of not guilty. A jury trial commenced on October 18, 1982. After the jury had been impanelled and sworn, and following opening statements and the testimony of two witnesses for the state, the trial court called counsel into chambers, where the following discussion and decision transpired:

"THE COURT: Let the record show we are in chambers. It is now 11:30, and we have been discussing a problem since nine-thirty this morning, and we have arrived at the situation which is as follows: "The Prosecutor will state that their [sic] evidence will not establish that the defendant while under extreme emotional stress brought on by serious provocation reasonably sufficient to incite him into using deadly force caused the death of another, and that the defendant's position is equally that his client was not under extreme emotional stress brought on by serious provocation reasonably sufficient to incite him into using deadly force. Is that correct?

"MR. HENSLEY [defense attorney]:  [***2] That's correct.

"THE COURT: And that is your agreement?

"MR. GOELZ [prosecutor]: That is our agreement.

"THE COURT: The state of the record being as it is and after a prolonged discussion of the impact of State v.. Solomon, 66 O.S. 2d 214, 20 O.O. 3d 213, and State v.. Muscatello, 55 O.S. 2d 201, 9 O.O. 3d 148, the first syllabus of which reads as follows:

"'Extreme emotional stress, as described in R.C. Sec. 2903.03, is not an element of the crime of voluntary manslaughter.' [T]his Court's view is that a normal interpretation of the statute under the rules of construction would make this a necessary element to be proved by the Prosecutor. The impact of Muscatello seems to indicate that this is not an element, which renders the statute vague and uncertain as not informing the defendant precisely with what he is charged, and is therefore unconstitutional. 

"MR. GOELZ: You want to in your entry get that langue [sic language] in, and after the holding of the Court that the statute is unconstitutional, you will want to dismiss the indictment against the defendant.

"MR. HENSLEY: I don't think you should go that far. "(Further discussion, off the [***3] record)

"THE COURT: Therefore, the Court dismisses the indictment. You prepare an entry and submit it to Jim [defense attorney] for approval. "There's no point in bringing the jury back, is there?

"MR. GOELZ: Not unless you want to advise them.

"THE COURT: I'll go back to the jury room and tell them, if that's all right with you.

"MR. GOELZ: That's all right. "(Court was then adjourned)."


1 This section was amended effective May 19, 1982.

The state then appealed this dismissal of the indictment. The court of appeals, in a decision rendered on April 18, 1983, found that R.C. 2903.03 was not unconstitutionally vague and thus reversed the decision of the trial court and remanded the cause for further proceedings. This decision was appealed to the Supreme Court of Ohio, and on September 14, 1983, this court overruled the motion for leave to appeal (case No. 83-948).

On January 12, 1984, appellee was again brought before the trial court for arraignment on the same charges and same indictment.  [***4] A plea of not guilty was entered.

Appellee then filed a motion to dismiss the indictment on the grounds that he had previously been placed in jeopardy for the same charge and on the same indictment. The court, in granting the motion, first determined that the dismissal of the indictment was on the judge's own motion and that the termination of the trial was against the desire of the appellee. The court then held that there was no manifest necessity to dismiss the indictment and that to retry the appellee at this time would violate the appellee's right not to be placed twice in jeopardy. The court reasoned that "[i]f the trial judge had allowed the trial to continue to its conclusion, and applied the prosecutor's interpretation of the statute, then the defendant's [appellee's] right to have his case determined by a 'particular tribunal' would have been protected. If the jury had returned a conviction, the judge could still have found that the statute was unconstitutionally vague and arrested the judgment pursuant to Rule 34 of the Ohio Rules of Criminal Procedure. This decision could have been appealed by the State, and if the appeals court then found that the statute was [***5] constitutional, and not vague, could have reinstated the jury conviction. This procedure or approach would have protected the defendant's [appellee's] rights as well as allowed for a determination of the validity of the statute."

On appeal, the decision of the trial court was affirmed, the court of appeals stating that it agreed "with the trial court that jeopardy attached, and * * * that * * * [it adopted the trial] court's well reasoned opinion as rationale for * * * [its] holding."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County (Ohio), which held that double jeopardy had attached to appellee's indictment for voluntary manslaughter. The appellate court held that the dismissal of appellee's first indictment was on the trial judge's own motion and that the termination of the first trial, following opening statements and the testimony of two state witnesses, was not of appellee's wishes.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, the issue was whether a subsequent retrial of a criminal defendant based on the same indictment was barred by double jeopardy where the trial judge sua sponte ruled midtrial that the statute upon which the indictment was based, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2903.03, was unconstitutionally vague and then terminated the proceedings. The court held that the trial court's reasoning for terminating the proceedings was not premised upon the insufficiency of the prosecutor's evidence. The court reasoned that the jury had neither found appellee guilty nor voted for his acquittal. The court held that both appellee and the state were entitled to have one complete trial which terminated in a verdict on a finding that the state's case was legally insufficient to sustain a conviction. The court reversed the appellate court's judgment and held that double jeopardy did not bar retrial where the trial judge ruled midtrial that § 2903.03, upon which the indictment was based, was unconstitutionally vague and dismissed the indictment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment, which held that retrial of appellee was barred by the doctrine of double jeopardy.

 

135 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Fred Stecker Lincoln-Mercury, Inc. v. Ohio Motor Vehicle Dealers Bd.


No. 84-1038


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 3d 391; 481 N.E.2d 635; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 463; 18 Ohio B. Rep. 444



August 7, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Relator, Fred Stecker Lincoln-Mercury, Inc., is a Delaware corporation qualified to conduct business in Ohio. At present, relator is a party to an agreement with Ford Motor Company, Lincoln-Mercury Division (hereinafter "Ford"), whereby relator is to operate a retail automobile dealership for the sale of new Lincoln and Mercury automobiles at a proposed facility in Orange Village, Ohio.

In April 1983, Ford, pursuant to R.C. 4517.50, notified the Motor Vehicle Dealers Board (hereinafter "Dealers Board"), a respondent herein, as well as other Lincoln-Mercury dealers in the relevant market area, of its intention to establish the new dealership. As permitted by R.C. 4517.50, three existing Lincoln-Mercury dealers filed protests to Ford's franchise proposal. After a lengthy hearing on the protests, the hearing examiner for the Dealers Board issued a recommendation to partially uphold the protests of the existing dealers.

Following an appeal of the hearing examiner's recommendation, the Dealers Board ruled in Ford's favor and denied the protests in a two-to-one decision dated March 30, 1984. Relator then applied to the Registrar of Motor Vehicles (hereinafter [***2] "Registrar"), also a respondent herein, for a dealership license in accordance with R.C. 4517.02 and 4517.04. The facility passed inspection and was assigned a permit number; however, prior to the issuance of the dealership license by the Registrar, the protestants sought reconsideration of the March 1984 decision of the Dealers Board. One of the members of the March 30, 1984 panel had by this time resigned, and the dissenter to the original decision, David Mainwaring, participated as a member of the reconstituted board which granted, on April 16, 1984, the request for reconsideration. On April 27, 1984, the reconstituted board reversed its earlier decision and issued a new order upholding the protests, thus denying the establishment of the proposed franchise. From this decision Ford instituted an appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County in accordance with R.C. 119.12. 1 


1 Hal Artz Lincoln-Mercury, Inc. et al. v.. Ford Motor Co., Lincoln-Mercury Div., case No. 84CV-05-2517.

 [***3] In the action now before this court, relator seeks a writ of mandamus, contending that respondents are under a clear legal duty to approve the application for a dealership license.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator retailer sought a writ of mandamus, contending that respondent Ohio Motor Vehicle Dealers Board was under a legal duty, pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code § 4517.02, to approve the retailer's application for a dealership license.


OVERVIEW: The retailer sought a dealership license from the Board under Ohio Rev. Code § 4517.02 to sell a manufacturer's cars. The manufacturer notified the Board and the dealerships in the relevant market area of the proposed new franchise as required by Ohio Rev. Code § 4517.50, however, the manufacturer's request was denied. The manufacturer sought relief in an independent action that was still pending. The court denied the retailer's request for a writ of mandamus to compel issuance of the license. The court held that the retailer failed to identify its legal right to be issued a new motor vehicle dealer's license as well as the Board's legal duty to issue the license because any right the retailer may have possessed to obtain the dealership license under Ohio Rev.
