Code § 4517 was contingent upon the approval of the manufacturer's franchise proposal. The court concluded that the retailer's action was a collateral attack upon the Board's decision to deny the manufacturer's franchise proposal.


OUTCOME: The court denied the retailer's request for a writ of mandamus requiring the Board to issue a dealership license.

 

136 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Cramer v. Bd. of County Comm'rs


No. 84-1149


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 3d 157; 480 N.E.2d 443; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 406; 18 Ohio B. Rep. 214



July 10, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Crawford County.

Appellees and cross-appellants, Marilyn Cramer, Clerk of the Crawford County Municipal Court, and Judge John F. Bender, Judge of the Crawford County Municipal Court (hereinafter "appellees"), submitted a budgetary request for the 1984 municipal court employee salary appropriation in the amount of $ 110,000 to appellants and cross-appellees, the Crawford County Board of County Commissioners and its individual members (hereinafter "appellants"). On March 7, 1984, appellees subsequently adjusted their request to an appropriation of $ 95,000 for municipal court employee salaries.

Appellants approved $ 81,625 for municipal court employee salaries for 1984. Appellees rejected appellants' appropriation. On March 20, 1984, appellants notified Judge Bender that no payroll vouchers would be signed and that no paychecks would be issued on March 23, 1984, until the appropriation dispute was resolved. On March 23, appellees filed a complaint in mandamus in the court of appeals seeking to compel appellants to grant the requested appropriation. On March 27, 1984, the court of appeals entered judgment denying [***2] appellees' complaint for mandamus. However, on March 30, the court of appeals set aside this judgment and issued an order directing appellants to approve and sign the payroll vouchers of the court employees and to approve appellees' appropriation request, or to show cause why they had not done so at a hearing to be held on April 16, 1984.

On April 16, the court of appeals held the scheduled hearing. Subsequently, the court, on June 19, 1984, ordered that the requested appropriation be approved, with the exception that the amount of the requested increase contained therein for the salary of appellee Marilyn Cramer, which was over the amount fixed for that position by appellants, be deleted.

On June 29, 1984, appellants filed a motion to stay the order of the court of appeals pending further appeal. The appellate court granted appellants' motion pending the outcome of the appeal to this court. Appellants filed a notice of appeal to this court and appellees cross-appealed.

This court, on June 5, 1985, modified the stay order of the court of appeals so as to affect only the personnel in the Crawford County Municipal Court whose salaries have been challenged in the within action.

 [***3] The cause is now before this court upon an appeal and cross-appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of county commissioners challenged a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Crawford County (Ohio), which ordered the board to approve and sign the payroll vouchers of certain court employees and to approve a budgetary appropriation request of appellees, a clerk and municipal judges. The clerk and judges filed a cross-appeal, asserting that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.31(C) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The board adjusted appellees' requested salary appropriation and appellees filed a complaint in mandamus to compel the board to grant the appropriation. The court affirmed the order directing approval. Pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.33, a municipal judge could appoint probation officers, typists, stenographers, statistical clerks, and official court reporters, each of whose salary was prescribed by the legislative authority. However, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.31(H) empowered the clerk of court to appoint deputy clerks and the clerk could prescribe the rate of compensation for such positions.The board contended that appellees classified several employees as deputy clerks for the sole purpose of precluding the board from establishing the rate of compensation. Municipal judges had wide latitude in prescribing particular duties of deputy clerks. The board failed to show an abuse of discretion. The municipal court properly appointed and set the salary of a bailiff who performed duties as a probation officer. The clerk's rate of compensation properly rested in the board. Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.31(C) was not a legislative encroachment upon powers of the judiciary.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment that directed the board to approve appellees' appropriation request. The court affirmed the judgment that the board had authority to set the clerk's rate of compensation.

 

137 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Johnson v. Adams


No. 84-460


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 3d 48; 479 N.E.2d 866; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 393; 18 Ohio B. Rep. 83



June 26, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Washington County.

In May 1981, appellees, Carmen Jean Johnson, Christopher Denver Johnson, and the Washington County Welfare Department, filed an action for necessaries against the appellant herein, George Denver Adams. The appellees alleged that the appellant was the natural father of Christopher Johnson (who was born on September 27, 1980), and sought judgment for expenses incurred on Christopher's behalf, an order for support, and a declaration of paternity. In a deposition taken during discovery, Carmen Johnson (Christopher's natural mother) stated that she had had sexual intercourse with the appellant during November and December 1979 and January 1980. She also stated that (1) she had married another man, Robert Glen Riggle (her sister's husband's brother), on May 19, 1980, (2) Riggle was aware that she was pregnant at the time of their marriage, (3) she had "seen" Riggle for only one week prior to their marriage, and (4) she and Riggle separated one week after their marriage.

Adams did not deny that he had had sexual intercourse with Carmen Johnson in November and December 1979 and January 1980, but he filed a motion [***2] for summary judgment on the grounds that Riggle, under the common law of Ohio, was conclusively presumed to be the father of Christopher Johnson. In support of this motion, the appellant cited Hall v. Rosen (1977), 50 Ohio St. 2d 135 [4 O.O.3d 135], which held:

"The biological father of a child can not be held for its support where the mother, during pregnancy, contracts marriage with another man, who marries her with full knowledge of her condition and thereby consents to stand in loco parentis to such child and to being the father of the child. ( Miller v. Anderson, 43 Ohio St. 473, approved and followed.)"

Upon the authority of Hall v. Rosen, the Court of Common Pleas of Washington County granted summary judgment for the appellant in September 1981.

In January 1983, the court of appeals reversed the trial court by holding, first, that R.C. Chapter 3111, as effective on June 29, 1982, was a "legislative reversal" of the conclusive presumption of paternity set forth in Hall and, second, that the amended terms of R.C. Chapter 3111 would be applicable to the appellees' claim on remand. Adams filed a motion for reconsideration on the grounds [***3] that amended R.C. Chapter 3111 could not be applied retroactively to the appellee's action, wherein judgment was entered prior to the effective date of amended R.C. Chapter 3111. The appellate court granted appellant's motion for reconsideration and vacated its original decision; but, in its second decision, the court again reversed the trial court by distinguishing the facts of Hall from those of the instant case 1 and remanding the cause for consideration of evidence to rebut the presumption that Riggle was the natural father of Christopher Johnson.


1 The court of appeals stated: "The facts of the case at bar can also be distinguished by noting the mother's marriage to her husband lasted only one week, whereas the marriage in Miller v. Anderson lasted until the death of the husband and the mother in Hall v. Rosen remarried her former husband, which marriage lasted over a year."

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment  [***4] affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant alleged father sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Washington County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's judgment and held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 3111 was a legislative reversal of the conclusive presumption of paternity and that the amended terms of § 3111 was applicable to appellees, mother, child, and welfare department's claims on remand, in the action for a declaration of paternity.


OVERVIEW: The mother asserted that she had had sexual intercourse with the alleged father, and then had married another man and that other man was aware that she was pregnant at the time of their marriage. The trial court entered judgment in favor of the alleged father on the ground that under the common law of Ohio, the mother's husband was conclusively presumed to have been the father. The court first held that § 3111 had no application to paternity actions in which judgment was entered prior to its enactment date because the statute was not retrospective. The court decided that the presumption of paternity in cases in which a man married a woman with knowledge that she was pregnant did not apply. The "common-sense" approach prevented the court from transforming the husband's relationship with a pregnant mother into a commitment to provide support for the child. The policy concerns behind the rebuttable presumption of paternity were legitimate. The court concluded that although the rebuttable presumption in § 3111 was not applicable, the rationale warranted its application in other paternity actions.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the appellate court's judgment.

 

138 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Earlenbaugh


No. 84-1087


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 3d 19; 479 N.E.2d 846; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 377; 18 Ohio B. Rep. 16; 52 A.L.R.4th 1153



June 19, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Medina County.

On April 22, 1983, at approximately 11:50 p.m., appellee, Leo R. Earlenbaugh, was operating a semi-tractor-trailer on northbound Interstate 71. At that time, Trooper Joe L. Anderson of the Ohio Highway Patrol had stopped to assist Trooper Harvey on a routine traffic matter. Anderson's cruiser was positioned behind Harvey's cruiser and was off the traveled portion of the highway some one and one-half feet from the solid white edge or berm line of northbound I-71. Both cruisers had their lights and flashers activated.

While Anderson was standing beside Harvey's cruiser, between that cruiser and the berm line of the northbound I-71 lanes, the appellee approached the parked vehicles in his semi-tractor-trailer. Anderson testified that appellee's rig began moving closer to the right edge of the lane nearest the berm. In order to avoid the oncoming rig, Anderson positioned himself flatly up against Harvey's cruiser. Anderson further testified that the appellee deliberately passed over the berm line with his tractor-trailer, to within six inches of Anderson and his cruiser, "in an apparent attempt to see how close he could [***2] get to me."

The appellee testified that he reduced his speed when he saw Anderson and the stopped vehicles. He agreed that Anderson positioned himself closely against Harvey's cruiser, but contended that he did not cross over the berm line with any portion of his truck.

Anderson then pursued the appellee for some four to five minutes, over a distance of six to seven miles, stopped him, and charged him with reckless operation in violation of R.C. 4511.20.

The Wadsworth Municipal Court found that appellee's rig crossed over the white berm line and passed within six inches of Anderson. The court concluded that "the act of crossing the line was in wanton disregard of the safety of Trooper Anderson and his vehicle" in contravention of R.C. 4511.20. The court made no finding that appellee was guilty of willful misconduct.

On appeal to the Court of Appeals for Medina County, the appellee raised the following assignment of error: "The trial court erred in finding the defendant guilty of reckless operation in violation of section 4511.20 of the Ohio Revised Code in that there was insufficient evidence to support a finding that defendant was guilty beyond a reasonable doubt." The [***3] court of appeals, while purporting to address the assigned error, held essentially that R.C. 4511.20 was unconstitutionally defective as applied to the facts of this case, and reversed. The court based this determination upon its conclusion that "[a]s the trial court herein was unable to find the defendant guilty of willful disregard, it follows he was not proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt of willful disregard of another's safety." The court of appeals, however, did not evaluate the sufficiency of the evidence supporting the trial court's finding that the appellee acted in wanton disregard of the safety of Trooper Anderson.

The cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state appealed a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Medina County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's judgment finding defendant guilty of reckless operation of a motor vehicle on the ground that there was insufficient evidence to support a finding that defendant was guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.


OVERVIEW: The trial court found that defendant was guilty of reckless operation of a motor vehicle. The appellate court reversed the trial court's finding on the ground that there was insufficient evidence to support a finding that defendant was guilty beyond a reasonable doubt. The appellate court's judgment was reversed and remanded for a determination of whether there was sufficient evidence to support the trial court's finding. The court held that the language of Ind. Code § 4511.20 was sufficiently definite to provide a clear and adequate notice of the conduct prescribed for willful and wanton operation of a motor vehicle. Thus, the court held that neither the terminology nor the application of § 4511.20 was violative of defendant's right to equal protection of the laws. The court held that every person accused of reckless operation was subject to the same requirements of the statute. Thus, the court found no violation of defendant's right to equal protection. There was sufficient evidence to support the trial court's finding that defendant violated § 4511.20 by operating a vehicle in wanton disregard of the safety of persons or property.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment reversing the trial court's finding that defendant was guilty of reckless operation of a motor vehicle, and remanded for a determination of whether there was sufficient evidence to support the trial court's finding.

 

139 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Reeder


No. 84-1025


Supreme Court of Ohio


18 Ohio St. 3d 25; 479 N.E.2d 280; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 379; 18 Ohio B. Rep. 21



June 19, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Allen County.

Appellee, William F. Reeder, was involved in an altercation with a customer at appellee's workplace, the Allen County Humane Center. The customer went to the center to obtain a refund for an animal which had died shortly after it was purchased there. An argument ensued and appellee jabbed and pushed the customer, used abusive language, and threatened to send him to jail.

A complaint was filed which alleged disorderly conduct by appellee. Upon consideration of the evidence, the trial court found appellee guilty of disorderly conduct in violation of R.C. 2917.11(A)(1). Specifically, the court noted that appellee at the least acted "reckless[ly]" and that his conduct "at the very least, is turbulent * * *."

On appeal, the court of appeals held that R.C. 2917.11(A)(1) is unconstitutionally vague in that its use of the words "turbulent behavior" does not sufficiently define the prohibited conduct. Inasmuch as the trial court based its finding of guilt, at least in part, on appellee's "turbulent" conduct, the court of appeals reversed the conviction and discharged appellee.

The cause is now before this court pursuant [***2] to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state appealed from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Allen County, Ohio, which overturned a trial court judgment which found defendant guilty of disorderly conduct pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2917.11(A)(1). The appellate court found the statute unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: After defendant was involved in an altercation with a customer in a pet store, he was charged and convicted of disorderly conduct pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2917.11(A)(1). Defendant appealed, asserting that the statute was unconstitutionally vague and the appellate court agreed. On review, the court reversed. The court found that the use of the term "turbulent," in Ohio's disorderly conduct statute, Ohio Rev. Stat. Ann. § 2917.11(A)(1), did not render the statute unconstitutionally vague because the enactment fairly informed a person of ordinary intelligence and understanding what conduct was prohibited by law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

140 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Smith


No. 84-1146


Supreme Court of Ohio


17 Ohio St. 3d 98; 477 N.E.2d 1128; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 322; 17 Ohio B. Rep. 219



May 15, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This is an appeal from the reversal of appellee's conviction of two counts of aggravated robbery. A divided court of appeals held that the trial court's refusal to permit the presentation of alibi testimony on the grounds that the appellee had failed to comply with Crim. R. 12.1 was a violation of appellee's constitutional rights as guaranteed by the Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution. The concurring judge found that defense counsel's failure to comply with the rule as noted above was a violation of defendant's rights in that he was deprived of his right to effective assistance of counsel and that the exclusion of the alibi testimony was an abuse of the trial court's discretion.

James N. Winston, Jr. and his brother, Lloyd E. Winston, were robbed by two men at gunpoint at approximately 12:45 a.m. on April 13, 1982. The assailants then forced their way into the Winston automobile and the four men drove away from the scene of the crime. Shortly thereafter, the Winstons were ordered out of the car. They then reported the crime to the police and gave a description of the stolen [***2] vehicle. Between 1:00 a.m. and 1:30 a.m. on the same night, Cleveland police officers Edward Starks and Leon Goodlow followed an automobile matching the description of the Winston vehicle. A chase ensued and the suspects lost control of the car, which crashed into a nearby house. After both men jumped out of the vehicle, the driver fired one shot at Officer Starks, and then fled. The suspects escaped.

On April 20, 1982, James Winston entered a gameroom on Cleveland's east side and spotted one of the men who had robbed him. Winston immediately informed the police and took them to the gameroom where he identified the appellee as his assailant. Winston later identified the appellee, Norman W. Smith, at a formal police lineup. At this time, Officer Starks also identified the appellee as both the driver of the stolen vehicle and the man who had shot at him.

The matter proceeded to trial. After the state had rested, counsel for the appellee announced his intention to call his client and other alibi witnesses, to establish that Smith was elsewhere at the time of the offense. Counsel had not filed a notice of alibi pursuant to Crim. R. 12.1, nor had he informed the prosecution [***3] of his planned use of an alibi defense. The trial court ruled that the appellee would not be permitted to testify as to his alibi, and that he could not call any alibi witnesses. The appellee was convicted of two counts of aggravated robbery, and the judgment of conviction was reversed upon appeal.

This cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The State appealed a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which reversed defendant's convictions for two counts of aggravated robbery.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with two counts of aggravated robbery. At trial, defendant was precluded from testifying as to an alibi because his counsel failed to file a notice of alibi as required under Ohio R. Crim. P. 12.1. Defendant was convicted. The appellate court reversed the convictions, finding that the refusal to permit the alibi testimony violated defendant's constitutional rights. The State appealed, and the court reversed the appellate court's judgment. Defense counsel's failure to timely file a notice of alibi did not constitute ineffective assistance of counsel. Counsel's noncompliance with Rule 12.1 was a trial tactic. As such, the common-sense enforcement of the notice of alibi rule, by the preclusion of defendant's testimony, did not violate his constitutional right to testify. That defendant was limited in his testimony was the result of his own failure to comply with the rules. Likewise, enforcement of Rule 12.1 did not violate defendant's right to compulsory process, as the rule did not prevent the issuance of process for witnesses. The State was unaware of the identity of the alibi witnesses, and it would have been prejudiced by the introduction of alibi testimony.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment, which reversed defendant's convictions for two counts of aggravated robbery.

 

141 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Celeste v. Smith


No. 85-589


Supreme Court of Ohio


17 Ohio St. 3d 163; 478 N.E.2d 763; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 387; 17 Ohio B. Rep. 364



May 8, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN PROHIBITION.

Intervening respondent, Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund (hereinafter "ODGF"), is a mutual deposit guaranty association incorporated pursuant to R.C. 1151.80 to 1151.92, inclusive, for the purpose of providing liquidity to its members and to guarantee the deposits in member savings and loan associations. ODGF is the only mutual deposit guaranty association in Ohio and was incorporated with Ohio's state chartered savings and loan associations as its members.

Its largest member is Home State Savings Bank, holding approximately $ 525 million in deposits. In March 1985, Home State Savings Bank failed and was unable to meet the demands of its depositors. It closed on March 9, 1985 and has not reopened.

As a result of the closing of Home State Savings Bank, it was feared that public confidence in state-chartered savings and loan associations would falter and in order to prevent mass withdrawals from other state-chartered savings and loan associations, emergency measures were undertaken.

On March 13, 1985, Sub. S. B. No. 113 was enacted effective immediately as an emergency measure. It was passed with thirty-one affirmative votes and one negative vote in the Ohio [***2] Senate (Senate Journal, Wednesday, March 13, 1985, at 121) and with seventy-three affirmative votes and fourteen negative votes in the Ohio House of Representatives (House Journal, Wednesday, March 13, 1985, at 255). The Senate Journal for March 13, 1985 reflects that a motion was "agreed to" to suspend the three-day reading requirement. (Senate Journal, Wednesday, March 13, 1985, at 119.) The House Journal also reflects a vote on March 13, 1985 to suspend the three-day rule and immediately consider Sub. S. B. No. 113. (House Journal, Wednesday, March 13, 1985, at 254.)

Sub. S. B. No. 113 amended R.C. 1151.01 to provide that a deposit guaranty association organized under R.C. 1151.81 to 1151.92 was included within the definition of "building and loan association" as that term was defined in R.C. Chapter 1157. 

The effect of that amendment was to allow the Superintendent of Savings and Loan Associations to appoint a conservator over a deposit guaranty association or liquidate a deposit guaranty association as formerly authorized only against savings and loan associations. Formerly, no statutes existed authorizing comparable overseeing or takeover powers with respect to a deposit [***3] guaranty association.

In Sections 3 and 4 of Sub. S. B. No. 113 (later amended in certain respects by Am. Sub. S. B. No. 143), the General Assembly authorized the creation of the Savings and Loan Stabilization Special Account to be created from funds from the liquor control profits and mortgage insurance fund. Section 4 also authorized the Director of Commerce, upon recommendation of the Superintendent of Savings and Loan Associations, to loan money to a new deposit guarantee fund to be created. It also provided that no savings and loan association over which a conservator had been appointed could be a member.

On March 20, 1985, former Superintendent of Savings and Loan Associations, Thomas Batties, appointed a conservator for ODGF pursuant to R.C. 1157.01(A).

On April 8, 1985, ODGF filed an action in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County which was assigned to respondent herein, Judge George C. Smith. The action was brought, inter alia, on authority of R.C. 1157.01(D) which authorizes suit to be filed in the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County to seek removal of a conservator.

The Franklin County action named Governor Richard F. Celeste, the present and former [***4] superintendents of savings and loan associations, Director of Commerce, Kenneth R. Cox, and the Deputy Superintendent of Savings and Loan Associations who was appointed conservator of ODGF, as defendants. In addition to relief under R.C. 1157.01(D), the action sought a declaratory judgment declaring Sub. S. B. No. 113 unconstitutional and an injunction against the defendants for violations of their federal constitutional rights under Section 1983, Title 42, U.S. Code.

Specifically, the complaint alleges that Sub. S. B. No. 113 was enacted without compliance with the three-reading rule in Section 15(C), Article II, Ohio Constitution. The complaint further alleges that the Act subjects ODGF to the deprivation of its property without due process of law and discriminates against ODGF; and that the Act's provisions authorizing the appointment of a conservator for ODGF is an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority and is unconstitutionally vague.

On April 12, 1985, the Superintendent of Savings and Loan Associations posted a notice taking possession of ODGF at its principal place of business in Hamilton County and filed liquidation proceedings in the Court of Common Pleas [***5] of Hamilton County, according to R.C. 1157.02.

On the same date, ODGF sought and obtained from Judge Smith an ex parte temporary restraining order prohibiting the defendants in the Franklin County action from "* * * attempting to liquidate, dispose of, take possession of or otherwise control the assets and funds of the Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund, and * * * [further enjoining them] from attempting to enforce against Ohio Deposit Guarantee Fund any power purportedly conferred upon defendants, or any of them, by S. B. 113 [sic]." On April 15, 1985, the temporary restraining order was amended on reconsideration in respects not pertinent herein.

Relators, Governor Celeste, the Director of Commerce, and Superintendent of Savings and Loan Associations Robert B. McAlister, then filed this original action in prohibition against Judge Smith, seeking the issuance of a writ to prevent him from enforcing his restraining order.

Relators' request for an alternative writ and ODGF's motion to intervene as a respondent were granted on April 17, 1985. ODGF then filed a motion to require relators to comply with the alternative writ which was denied.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relators, a governor and other state officials, filed an original action in prohibition against respondent trial court judge, seeking the issuance of a writ to prevent him from enforcing a restraining order in a case brought by respondent deposit guarantee fund. The fund sought to prevent the relators from proceeding with liquidation of an insolvent financial institution pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1157.02.


OVERVIEW: The association was a mutual deposit guaranty association incorporated for the purpose of providing liquidity to its members and to guarantee the deposits in member institutions. When its largest member failed, legislation was enacted allowing appointment of a conservator over the association. A conservator was appointed for the association. The association filed an action pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1157.01(D) seeking removal of the conservator. Subsequently, liquidation proceedings were commenced against the association pursuant to § 1157.02. On the same day, the association obtained an ex parte temporary restraining order (TRO) prohibiting relators from attempting to liquidate the association. The court granted the relators' writ in prohibition against the trial judge holding that the TRO he issued had the effect of precluding relators from pursuing the exclusive statutorily prescribed remedies in § 1157.02 and was a usurpation of judicial power. The court reasoned commencement of liquidation proceedings under §1157.02 automatically terminated a prior conservatorship imposed pursuant to § 1157.01(A), and consequently mooted any action commenced under § 1157.01(D).


OUTCOME: The court allowed the writ of prohibition filed by the relators against the trial court judge.

 

142 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Chevalier v. Brown


No. 85-402


Supreme Court of Ohio


17 Ohio St. 3d 61; 477 N.E.2d 623; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 311; 17 Ohio B. Rep. 64



April 16, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

Joseph Zahorec was elected Mayor of the city of Lorain, Ohio for the term beginning January 1, 1984 and ending December 31, 1987. On December 31, 1984, he was killed in an automobile accident. Upon Zahorec's death, the President of the Lorain City Council was appointed mayor.

On January 10, 1985, the Secretary of State's office advised the Director of the Lorain County Board of Elections that an election would be held in November 1985 for the balance of the mayor's term. Several prospective candidates filed nominating petitions for the mayoral office which were certified by the board of elections on or about February 26, 1985. The candidates had expended funds to advance their candidacies, and some had abandoned plans to file petitions for city council offices in order to join the mayoral race. Relator, Charles F. Chevalier, filed a petition for the mayoral race and did not pursue previous plans to file a petition for reelection to his council seat.

On March 7, 1985, the Secretary of State's office advised the Lorain County Board of Elections that the secretary's communication of January 10, 1985 had been in error and that no election would be held for the [***2] balance of the mayoral term ending December 31, 1987.

This action was then commenced by Chevalier and Rita Hartman, a registered voter of the city of Lorain, against the Secretary of State, the Lorain County Board of Elections and all others who had filed petitions for the Lorain mayoral race. Relators seek the issuance of a writ to either compel respondent election officials to conduct the mayoral race as originally scheduled, or, alternatively, to accept late petitions for city council offices.



DISPOSITION: Writ denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator, a member of the Lorain, Ohio, City Council, commenced an action in mandamus against respondents, the Secretary of State and the Lorain County, Ohio, Board of Elections. The council member sought the issuance of a writ to either compel election officials to conduct the mayoral race as originally scheduled, or, alternatively, to accept late petitions for city council offices.


OVERVIEW: After the mayor of the city of Lorain died, the Secretary of State's office advised the Board that an election would be held later that year. Several prospective candidates filed nominating petitions, including the council member. Because he thought that he had entered the mayoral race, the council member did not pursue his previous plans to file a petition for reelection to his council seat. The Board was soon advised, however, that the communication by the Secretary of State's office had been in error and that no election would be held for the balance of the mayoral term. Apparently none of the parties were aware of a July 26, 1984 amendment to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 733.08, which did not authorize any election. The court denied the writ, holding that § 733.08 was not to be retroactively applied. The court noted that the vacancy occurred over five months after the effective date of the amendment. The court noted that it was unfortunate that the council member and others relied to their detriment upon the erroneous statements and actions of the Board; however, the principle of estoppel did not apply against a state or its agencies in the exercise of a governmental function.


OUTCOME: The court denied the writ.

 

143 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Davis


No. 84-62


Supreme Court of Ohio


16 Ohio St. 3d 34; 476 N.E.2d 655; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 286; 16 Ohio B. Rep. 449



April 10, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Madison County.

On July 17, 1981, various officers from the West Jefferson Police Department and from the State Bureau of Criminal Identification and Investigation, acting pursuant to a validly-issued search warrant, seized approximately two hundred marijuana plants found growing on the property of Lewis H. Davis, appellee. Upon subsequent determination, the seized plants (including stalks but minus roots) were found to weigh 1,298.2 grams.

Appellee was charged with and convicted of possession of three times the bulk amount of marijuana, in violation of R.C. 2925.03(A)(6). At trial, appellee contended that the plant stalks should be excluded from the weight determination; further, appellee attempted to assert the affirmative defense of personal use as set forth in R.C. 2925.03(F). The trial court ruled against appellee on both claims, holding as to the latter that the personal use defense was not available to appellee.

On appeal, the court of appeals reversed the judgment of the trial court, on two grounds: (1) that plant stalks should be excluded when determining weight for purposes of statutory drug offenses, and (2) that the [***2] personal use defense may be asserted by a defendant charged with possession of three times the bulk amount of marijuana. Finding its judgment on the weight issue to be in conflict with the decision rendered in State v.. Tucker (Nov. 29, 1977), Franklin App. No. 77AP-319, unreported, the court of appeals certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals for Madison County (Ohio) certified for review and final determination its decision, which reversed the trial court's judgement that convicted defendant of possession of three times the bulk amount of marijuana.


OVERVIEW: At defendant's trial he asserted that the marijuana plant stalks were to be excluded from the weight determination and attempted to assert the affirmative defense of personal use as set forth in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2925.03(F). The trial court ruled against defendant and he was convicted. The appellate court reversed on the grounds that the plant stalks should have been excluded and that defendant should have been able to assert the personal use defense. On appeal, the court stated that it had previously determined that the State had no burden to separate any portion of the marijuana plant when it determined weight. The court stated that the defense set forth in § 2925.03(F) was clear on its face as not available to persons charged with possession of three times the bulk amount of a controlled substance. The court stated that because defendant was charged with possession of three times the bulk amount of marijuana he could not assert the affirmative defense of personal use.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment, which had reversed the trial court's judgment that convicted defendant for possession of three times the bulk amount of marijuana.

 

144 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Bradfield v. Stop-N-Go Foods, Inc.


No. 84-1730


Supreme Court of Ohio


17 Ohio St. 3d 58; 477 N.E.2d 621; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 310; 17 Ohio B. Rep. 62



April 3, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Montgomery County.



DISPOSITION: This cause, certified by the court of appeals (case No. 8709), is reversed on authority of Jones v.. VIP Development Co. (1984), 15 Ohio St. 3d 90.

 

145 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Black v. Board of Revision


No. 84-236


Supreme Court of Ohio


16 Ohio St. 3d 11; 475 N.E.2d 1264; 1985 Ohio LEXIS 288; 16 Ohio B. Rep. 363



March 27, 1985, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The subject of this appeal is the value of the Union Commerce Building for real estate tax purposes in the tax years 1977 and 1978.

In January 1978, appellant and cross-appellee, the Cleveland Board of Education (hereinafter "board of education") through its attorneys filed a complaint against the owners of the Union Commerce Building, Robert F. Black et al., Trustees of First Union Realty, with the Cuyahoga County Board of Revision (hereinafter "board of revision"). In its complaint, the board of education sought an increase in the assessed value of the property from $ 9,247,390 to $ 12,586,700. The $ 3,339,310 increase was derived from a reassessment of the fair market value of the building from $ 26,444,828 to $ 35,962,000.

A full evidentiary hearing was held before the board of revision and a voluminous record was compiled. Based on this record, which consisted of expert testimony and a substantial compilation of other evidence, the board ruled that the assessed valuation for the Union Commerce Building be increased by $ 5,452,610 to $ 14,700,000. This latter figure constituted thirty-five percent [***2] of $ 42,000,000, the fair market value of the property as determined by the board.

Robert F. Black et al., as taxpayer, and the Union Commerce Bank, as lessee of the building (hereinafter collectively "UCB"), appealed the board's decision to the court of common pleas pursuant to R.C. 5717.05. Specifically, UCB took exception to the fair market valuation as noted above. The court gave the parties numerous opportunities to supplement the record with additional evidence, but did not permit a trial de novo.

The matter proceeded to oral argument. The trial court heard the appeal upon the record filed with the court by the board of revision, stipulations of the parties, resolutions by the board of education authorizing its law firm to initiate the reassessment complaints on its behalf, and the briefs and oral arguments of counsel.

Based upon its independent assessment of the evidence, the court essentially upheld the board of revision's valuation of the contested property. The court found the fair market value of the building to be $ 41,500,000 for 1977 and $ 42,000,000 for 1978. The court further concluded that the assessed value would be thirty-five percent of the true value [***3] of the property. This judgment was later modified to reflect a correction in the calculation of maintenance expenses, thereby fixing the 1977 and 1978 fair market values at $ 41,000,000 and $ 41,500,000 respectively.

UCB appealed the decision to the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County. On appeal, UCB argued, inter alia, that the refusal of the common pleas court to conduct a trial de novo contravened R.C. 5717.05, with the resultant effect of depriving UCB of its constitutional rights. UCB further contended that the common pleas court violated Ohio law in its valuation of the property. Finally, UCB alleged that the common pleas court applied a discriminatory and, therefore, unconstitutional level of assessment. The court of appeals agreed and, accordingly, reversed and remanded the cause for a full evidentiary hearing consistent with its findings.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion and cross-motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant board of education appealed from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which reversed the decision upholding the Cuyahoga County Board of Revision's valuation of contested property, in the board of education's complaint against the owners of a building seeking an increase in the assessed value of the property, and remanded for a full evidentiary hearing.


OVERVIEW: The issues presented on appeal were whether the common pleas court abused its discretion in refusing to conduct a trial de novo or erred in its valuation of the building's property and whether a discriminatory level of assessment was applied. The court found that the court of common pleas did not abuse its discretion in disallowing a trial de novo. The court found that the court of common pleas was only required to review the evidence thoroughly and comprehensively, and based on its evaluation of the evidence, the court was required to make an independent judgment regarding the taxable value of the property. Furthermore, the record did not establish that the court misunderstood the submitted evidence or erroneously determined the valuation of the property in question. The evidence showed that the court maintained an adequate administrative record. The court further held that the court of common plea's method of valuation and application of a uniform rate of assessment were proper. The court of common pleas based its decision upon ample evidence and modified the original findings to correct any existing errors. The applied level of assessment was not discriminatory.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment, which reversed the decision upholding the board of revision's valuation of contested property.

 

146 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Caruso v. Aluminum Co. of America


No. 84-13


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 3d 306; 473 N.E.2d 818; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1292; 15 Ohio B. Rep. 436



December 31, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The plaintiff-appellee, Mrs. Pina Caruso, filed a claim for workers' compensation death benefits in 1976. 1 This claim alleged that the plaintiff's husband, Anthony Caruso, had died as a direct result of the occupational disease silicosis, which he had contracted within the course and scope of his fifteen-year employment with the defendant-appellant, Aluminum Company of America ("ACA"). Mr. Caruso had retired from ACA on March 1, 1966, but he apparently did not exhibit symptoms of silicosis until September 1975. At that time, Mr. Caruso was admitted to a hospital with complaints of shortness of breath and pain in his legs. He remained hospitalized until his death on November 2, 1975.


1 Apparently, as a result of a "clerical error," plaintiff's counsel became confused as to the exact date on which his client had filed her claim for death benefits. This confusion then resulted in both parties devoting considerable time, both in the court of appeals and in this court, to "statute of limitations arguments." Since these arguments were never presented in the trial court, they are not properly before this court and will not be discussed in this opinion.

 [***2] On September 13, 1978, a district hearing officer for the defendant Industrial Commission issued an order denying plaintiff's claim for death benefits. The hearing officer's order was based upon R.C. 4123.68(Y), which, at the time that plaintiff filed her claim, stated in relevant part: "Compensation * * * on account of silicosis * * * [is] payable only in the event of [disability] * * * or death, in accordance with sections 4123.56, 4123.58, and 4123.59 of the Revised Code, and only in the event of such disability or death resulting within eight years after the last injurious exposure; provided that such eight-year limitation shall not apply to disability or death occurring after January 1, 1976 * * *." 2 (Emphasis added.) Because Mr. Caruso's "last injurious exposure" to substances known to cause silicosis had occurred no later than his last day of employment on March 1, 1966, nine years and eight months had elapsed before his death on November 2, 1975. For this reason, the hearing officer found that he did not have subject matter jurisdiction over plaintiff's claim.


2 This version of R.C. 4123.68(Y) became effective on January 1, 1976. (136 Ohio Laws, Part II, 2917, 2937.) See fn. 3, infra.

 [***3] Plaintiff appealed first to the Cleveland Regional Board of Review which affirmed the hearing officer's order. The Industrial Commission affirmed the board of review. Plaintiff then appealed the decision of the Industrial Commission to the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County. ACA filed a motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, and, on September 2, 1982, the court granted this motion.

On appeal, the judgment of the court of common pleas was reversed. The appellate court held that the portion of R.C. 4123.68(Y) which denies compensation for silicosis-related deaths occurring prior to January 1, 1976 but more than eight years after "injurious exposure" is a violation of the plaintiff's constitutional rights to equal protection and due process.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant employer appealed from a decision from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which held that the portion of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.68(Y) denying workers' compensation benefits for silicosis-related deaths that occurred prior to January 1, 1976 but more than eight years after "injurious exposure" was a violation of plaintiff widow's constitutional rights to equal protection and due process.


OVERVIEW: The only issue before the court was whether Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.68(Y) (amended 1976) was unconstitutional as it applied to a claimant that sought compensation for a silicosis-related death, which occurred prior to January 1, 1976 but more than eight years after the decedent's work-related exposure to substances known to cause silicosis. The court held that it was unconstitutional and affirmed. The test was whether the statutory prerequisites to compensation were rationally related to the accomplishment of some state objective at least as important as the purpose contained in Ohio Const. art II, § 35 and reflected in the statute. Here, the statute was first enacted in 1945 when medical knowledge regarding silicosis was limited and the viability of the workers' compensation system was in doubt. However, each law's constitutionality was not cast in stone at the time of the law's enactment; nor was a law once found to be constitutional forever free from judicial scrutiny. Medical knowledge showed that silicosis could manifest after an eight-year, post-exposure period, and the workers' compensation system was no longer in danger of collapse.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed and held that the statute was unconstitutional.

 

147 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


C&D Partnership v. Gahanna


No. 83-1838


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 3d 359; 474 N.E.2d 303; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1303; 15 Ohio B. Rep. 480



December 31, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Appellants, C&D Partnership and its two general partners, John J. Cox and Michael A. Dehlendorf & Co., filed this action on March 4, 1982 against the city of Gahanna, Mayor John Breen, the city council, the planning commission, and city council and planning commission members who served during 1979 and 1980. Suit was brought against Mayor Breen and the members of council and the planning commission in both their official and individual capacities.

The parties stipulated to the following facts. On December 26, 1978, a preliminary plat of Deer Run, a proposed subdivision located within Gahanna, was submitted to the zoning officer for the planning commission pursuant to Section 1105.02 of the Planning and Zoning Code of the Codified Ordinances of Gahanna. The planning commission approved the preliminary plat on January 10, 1979, contingent upon the availability of proper water service. On or about July 31, 1979, appellants submitted the final plat for final approval by the planning commission and municipal engineer pursuant to Section 1105.04 of the city code. The director of public service of Gahanna certified [***2] to the planning commission that the availability of proper water service was assured on August 30, 1979 and thereafter, on September 12, 1979, the planning commission recommended to the council approval of the final plat.

On September 18, 1979, Ordinance No. 105-79, approving and accepting the final plat, was introduced to the council and received its first reading. Council, on October 2, 1979, voted to postpone the second reading of the ordinance until December 4, 1979 and on that date, council again voted to postpone consideration. Council approved and accepted the final plat on April 1, 1980 by passing Ordinance No. 33-80. The sole reason of the council for delaying approval and acceptance of the final plat from October 2, 1979 to April 1, 1980 was to study and make recommendations to solve storm water drainage problems in an approximately one-thousand-acre area of which the subject premises was a part, which storm water drainage problems became apparent as a result of flooding which occurred in August and September 1979. 1 


1 The parties also agreed that all depositions could be used for purposes of motions for summary judgment and replies thereto.

The complaint also [***3] alleged that the members of the planning commission and council, both in their official and individual capacities, acted willfully and maliciously, and with bad faith in delaying plat approval. Further, Mayor Breen was alleged to have acted willfully and maliciously to coerce appellants to comply with storm drainage regulations which were enacted subsequent to the plat submission and which were not made retroactive.

Appellants sought compensatory damages and attorney fees against the city, council, and the planning commission and sought compensatory and punitive damages and attorney fees against members of council, the planning commission and Mayor Breen pursuant to state law and Section 1983, Title 42, U.S. Code.

The city filed a counterclaim, alleging appellants had begun grading and other construction and development work and had agreed to transfer some platted lots prior to the final plat approval contrary to local ordinances.

The trial court, ruling on the cross-motions for summary judgment, found that appellees were entitled to judgment as a matter of law on the grounds that the actions involved, as stipulated and testified to in the depositions herein, were discretionary [***4] and legislative rather than merely ministerial, noting that council had authority to consider drainage in its plat approval decision. The court also found that appellants had "* * * failed to demonstrate that any delay arises to the level of a federal constitutional violation so as to justify relief under 43 [sic] U.S.C. Section 1983."

The court of appeals affirmed the judgment of the trial court in a split decision. The majority held that in failing to approve the proposed subdivision plat, the council was acting in an administrative rather than a legislative capacity, but that immunity from suit nonetheless attached because the action of approving a subdivision plat involves the making of a basic policy decision which is characterized by a high degree of official judgment or discretion. The court further found that the individual members of council and the mayor were likewise immune from suit under Section 1983 and state law because the record indicates good faith, a genuine concern about flood drainage, and a lack of malice. Finally, the court held the trial court properly overruled the motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of liability under Section 1983 [***5] because, at the very least, reasonable minds could differ as to whether delay in approving the plat is sufficient to constitute deprivation of a federal right.

The dissent contended that sovereign immunity did not attach, reasoning that once the plat complied with the appropriate ordinances, neither the planning commission nor city council had discretion to refuse to approve the plat. Correspondingly, the dissent further asserted that since under state law, there are genuine issues of fact with respect to liability and damages for the failure of the various individual defendants to comply with the ordinance, summary judgment was improperly granted.

This cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant partnership challenged the order of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's grant of summary judgment in favor of appellees, city of Gahanna, its mayor, city council, planning commission, and certain members of the council and commission, on appellant's claims under state law and 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 for compensatory and punitive damages for delay of approval of a subdivision plat and bad faith.


OVERVIEW: The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of appellees, the city of Gahanna, its mayor, city council, planning commission, and certain members of the council and commission, against appellee partnership on claims related to delay in approval of a subdivision plat because the appellees' actions were discretionary and legislative rather than merely ministerial, and appellants had failed to demonstrate that any delay constituted a federal constitutional violation under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983. The sole reason for the delay was to study and make recommendations to solve storm water drainage problems. The court affirmed and held that while the action of council in approving the subdivision was administrative in nature, sovereign immunity attached because the action involved the making of a basic policy decision characterized by the exercise of a high degree of official judgment or discretion. Individual members of the planning commission, council, and the mayor were immune from suit under state law and 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 because there was no evidence of bad faith. The city was immune from suit under § 1983 because it did not act unlawfully or arbitrarily.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed summary judgment in favor of appellees, the city of Gahanna, its mayor, city council, planning commission, and certain members of the council and commission, on appellant partnership's claims because sovereign immunity attached for actions involving a high degree of discretion, there was no bad faith, and appellants were not deprived of any constitutional rights.

 

148 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


General American Transp. Corp. v. Limbach


No. 84-400


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 3d 302; 473 N.E.2d 814; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1291; 15 Ohio B. Rep. 432



December 31, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County.

This appeal arises from an assessment of personal property tax upon certain inventory property of appellee and cross-appellant, General American Transportation Corporation ("GATC"). GATC is a manufacturer of railroad tank cars and has a manufacturing facility located in Masury, Ohio. Approximately twenty-five percent of the tank cars are built for purposes of sale, while the remaining seventy-five percent are built for lease.

In July 1980, the Tax Commissioner of Ohio, appellant and cross-appellee, assessed GATC for deficiencies determined in GATC's personal property tax returns for the years 1975-1978, inclusive. Specifically, GATC had included as personal property only twenty-five percent of its average monthly raw material inventory ("RMI"), reflecting the ratio of tank cars sold to tank cars manufactured. The Tax Commissioner recomputed GATC's tax obligation to reflect the full value of average monthly RMI levels, thus including the percentage of RMI to be used in the manufacture of leased cars as well.

GATC appealed the assessment to the Board of Tax Appeals ("BTA"), which affirmed the Tax Commissioner [***2] on all questions pertinent to this appeal.

On appeal, the court of appeals reversed the ruling of the BTA, holding that only twenty-five percent of GATC's average monthly RMI was subject to personal property taxation. The court of appeals rejected GATC's contention that its RMI was not subject to personal property taxation by virtue of GATC's status as a public utility; however, the court did agree with GATC's argument that seventy-five percent of its average monthly RMI was exempt due to the leasing of seventy-five percent of the total cars manufactured.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion and cross-motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Tax Commissioner of Ohio and cross-appellant taxpayer sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County (Ohio), which reversed a ruling of the Board of Tax Appeals affirming the Commissioner's assessment of deficiencies in the taxpayer's personal property tax on certain inventory property.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer manufactured railroad tank cars. Approximately 25 percent of the cars were built for purposes of sale, and the remainder were built for lease. The Commissioner assessed deficiencies in the taxpayer's personal property tax due to its inclusion of only 25 percent of its average monthly raw material inventory (RMI) in the computation. The Commissioner computed the tax based on the full value of average monthly RMI levels, and the Board affirmed the assessment. The trial court reversed the Board's decision. On appeal, the court held that the average monthly value of all RMI of a manufacturer was subject to personal property tax, regardless of whether the final product was sold or leased, because the RMI of a manufacturer was "used in business" within the meaning of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5701.08(A), (B). The court also held that the taxpayer's RMI was not exempt from personal property taxes by virtue of its public utility status because the taxpayer's manufacturing operations were distinct from its equipment leasing operations and the taxpayer was an equipment company for purposes of the exemption only to the extent that it was engaged in leasing cars.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment.

 

149 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Maurer


No. 84-642


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 3d 239; 473 N.E.2d 768; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1285; 15 Ohio B. Rep. 379



December 20, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Stark County.

On September 29, 1982, Dawn M. Hendershot, a seven-year-old girl, failed to return home from school where she attended second grade. An extensive search was conducted in and around the Massillon, Ohio area where Dawn Hendershot resided, but was unsuccessful in locating the missing girl.

Witnesses established that the girl had been seen entering a car upon leaving school the day she disappeared and that a young girl fitting Dawn Hendershot's description had been seen with a man in a car on a county road near a wooded area.

Donald L. Maurer (hereafter referred to as appellant), who resided across the street from the Hendershot family, was interviewed several times by police in connection with Dawn Hendershot's disappearance. On October 1, 1982, appellant's car was searched pursuant to a warrant and, among other things, a twelve-gauge shotgun with ammunition was seized. That evening, appellant arrived at the police station at the invitation of the police. After questioning, appellant confessed to the killing of Dawn Hendershot.

Appellant stated that he had arrived at the victim's school in order [***2] to pick up his stepchildren and other neighborhood children. Dawn Hendershot entered appellant's vehicle. Before any other children entered appellant's vehicle, appellant drove away. Appellant and Dawn Hendershot drove into the country and stopped near a wooded area. From there appellant and Dawn Hendershot left the vehicle and entered the woods on foot. Appellant carried a twelve-gauge shotgun with him. Appellant sat the young girl on a fallen tree and attempted to sexually molest her by placing a finger into her vagina. Appellant then became frightened and tried to strangle Dawn Hendershot with her sweater. When the girl struggled, appellant shot Dawn Hendershot in the back with the shotgun. Appellant then covered Dawn Hendershot's lifeless body with twigs and leaves and returned home.

On the morning following his statement, appellant led police to Dawn Hendershot's body.

Appellant was indicted for aggravated murder with a specification, 1 kidnapping, and gross sexual imposition. The cause proceeded to a jury trial where guilty verdicts were returned on each count of the indictment, including the death penalty specification. The cause then proceeded to the sentencing [***3] phase where the same jury recommended that appellant receive the death penalty. The trial court adopted the jury's recommendation and ordered that appellant be executed. In addition, appellant received concurrent sentences of seven to twenty-five years for kidnapping and two to five years for gross sexual imposition.


1 R.C. 2929.04(A)(7).

The court of appeals affirmed appellant's convictions and death sentence in all respects. The cause is now before this court on appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of aggravated murder with kidnapping, gross sexual imposition and death penalty specifications. The trial court adopted the jury's recommendation and ordered that defendant be executed. The Court of Appeals for Stark County (Ohio) affirmed. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: The charges against defendant stemmed from the death of a seven-year-old female neighbor. On review, the court held that (1) the aggravating circumstance of kidnapping was not unconstitutionally overbroad, (2) to death-qualify a jury prior to the guilt phase of a bifurcated capital prosecution did not deny defendant a trial by an impartial jury, (2) the evidence did not reveal any mitigating factors weighing against the aggravating circumstance, (3) no factors mitigated against the imposition of the death penalty, (4) the death penalty was not disproportionate, (5) defendant was not prejudiced by the failure of the trial court to enunciate its reasoning for why the aggravating circumstance outweighed the mitigating factors, (6) defendant's statements were not the product of an illegal arrest and were obtained in full compliance with the Miranda requirements, (7) the confession was voluntary and admissible, (8) defendant's stipulation as to the cause of death did not automatically render gruesome victim photographs inadmissible, and (9) he was not entitled to an instruction on the lesser included offense of abduction.


OUTCOME: The judgment of conviction for aggravated murder and the death sentence was affirmed. Defendant received an objective, impartial, and unprejudiced review at each stage of the proceedings.

 

150 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Jenkins


No. 84-478


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 3d 164; 473 N.E.2d 264; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 84; 15 Ohio B. Rep. 311



December 17, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On the morning of October 21, 1981, Leonard Jenkins (hereafter referred to as appellant) and Lester Jordan entered a branch of National City Bank. Appellant, brandishing a handgun, directed the individuals in the bank to the rear of the building.

Appellant proceeded to disarm the bank's security guard by holding his gun to the guard's head. Now in possession of two guns, appellant advanced with Jordan to each teller. Appellant held each teller at gunpoint while Jordan removed the money from the drawers. While this action was taking place, bank personnel were able to activate silent alarms connected directly to the police department. Within minutes police were dispatched to the scene.

Officers John Myhand and Anthony Johnson were the first to arrive and parked their patrol car near the front of the bank. Myhand approached the bank on foot, with Johnson following several steps behind. Myhand reached the front door of the bank, peered inside, and viewed appellant near the door. Myhand observed that appellant was armed and told Johnson, "This is a good one, take cover." Immediately Myhand turned and began [***2] to run from the bank.

After Myhand had run a short way, he heard a single shot and then several more shots. In the exchange of gunfire, both appellant and Johnson were wounded by bullets, Johnson mortally. At that instant Myhand felt a sharp pain in the back of his right knee. Apparently, believing that he had been shot, Myhand continued to hobble away from the bank and eventually fell to the ground.

Inside the bank, when appellant saw a police officer approach the front door and look inside he stated that they would have to shoot their way out and proceeded to fire a shot in the direction of the front door. After firing this single shot, appellant exited the bank where he and Johnson exchanged fire.

Having stumbled to the ground, Myhand looked back at the entrance of the bank where he saw both Johnson and appellant lying on the ground outside the bank's entrance. At that moment, Myhand observed a car backing toward him.

At this point Officers Jerome Howard and Gregory L. Henderson arrived on the scene in response to the original dispatch to the bank. Shortly before reaching the bank, Howard and Henderson had heard what they believed to be gunfire. Howard and Henderson [***3] observed Johnson and appellant lying in the vicinity of each other outside the bank as well as the car backing toward Myhand who was then struggling to get to his feet. Thinking that the approaching vehicle was attempting to run him over, Myhand drew his gun and fired a single shot at the car. Howard and Henderson both drew their weapons, each firing several shots in the direction of the car. Two of the car's tires were flattened and the passenger window was shattered. Nevertheless, the driver of the car managed to leave the scene of the shooting. 1


1 The driver of the car, Douglas H. Robinson, was not involved in the commission of the robbery and appears to have been simply an innocent bystander. Robinson's account was that he had driven a neighbor to the bank and was waiting in the parking lot with the engine running and the gear in reverse when the shooting began. Robinson ducked to avoid the gunfire and lay down in the front of his car. Robinson's car then began to drift toward Myhand which prompted the police to fire upon Robinson's vehicle. Robinson received a gunshot wound to the back of his head but was able to drive to a friend's house and was taken to the hospital.

 [***4] Jordan then exited the bank, was disarmed, apprehended, and made to lie down near appellant. Appellant, Johnson, and Myhand were immediately transported by ambulance to the hospital. Johnson subsequently died of a gunshot wound to the head. Appellant received a gunshot wound which severed his spinal cord rendering him permanently paralyzed below the waist. It was revealed that Myhand had not been shot but that, in seeking cover, he suffered a compound fracture of the fibula.

Having received emergency medical treatment, appellant was interviewed by police officers in the hospital and gave a statement to the effect that he shot at the police because he did not want to get caught.

Appellant was indicted for aggravated murder with specifications, 2 eight counts of aggravated robbery, two counts of attempted murder, eight counts of kidnapping, having a weapon while under a disability, and possession of criminal tools. Prior to trial, the state dismissed one kidnapping and one attempted murder count. The court at the request of both parties severed the charge of having a weapon while under a disability and ordered a separate trial on that count.


2 R.C. 2929.04(A)(3), (A)(5), (A)(6) and (A)(7). See discussion, infra.

 [***5] The cause proceeded to a jury trial. Upon the close of the state's case, the state dismissed two additional counts of kidnapping. The jury returned guilty verdicts on all counts, including the aggravated murder count and specifications relating to the death of Johnson. At the conclusion of the sentencing phase, the same jury recommended that appellant be sentenced to death. The trial court accepted the jury's recommendation and ordered that appellant be executed.

The court of appeals vacated appellant's conviction for possession of criminal tools on the basis of insufficient evidence. The court of appeals unanimously affirmed appellant's conviction and sentence in all other respects.

This cause is now before the court on appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which convicted him of aggravated murder with specifications, aggravated robbery, attempted murder, and kidnapping. Defendant also appealed his death sentence.


OVERVIEW: The court determined that defendant's convictions and sentence were proper. The court held that the death sentence statute was constitutionally valid because the sentencing authority was suitably directed and limited so as to minimize the risk of a wholly arbitrary and capricious action in imposing the death sentence. The court determined that the trial court properly placed the burden of proving mitigating factors by a preponderance of the evidence upon defendant and that the State carried the burden of proving by proof beyond a reasonable doubt that the aggravating circumstances defendant was found guilty of committing outweighed the mitigating factors. The court held that defendant was not denied his right to a fair trial by an impartial jury when the trial court excused four jurors for cause because the jurors displayed feelings regarding capital punishment that exceeded mere moral opposition against its imposition. The court held that defendant was not denied his statutory and constitutional rights to present evidence in mitigation of the death penalty by the trial court's action in excluding, as either irrelevant or incompetent, evidence proffered for purposes of mitigation.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the lower court, holding that defendant's various contentions were without merit.

 

151 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Tanner


No. 84-443


Supreme Court of Ohio


15 Ohio St. 3d 1; 472 N.E.2d 689; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1247; 15 Ohio B. Rep. 1; 54 A.L.R.4th 139



December 6, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

Charles R. Tanner, appellant herein, pleaded no contest to, and was found guilty of, driving while intoxicated in violation of R.C. 4511.19(A)(2). Appellant had submitted to an intoxilyzer test which recorded a .18 percent blood alcohol level.

Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed the trial court's ruling. For the purpose of this appeal, appellant stipulates to the propriety of his conviction and chooses to appeal solely on the averred lack of constitutionality of R.C. 4511.19(A)(2).

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which affirmed his conviction for driving while intoxicated in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.19(A)(2), on the ground that § 4511.19(A)(2) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: After defendant was convicted of driving while intoxicated, in violation of Ohio's driving while intoxicated statute, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4511.19(A)(2), defendant challenged his conviction solely on the ground that § 4511.19(A)(2) was unconstitutional. The appellate court affirmed the conviction, and defendant sought review. On appeal, the court reviewed the three rationales supporting the "void for vagueness" doctrine and found that § 4511.19(A)(2) provided fair warning, precluded arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement, and did not unreasonably impinge, or inhibit, constitutionally protected freedoms. The court applied a two-prong test to determine if the statute was overbroad and held that the statute protected a substantial state interest and that the blood alcohol level set by the statute was reasonably related to lawful legislative ends. The court held that § 4511.19(A)(2) did not create an irrebuttable presumption of guilt. The court ruled that § 4511.19(A)(2) represented a constitutionally valid means for dealing with drunk driving.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction because the statute under which defendant was convicted was constitutional, was not void for vagueness or overbroad, and did not create an unconstitutional irrebuttable presumption.

 

152 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Farrier v. Connor


No. 83-686


Supreme Court of Ohio


12 Ohio St. 3d 219; 466 N.E.2d 557; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1202; 12 Ohio B. Rep. 303



August 1, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On September 20, 1978, Michael Farrier died as a result of injuries sustained in an army jeep accident. At the time of the accident, Farrier was involved in annual summer training exercises near Fort Knox, Kentucky, pursuant to his duties as a member of the Ohio National Guard.

Plaintiff-appellant, Marjorie Farrier, filed a workers' compensation claim for death benefits with the Industrial Commission of Ohio as Michael Farrier's widow, pursuant to R.C. 4123.59. This claim was disallowed by the district hearing officer, based on the finding that Michael Farrier's death did not result during an Ohio employment within the ambit of R.C. 4123.021 and 4123.022, because the widow-claimant was eligible for, and received death benefits provided for in Section 321, Title 32, U.S. Code.

Appellant then appealed this decision to the Regional Board of Review and the Industrial Commission, successively, but was unsuccessful on both occasions. As a result, appellant filed this action in the court of Common Pleas of Franklin County, pursuant to R.C. 4123.519, for death benefits. Thereafter, both parties filed motions for summary [***2] judgment. On October 12, 1982, the trial court granted appellees' motion for summary judgment, holding that appellant could not make a showing that the decedent was on "state active duty" at the time of his death in accordance with R.C. 4123.022; and that R.C. 4123.021 excludes from the definition of "state active duty" those persons for whom federal benefits are provided.

Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed. The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant widow filed an action for workers' compensation death benefits after the decedent was killed while on duty for the Ohio National Guard. The trial court granted summary judgment for appellees, an official and others, on the ground that the decedent was not on "state active duty" under Ohio Rev. Code §§ 4123.021 and 4123.022. After the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) affirmed the trial court's decision, the widow appealed.


OVERVIEW: The decedent was killed during summer training exercises for Ohio National Guard members. The court held that although the decedent had been ordered to duty by Ohio, thereby meeting the first requirement for a National Guard member to be considered an employee of the State of Ohio for workers' compensation purposes, he had not met the second requirement that federal benefits not be provided to a National Guard member. The court noted that the widow had received federal benefits on behalf of the member, including a death gratuity, a burial allowance, and a life insurance policy. The court rejected the widow's argument that the denial of state benefits violated equal protection. It stated that the legislature had reasonable grounds for preventing employees who were eligible for federal benefits from receiving state benefits, the grounds being the legislature's intent to prevent a double recovery from both the Ohio and federal governments for the same injury, death, or occupational disease. Furthermore, the court stated, there was no merit to the widow's contention that Ohio Rev. Stat. § 4123.021 denied her due process under Ohio Const. art. I, § 16.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the court of appeals' decision.

 

153 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


City of Niles v. Howard


No. 83-1151


Supreme Court of Ohio


12 Ohio St. 3d 162; 466 N.E.2d 539; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1191; 12 Ohio B. Rep. 232



July 25, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County.

The Council of the city of Niles, Ohio, adopted Ordinance No. 13-82 on March 3, 1982. This ordinance amended Niles Codified Ordinance Sections 513.03(c)(2) and 513.03(d), imposing a first degree misdemeanor penalty for possession of marijuana in an amount less than bulk. "Less than bulk amount" is statutorily defined as less than one hundred grams of marijuana, or if resin less than five grams, or if liquid concentrate, liquid extract, or liquid distillate form less than one gram. 1 The sections as amended varied from R.C. 2925.11, which only imposes a minor misdemeanor penalty for the possession of marijuana in an amount less than bulk.


1 Pursuant to R.C. 2925.11(C)(3).

On April 16, 1982, the defendant-appellee, Jeff Howard, was arrested within the city of Niles for a violation of Section 513.03. The arrest was made pursuant to a validly executed search warrant. At the time of his arrest the defendant was found to have in his possession 46.85 grams of marijuana.
