On June 9, 1982, the defendant was convicted of possession of marijuana, a violation of Section 513.03(c)(2), by the Niles Municipal Court. The court [***2] sentenced him to six months in the city jail, five months of which were suspended, and a fine of $ 550.

The defendant appealed the judgment of the trial court to the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County, alleging that Section 513.03 was unconstitutional, in that a municipal ordinance may not conflict with the general laws of the state of Ohio. On June 6, 1983, the court of appeals reversed the judgment of the trial court. The appellate court ruled that Section 513.03 was unconstitutional because it provided for a greater penalty than R.C. 2925.11(C)(3) and (D) and 2929.21(D). 2 In a unanimous decision the court entered final judgment for the defendant and ordered him discharged.


2 R.C. 2925.11 provides in part:

"(C) Whoever violates this section is guilty of drug abuse.

"* * *

"(3) If the drug involved is marihuana, drug abuse is a misdemeanor of the fourth degree, unless the amount of marihuana involved is less than one hundred grams, the amount of marihuana resin, or extraction or preparation of such resin, is less than five grams, and the amount of such resin in a liquid concentrate, liquid extract, or liquid distillate form, is less than one gram, in which case drug abuse is a minor misdemeanor.

"(D) Arrest or conviction for a minor misdemeanor violation of this section does not constitute a criminal record and need not be reported by the person so arrested or convicted in response to any inquiries about the person's criminal record, including any inquiries contained in any application for employment, license, or other right or privilege, or made in connection with the person's appearance as a witness."

 R.C. 2929.21 provides in part:

"(D) Whoever is convicted of or pleads guilty to a minor misdemeanor shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars."

 [***3] The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant City of Niles, Ohio sought review of an order of the Court of Appeals for Trumbull County (Ohio), which reversed defendant's conviction for possession of marijuana in violation of Niles, Ohio Codified Ordinance § 513.03(c)(2), (d). The court of appeals ruled that the ordinance was unconstitutional because it provided for a greater penalty than Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §§ 2925.11(C)(3), (D), 2929.21(D).


OVERVIEW: The court rejected the city's argument that the state drug statutes were not general laws and were outside the constitutional provision that authorized municipalities to exercise powers of local self-government and to adopt regulations that were not in conflict with general laws. The remaining question, then, was whether the city's municipal ordinance, which made the offense a first degree misdemeanor, conflicted with the general laws, under which the offense was a minor misdemeanor. The court held that in determining whether an ordinance was in conflict with general laws, the test was whether the ordinance permitted or licensed that which the statute forbade and prohibited, and vice versa. However, a police ordinance was not in conflict with a general law on the same subject merely because different penalties were provided for the same acts, even though greater penalties were imposed by municipal ordinance. Indeed, where the only distinction between a state statute and a municipal ordinance was the penalty and not to the degree of the offense, as measured by whether the offense was a misdemeanor or felony, the ordinance was not in conflict with the general laws of the state.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

154 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Vega


No. 83-1933


Supreme Court of Ohio


12 Ohio St. 3d 185; 465 N.E.2d 1303; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1196; 12 Ohio B. Rep. 251



July 25, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Tuscarawas County.

Pete A. Vega, appellee, was charged on November 9, 1982 with operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol in violation of R.C. 4511.19. An intoxilyzer test was administered; appellee tested at .17 of one percent of blood alcohol by weight. Appellee pleaded not guilty.

Prior to trial, on April 12, 1983, the state filed a motion in limine to exclude the testimony of appellee's proposed expert witness, Dr. Walter J. Frajola. The trial court delayed its ruling.

A jury trial was commenced in the Municipal Court of New Philadelphia, Ohio, on April 12, 1983. When appellee called Dr. Frajola as a witness, the trial judge did not permit him to testify. The court in its judgment entry found that "* * * Dr. Frajola had no personal knowledge of the particular intoxilyzer instrument utilized in the administration of the breath test to * * * [appellee] * * * and, consequently, Dr. Frajola's testimony would have been relating, generally, to the reliability of the intoxilyzer and as such must be excluded upon the authority of State v.. Grimes * * * [(Dec. 30, 1980), Franklin App. No. 80AP-651, unreported],  [***2] which this court finds persuasive in its reasoning and the rule of law * * * [which] shall be applied in this jurisdiction." Appellee then proffered Dr. Frajola's testimony.

Appellee was subsequently convicted and sentenced accordingly. Appellee filed a notice of appeal on May 18, 1983.

In a split decision, the court reversed, holding that an accused may present expert testimony to attack the reliability of intoxilyzers in general. The court stated that "* * * R.C. 4511.19(B), while replacing the requirement of expert testimony by statutory presumption, does so only insofar as the state is concerned. * * * There is no prohibition (nor can there ever be constitutionally) against the presentation of expert medical testimony on the part of the accused to show the nonexistence of a nexus between the testing result and the ultimate physical condition of the accused." The court concluded, then, that "[t]o the extent that the appellant was prevented from going forward with his evidence on the element of whether or not he was under the influence of alcohol, the state was relieved of its constitutional duty to prove appellant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt on that element of [***3] the offense of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol * * *."

In dissent, Judge Hoffman reasoned that inasmuch as the proffered testimony was general and speculative in nature and did not speak to the specific test of the specific accused at trial, the testimony was properly excluded because R.C. 4511.19 provides for the admission of breath tests if properly administered. He further stated that no constitutional right was destroyed as a result because the accused has no such right to introduce non-relevant general testimony.

The court of appeals, finding its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County in State v.. Grimes, supra, and the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Auglaize County in State v.. Balderaz (May 25, 1983), No. 2-82-5, unreported, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Court of Appeals for Tuscarawas County (Ohio) reversed defendant's conviction because the trial court excluded the testimony of defendant's expert witness in his trial for operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 4511.19. The state appealed.


OVERVIEW: Defendant tested at .17 of one percent of blood alcohol by weight on an intoxilyzer test and was charged with and convicted of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol, in violation of Ohio Rev. Code § 4511.19. At trial, the trial court excluded the testimony of defendant's expert, which would have attacked the reliability of intoxilyzers generally. On appeal, the court found that the testimony was properly excluded because § 4511.19 created a presumption that such tests were reliable. The court found that the presumption did not deprive defendant of his right to present a defense because it was rebuttable by any other competent evidence bearing upon the question of whether he was under the influence of intoxicating liquor. Such evidence included non-technical evidence of sobriety, such as a video tape or testimony by the accused or by witnesses concerning the accused's sobriety and amount of consumption, as well as technical evidence, such as additional chemical tests and the completion of field sobriety tests.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the appellate court, which had reversed defendant's conviction.

 

155 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Mauk v. Mauk


No. 83-1337


Supreme Court of Ohio


12 Ohio St. 3d 156; 466 N.E.2d 166; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1190; 12 Ohio B. Rep. 226



July 25, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Marion County.

This cause stems from a motor vehicle accident occurring on or about June 21, 1980 in Marion County. Appellants are Harry E. Mauk and Norma L. Mauk, husband and wife. Appellee, Timothy W. Mauk, is their son who at all times relevant was an unemancipated minor. The underlying facts are not in dispute and are set forth below.

Harry Mauk was operating his automobile in a northerly direction along State Route 423 in Pleasant Township. Norma Mauk was traveling as a passenger in that vehicle. Directly in front of them was appellee who was operating a truck owned by his father. Attached to the top of the truck was a fourteen-foot extension ladder.

At some point, the ladder fell off the truck and into Harry Mauk's path. He attempted to avoid it, thereby losing control of the car. A collision resulted and appellants were injured. They subsequently filed a complaint in negligence alleging that appellee had improperly secured the ladder.

Appellee moved for summary judgment, asserting that the claim was barred by the doctrine of parent-child immunity. On the basis of Karam v.. Allstate Ins. Co. (1982), 70 [***2] Ohio St. 2d 227 [24 O.O.3d 327], certiorari denied (1982), 74 L. Ed. 2d 632, the trial court agreed and granted appellee's motion. The court of appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff parents sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Marion County (Ohio), which affirmed summary judgment in favor of defendant minor, who was the son of the parents, in a negligence action brought by the parents against the minor for damages for injuries that they sustained in a car accident.


OVERVIEW: The parents were traveling in a car and their minor son was driving a truck directly in front of them on top of which a ladder was attached. The ladder slid off of the truck and caused the father to lose control of the car and crash. The parents were injured as a result of the accident and brought a negligence action against the minor. The minor moved for summary judgment claiming that the action was barred by the parent-child immunity doctrine. The trial court agreed and granted summary judgment, which was affirmed by the appellate court. The parents sought review, contending that the time was right to repeal parent-child immunity. On review, the court affirmed and ruled that the parents were not only the minor's mother and father but they were also the owners of both of the vehicles and probably insured both. Thus, the court doubted that parties' interests were truly adverse, which could lead to fraud and collusion. Alternatively, if the party's interests truly were adverse, then the family unit would be disrupted. The court concluded that either result was unacceptable and thus the appellate court did not err in ruling that the parents' claim was barred by the minor's immunity.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed judgment granting summary judgment in favor of the minor.

 

156 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Roosevelt Properties Co. v. Kinney


No. 83-226


Supreme Court of Ohio


12 Ohio St. 3d 7; 465 N.E.2d 421; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1150; 12 Ohio B. Rep. 6



July 3, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

This cause originated before the Board of Tax Appeals (hereinafter "BTA") upon applications for review filed by Apartment & Home Owners Association et al. and Roosevelt Properties Company et al., appellants herein. The applications were filed in accordance with R.C. 5703.14 and 5715.61 in order to contest a recently adopted rule by appellee, the Commissioner of Tax Equalization.

The rule promulgated by appellee consisted of an amendment to Ohio Adm. Code 5705-3-06. The amendment was undertaken in accordance with the General Assembly's directive contained in R.C. 5713.041 that the commissioner adopt rules governing the separate calculation of tax reduction factors authorized under Section 2a, Article XII of the Ohio Constitution. 

By way of background, it should be noted that a tax reduction factor consists of a calculation designed to reduce the effect of inflation on a property owner's tax liability. Prior to the approval by Ohio's electorate in November 1980, of Section 2a, Article XII, one reduction factor was employed for all classes of real property affected by a tax levy. Section 2a, Article XII, however, authorized the division [***2] of real property into two classes in an attempt to alleviate the unfair tax burden placed upon residential and agricultural property owners as a result of spiraling inflationary trends. State, ex rel. Swetland, v.. Kinney (1982), 69 Ohio St. 2d 567, 572 [23 O.O.3d 479].

Because Section 2a, Article XII was not self-executing, the General Assembly enacted legislation to effectuate the amendment. See State, ex rel. Swetland, v.. Kinney, supra, at 572. R.C. 5713.041 provides in pertinent part:

"* * * For purposes of this section, lands and improvements thereon used for residential or agricultural purposes shall be classified as residential/agricultural real property, and all other lands and improvements thereon and minerals or rights to minerals shall be classified as nonresidential/agricultural real property. * * *

"The commissioner shall adopt rules governing the classification of property under this section, and no property shall be so classified except in accordance with such rules.

"In response to this legislative directive, the commissioner promulgated an amendment to Ohio Adm. Code 5705-3-06, which became effective October 20, 1981. Ohio Adm. Code 5705-3-06(B)(5)  [***3] provides as follows:

"'Residential land and improvements' -- The land and improvements to the land consisting of one, two, three, or four dwelling units, one of which is occupied by the owner of the property."

In November 1981, appellants filed their respective applications for review of Ohio Adm. Code 5705-3-06(B)(5) with the BTA, contesting the reasonableness and lawfulness of the commissioner's classification rule for "residential property" as that term is utilized within Section 2a, Article XII and R.C. 5713.041. Appellants further sought to have the rule declared unconstitutional for being in conflict with the "uniform rule" requirement of Section 2, Article XII of the Ohio Constitution, as well as being violative of the Equal Protection Clause of the United States Constitution. 

On January 11, 1983, the BTA issued a split decision on appellants' application, with only two of the three statutory members of the board participating. Since no majority existed among the BTA members, the board was required to uphold the rule. See R.C. 5703.14(D). In addition, the BTA correctly refused to address appellants' constitutional arguments on the basis that such arguments are not [***4] within its jurisdictional authority. See S. S. Kresge Co. v.. Bowers (1960), 170 Ohio St. 405 [11 O.O.2d 157], paragraph one of the syllabus, and Herrick v.. Kosydar (1975), 44 Ohio St. 2d 128, 130 [73 O.O.2d 442].

The cause is now before this court on an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Decision affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant owners challenged as of right a decision from the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio). The decision upheld an amendment to a rule in Ohio Admin. Code § 5705-3-06(B)(5) adopted by appellee, the Ohio Commissioner of Tax Equalization, that defined "residential land and improvements."


OVERVIEW: The rule excluded the taxation of the owners' multi-unit rental properties from the application of residential reduction factors. The owners contended that the rule conflicted with existing law, was beyond the Commissioner's authority, and was beyond the public and the legislature's contemplation. The court affirmed the contested decision. The court found the rule delineated between homeowners and residential property owners, and those persons or concerns who owned land not as their home, but for commercial purposes or as business land-holders. The court concluded that § 5705-3-06(B)(5) was consistent with Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2a, and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 5713.041. The court found that Ohio Admin. Code § 5705-3-06(B)(5) did not violate Ohio Const. art. XII, § 2, because the owners' properties were used in a business or commercial capacity. The court concluded that the owners failed to demonstrate that the classification in Ohio Admin. Code § 5705-3-06(B)(5) rested upon an unreasonable basis. The court decided that the requirement of owner occupancy was rationally related to a tax reduction factor for residential homeowners, rather than for commercial or business concerns.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision appealed by the owners, which accepted the Commissioner's rule and its contested definition.

 

157 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Kisil v. Sandusky


No. 83-1449


Supreme Court of Ohio


12 Ohio St. 3d 30; 465 N.E.2d 848; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1155; 12 Ohio B. Rep. 26



July 3, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Erie County. In

the fall of 1981, plaintiff-appellant, Michael Kisil, purchased a single-family residence located at 508 Huron Avenue, Sandusky, Ohio. The zoning classification for the neighborhood, in which plaintiff's property is located, is R2F, residential two-family. In December 1981, plaintiff requested the approval of the city planning commission to convert the residence situated at 508 Huron to a duplex. The request was denied by the commission on January 13, 1982. The reason for the denial of plaintiff's request was that the lot on which the residence was located was insufficient in size to maintain a duplex, pursuant to Section 151.21 of the Sandusky Code of Ordinances. Section 151.21 requires that the minimum lot size for a two-family dwelling in R2F district is 2,750 square feet per unit or a total of 5,500 square feet. The plaintiff's property is only 2,100 square feet. The plaintiff further admitted to the commission that he knew, at the time of purchase, that the previous owner's request to convert the property to a multifamily residential use had been denied. The decision of the commission was affirmed on appeal [***2] by the Sandusky Zoning Code Board of Appeals on February 25, 1982.

On March 3, 1982, plaintiff filed a notice of appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Erie County pursuant to R.C. Chapter 2506. He sought a reversal of the decision of the board as unreasonable, arbitrary and capricious. In his amended notice of appeal plaintiff further sought declaratory relief finding the enforcement of the minimum lot size requirement contained in Section 151.21 as unconstitutional, in that it violates the equal protection provisions of the United States Constitution and the Ohio Constitution. The trial court reversed the decision of the board, finding the denial of a variance to be unreasonable and arbitrary in view of a variance granted to a neighboring property owner and the entire character of the neighborhood. The court dismissed the request of plaintiff for declaratory judgment, finding the administrative appeal effectual to afford the relief plaintiff sought.

The defendants-appellees appealed the decision of the trial court. The appellate court reversed the trial court finding the substantial variance between plaintiff's lot size and the minimum requirement contained in Section 151.21,  [***3] coupled with plaintiff's prior knowledge of the commission's denial of a similar request by the previous landowner, did not support a finding that the action of the board was unreasonable or discriminatory.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action against defendants, city and others, the trial court reversed the zoning board's decision affirming the planning commission's denial of plaintiff landowner's request to convert a residence to a duplex. The Court of Appeals for Erie County (Ohio) reversed the trial court's decision because the trial court's finding of unreasonable or discriminatory board action was not supported. The landowner filed a motion to certify the record.


OVERVIEW: The city denied the landowner an area variance to allow the conversion of a single-family residence to a two-family residence on a lot that was below the minimum area and yard requirements of the city zoning provisions. The court held that the grant of a variance would not have altered the character of the surrounding neighborhood because the record revealed the majority of the neighborhood was used as two-family residential rental property and many of these duplexes were on lots insufficient in size. The standard for granting a variance that related solely to area requirements was a showing of practical difficulties, not unnecessary hardship as required for variances that related to use. The court held that the allowance of other duplexes on lots insufficient in size in the same neighborhood and the granting of a multifamily variance to a neighboring landowner, while denying the landowner's request for a variance, were unreasonable and arbitrary enforcement of the zoning ordinances. The trial court did not abuse its discretion in reaching its judgment.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment that the trial court's finding of unreasonable or discriminatory board action was not supported.

 

158 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Ferrell v. Std. Oil Co.


No. 83-1563


Supreme Court of Ohio


11 Ohio St. 3d 169; 464 N.E.2d 550; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1127; 11 Ohio B. Rep. 484



June 20, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Appellant, Dennis C. Ferrell, was injured in the course of his employment with appellee Standard Oil Company of Ohio. A claim for left shoulder injury was allowed, and appellant was awarded temporary total disability benefits. Appellee appealed to the Columbus Regional Board of Review, which affirmed. The Industrial Commission refused further appeal. Appellee then filed a notice of appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Franklin County.

Appellant moved to dismiss this appeal on the grounds that R.C. 4123.519, the statute governing appeals to the court of common pleas in workers' compensation cases, is unconstitutional. This motion was overruled. Upon appeal, the court of appeals dismissed, ruling that it was without jurisdiction to entertain the appeal for lack of a final, appealable order.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a workers' compensation matter, the Court of Appeals of Franklin County (Ohio) dismissed appellant employee's challenge to a trial court order that overruled his motion to dismiss an appeal filed by appellee employer because it was without jurisdiction to entertain the appeal for lack of a final, appealable order.


OVERVIEW: The employee was injured in the course of his employment and was awarded temporary total disability benefits. The employer appealed to the Board of Review, which affirmed. The Industrial Commission refused further appeal. The employer then filed a notice of appeal to the trial court, which overruled the employee's motion to dismiss the employer's appeal. The court of appeals dismissed the employee's appeal for lack of a final, appealable order. The decision from the court of appeals was affirmed. The court found that the overruling of the employee's motion to dismiss an appeal filed in the trial court by the employer pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.519 was not a final, appealable order within the meaning of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2505.02. The trial court's order was not an order affecting a substantial right made in a special proceeding, and did not comport with that portion of § 2505.02 making such orders final and appealable. Moreover, the trial court's order did not determine the action, as the merits of the employer's appeal had yet to be addressed. The court of appeals was, therefore, correct in ruling that it was without jurisdiction to hear the cause.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

159 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Dix v. Celeste


No. 83-1408


Supreme Court of Ohio


11 Ohio St. 3d 141; 464 N.E.2d 153; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1122; 11 Ohio B. Rep. 436



June 13, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

IN PROHIBITION.

The parties stipulated and agreed to the truth of the following facts and to the authenticity of the documentary evidence in support thereof.

Relator, Thomas J. Dix, was appointed by the Governor of the state of Ohio, with the consent of the Senate, to the Ohio Development Financing Commission for a term beginning January 1, 1978 and ending December 31, 1984. Relator's compensation, as specified by R.C. 122.40, was $ 5,000 annually, payable in monthly installments.

On July 14, 1983, Amended Substitute Senate Bill No. 227 (Am. Sub. S.B. No. 227) was signed by Richard F. Celeste, Governor of the state of Ohio. The subject matter of this bill, as expressed in pertinent part in its title, is as follows:

"To amend * * *, to enact * * * and to repeal sections [various sections of the] Revised Code to abolish the Ohio Development Financing Commission and transfer its duties to the Director of Development, to create the Development Financing Advisory Board, the Development Financing Policy Board, and the Division of Development Financing in the Department of Development * * *, to abolish the Development Advisory Committee, to provide for the appointment [***2] of legislative members to the various development program advisory boards and commissions, and to generally consolidate and reorganize the state's economic development assistance programs, and to make an appropriation."

The bill became law immediately upon approval of the Governor, containing an appropriation for the current expense of state government.

On September 9, 1983, relator filed this original action in mandamus and prohibition, naming as respondents the following officials of the state of Ohio: Richard F. Celeste, Governor, Thomas E. Ferguson, Auditor, Mary Ellen Withrow, Treasurer, Alfred S. Dietzel, Director of Development, Myrta Cristina Sale, Director of Budget and Management and William G. Sykes, Director of Administrative Services. In his complaint relator prayed this court to declare that Am. Sub. S.B. No. 227 is unconstitutional and void, that the Ohio Development Financing Commission continues in force, that members of the Ohio Development Financing Commission as of July 13, 1983 may serve to the ends of their respective terms, and that a writ of mandamus issue to effectuate these ends. Relator further sought a writ of mandamus to cause legal payroll warrants [***3] to be issued in payment of his statutory compensation as a member of the Ohio Development Financing Commission for July and August 1983. Additionally, relator prayed for a writ of prohibition to be issued to respondents Celeste and Dietzel barring them from taking any further action to implement Am. Sub. S.B. No. 227 and to respondent Withrow prohibiting the issuance of state of Ohio revenue bonds pursuant to Am. Sub. S.B. No. 227.



DISPOSITION: Writs denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator appointee filed a declaratory judgment action that sought to declare Am. Sub. S.B. No. 227 unconstitutional and void and for a writ of mandamus to allow he and other members of the Development Financing Commission to complete their terms against defendant Governor.


OVERVIEW: The Governor approved Am. Sub. S.B. No. 227, abolishing the Commission the appointee was currently serving a term with, which led the appointee to file a declaratory judgment action that sought to declare the bill unconstitutional and void as well as for a writ of mandamus to compel the Governor to continue the Commission until the appointee's term had expired. The court denied the writ. The court ruled that Am. Sub. S.B. No. 227 was not enacted in violation of Ohio Const. art. II, § 15(D), which precluded bills containing more than one subject. The court held that the precedent dictated that the one subject rule contained in Ohio Const. art. II, § 15(D) was directory rather than mandatory, thereby reducing judicial interference with legislative action. However, the court noted that they had a duty to enforce the Ohio Constitution, therefore a manifestly gross and fraudulent breach of the one subject rule will cause an enactment to be invalid. The court held that Am. Sub. S.B. No. 227 was not legislation contrary to the one subject rule because the topics in the bill, such as appropriation of funds and the abolishment of the Commission, related to the same subject matter.


OUTCOME: The court denied the appointee's declaratory judgment action and his writ of mandamus against the Governor.

 

160 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Nichols


No. 83-906


Supreme of Court of Ohio


11 Ohio St. 3d 40; 463 N.E.2d 375; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1099; 11 Ohio B. Rep. 188



May 23, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Columbiana County.

In January 1979, Richard L. Nichols, appellant herein, was arrested, while on parole, for committing a series of burglaries. Appellant was subsequently indicted by the Columbiana County Grand Jury on one count of aggravated burglary, three counts of burglary and sixteen counts of breaking and entering. Appellant thereafter plea bargained and pled guilty in the Court of Common Pleas of Columbiana County to four counts of burglary and one count of breaking and entering. Sentencing was deferred for two months pending the preparation of a presentence report.

Nichols was subsequently sentenced as follows: "* * * to be imprisoned in the Ohio State Penitentiary on Counts 1, 2, 3, and 4 for a term of not less than 3 nor more than 15 years, and on Count 7, to the Ohio State Penitentiary for a term of not less than 1 nor more than 5 years, and they are ordered to be served consecutively."

On September 9, 1979, shock probation was denied. Subsequently, Nichols' motion for probation was also denied. On October 4, 1979 Nichols filed his first petition (denominated "motion") for postconviction relief, pursuant to R.C. 2953.21,  [***2] averring violations of his constitutional rights. That petition was overruled on November 16, 1979. On December 20, 1979 a second petition for postconviction relief, pursuant to R.C. 2953.21, was filed. This second petition was effectively denied when the state's motion for summary judgment was sustained on January 18, 1980.

Nichols, on January 31, 1980, filed a notice of appeal from the latter summary judgment motion. On September 11, 1980, appellee filed a motion to dismiss on the ground that appellant had failed to cause a timely transmission of the record in this case. On October 3, 1980 appellee's motion to dismiss the case was overruled and appellant's motion for extension of time was also overruled as moot. Finally, on October 21, 1980, the court of appeals affirmed the court of common pleas' grant of appellee's motion for summary judgment. Appellant subsequently filed another appeal, which we declined to review on May 27, 1981 (case No. 80-1770, no substantial constitutional question).

Undaunted, Nichols redirected his efforts to the federal court system by seeking a writ of habeas corpus based upon issues not heretofore raised in the state courts. The United States [***3] Magistrate reviewing appellant's petition correctly stated that Nichols had not exhausted all of his state court remedies with respect to his new constitutional claims and accordingly, under the federal habeas corpus statute, could not proceed with his petition. The magistrate went on to suggest appellant should file a motion for leave to take a delayed appeal in order to review the trial court's judgment of January 18, 1980 and the findings of fact and conclusions of law rendered therein on September 3, 1980. It is unclear whether the delayed appeal was to be with respect to appellant's original sentencing or later postconviction relief proceedings.

On April 13, 1983 the Court of Appeals for Columbiana County denied appellant's motion for leave to take a delayed appeal with respect to postconviction relief under the rationale that there was no provision for such an appeal in a civil action. On May 4, 1983 appellant had perfected his appeal to this court and on September 28, 1983 we accepted jurisdiction. While the matter of jurisdiction was pending, the United States Magistrate issued his report and recommendations on July 6, 1983 and intimated this court would not accept jurisdiction.  [***4] On November 8, 1983 the district court issued a writ of habeas corpus which was subsequently vacated and stayed on January 17, 1984, pending the decision of this court.

The case is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant inmate sought review of a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Columbiana County (Ohio), which affirmed a grant of summary judgment in favor of the State on the inmate's second petition for postconviction relief following his conviction for burglary and breaking and entering.


OVERVIEW: The inmate was arrested for committing a series of burglaries. He pled guilty and was sentenced. The inmate's first petition for postconviction relief was denied, and his appeal from the denial of his second petition for postconviction relief was denied. Thereafter, the inmate went to the federal courts by seeking a writ of habeas corpus on constitutional claims. The federal judge suggested that the inmate take a delayed appeal in order to review the grant of summary judgment. The preceding court denied the delayed appeal because there was no provision for such an appeal in a civil action. On appeal, the court held that a delayed appeal filed pursuant to Ohio R. App. P. 5(A) was not available in the appeal of a postconviction relief determination under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2953.23(B). In affirming, the court noted that postconviction relief proceedings were governed by the Ohio Rules of Appellate Procedure as applied to civil actions. The court stated that it was an inappropriate forum because the inmate's constitutional claims were never heard on appeal and concluded that the inmate had the option of filing a motion for delayed appeal from the original judgment and conviction.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court.

 

161 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Wargetz v. Villa Sancta Anna Home for the Aged


No. 83-848


Supreme Court of Ohio


11 Ohio St. 3d 15; 462 N.E.2d 1215; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1092; 11 Ohio B. Rep. 49



May 9, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

On June 17, 1980, Erma M. Wargetz, appellant, filed an application with the Bureau of Workers' Compensation of Ohio for workers' compensation benefits stemming from an injury incurred on May 10, 1976 while she was employed by appellee Villa Sancta Anna Home for the Aged. The injury caused appellant to be absent from work for approximately two weeks, for which time wages were paid to her by her employer. Appellee employer, a state fund insured employer, also paid appellant's medical bills relating to her injury. No notice of the injury was given to the bureau or to the Industrial Commission prior to the June 17, 1980 filing.

The claim was disallowed by an Industrial Commission district hearing officer on October 6, 1980 as not being timely filed in compliance with the applicable two-year statute of limitations. 1 The regional board of review affirmed the disallowance, and the commission refused appeal.


1 R.C. 4123.84, in 1976, read in pertinent part:

"(A) In all cases of injury or death, claims for compensation or benefits for the specific part or parts of the body injured shall be forever barred unless, within two years after the injury or death:

"(1) Written notice of the specific part or parts of the body claimed to have been injured has been made to the industrial commission or the bureau of workmen's compensation;

"(2) In the event the employer has elected to pay compensation or benefits directly, one of the following has occurred:

"(a) Written notice of the specific part or parts of the body claimed to have been injured has been given to the commission or bureau;

"(b) Compensation or benefits have been paid or furnished equal to or greater than is provided for in sections 4123.52, 4123.55 to 4123.62, inclusive, and 4123.64 to 4123.67, inclusive, of the Revised Code.

"(3) Written notice of death has been given to the commission or bureau.

"(B) As used in division (A)(2)(b) of this section 'benefits' means payment of a self-insured employer to, or on behalf of, an employee for:

"(1) A hospital bill;

"(2) A medical bill to a licensed physician or hospital;

"(3) An orthopedic or prosthetic device."

 [***2] On appeal to the Court of Common Pleas of Cuyahoga County, the appellees, administrator of the bureau and the commission, filed a motion to dismiss for lack of subject matter jurisdiction. The court granted the motion to dismiss despite appellant's objection that the bifurcated tolling provisions of R.C. 4123.84, as that statute read in 1976, were unconstitutional as applied to her. 2 The court of appeals affirmed the dismissal.


2 Appellees Industrial Commission and bureau administrator claim that the issue of constitutionality was not brought before the trial court and thus cannot be heard on appeal. Although appellant did not specify at trial which constitutional provision had been allegedly violated, we agree with the court of appeals that her reference to the "unreasonable, arbitrary, and capricious application" of the statute and to the different treatment of "similar employees with similar claims" sufficiently preserved an equal protection claim at the appellate level.

The cause is now before this [***3] court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant employee sought review of the decision of the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio), which affirmed the dismissal of the employee's claim for worker's compensation benefits in favor of appellees, employer, Industrial Commission, and bureau administrator.


OVERVIEW: The employee was injured at work in 1976 and filed an application for workers' compensation benefits in 1980. The application was denied as untimely. The employee argued that the bifurcated tolling provisions of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.84, which created a distinction between state fund insured employers and self-insured employers violated Ohio Const. art. II, § 26. On appeal, the court affirmed the decision of the appellate court and found that the statutory classification contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4123.84 was rationally related to the permissible objective of insuring that the proper processing agent of workers' compensation claims received notice of potential claims before the continuing jurisdiction provision of § 4123.52 were invoked by the tolling of the statute of limitations. The court found that notice was imperative in that subsequent measures could be taken by the responsible party to protect its resources. Therefore, the court determined that the classification was not violative of the Ohio Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court to affirm the dismissal of the employee's claim for worker's compensation benefits.

 

162 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


DeMoise v. Dowell


No. 83-782


Supreme Court of Ohio


10 Ohio St. 3d 92; 461 N.E.2d 1286; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1071; 10 Ohio B. Rep. 421



April 18, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Stark County.

Plaintiffs-appellees in the present case are all homeowners who live in Stark County, Ohio. Each of the homes involved in the present action has been and is presently served by an individual household sewage disposal (septic) system.

In 1978, a private developer began construction of a private sewer line in the street adjacent to the property owned by appellees. This sewer line was authorized by the Stark County Commissioners by resolution executed pursuant to R.C. 307.73. The purpose of this construction was to permit the development of a new allotment, providing sewer linkage to future owners. Upon completion, the sewer line was donated to Stark County for use as a part of its sewerage system. Appellees had no actual knowledge of the private sewer line until construction began.

When the new sewer line became operational the Stark County Board of Health ordered appellees to abandon their septic systems and to connect their residences to the new sewer line. Appellees were later notified by the county prosecutor that they would be prosecuted if they failed to comply with the order. No inspection of the septic systems [***2] was made, prior to the board of health order, to determine if they violated any pollution or sanitation regulations. Apparently, the only inspection was made one week before trial. It revealed that all septic systems, save one or two, were in good operating condition.

Appellees filed this action seeking declaratory relief and seeking to enjoin any further action being taken to force them to connect to the sanitary sewerage system. The trial court held that the board of health acted within the lawful scope of its authority to "protect the public health by reducing the likelihood of health nuisances as a result of malfunctioning septic systems." On appeal the court of appeals reversed.

This cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Board of Health sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Stark County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's denial of appellee homeowners' declaratory relief action that sought to enjoin any further action being taken to force them to connect to a sanitary sewerage system.


OVERVIEW: Appellant Board of Health sought review of the lower appellate court's judgment, which reversed a trial court's denial of appellee homeowners' declaratory relief action that sought to enjoin any further action being taken to force them to connect to a sanitary sewerage system. The lower appellate court's judgment was reversed. The court held that appellant possessed the authority to require that whenever a sanitary sewerage system became accessible to a property, the household sewage disposal system was required to be abandoned and the house sewer directly connected to the sewerage system. Thus, the court concluded that the requirement that house sewers be directly connected to a sanitary sewerage system when such a system became accessible bore a real and substantial relationship to the public health, was not unreasonable or arbitrary, and did not constitute a deprivation of due process of law.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower appellate court's judgment, which reversed a trial court's denial of appellee homeowners' declaratory relief action, because appellant Board of Health possessed the authority to require appellees to abandon their household sewage disposal system and directly connect to the sewerage system whenever a sanitary sewerage system became accessible.

 

163 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


City of Cleveland v. PUC


No. 83-699


Supreme Court of Ohio


10 Ohio St. 3d 18; 460 N.E.2d 1113; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1054; 10 Ohio B. Rep. 171



March 15, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio.

On November 13, 1981, the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Co., intervening-appellee, filed notice of its intent to file an application with the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio (the "commission"), appellee, for an increase in rates. The city of Cleveland, appellant, filed a petition to intervene on December 5, 1981. The application was accepted for filing as of March 19, 1982 (case No. 81-1378-EL-AIR). Appellant was granted leave to intervene on March 22, 1982. The commission's staff conducted an investigation, after which public hearings were held.

Almost simultaneous to the events described above, the commission initiated proceedings concerning R.C. 4905.71 and 4905.72, enacted by the General Assembly effective November 2, 1981 (case No. 81-1109-AU-UNC). Those sections require public utilities to permit attachments to their utility poles upon terms, conditions, and the payment of charges, all subject to regulation by the commission. By entry dated February 10, 1982, the commission announced its intention to conduct hearings on the matter. A request for proposed tariffs was journalized on March 31, 1982. Intervening-appellee [***2] submitted a proposed tariff pursuant to that entry which was not acted upon in that docket, but rather was acted upon at the staff's recommendation in the above-described rate case.

The commission issued its opinion and order on January 5, 1983. That order approved a tariff which, inter alia, was limited in scope to cable television companies, private communications systems, and non-public and non-municipal utilities. Appellant's application for rehearing was denied.

The cause is not before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Order affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant city sought review of the order of appellee Public Utilities Commission of Ohio (commission), which approved a tariff which was limited in scope to cable television companies, private communications systems, and non-public and non-municipal utilities.


OVERVIEW: The question presented on appeal was whether the phrase, "any person or entity other than a public utility," as found in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4905.71(A), included municipal utilities. The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court and held that a municipal utility was a public utility as defined by the statute. The court further held that in ascertaining the legislative intent of a statute, it was the duty of a court to give effect to the words used, not to delete words used or to insert words not used.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the determination of the commission.

 

164 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Ryan v. City Council of Gahanna


No. 83-763


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 3d 126; 459 N.E.2d 208; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1021; 9 Ohio B. Rep. 377



February 1, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] IN MANDAMUS.

This action in mandamus was instituted by relator, James M. Ryan, as a taxpayer and a citizen of the city of Gahanna, Ohio, against respondents, the City Council of Gahanna, the individual members of the city council, the clerk of council and the Mayor of Gahanna. Relator filed his action on May 13, 1983, to block the issuance of bonds pursuant to Gahanna Ordinance No. 58-82.

Involved in this action is a dispute concerning the funding of an urban redevelopment project ("project") begun by the city of Gahanna in 1978. The initial legislation, adopted on March 20, 1978, which instituted the project was Ordinance No. 30-78. The preamble of this ordinance purported in pertinent part that:

"* * * [I]t is in the best interest of the city of Gahanna, Franklin County, Ohio, and its inhabitants to provide for an area within the City to attract industry and thereby creating [sic] jobs and employment opportunities * * *."

Ordinance No. 30-78 incorporated a previously conceived Urban Renewal and Redevelopment Plan which had been prepared by the city's Department of Development. The stated objectives of that plan included the acquisition of land for the [***2] purpose of demolishing substandard structures, removal of blighting influences and establishing the use of the area for an industrial and office park.

On September 21, 1978, the city enacted Ordinance No. 85-78 which established additional guidelines for the plan. The ordinance defined an "Urban Redevelopment Project," as "* * * undertakings and activities of the City, in accordance with the Urban Renewal or Redevelopment Plans in a blighted area for the elimination and for the prevention of the development or spread of blight * * *."

Ordinance No. 58-82 was enacted on June 16, 1982. It provided for the issuance of bonds or notes in the amount of $ 2,000,721 for the funding of the project. This is the first ordinance which addressed the manner of the funding of the project. Ordinance No. 58-82 provided in pertinent part, that "* * * Notes shall be the full general obligations of the City, and the full faith, credit and revenue of the city are hereby pledged for the prompt payment of the same." This ordinance also levied upon all taxable property in the city an additional tax for the payment of bonds and provided that:

"The funds derived from said tax levy hereby required [***3] shall be placed in a separate and distinct fund and, together with interest collected on the same shall be irrevocably pledged for the payment of the principal and interest of the Notes, or the bonds in anticipation of which they are issued, when and as the same fall due * * *."

Relator's complaint in mandamus alleges that Ordinance No. 58-82, by issuing bonds as general obligations of the city and pledging moneys raised by taxation for their payment, was in violation of Sections 6 and 13, Article VIII of the Ohio Constitution and either R.C. Chapters 725 or 761. The complaint asked that a writ be issued to compel respondents to issue the bonds in such a manner that they are revenue bonds not general obligations of the city, and not payable from tax dollars.

On May 25, 1983, this court granted relator's request for an alternative writ to stop the issuance of the bonds pursuant to Ordinance No. 58-82. Respondents then enacted Ordinance No. 48-83 on June 21, 1983. This ordinance authorized the issuance of the bonds in the same manner as set forth in Ordinance No. 58-82. On June 24, 1983, the bonds were issued. As a result of the June 24, 1983 issuance of the bonds, in the manner [***4] prohibited by the alternative writ issued by this court, respondents were found in contempt of court. The order of contempt fined each respondent five hundred dollars or in the alternative gave them the option of reissuing the bonds in conformity with the alternative writ or cancelling the bonds. Respondents chose to pay the fines on August 1, 1983.

The cause is now before this court upon the merits of the complaint for a writ of mandamus.



DISPOSITION: Writ allowed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Relator taxpayer brought an action in mandamus against respondents, a city council and its members, the clerk of council, and the mayor, to block the issuance of bonds or notes for an urban redevelopment project. The taxpayer argued that the issuance of the bonds or notes would violate Ohio Const. art. VIII, §§ 6 and 13.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer contended that the issuance of the bonds as general obligations of the city and and the pledging of moneys raised by taxation for their payment violated the Ohio Constitution. Respondents argued that because they were clearing a blighted area and redeveloping it as an industrial park, they were involved in a public purpose, not in a joint venture with private corporations as prohibited by Ohio Const. art. VIII, § 6. The court rejected this argument. Stating that respondents had leased the property financed by municipal notes, which were issued in anticipation of long-term bonds, at a favorable rate to private corporations, the court stated that this was as much a joint enterprise as if respondents had given the money directly to the corporations to develop the land, construct their buildings, and carry on their activities in the industrial park. Moreover, the court stated, although Ohio Const. art. VIII, § 13 allowed for joint ventures for the purpose of economic development as long as moneys raised by taxation were not obligated or pledged for the payment of bonds, here respondents had pledged tax revenue for the repayment of the bonds.


OUTCOME: This court ordered that a writ issue compelling respondents to comply with Ohio Const. art. VIII, §§ 6 and 13. It further restrained respondents from issuing the bonds or notes until they clearly stated on their face that such bonds or notes were not guaranteed by nor payable from specially designated tax moneys authorized by respondents.

 

165 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Reed v. Rootstown Township Bd. of Zoning Appeals


No. 83-177


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 3d 54; 458 N.E.2d 840; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1005; 9 Ohio B. Rep. 260



January 25, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL From the Court of Appeals for Portage County.

Appellants, Dempsey T. Reed and Joan Reed, own a 32.58 acre tract in Rootstown Township, Portage County, which they purchased in 1974. In 1979 appellants commissioned a survey and thereafter sought to carve out a 2.834 acre lot for a single family dwelling. Appellants were advised by township officials that they would need to apply for a variance because the lot lacked frontage on a public road as required by the township zoning resolution. The lot is accessible via a private road, the right of way of which was created by easements in appellants' deed and the deeds of other abutting owners. This private road has been used continuously for approximately forty years.

Sometime after they had initially applied for and been denied a variance by the Rootstown Board of Zoning Appeals ("board") and had filed an appeal with the court of common pleas, appellants were informed that most of the subject property was located in an open space and conservation (O-C) district, while only ten to twenty percent was located in the adjoining residential (R-1) district. Appellants' proposed dwelling would necessarily be located in the O-C [***2] portion of the lot. Minimum lot size in the O-C district is five acres under the zoning resolution.

Appellants reapplied to the board and upon rehearing the board again denied the application, finding "no hardship" to justify the variance. Appellants again appealed to the court of common pleas, which, in an action consolidating both appeals, reversed the board. The court determined that the board had abused its discretion, noting that other homes had been built along the private road since the adoption of the zoning resolution. The board appealed this decision to the court of appeals which reversed the trial court and reinstated the board's denial of a variance. The court of appeals held that the board properly exercised its discretion, determining that the five acre minimum lot size was reasonable in light of the swampiness of the O-C district. The court further noted that appellants could have used their surrounding property to create a five acre lot and thereby obviate the need for a variance with respect to the minimum lot size.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners sought review of the Court of Appeals for Portage County (Ohio), which reversed the lower trial court and reinstated a decision of respondent township zoning board that denied appellants request for a variance in order to build a single family home on their existing property.


OVERVIEW: Respondent zoning board denied appellant property owners a variance. The lower trial court reversed respondent's decision but the lower appellate court reinstated it and the court affirmed. The court found denial of the variance was proper because even if enforcement of the resolution requiring frontage on a public road to meet certain minimum standards was overcome, appellants could not overcome the required five acre minimum lot size requirement. The court first found that appellants created their own hardship in this regard because they could not explain why they had their surveyor not make the lot conform with the minimum size. The court also found that respondent had a legitimate reasons for the requirement including preserving the area's environment and reducing the problems of intensive development. Since these reasons were not arbitrary, confiscatory or unreasonable the denial was appropriate.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the lower appellate court that reversed the lower trial court and reinstated a decision of respondent township zoning board that denied appellant property owners' request for a variance in order to build a single family home on their existing property.

 

166 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Opalko v. Marymount Hosp.


No. 82-1680


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 3d 63; 458 N.E.2d 847; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1006; 9 Ohio B. Rep. 267



January 25, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

This appeal arises from an action in medical malpractice filed by Michael Opalko, through his father, and by his father, individually, against defendants-appellees, various doctors and Marymount Hospital, Inc. Michael Opalko died on March 2, 1981, after which his father as administrator of his estate was substituted as a party.

The alleged malpractice of the various defendants occurred at Marymount Hospital between June 17, 1974 and November 6, 1974, during which time Michael Opalko became nine years of age. The Ohio Medical Malpractice Act, including the amendment to R.C. 2305.11, became effective on July 28, 1975.

The original complaint was filed on April 8, 1980. On April 28, 1981, the trial court granted defendants' motions for summary judgment on the grounds that the statute of limitations had expired. Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed, holding first that R.C. 2305.11(B) may be applied retroactively so as to bar the cause of action that accrued in 1974 and, second, that the statute of limitations therein did not violate the Equal Protection Clauses of either the United States or Ohio Constitutions.

 [***2] The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant executor sought review of a grant by the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) of appellee medical provider's motion for summary judgment in the executor's suit for malpractice.


OVERVIEW: Decedent was a minor when he died. The executor contended that the medical care providers committed malpractice in the treatment of decedent and brought suit. The medical care providers contended the action was time barred under Ohio Rev. Code § 2305.11. The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of the medical care providers. The executor appealed. The court found that § 2305.11(B) arbitrarily restricted the right of a child to bring an action and created an unconstitutional deprivation of equal protection. The court found that § 2305.11(B) placed an absolute limit of four years after the accrual of an injury due to malpractice in which an injured party could bring suit. The court affirmed the prior grant of summary judgment in favor of the medical care providers.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the prior grant of summary judgment in favor of the medical care providers in the executor's suit for malpractice.

 

167 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Hudson v. Albrecht, Inc.


No. 83-142


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 3d 69; 458 N.E.2d 852; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1007; 9 Ohio B. Rep. 273



January 25, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County.

Appellant Albrecht, Inc. ("Albrecht"), is the lessee with option to purchase of a shopping center known as Hudson Plaza. The center is located within the village of Hudson, appellee herein.

In March 1978, Albrecht submitted building plans to the village relating to the proposed expansion of Acme Store Number 4, a property located within the shopping center. The plans detailed work to be performed on the south, west and east sides of the building but did not indicate any alterations to the north side, which is that side which fronts the public street. Appellant Krumroy Construction Company was hired by Albrecht to complete the work.

The plans were reviewed and approved by James R. Cox, Superintendent of Service and Superintendent of Building Inspection for the village. They were then approved by the village's Architectural and Historic Board of Review ("board"), and a certificate of occupancy and a building permit were issued. No additional or modified plans concerning the store were submitted to the village although, at appellants' request, Cox reapproved the original plans in May 1980, prior to the commencement of construction.

 [***2] Thereafter, on the morning of March 4, 1981, Cox observed alterations being done to the north side of Acme Store Number 4. Workmen were removing a long row of large plate glass windows from the building and replacing them with solid stone aggregate panels. Due to the fact that this alteration had not been included in the approved plans, Cox issued a verbal stop work order and later that day issued a written stop work order. Both orders were ignored by appellants and the replacement panels were completely in place on the following day.

On May 15, 1981, the village filed an amended complaint in the court of common pleas seeking, inter alia, to enjoin appellants from performing any further work on the store or from occupying or using it until a permit for the disputed work was obtained. Appellee further sought an order commanding appellants to remove the new panels from the building.

Appellants filed an amended counterclaim asserting, among other things, that portions of appellee's zoning ordinances were unconstitutional. 

The trial court upheld the validity of the village ordinances and ordered appellants to submit their plans for the disputed alterations in accordance [***3] with the ordinances. The counterclaim was dismissed and final judgment was entered for the village. Upon appeal, the court of appeals affirmed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a lessee and a construction company, sought review of a judgment by the Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio), which held that appellee village's zoning ordinance was constitutional and ordered the lessee and the construction company to submit their plans for the disputed building alterations in accordance with the ordinance.


OVERVIEW: The lessee of a shopping center hired the construction company to complete a store expansion. They received approval of the plans and a building permit. Once the work began, a village official noticed that alterations were being done that were not part of the approved plan. The village filed suit to enjoin those alterations and the lessee and the construction company filed a counterclaim asserting that portions of the zoning ordinance were unconstitutional. The trial court and the court of appeals upheld the ordinance and ordered the lessee and the construction company to submit their plans for the disputed alterations for approval. The court held that there was a legitimate governmental interest in maintaining the aesthetics of the community and that, as such, aesthetic considerations could be taken into account by the legislative body in enacting zoning legislation. The court further found that the ordinance also reflected a concern for maintaining property values, which was another legitimate interest of the village. The court also held that the ordinance set forth sufficient standards to guide the review board in reviewing applications for building permits.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment.

 

168 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Barnett v. Barnett


No. 82-1801


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 3d 47; 458 N.E.2d 834; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 1004; 9 Ohio B. Rep. 165; Bankr. L. Rep. (CCH) P69,786



January 18, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Warren County.

The instant case presents the question of whether the automatic stay provision as provided in Section 362, Title 11, U.S. Code, is violative of the Tenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States insofar as such federal enactment stays a state court contempt action to enforce a provision of a divorce decree dividing marital property.

The facts involved in this matter are not intricate. On November 14, 1980, the Court of Common Pleas of Warren County granted a final judgment of divorce to Janet L. Barnett, appellee herein. She received custody of the three minor children of the marriage. Dallas W. Barnett, appellant herein, was required by a provision of the divorce decree to pay the debts of the parties incurred during the marriage contracted on or before the date of September 2, 1980.

Appellant was unable to meet the obligations of his creditors, and filed for relief in bankruptcy on February 27, 1981 in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of Ohio, Western Division. Appellee was listed as a creditor in the bankruptcy petition schedules by way of an amendment filed on May [***2] 13, 1981. The filing of a petition in bankruptcy operates as a stay of certain legal proceedings against the debtor, including the enforcement of judgments against him as set forth in Section 362, Title 11, U.S. Code. 1 


1 "§ 362. Automatic stay.

"(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a petition filed under section 301, 302, or 303 of this title operates as a stay, applicable to all entities, of --

"(1) the commencement or continuation, including the issuance or employment of process, of a judicial, administrative, or other proceeding against the debtor that was or could have been commenced before the commencement of the case under this title, or to recover a claim against the debtor that arose before the commencement of the case under this title; * * *"

It appears from the record herein that in the interim, on May 8, 1981, appellee had filed a motion seeking a contempt order against appellant for his failure to pay the debts of the marriage, pursuant to the order of the divorce decree.  [***3] Specifically, said motion alleged that appellant had failed "to pay the debt owing to The First National Bank of Warren County, Ohio. Said willful act is jeopardizing Plaintiff's credit and could result in the repossession by said Bank of her motor vehicle." Appellant responded in such contempt action that an automatic stay existed since the filing of his petition in bankruptcy and that, accordingly, the action in the state court could not go forward.

A referee in the Division of Domestic Relations, Court of Common Pleas of Warren County, heard the matter, and found that the automatic stay of the bankruptcy court existed and was effective as to the provisions in the divorce decree relating to the marital debts. The referee recommended to the court to deny the motion for contempt until such time as the bankruptcy court ruled whether the debts were dischargeable in bankruptcy. The referee's report was subsequently adopted by the court.

There appears to be no disagreement that appellee did not pursue any means available to obtain relief from the stay pursuant to Section 362(d), Title 11, U.S. Code. 2 Also, it appears that appellee did not contest the discharge of any of the debts [***4] listed on the petition in bankruptcy or its amendment. Appellant's lawfully dischargeable debts were, on July 20, 1981, accordingly discharged.


2 Section 362(d), Title 11, U.S. Code, provides in part:

"On request of a party in interest and after notice and a hearing, the court shall grant relief from the stay provided under subsection (a) of this section, such as by terminating, annulling, modifying, or conditioning such stay --

"(1) for cause, including the lack of adequate protection of an interest in property of such party in interest; * * *"

An appeal of the trial court's decision was taken to the Court of Appeals for Warren County. That court, sua sponte, raising the constitutional issue, reversed the judgment of the trial court, holding that the automatic stay provision of the Federal Bankruptcy Act is unconstitutional as being violative of the Tenth Amendment to the Constitution of the United States 3 insofar as it stays the state court's contempt proceedings to enforce a divorce decree ordering [***5] the division of marital property.


3 "The powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people."

This cause is now before the court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In a prior divorce action, defendant husband was ordered to pay marital debts. He failed to pay, and filed for bankruptcy. Plaintiff wife then brought contempt action, which action was stayed by the trial court. The Court of Appeals (Ohio) reversed, holding that the automatic stay provision of 11 U.S.C.S. § 362(a) violated the Tenth Amendment. The husband appealed.


OVERVIEW: The wife did not argue that the husband's obligation to pay the marital debt was nondischargeable. Further, the court noted that the contempt action was not brought to uphold the dignity of the trial court, but to enforce a judgment. The court held that the automatic stay provision did not violate the Tenth Amendment because 1) the automatic stay provision did not regulate the "states as states," but regulated individual creditors and debtors involved in bankruptcy proceedings; 2) the automatic stay provision did not attempt to address matters that were "indisputably attributes of state sovereignty." Rather, matters of bankruptcy were exclusively within the jurisdiction of the bankruptcy courts. The provision allowed the bankruptcy court a period of time to determine which of the debtor's debts were dischargeable; and 3) the automatic stay provision did not "directly impair" the state's ability to structure integral operations in areas of traditional governmental functions. The provision did not foreclose the state court's use of contempt powers in matters generally within divorce proceedings.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's reversal of the trial court's stay of proceedings.

 

169 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Richley v. Youngstown Civil Service Com.


No. 83-603


Supreme Court of Ohio


9 Ohio St. 3d 15; 457 N.E.2d 829; 1984 Ohio LEXIS 997; 9 Ohio B. Rep. 64



January 4, 1984, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County.

March 21, 1978, appellants, J. Phillip Richley, Mayor of the city of Youngstown, and the city of Youngstown, filed a declaratory judgment action in the Mahoning County Court of Common Pleas. The named defendants were the Youngstown Civil Service Commission and its three members, and twenty-seven employees of the city's Community Development Agency (hereinafter "CDA"). The complaint requested the court to determine the status of the CDA employees in relation to Ohio civil service coverage and to declare R.C. 124.271 to be unconstitutional. 

On March 30, 1978, the mayor and the city filed a second declaratory judgment action, this time naming as defendants the Youngstown Civil Service Commission and its three members, and sixteen employees of the city who had been accorded permanent civil service status as a result of the application of R.C. 124.271. Again, the mayor and the city alleged that the application of R.C. 124.271 was unconstitutional. 

The trial court consolidated the two cases, and, following trial held that R.C. 124.271 was constitutional and that all city employees who met the provisions therein were entitled [***2] to permanent civil service status.

On appeal, the court of appeals affirmed the judgment of the trial court.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to an allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, a city and its mayor, sought review of an order from the Court of Appeals for Mahoning County (Ohio), which, in a declaratory judgment action brought against the city civil service commission and employees of the city's community development agency (CDA), affirmed a ruling that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. 124.271 was constitutional and that all city employees who met the provisions therein were entitled to permanent civil service status.


OVERVIEW: The mayor and the city alleged that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.271 was unconstitutional in that it violated the constitutional mandate that merit and fitness for civil service positions be ascertained by competitive examination. On review the court disagreed. The court found that Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10 did not pose an inflexible mandate of testing. The court recognized the danger and embarrassment that would probably attend any attempt to fix, by a provision in the constitution, any hard and fast method of determining the constitutional requirement of merit and fitness. The court noted that the employees had requested examinations, but their efforts were frustrated by the mayor's failure to follow the proper appointing procedures. The court held that an appointing authority could not assert the failure of the employees to take examinations when the failure was the result of his neglect of his statutory duty. The court held that continuous performance in a position for two years might constitute an acceptable substitute for competitive testing to determine the constitutional requirement of "merit and fitness."


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

170 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State, Div. of Wildlife v. Barker


No. 82-1696


Supreme Court of Ohio


8 Ohio St. 3d 39; 457 N.E.2d 312; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 879; 8 Ohio B. Rep. 401



December 21, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Meigs County.

On July 29, 1980, defendant-appellee Michael R. Barker, a resident of West Virginia, and two companions drove an automobile into Ohio to hunt deer. According to Barker's testimony, attached to, and operated from, the car driven by Barker was a spotlight which was later used from within the car to locate and kill a doe. The automobile was used for these "personal" purposes without the permission of the registered owner, Barker's employer, defendant-appellee Joe Holland Chevrolet, Inc. Barker did, however, have limited authorization to use the vehicle and had he been in an accident, there was testimony to the effect his employer's insurance would have covered such a contingency.

Once the doe was caught in the ray of the spotlight, Barker shot and killed it from the automobile. This technique, known as "spotlighting" or "jacklighting," is prohibited by R.C. 1533.161. Jacklighting involves shining a light into the eyes of the deer. The deer will then freeze, making it an easy target for the hunter.

On July 31, 1980, Barker pled guilty to having violated R.C. 1533.161. The car was subsequently ordered forfeited pursuant [***2] to R.C. 1531.20. The court of appeals reversed the decision of the trial court, and upon appeal, this court, in case No. 81-1735, remanded the cause to the court of appeals for determination on the second assignment of error. On remand, the court of appeals reversed.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff State sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Meigs County (Ohio), which reversed a forfeiture judgment entered against defendants, an employer and its employee, in the State's action under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §1533.161 and Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1531.20.


OVERVIEW: Using a spotlight mounted to his employer's truck, the employee "spotlighted" a doe and shot her. He subsequently pleaded guilty to violating Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.161 and the State initiated a forfeiture action against the truck pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1531.20. The trial court entered a forfeiture judgment in favor of the State and upon review, the appellate court reversed. The court, however, held that an automobile was an "other device" within the meaning of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1531.20 when construed in pari materia with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1533.161. The court held that thus the employer's truck could be forfeited because it was used for an illegal purpose. The court held that the forfeiture did not violate due process of law under the Constitutions of the United States and the State of Ohio because it was within the State legislature's police power to enact statutes for deterrent and punitive purposes. The court held that the forfeiture scheme was not rendered unconstitutional simply because the owner of the seized property was innocent.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment, which had reversed a forfeiture judgment against the employer's truck.

 

171 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Shady Acres Nursing Home, Inc. v. Rhodes


No. 83-309


Supreme Court of Ohio


7 Ohio St. 3d 7; 455 N.E.2d 489; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 861; 7 Ohio B. Rep. 318



November 2, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant state sought review of the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which found that there was not an accord and satisfaction in the state's agreement with appellee nursing home and that the use of regulations to set reimbursement rates was an unconstitutional retroactive application of law.


OVERVIEW: The state and the nursing home disagreed over payment for beds used by Medicaid patients. After reaching an agreement, the court released an opinion on a similar case that made it clear that a final decision had not been reached between the parties. The state told the nursing home that it would not pay until a final judgment was entered.
