The nursing home stated that it would accept the payment and leave the additional payment to be determined by the newly decided case. The nursing home cashed the check and filed suit against the state for the additional payments. The trial court found an accord and satisfaction and found in favor of the state. The appellate court found that there was no accord and satisfaction and that there had been a retroactive application of the law in determining the reimbursement rates. On appeal, the court reversed finding that it was error for the appellate court to reverse the trial court because the trial court's findings were not against the manifest weight of the evidence. The court found that there was no retroactive application of the reimbursement law because the nursing home's right to reimbursement did not vest until after the new law was passed.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

172 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Willitzer v. McCloud


No. 82-1020


Supreme Court of Ohio


6 Ohio St. 3d 447; 453 N.E.2d 693; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 853; 6 Ohio B. Rep. 489



September 7, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Lucas County.

This matter arises from an action filed in the Court of Common Pleas of Lucas County by fourteen workers' compensation claimants ("appellees") against the Industrial Commission of Ohio, three members thereof, and William J. McCloud, M.D. ("appellants"). 1 Appellees alleged that Dr. McCloud had examined twelve of them; that his examinations had been inadequate and incomplete; and that the reports of these examinations contained intentional misrepresentations resulting in the denial or reduction in their workers' compensation benefits. Hence, they sought judgment against Dr. McCloud for compensatory and punitive damages. Moreover, appellees sought injunctive relief for the purpose of preventing the commission from referring any and all claimants to Dr. McCloud.


1 Dr. McCloud is an orthopedic specialist, who, when requested by the commission, performs three functions: (1) examines workers' compensation claimants to determine the nature and extent of their claimed injury and resulting disability; (2) prepares and submits his medical report containing his medical findings and opinions relating to his examination of the claimants; and (3) testifies as to his medical findings and opinions at administrative and judicial proceedings.

 [***2] Appellants subsequently filed motions for summary judgment, which were granted. The basis of the decision in favor of Dr. McCloud was that the "* * * function being performed by Dr. McCloud in examining the claimants and filing material reports is that of a witness furnishing testimony in an adjudicatory proceeding which entitles him to absolute immunity from civil suit."

Appellees appealed the trial court's decision to the court of appeals. The appellate court affirmed the summary judgment entered for the Industrial Commission because the subsequent action of the parties had rendered the issue moot. The appellate court, however, reversed the summary judgment entered for Dr. McCloud. The basis of its decision was that:

"* * * a doctor who has undertaken a duty to examine an individual for the purpose of reporting the medical condition of that individual to an adjudicatory body is liable for any damages resulting from said doctor's failure to conduct a medically adequate examination, notwithstanding that the report thereon is privileged under the doctrine of witness immunity."

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of motions to certify the record.



DISPOSITION:  [***3] Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellants, the Industrial Commission of Ohio (commission) and a doctor, sought review of a judgment entered by the Court of Appeals for Lucas County (Ohio), which reversed the summary judgment in favor of the doctor in appellee employees' action alleging that the doctor's inadequate examinations and material misrepresentations resulted in the denial of the employees' workers' compensation claims.


OVERVIEW: The employees sought to recover compensatory and punitive damages from the doctor, and sought to enjoin the commission from referring workers' compensation claimants to the doctor. The doctor asserted that the function performed in examining the employees and filing material reports was that of a witness furnishing testimony in an adjudicatory proceeding, which entitled him to absolute immunity from civil suit. On appeal, the court found that the doctor was not entitled to immunity. The court held that an independent physician examining workers' compensation claimants, at the request of the commission for the purpose of reporting their medical conditions, was not absolutely immune from a civil suit based on his examinations, notwithstanding that his report and testimony at an adjudicatory proceeding were privileged under the doctrine of witness immunity. The doctor's out-of-court physical examinations of the employees were a medical fact-finding function rather than a quasi-judicial function. Furthermore, the employees did not have any protection from inadequate medical examinations.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the appellate court that reversed the summary judgment in favor of the doctor.

 

173 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Schwan v. Riverside Methodist Hosp.


No. 82-234


Supreme Court of Ohio


6 Ohio St. 3d 300; 452 N.E.2d 1337; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 826; 6 Ohio B. Rep. 361



August 24, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

Appellant, Riverside Methodist Hospital, treated appellee, Scott A. Schwan, on July 18, 1977. Appellee was born on January 9, 1963.

On November 21, 1979, appellee filed a complaint alleging injury resulting from negligent treatment by appellant's employees. The court of common pleas granted appellant's motion for summary judgment because appellee's "* * * action was not commenced within one year as required by Section 2305.11 of the Ohio Revised Code, as interpreted by the Ohio Supreme Court in Vance, et al. v.. St. Vincent Hospital and Medical Center, et al., 64 Ohio St. 2d 36 [18 O.O.3d 216] (1980)."

The court of appeals held that R.C. 2305.11(B) is unconstitutional with respect to medical malpractice litigants who are minors and reversed.

The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee patient filed a complaint alleging injury resulting from negligent treatment by appellant hospital's employees. The hospital's motion for summary judgment was granted because the patient's action was not commenced within one year as required by Ohio Rev. Code Ann. §2305.11. The Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) held that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(B) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The hospital treated the 14-year-old patient in 1977. The complaint was filed in 1979. The Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(A) established a one-year statute of limitations in actions for malpractice against hospitals. Section 2305.11(B) provided that a minor who had not attained his tenth birthday had until his fourteenth birthday in which to file an action for malpractice against a physician or hospital. Section 2305.11(B) led the court to the conclusion that the statute created a distinction, without reasonable grounds, between medical malpractice litigants who were younger than ten years of age and those who were older than ten but still minors. Under § 2305.11(B) a child whose cause of action accrued on the day before his tenth birthday could file an action any time until his fourteenth birthday. Yet, if the same cause of action accrued on the day after the child's tenth birthday, the one-year provision of § 2305.11(A) apparently controlled. Therefore, in light of the conclusion that § 2305.11(B) created an irrational classification, the court held that § 2305.11(B) was unconstitutional on its face with respect to medical malpractice litigants who were minors.


OUTCOME: The appellate court's order holding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2305.11(B) was unconstitutional was affirmed.

 

174 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Williams


No. 82-659


Supreme Court of Ohio


6 Ohio St. 3d 281; 452 N.E.2d 1323; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 823; 6 Ohio B. Rep. 345



August 24, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County.

Shortly before midnight on April 19, 1977, a motorist entered the Speedway gas station at the corner of Pippin and Galbraith Roads in Hamilton County, Ohio. There, he discovered the body of Jeffrey D. Stahl, a high school student and Speedway attendant, who had been shot in the chest. The cash register on the counter was open, and it was subsequently determined that $ 166.37 had been stolen from the station. As police officials had earlier that evening investigated an incident occurring nearby in which appellant Tyrone C. Williams, Kevin Metz and a juvenile had, armed with a pistol, threatened a young boy, the officers decided to question the three regarding the murder. The officers first queried Metz and the juvenile, whose comments alerted the officers of appellant's possible involvement in the murder.

The officers, acting without a warrant, were admitted into appellant's home by his sister. After appellant was arrested and advised of his rights, he led the officers to a stereo set in which was concealed a .38 caliber revolver. While en route to the police station, appellant made inculpatory statements to Deputy [***2] Sheriff Robert D. Pieper and later, while in custody at the station, issued another statement admitting his involvement in the crime. Both statements were made after appellant received recitations of his Miranda rights. The latter statement was taped.

In pretrial hearings, appellant moved to suppress the admission into evidence of the first confession and the gun, alleging that his arrest violated the mandates of the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution. Appellant also sought suppression of the second confession, claiming that it was obtained through the breach of his Fifth Amendment guarantee against self-incrimination. The trial court denied both motions, and in a jury trial appellant was subsequently convicted of both aggravated robbery and aggravated murder with specification. For his offenses, appellant was sentenced, respectively, to a prison term of seven to twenty-five years and death.

Upon appeal, the appellate court, after granting appellant's motion to modify the death sentence to life imprisonment, upheld both convictions. The court of appeals ruled that both the arrest and the interrogation preceding appellant's second confession were legal.  [***3] Moreover, the panel determined that the trial court had not committed prejudicial error in conducting the in camera voir dire of jurors who had been exposed to improper influence during a view of the scene of the crime and that the court had not abused its discretion in refusing to discharge one of the jurors upon conclusion of the voir dire.

This court initially overruled appellant's motion for leave to appeal on March 4, 1981 (case No. 81-73), and he then appealed to the United States Supreme Court. In a ruling, rendered June 15, 1981, that Court issued an order which stated, in pertinent part:

"ON CONSIDERATION WHEREOF, it is ordered and adjudged by this Court that the judgment of the above court [First District Court of Appeals] in this cause is vacated, and that this cause is remanded to the Court of Appeals of Ohio, Hamilton County, for further consideration in light of Edwards v.. Arizona, 451 U.S. [477] (1981)."

Upon remand, the court of appeals again affirmed the trial court's judgment, holding that appellant's second confession was not unlawfully induced and that even if it had been, the admission of the confession would merely have been harmless [***4] error.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of aggravated robbery and aggravated murder. On appeal, the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio) upheld both convictions. The court of appeals initially overruled defendant's motion for leave to appeal. On appeal to the United States Supreme Court, the Court ordered a remand to the court of appeals for further consideration. On remand, the court of appeals affirmed the trial court's judgment. Defendant appealed.


OVERVIEW: The supreme court found: (1) defendant's first confession was admissible because the law enforcement officials were acting in good faith reliance upon the then constitutional interpretation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2935.04 when they arrested defendant without a warrant; (2) the trial court's failure to ensure defendant's presence at the voir dire proceeding was a violation of both his constitutional and statutory rights, but the error was not grounds for reversal because the defendant's interests were adequately represented by his attorney, his attendance would have contributed little to his defense, and his failure timely to object constituted a waiver of his right to be present; (3) the court's decision not to discharge a juror mandated the invalidation of appellant's convictions because the juror gave unqualifiedly affirmative replies to the court's inquiries concerning her capacity to disregard and to remain impartial despite the improper communication she had been exposed to; and (4) admission of confession obtained in violation of defendant's constitutional rights was harmless, because the remaining evidence alone comprised overwhelming proof of defendant's guilt.


OUTCOME: The supreme court affirmed the judgment of the court of appeals.

 

175 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Boothe Financial Corp. v. Lindley


No. 82-1305


Supreme Court of Ohio


6 Ohio St. 3d 247; 452 N.E.2d 1295; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 816; 6 Ohio B. Rep. 315



August 17, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Board of Tax Appeals.

This is an appeal from a decision by the Board of Tax Appeals ("BTA"). In its decision, the BTA imposed assessments on appellant, Boothe Financial Corporation. 1 These assessments arose out of appellant's operations in tax years 1970 and 1971.


1 Boothe Financial Corporation was formerly known as Boothe Computer Corporation.

During those years, appellant owned computer equipment which it leased to customers in Ohio. The equipment appellant leased was manufactured by International Business Machines ("IBM"), and appellant acquired this equipment either by direct purchase from IBM or indirectly through third-party transactions. 2 During this period, IBM also leased the same type of computer equipment to customers in Ohio.


2 Appellant would effect indirect purchases from IBM by giving the purchase price of a computer to one of IBM's lessees. Then the lessee would use the money to purchase the equipment from IBM by exercising an option in its lease agreement with IBM. Appellant would take title to the computer and lease it to the former IBM lessee.

 [***2] On their Ohio personal property tax returns, both IBM and appellant were required to report the leased equipment under Schedule Four as property not used in manufacturing. Each was required to report the "true value" of the equipment. The leased computers were taxed at seventy percent of true value.

IBM based true value on manufacturing cost less depreciation. In its tax returns for 1970 and 1971, appellant filed a claim to reduce the value of its equipment to a level uniform with IBM. Like IBM, appellant sought to reach true value by manufacturing cost less depreciation.

Upon an audit of appellant's return, the appellee's agent increased the true value of the equipment to acquisition cost less depreciation. Consequently, appellant's equipment was assigned a true value approximately six times that of IBM's for the same type of equipment. 3 


3 In some instances the same computers were involved. Appellant would indirectly purchase computers that IBM had been using. The following year, appellant was required to base the value of the machine on acquisition cost so that the value would increase about six-fold.

 [***3] Appellant filed applications for redetermination with the appellee. In part, appellant argued that the disparity of true value between it and IBM constituted a denial of equal protection. The appellee rejected this argument, finding that it did not have jurisdiction to address this constitutional issue.

Appellant appealed to the Board of Tax Appeals. The board affirmed, without addressing appellant's constitutional claim.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant taxpayer sought review of a judgment from the Board of Tax Appeals (Ohio), which upheld the imposition by appellee Ohio Tax Commissioner of assessments on the taxpayer arising out of the taxpayer's operations in two tax years.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer and a competitor were required by statute to list their personal property at 70 percent of true value in money by using depreciated book value. The taxpayer, who leased his equipment, was required to base its book value on acquisition cost, while a competitor, who manufactured equipment, based its book value on manufacturing cost, with its concomitant gross undervaluation. The Board of Tax Appeals affirmed the Commissioner's decision. The taxpayer sought review, contending that the unequal treatment of the taxpayer and the competitor denied the taxpayer equal protection. On appeal, the court held that the taxpayer was denied equal protection when a competitor, who manufactured and leased essentially identical equipment, was allowed to grossly undervalue its property by reporting the property's value as manufacturing cost less depreciation, and the taxpayer was not allowed to value his property in the same manner. The Commissioner intentionally and systematically treated members of the same class, lessors of equipment, differently because one was a manufacturer.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the decision of the Board of Tax Appeals, which had upheld the Commissioner's imposition of tax assessments on the taxpayer, and remanded the cause in order that the taxpayer may have been allowed to report the value of its property in the same manner as its competitor.

 

176 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Johnson v. Shoemaker


No. 82-1293


Supreme Court of Ohio


6 Ohio St. 3d 215; 451 N.E.2d 1231; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 809; 6 Ohio B. Rep. 267



August 10, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

This is an appeal as of right from the denial of a complaint for a writ of mandamus by the court of appeals.

On November 3, 1972, relator-appellant, Carr Johnson, was convicted of first degree murder and first degree murder in the perpetration of robbery under former R.C. 2901.01, and he was sentenced to consecutive terms of life imprisonment. Appellant was subsequently advised by respondent-appellee, Wallace E. Stein, Chief Records Clerk of the Southern Ohio Correctional Facility, that his parole eligibility date was November 1992 or after twenty years full imprisonment.

Relator's mandamus action sought the establishment of a parole eligibility date in November 1982, or after ten full years of imprisonment, by reason of former R.C. 2967.13(C), effective January 1, 1974, which provides for such eligibility "* * * for a noncapital offense * * *."



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed.

 

177 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Schultz v. Garrett


No. 82-1574


Supreme Court of Ohio


6 Ohio St. 3d 132; 451 N.E.2d 794; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 791; 6 Ohio B. Rep. 189



August 3, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Clark County.

Appellant, William G. Schultz, was elected to the office of Clerk of the Springfield Municipal Court for the six-year term commencing January 1, 1978. His salary was computed pursuant to R.C. 1901.31 (C), which at the time he took office provided that "* * * the clerk shall receive annual compensation in a sum equal to eighty-five per cent of the salary of a judge of such court. * * * The clerk's compensation shall not exceed that of the clerk of courts of the county in which the municipal court is located."

When appellant took office, the Springfield Municipal Court judges were paid a salary of $ 38,750 per year, eighty-five percent of which is $ 32,937. However, pursuant to R.C. 325.08, the salary of the Clark County Clerk of Courts was fixed at $ 22,500. Due to the limitation in R.C. 1901.31 (C), appellant's salary was fixed at $ 22,500.

Effective December 20, 1980, R.C. 325.08 was amended to provide for an increase in the salary of the Clark County Clerk of Courts to $ 24,750 in 1981, $ 26,250 in 1982, $ 27,750 in 1983, and $ 29,250 in 1984 and thereafter.

Appellant requested an increase in his salary equal to that [***2] granted the county clerk by the amendment of R.C. 325.08, which request was denied by the appellees, the Finance Director for the city of Springfield and the Clark County Auditor.

Appellant then brought this action in the court of common pleas against the city finance director and the county auditor seeking a judgment declaring that he was entitled to the increase in salary. The court of common pleas held that the appellant was not entitled to the increase in salary and the court of appeals affirmed. 1 The court of appeals, finding its judgment to be in conflict with the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Stark County in Radel v.. Wurzbacher (March 4, 1981), No. C.A. 5407, unreported, certified the record of the case to this court for review and final determination.


1 Effective November 2, 1981, R.C. 1901.31 (C) was amended, deleting the limitation that the municipal clerk's salary cannot exceed that of the county clerk. On the basis of this amendment, appellant also argued before the court of common pleas and the court of appeals that he was entitled to a salary of $ 32,937 (eighty-five percent of a municipal judge's salary). Appellant has apparently abandoned this argument on appeal to the court. Therefore, the court does not address this issue in its opinion.

 [***3]



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant Clerk of the Springfield Municipal Court sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Clark County, which affirmed the trial court's decision that the Clerk was not entitled to a salary increase in the Clerk's action against appellees, Springfield, Ohio, City Finance Director and the Clark County, Ohio, Auditor, to compel a salary increase.


OVERVIEW: The Clerk was elected to the office of Clerk of the Springfield Municipal Court for a six-year term. His salary was computed pursuant to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.31(C). After an amendment to Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 325.08 to provide for an increase in the salary of the Clark County Clerk of Courts, the Clerk requested an increase in his salary equal to that granted the county clerk by the amendment of § 325.08. The Finance Director and County Auditor denied the request. The Clerk brought an action in the trial court against the Finance Director and the County Auditor seeking a judgment declaring that he was entitled to the increase in salary. The trial court held that the Clerk was not entitled to the increase in salary, and the intermediate court of appeals affirmed. The Clerk appealed. On appeal, the court held that the clerk was entitled to his salary increase occasioned by the amendment of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 325.08. The increase was not in conflict with Ohio Const. art. II, § 20 when paid to the Clerk while in term. The salary was not a change in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1901.31(C), the section setting forth the formula for calculating the Clerk's salary.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the intermediate court of appeals, which had affirmed the trial court's judgment against the clerk.

 

178 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Ferguson


No. 82-441


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 3d 160; 450 N.E.2d 265; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 740; 5 Ohio B. Rep. 380



June 22, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County.

The events leading to this appeal are as follows:

Raymond E. Ferguson, appellee and cross-appellant herein ("appellee"), was the manager of an apartment complex in Bedford Heights. Susan Zelko, the victim and prosecuting witness, approached appellee in the course of her efforts to locate an apartment in the area. Appellee subsequently arranged to lease her an apartment. Evidently a friendship arose between the two and they dated on several occasions prior to the incident which culminated in appellee's arrest and conviction. The victim testified that on these prior occasions, she and appellee had kissed, necked, and petted, but never had sexual intercourse.

On the evening of March 12, 1980, appellee and the victim went together to a restaurant and lounge called the Proud Pony where both had several drinks. After spending several hours at the Proud Pony, the victim invited appellee to her apartment for another drink.

While at her apartment, the victim received a telephone call from a person identified as Ron Buzzato, a friend of the victim's. It appears that Buzzato questioned the victim as to her [***2] whereabouts that evening. In the presence of appellee, the victim responded that she had been out with girlfriends and terminated the telephone call shortly thereafter. Appellee allegedly became enraged that the victim had been untruthful in not admitting being with him all evening. An angry confrontation ensued and the victim attempted to evict appellee from her apartment. After appellee refused to leave, the sexual attack which provided the basis for appellee's arrest and conviction occurred. The victim testified:

"He made me perform oral sex a couple times, three times. And he did it to me. And then we had intercourse a couple times. Just kept going back and forth."

Appellee was indicted on six counts of rape under R.C. 2907.02 as a result of the above episode. At trial, the prosecution was based mainly on the testimony of the victim. Appellee exercised his privilege not to testify on his own behalf. A jury convicted appellee of all six counts in the indictment. Appellee was sentenced to serve consecutive terms of seven to twenty-five years on two counts and four to twenty-five years on the remaining four counts.

Appellee gained a new trial in the court of appeals [***3] on two grounds. First, the court of appeals ruled that appellee should have been permitted to cross-examine the victim concerning a contemplated civil suit between the victim and appellee's former employer. Second, the court below determined that the prosecutor's reference to "uncontradicted" evidence in closing argument was an impermissible comment on appellee's failure to take the stand. The court below rejected appellee's contentions that the state produced insufficient evidence for a conviction and that R.C. 2907.02(D) was unconstitutional as applied.

The cause is now before the court upon allowance of a motion and cross-motion for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with two counts of rape involving vaginal or anal intercourse and four counts of rape involving fellatio and cunnilingus. The trial court convicted defendant but the Court of Appeals for Cuyahoga County (Ohio) reversed and ordered a new trial. The state appealed.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court granted defendant a new trial because the State impermissibly commented on defendant's failure to testify and defendant was barred from cross-examining the victim about a civil suit against defendant's former employer. The court found that (1) a reference by the State in closing argument to uncontradicted evidence was not an impermissible comment on defendant's failure to testify where the comment was directed to the strength of the State's evidence, and the jury was instructed not to consider defendant's failure to testify, (2) evidence of the victim's prior sexual activity with a person other than defendant was inadmissible to impeach the victims testimony, (3) the victim's contemplated civil action against defendant's former employer, stemming from the victim's alleged rape, was a permissible subject of cross-examination in order to demonstrate any possible bias because the victim stood to benefit financially from defendant's conviction, and (4) the victim's testimony that she and defendant had intercourse was insufficient to sustain the rape convictions absent evidence of penetration or explicit reference to sexual intercourse.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the appellate court's judgment on the issues of the State's comments on defendant's failure to testify and the sufficiency of the evidence to support the convictions for rape involving vaginal or anal intercourse, affirmed in all other respects, ordered that judgments of acquittal be entered on the two counts of rape involving vaginal or anal intercourse, and ordered a new trial on the remaining counts.

 

179 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Nicodemus v. Indus. Comm'n


No. 82-717


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 3d 58; 448 N.E.2d 1360; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 728; 5 Ohio B. Rep. 115



May 25, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL and CROSS-APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County. On May 18, 1978, Glenn E. Nicodemus was involved in a fatal accident while in the employment of Contractors Service Co. His surviving spouse, Carol Nicodemus, appellee and cross-appellant herein (hereinafter "relator"), filed an application for death benefits. The claim was allowed and the employer timely appealed to the Dayton Regional Board of Review. On December 17, 1979, the board of review affirmed the commission's order allowing the claim and on February 7, 1980, mailed copies of its order to relator, her attorney, the bureau's law director, the employer and Gates, McDonald & Company, an actuarial firm which had appeared at all hearings on behalf of the employer. Gates, McDonald received a copy of the order on February 8, 1980. The employer's copy, however, was sent to the wrong address and returned to the commission by postal authorities. In March 1980, a check was mailed to relator for payment in accordance with the order. Apparently, the employer was notified that payment had been made and thereupon contacted Gates, McDonald to inquire about the payment. On April 10, 1980, Gates, McDonald [***2] mailed a copy of the order to the employer which was received no later than April 13, 1980. On May 13, 1980, the employer filed a motion under R.C. 4123.522 to obtain additional time in which to appeal. The motion was denied by the Industrial Commission and the employer appealed to the board of review. The board determined that it was without jurisdiction to consider the appeal and transferred the appeal to the Industrial Commission for hearing. Following a hearing on February 24, 1981, the commission entered an order granting the employer's motion and allowing the employer an additional twenty days in which to file an appeal. Copies of the order were mailed on March 6, 1981, and on March 11, 1981, the employer filed its notice of appeal. Relator then brought this action in mandamus in the court of appeals, alleging that the commission abused its discretion by granting the employer relief under R.C. 4123.522, and requesting that a writ issue to compel the commission to vacate its order. Stipulations of fact and the claim file were submitted to the court of appeals. The court of appeals allowed the writ and the cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right taken by [***3] the commission. Relator has filed a cross-appeal, urging that R.C. 4123.522 is unconstitutional.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In an action regarding the payment of death benefits to relator, the spouse of a deceased employee, an appeal was taken from a decision of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio) that allowed a writ of mandamus compelling respondent industrial commission to vacate a judgment granting the employer additional time in which to appeal an order allowing the spouse's claim.


OVERVIEW: The appellate court granted a writ of mandamus compelling the industrial commission to vacate an order granting the employer additional time in which to appeal a judgment allowing relator's claim for benefits. The industrial commission's order had been based on a finding that the employer had not received proper notice that the time for further appeal had begun to run. On appeal, the court noted that the appellate court had determined that timely receipt of notice by the employer's actuarial firm, which had been involved in the proceedings, served as notice to the employer. The court disagreed and reversed. It held that if the actuarial firm, as the employer's representative, had been an attorney, the notice received would have been imputed to the employer. As that was not the case, the employer could not have been said to have received timely notice, the decision granting the writ was reversed, and the writ was denied.


OUTCOME: The decision of the appellate court that allowed a writ of mandamus compelling the industrial commission to vacate a judgment granting the employer additional time in which to appeal an order allowing the spouse's claim was reversed and the writ was denied.

 

180 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Beckley


No. 82-593


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 3d 4; 448 N.E.2d 1147; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 704; 5 Ohio B. Rep. 66



May 18, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEALS from the Court of Appeals for Marion County. On October 23, 1980, the Grand Jury of Marion County indicted six individuals 1 for violations of R.C. 1333.92, sometimes referred to as a section of the Ohio Pyramid Sales Act. 2 The indictments charged that each individual: "* * * [D]id propose, plan, prepare, or operate a pyramid sales plan or program as defined in Section 1333.91 of the Revised Code; said proposed plan, preparation or operation of compensation in said pyramid sales plan or program being in excess of $ 150.00 in violation of Section 1333.92 and Section 1333.99(H) of the Ohio Revised Code."


1 They are: Todd Simon Beckley, Michael Tyrrell Harris, James Edward Kinsey, Beverly Kae Short, Gordon Willard Short and Marianne Walton.


2 Counsel in their briefs and otherwise in these matters before us refer to the Ohio Pyramid Sales Act as R.C. 1333.91 et seq. In Page's Ohio Revised Code Annotated the precise heading is "Pyramid Sales Plan or Program." Regardless, we are concerned with specific statutory sections, as herein referenced, not with all sections of the so-called Ohio Pyramid Sales Act.

All six defendants filed motions to dismiss [***2] the indictments. In ruling on the motions on March 18, 1981, the court of common pleas held that the words "plan" and "prepare" in R.C. 1333.92 were unconstitutionally vague and sustained that portion of defendants' motions. Resultantly, the motions to dismiss were granted, and upon appeals by the state, the court of appeals affirmed the judgments below dismissing all defendants. However, the court of appeals did not find R.C. 1333.92 unconstitutionally vague; rather the appellate court concluded that R.C. 1333.92 is unconstitutional because it is overbroad. The court of appeals stated: "* * * R.C. 1333.92 is overbroad in that it encompasses within its provisions and might well penalize conduct which is not criminal in nature * * *." (Emphasis added.) The six cases were consolidated below as they are here. The causes are now before this court upon the allowance of motions for leave to appeal.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state sought review of a judgment from the Court of Appeals for Marion County (Ohio), which affirmed the grant of defendants' motions to dismiss indictments for violations of the Ohio Pyramid Sales Act, Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.92.


OVERVIEW: Six defendants were indicted by a grand jury for violations of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.92, the Ohio Pyramid Sales Act. The trial court granted defendants' motions to dismiss the indictments because the words "plan" and "prepare" in § 1333.92 were unconstitutionally vague. The lower appellate court affirmed the dismissal of the indictments, but it concluded that § 1333.92 was unconstitutional because it was overbroad. On appeal, the court found § 1333.92 and the penalty provision of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.99 was constitutional, and reversed the dismissal of the indictments. The court agreed with the lower appellate court's holding that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.92 was not unconstitutionally vague. There could be no constitutional challenge to any set of particular facts that were before the trial court because it did not have any true evidence before it. Next, § 1333.92, when considered together with Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1333.99, was not unconstitutionally overbroad. Finally, any determination of whether there had been a violation of either statute could only be made by a trier of fact, and was not a question of the facial constitutionality of the statute.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the lower appellate court's judgment, which affirmed the grant of defendants' motions to dismiss the indictments for violations of the Ohio Pyramid Sales Act (Act), because the penalty section of the Act was not vague nor overbroad and was constitutional.

 

181 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Torok v. Jones


No. 82-567


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 3d 31; 448 N.E.2d 819; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 708; 5 Ohio B. Rep. 90



May 18, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Summit County. This is an appeal from a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Summit County. That court affirmed a trial court's decision which enjoined appellants 1 from constructing apartment complexes on two parcels of land located in Green Township, Summit County. The appellees, who initiated this action, were the Board of Trustees of Green Township.


1 The appellants are Phillip G. Rock, Thomas Zaratsian and Olean E. Jones, executrix of the estate of Royce Jones. Royce Jones was one of the defendants; however, his death necessitated the substitution of the executrix of his estate as a party.

This dispute arose out of an amendment to the Green Township zoning ordinance. On April 23, 1980, the appellees amended the Green Township zoning ordinance, in part, to exclude multi-family structures from R-1 zones. The ordinance became effective May 24, 1980. On the same day that the zoning ordinance was amended, April 23, 1980, appellants received a zoning permit to construct a twenty-four-unit apartment complex on Olean Avenue. This permit specified a ninety foot by three hundred eighty-four foot foundation for such complex. Although [***2] that use was permissible under the pre-amended version of the zoning ordinance, such a use was prohibited after the amendment. The zoning permit provided that, pursuant to Section 10.6 of the zoning ordinance, the permit would expire six months after its issuance. On May 13, 1980, prior to the effective date of the restrictive amendment, appellants were awarded another zoning permit to construct a forty-eight-unit apartment complex on Melanie Drive. This permit provided for a foundation, one hundred fifty feet by six hundred one feet. Like the Olean Avenue site, this apartment complex would cease being a sanctioned use under the amended ordinance. Also, the zoning permit would terminate in six months. On November 10, 1980, after the permit for Olean Avenue expired, partial footers were poured at each location. At the Olean Avenue site, the construction commenced consisting of a partial footer, twenty-four feet by eighty-seven feet. At the Melanie Drive site, a partial footer, measuring twenty-seven feet by one hundred eleven feet, had been installed by such date. Subsequently, appellants were notified that their zoning permits were no longer effective, and this action ensued.  [***3] The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellee municipal board of trustees brought an action against appellant property owners seeking an injunction to prevent the construction of nonconforming apartment complexes. The Court of Appeals for Summit County (Ohio) affirmed a trial court's decision, which enjoined the property owners. The property owners appealed.


OVERVIEW: The property owners raised the following arguments on appeal: (1) that the six-month limitation contained in the zoning permits was invalid; (2) that the courts below applied the incorrect standard to determine whether they had established a lawful nonconforming use; and (3) that an application of the amended version of the zoning ordinance deprived them of vested property rights. The judgment of the court of appeals was affirmed. The court found that in the absence of contrary direction from the general assembly, a zoning ordinance provision, which limited the life of a zoning permit to six months, was a reasonable exercise of the power to zone contained in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. Chapter 519. The court further determined that the proper standard was applied to determine whether the property owners had established a lawful nonconforming use, and that even assuming a more liberal standard applies to amendments as well as the initial passage of the zoning ordinance, that the property owners failed to prove that they were entitled to its protection. Finally, the court held that the property owners failed to show substantial nonconforming use of the property.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the court of appeals, which affirmed the trial court's order enjoining the property owners from constructing the nonconforming apartment complexes, was affirmed.

 

182 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Pschesang v. Terrace Park


No. 82-870


Supreme Court of Ohio


5 Ohio St. 3d 47; 448 N.E.2d 1164; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 711; 5 Ohio B. Rep. 104



May 18, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County. Paul J. Pschesang, appellant, is the owner of real estate located at 406 Western Avenue, Terrace Park, Hamilton County, Ohio. Appellant, a dentist, and a partner purchased the land and residential building in 1959 from a medical doctor. Later, in 1960, appellant purchased the property from his partner. After purchasing the property, appellant used the building for a residence and as an office for his dentistry practice. In 1966, he abandoned the use as a residence and used the property exclusively as a professional office. The property was zoned "Residence A" (single family) prior to the purchase by appellant and at the time this action was initiated. When appellant purchased the property, the zoning ordinance permitted the following uses: "(a) In any Residence A District no building, structure, or premises shall be used or arranged or designed to be used in any part except for one or more of the following specified uses: "* * * "3. The office of a resident physician." In 1963, the ordinances were revised. Section 1161.01 of the Codified Ordinances of Terrace Park permitted the continuation and enlargement or structural alteration [***2] of a use which did not conform to the zoning ordinance for the district. In May 1979, appellant filed an application with the zoning inspector for a building permit to expand the premises. The permit was denied on the ground that appellant's use of the premises was prohibited by the zoning ordinance, Section 1161.01. On January 25, 1979, the board of zoning appeals affirmed the decision of the building inspector. On August 22, 1979, appellant filed a complaint in the Court of Common Pleas of Hamilton County, against appellees, the village of Terrace Park, John Eberhard, building inspector, and William J. Brown, Attorney General. The complaint prayed for a declaratory judgment finding Section 1161.01 to be unconstitutional as applied 1 and an order for the issuance of the requested building permit. The trial court found that the zoning ordinance was unconstitutional as applied and ordered the issuance of the permit. The court of appeals reversed finding that appellant's use of the property was illegal ab initio and, therefore, does not constitute a valid nonconforming use.


1 Although "resident physician" is not defined in the Terrace Park ordinances, appellant did not argue that his dentist's office qualifies as a physician's office. Because he did not assert that a physician's and a dentist's offices are similar for zoning purposes and his complaint did not allege that the ordinance was unconstitutional on its face, this issue was not considered.

 [***3] The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant dentist sought review of a decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's finding that Terrace Park, Ohio Ordinance § 1161.01 was unconstitutional. The appellate court held that the dentist's use of certain property was illegal ab initio and therefore that it did not constitute a valid nonconforming use.


OVERVIEW: The dentist, with a partner, purchased the land and a residential building from a medical doctor. He then purchased the whole property from his partner. The dentist used the building for a residence and as an office for his dentistry practice. Later, he abandoned the use as a residence and used the property exclusively as a professional office. The dentist filed an application with the zoning inspector for a building permit to expand the premises. The permit was denied on the ground that the dentists' use of the premises was prohibited by the zoning ordinance. The board of zoning appeals affirmed. The trial court, however, found that the ordinance was unconstitutional and ordered the issuance of the requested building permit. The appellate court reversed. On appeal, the court affirmed. The court held that pursuant to both the ordinance and to Ohio Rev. Code § 713.15, the dentist's use was illegal when he purchased the property and began using it as a dentist's office. Consequently, the court held that it did not constitute a nonconforming use when he subsequently applied for a building permit.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the decision of the appellate court, which held that the dentist's use of the property was not a nonconforming use.

 

183 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Dayton Power & Light Co. v. Public Utilities Com.


No. 82-526


Supreme Court of Ohio


4 Ohio St. 3d 91; 447 N.E.2d 733; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 673; 4 Ohio B. Rep. 341



April 13, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio. This appeal is taken from an order of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio (hereinafter "commission") granting appellant, the Dayton Power & Light Company (hereinafter "DP&L"), a rate increase in case No. 81-21-EL-AIR. DP&L filed its application to increase rates for electric service with the commission on April 4, 1981. The commission designated the period beginning October 1, 1980 and ending September 30, 1981 as the statutory test period and set March 31, 1981 as the date certain. After public hearings were held, the commission issued an order on February 3, 1982. The order inter alia denied DP&L's requests (1) to include a post-test-year wage adjustment, (2) to allow recovery for installment payments of a one percent gross receipts tax payable after the test year, and (3) to amortize its investment in a cancelled power plant. DP&L applied for a rehearing on the aforementioned issues, which the commission denied. 1 


1 The commission did grant a limited rehearing in connection with changes in the treatment of investment tax credits prompted by the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981. This matter is not, however, before this court.

 [***2] On November 20, 1979, DP&L and the Utility Workers of America entered into an agreement providing for a 7.48 percent wage increase effective October 25, 1981, approximately one month after the designated test year ended. Appellant sought to adjust the hourly wage rate to be used in calculating its cost of service to reflect the October 25, 1981 wage increase. The proposed adjustment would have raised the average hourly wage rate from $ 9.76 to $ 10.3194. The commission denied this adjustment on authority of Consumers' Counsel v.. Pub. Util. Comm. (1981), 67 Ohio St. 2d 372 [21 O.O.3d 234]. Appellant also requested an adjustment to allow the full recovery of tax payments made pursuant to Am. S.B. No. 448, which imposed a temporary one percent gross receipts tax on utility companies effective January 1, 1981. The commission had allowed recognition of the one percent gross receipts tax in DP&L's most recent prior rate case, case No. 80-687-EL-AIR, but the rates established in that case were not in effect long enough to allow DP&L to recover the total amount paid pursuant to Am. S.B. No. 448. In its order the commission overrode its staff's recommendation 2 and denied rate [***3] recognition for the balance of one percent temporary tax payments, distinguishing the instant case from case No. 80-687-EL-AIR for the following reasons: "In applicant's prior case, as in those other rate proceedings wherein we approved an allowance for the temporary one percent increase in the gross receipts tax, rate recognition of the increase was clearly required if the rates authorized were to reflect the cost of providing service during the period the rates were to be in effect * * *. However, the same factors are not at work here, for although the temporary increase was in effect during the test period and a payment at the increased rate was made subsequent to the test period, the obligation to pay the tax at the increased rate has now terminated * * *. As we have held on so many occasions as to make citation unnecessary, it is not the Commission's function to provide for dollar-for-dollar recovery of specific past expenses, but to provide a reasonable future earnings opportunity. Accordingly, there should be no allowance in this proceeding for the temporary one percent increase in gross receipts tax imposed by Am. Senate Bill No. 448."


2 The staff recommended "that full recovery be allowed but that applicant [appellant] be required to file tariffs containing reduced rates upon full recovery of the one percent increase."

 [***4] In its application for rehearing DP&L argued that the enactment of R.C. 4909.161, effective November 15, 1981, mandated full recovery of the tax payments in question. The commission declined to modify its order, finding that "the cited statute [R.C. 4909.161] does provide for recovery of certain excise tax increases; but we think it apparent that the legislation cannot logically be interpreted to permit recovery of a tax increase which had expired long before the rates set in this case became effective." Appellant's application proposed an adjustment providing for the amortization of $ 4,796,000 in expenditures associated with the cancellation of construction of the Killen Generating Station Unit 1 (hereinafter "Killen"). The commission denied the amortization, citing Consumers' Counsel v.. Pub. Util. Comm. (1981), 67 Ohio St. 2d 153 [21 O.O.3d 96]. The Office of Consumers' Counsel (hereinafter "OCC") has been granted leave to intervene as an appellee. The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant utility company sought review of the decision of the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio, which denied its request for an increase in the hourly wage rate to be used in calculating its cost of service, denied the company's request for an adjustment to allow the full recovery of a temporary tax, and denied the company's request to treat its investment in a cancelled facility as amoritizable costs.


OVERVIEW: The utility company's rates were increased after a statutory test period. Thereafter, the company entered into an agreement with a union for an employee wage increase. A temporary tax was also imposed on public utilities. The company requested an adjustment to account for these expenditures, which the Commission denied. The company appealed. The court denied the wage increase adjustment, but partially granted the company's tax adjustment, holding that because one of the tax payments had been made after the passage of Ohio Rev. Code § 4909.161 the Commission was required to allow the tax adjustment. The company also appealed the Commission's decision refusing to allow the company to amortize the costs of a cancelled facility. The court, however, rejected the company's claims that the Commission's decision resulted in an unconstitutional taking of the company's property. The court held that the proposed amortization would inequitably shift the financial burden of the failed plant from the company's investors to its ratepayers.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed in part and reversed in part, and remanded the cause to the Commission for further proceedings to determine the amount of the tax installment payments made by the company.

 

184 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Dorso


No. 82-425


Supreme Court of Ohio


4 Ohio St. 3d 60; 446 N.E.2d 449; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 666; 4 Ohio B. Rep. 150



March 23, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County. On December 12, 1980, appellee, Michael Dorso, manager of Cincinnati Gardens Roller Rink, was charged in the Hamilton County Municipal Court with having violated Section 910-9 of the Cincinnati Municipal Code. 1 At appellee's trial, which commenced January 21, 1981, his motion for dismissal of the complaint, based upon the alleged constitutional infirmity of the predicate statute, was overruled. He was subsequently found guilty and sentenced.


1 Section 910-9 of the Cincinnati Municipal Code states, in pertinent part: "No person, association, firm or corporation, operating a restaurant, hotel, summer garden or other place of refreshment or entertainment, shall permit, nor shall any person in or about such restaurant, hotel, summer garden or other place of refreshment or entertainment engage in the playing or rendition of music of any kind, singing, loud talking, amplification of sound, or other noises on or about the premises, in such manner as to disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood, having due regard for the proximity of places of residence, hospitals or other residential institutions and to any other conditions affected by such noises.

 [***2] Upon appeal, the appellate court reversed the lower court decision upon finding the subject ordinance, particularly as it employed the term "neighborhood," to be unconstitutionally vague. The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The city sought review of a decision from the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County (Ohio), which reversed the conviction of defendant for violating its "Loud Musical Noises" ordinance, Cincinnati, Ohio, Municipal Code § 910-9, on the basis that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted for violation of the "Loud Musical Noises" ordinance, codified as § 910-9. He appealed, contending that the ordinance failed to meet the constitutional prescriptions for definiteness. The court of appeals reversed the conviction, concluding that the ordinance was unconstitutionally vague. The city appealed and the court reversed, finding that the ordinance provided the requisite fair notice of what behavior was deemed criminal. The city was not required to define every term used in the ordinance, and terms left undefined were to be accorded their common everyday meaning. The court held that the use of the word "neighborhood" in the ordinance gave a person of ordinary intelligence fair warning of what the ordinance proscribed by having it apply to the people living near defendant's place of business. The ordinance was not meant to apply to persons of special sensibilities, but, rather, to proscribe the transmission of sounds that disrupted the reasonable conduct of basic human activities, such as conversation or sleep.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment that overturned defendant's conviction.

 

185 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Fowler


No. 82-215


Supreme Court of Ohio


4 Ohio St. 3d 16; 445 N.E.2d 1119; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 656; 4 Ohio B. Rep. 14



March 9, 1983, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CERTIFIED by the Court of Appeals for Clark County. Richard A. Fowler, Jr., appellant, was indicted on a charge of aggravated burglary in violation of R.C. 2911.11(A)(3). Specifically, the indictment alleged that on or about October 13, 1980, appellant and Dave Wilson trespassed in an occupied structure with the purpose to commit a theft offense, and that the occupied structure was the habitation of Lori L. Lanier in Clark County in which at the time of the trespass Lanier was present or likely to be present. Prior to appellant's trial, Dave Wilson pleaded guilty to a charge of burglary in violation of R.C. 2911.12. Both Lanier and Wilson testified at appellant's trial. Lanier testified that she and her husband left for work at a Springfield pizza establishment at 3:30 p.m. on October 12, 1980, and did not leave work until 4:30 a.m. on October 13. When they left work, they did not go straight home but went to a friend's house to play cards. They returned home at 6:30 a.m., and upon their return, discovered an entry into their home, the bedroom and den ransacked, and various items of property missing including stereo equipment and a microwave oven. Wilson testified that he [***2] and appellant met at about 9:15 p.m. on the night of the burglary and arrived together at the Lanier home within the hour. According to Wilson's testimony, prior to their arrival at the Lanier home, Wilson and appellant stopped at a pay telephone, dialed the Lanier home number and left the phone off the cradle. When they reached the Lanier home and entered the garage, the telephone was still ringing. Appellant, according to Wilson's testimony, entered the home with a .38 caliber firearm, an automatic "clip-fed" weapon fully loaded with hollow point ammunition designed to "splatter on impact." Appellant told Wilson "if any body comes through the garage door he [appellant] was going to blow them away." Upon trial to a jury, appellant was found guilty of aggravated burglary in violation of R.C. 2911.11(A)(3) and sentenced to a term of five to twenty-five years imprisonment. The judgment of conviction was affirmed by the Court of Appeals for Clark County, and the court, finding its judgment to be in conflict with the decision of the Court of Appeals for Hamilton County in State v.. Durham (1976), 49 Ohio App. 2d 231 [3 O.O.3d 367], 1 certified the record of the case to [***3] this court for review and final determination.


1 The syllabus of the court of appeals in State v.. Durham (1976), 49 Ohio App. 2d 231 [3 O.O.3d 367], reads: "Where a person individually occupies an apartment and his usual and ordinary work habits take him away from it regularly during certain hours of the day, at that time there is a minimal likelihood that a person will be present therein, and a finding of aggravated burglary, under R.C. 2911.11, on these facts alone is based on insufficient evidence."



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant challenged the decision of the Court of Appeals for Clark County (Ohio), which affirmed the trial court's decision to convict defendant of aggravated burglary in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.11(A)(3).


OVERVIEW: The trial court convicted defendant of aggravated burglary in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.11(A)(3). On appeal, defendant claimed, inter alia, that proof that a permanent or temporary habitation or dwelling had been burglarized was alone insufficient to establish an element necessary to support a conviction for aggravated burglary. The court affirmed the conviction, holding that where the state proved that an occupied structure was a permanent dwelling house that was regularly inhabited, that the occupying family was in and out on the day in question, and that such house was burglarized when the family was temporarily absent, the state had presented sufficient evidence to support a charge of aggravated burglary under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2911.11. The jury was free to infer from the evidence presented that the family member was likely to be present at her residence at the time of the trespass.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed defendant's conviction for aggravated burglary.

 

186 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Prem v. Cox


81-1734


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 3d 149; 443 N.E.2d 511; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 636; 2 Ohio B. Rep. 694



January 5, 1983 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Butler County.

On March 6, 1977, Sandra G. Davis was killed in an accident when the automobile in which she was riding as a passenger collided with another vehicle. Appellant, the administrator of Sandra Davis' estate, an attorney, brought this wrongful death action against appellee, Steven Davis, the decedent's husband, who was driving the automobile in which the decedent was riding at the time of the fatal accident, and Darlene K. Cox, the driver of the other vehicle.

Appellee filed a motion for summary judgment, based upon the doctrine of interspousal immunity and accompanied by an affidavit stating that he was married to the decedent at the time of the accident. The Court of Common Pleas of Butler County granted appellee's motion 1 and the court of appeals affirmed.


1 The cause was continued until further order as to defendant Cox.

The cause is now before this court pursuant to the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant, the administrator of decedent's estate, challenged a judgment of the Court of Appeals for Butler County (Ohio), which granted appellee husband's motion for summary judgment of the administrator's wrongful death action based upon the doctrine of interspousal immunity. The decedent was the husband's wife and the passenger in a vehicle that he was driving, which was involved in a motor vehicle accident resulting in the wife's death.


OVERVIEW: The decedent wife was killed in an accident when the car in which she was a passenger, driven by her husband, collided with another vehicle. The administrator of the decedent's estate brought a wrongful death action against the husband and the driver of the other car. On appeal, the court reversed the trial court's grant of the husband's motion for summary judgment. The court noted that, although interspousal immunity could have been asserted to protect the husband from liability in an action by his injured wife, the husband's negligent driving continued to be a tortious act and therefore it supported an action in favor of other parties free from the immunity, such as the administrator. The court held that interspousal immunity was personal and did not inhere to the tort itself. Because the wrongful death action was not brought for the benefit of the decedent, any personal immunity existing solely because of the marital relationship was not included in the conditional clause of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2125.01.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the trial court and remanded the action to the trial court for further proceedings.

 

187 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Nyitray v. Industrial Com. of Ohio


82-247


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 3d 173; 443 N.E.2d 962; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 640; 2 Ohio B. Rep. 715



January 5, 1983 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Franklin County.

On April 24, 1974, Paul J. Nyitray was exposed to carbon dioxide while in the course and scope of his employment with Liquid Carbonic Corporation, an appellee herein, and as a result sustained a myocardial infarction. Subsequently, he filed a claim with the Bureau of Workers' Compensation. He was awarded temporary total disability benefits for the period from April 25, 1974 to February 8, 1976.

On August 15, 1977, Nyitray filed a motion requesting reimbursement for medical bills previously paid and also that the temporary total disability benefits continue from February 1976 to August 1977, and thereafter be contingent upon medical proof. Hearings were held on the motion and on September 8, 1977 and January 17, 1978, the district hearing officer granted the requests. Pursuant to the January 1978 order, a warrant in the amount of $9,104 for temporary total disability compensation was issued and mailed to Nyitray.

As a result of the industrial injury, Nyitray died on January 29, 1978, prior to receiving the compensation awarded. Subsequently, the Bureau of Workers' Compensation cancelled the previously [***2] issued warrant.

On February 13, 1978, Angela Nyitray, the widow-appellant, filed an application for payment of compensation accrued at the time of her husband's death. At a hearing on April 17, 1978, the application was granted for fifteen percent permanent partial disability which had been awarded on November 22, 1977 pursuant to a separate claim for an injury to the lumbosacral region of the back.

On November 7, 1978, appellant filed a motion requesting payment of the temporary total disability compensation and medical bills previously awarded, additional payment of temporary total disability compensation to date of death and also death benefits. Thereafter, the district hearing officer granted the request for death benefits. On May 29, 1979, the hearing officer granted reimbursement of medical bills, but, denied the temporary total disability compensation. Upon appeal, the Toledo Regional Board of Review affirmed the order of May 1979. The Industrial Commission, appellee herein, refused further appeal.

Thereafter, appellant initiated this action in the Court of Appeals for Franklin County seeking a writ of mandamus to compel the Industrial Commission to make the award.  [***3] The court of appeals denied the writ.

The cause is now before this court upon an appeal as of right.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant widow challenged the order of the Court of Appeals for Franklin County (Ohio), which denied her writ of mandamus to compel appellee industrial commission to make payment of the temporary disability benefits awarded to her husband prior to his death.


OVERVIEW: The employee was injured during the course of his employment. He was awarded temporary total disability benefits but died prior to receiving them. Subsequently, the bureau of workers' compensation canceled the previously issued warrant. The widow filed an application for payment of compensation that had accrued at the time of her husband's death and for the previous awards of temporary disability and medical bills. The death benefits and medical bills were awarded, but the claim for the benefits associated with the temporary disability was denied. The review board affirmed, and the industrial commission refused further appeal. The widow sought an order that the commission pay her the temporary disability compensation her husband was entitled to receive. The court reversed the denial of the widow's writ because the classification that denied dependents of workers who died from work-related causes from obtaining compensation due, while paying the dependents of workers who died from other causes, was inherently unfair and unconstitutional. There was no danger of "double-dipping" because the employee never received the payment he was entitled to receive.


OUTCOME: The denial of the widow's writ that sought payment of temporary disability benefits awarded to her husband prior to his death was reversed and remanded to the bureau of workers' compensation for further proceedings.

 

188 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State ex rel. Bloomingdale v. Fairborn


82-542


Supreme Court of Ohio


2 Ohio St. 3d 142; 443 N.E.2d 181; 1983 Ohio LEXIS 634; 2 Ohio B. Rep. 689



January 5, 1983 


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] APPEAL from the Court of Appeals for Greene County.

Relator-appellant, Donald E. Bloomingdale, brought this action in the Court of Common Pleas of Greene County on February 25, 1980, seeking a declaratory judgment holding as invalid and unenforceable that part of respondent-appellee city of Fairborn's Affirmative Action Plan which codifies a policy of not hiring applicants for city departments in which a relative holds a supervisory position. Relator had applied in 1975 and 1976 for employment as a police officer in the city of Fairborn police department. His father was at that time a lieutenant in the department. Relator placed second on two civil service competitive examinations for the position, and achieved first place on the resultant initial employment eligibility lists following a screening process. However, relator was passed over by the city, which chose others to fill three vacancies which arose while the eligibility lists were in effect. The reason given by the city for its refusal to accept relator's application was a "no relatives" policy, in force as part of the Affirmative Action Plan adopted by resolution of the city council. While the city filled [***2] one vacancy with an applicant listed below relator on the initial employment eligibility list, the other two were filled as non-competitive interdepartmental transfers. Transfers are given preference over persons on initial employment lists, by virtue of a policy ranking "in-house" hiring above outside applicants, as codified in the city's Personnel Rules and Regulations.

The trial court determined that the "no relatives" policy contravened provisions in the city charter and Ohio Constitution which mandate hiring on the basis of merit and fitness. The court of appeals reversed, finding the policy valid and enforceable. The cause is now before this court upon the allowance of a motion to certify the record.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed and cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant job applicant challenged the judgment of the Court of Appeals for Greene County (Ohio), which reversed the trial court's judgment that appellee city's "no relatives" policy contravened provisions of the city charter and Ohio Const. art. XV, § 10. The applicant brought the action to declare the city's policy of not hiring applicants for city departments in which a relative held a supervisory position unenforceable.


OVERVIEW: The applicant had twice applied for employment as a police officer in the city's police department. His father was a lieutenant in the department. The applicant placed second on two civil service competitive examinations for the position, and he achieved first place on the initial employment eligibility lists following a screening process. However, he was passed over by the city because of the "no relatives" policy. On appeal, the court held that the "no relatives" policy conflicted with the merit and fitness provision of the city charter, and was, therefore, of no effect. The city charter required all appointments and promotions to be made solely on the basis of merit and fitness. The "no relatives" policy, however, penalized the applicant for a condition over which he had no control. The mere existence of a blood connection acted to deprive the applicant of the impartial evaluation of competence mandated by city charter and precluded consideration of his individual qualifications. By placing at the top of two competitive eligibility lists, relator demonstrated his merit and fitness for the position of police officer.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the judgment of the lower appellate court and remanded the case. The court reinstated the judgment of the trial court ordering appointment of the applicant as police officer, provided he passed the required physical examination, and scheduling a hearing for damages.

 

189 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Newbury Township Bd. of Township Trustees v. Lomak Petroleum, Inc.


Case No. 88-G-1489


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eleventh Appellate District, Geauga County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4876



December 29, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] CHARACTER OF PROCEEDINGS: Civil Appeal from the Geauga County, Court of Common Pleas, Case No. 87 M 747.



DISPOSITION: JUDGMENT: Affirmed as modified.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant township filed a complaint for injunctive relief to prevent appellee petroleum company from drilling gas and oil wells in a residential area of the township in violation of local ordinances. The Geauga County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) granted the petroleum company's motion for summary judgment and dismissed the complaint on the ground that state law preempted the matter. The township appealed.


OVERVIEW: The petroleum company was going to drill approximately 250 feet from an inhabited dwelling. Drilling that close to an inhabited dwelling violated a local zoning ordinance. The court modified the trial court's judgment to reflect that judgment was granted in favor of the petroleum company. The court stated that the township's general power to prohibit oil and gas wells in certain areas had been preempted by state law on the issue under Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1509. The court also held that even though Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1509.39 placed greater restrictions on counties and townships, as compared to municipalities, in that the former could not enact minimum acreage and distance requirements or require a permit or license, it did not violate Ohio Const. art. II, § 26. The court noted that the township had failed to set forth any reason why the classifications in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 1509.39 were unreasonable. Considering the nature of a municipality as compared to a township or township, it was manifestly reasonable to give the former more latitude in restricting gas and oil wells.


OUTCOME: The court modified the trial court's judgment to reflect that judgment was granted in favor of the petroleum company.

 

190 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Ohio Holding Co. v. Grove City


No. 89AP-213


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4867



December 28, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL from the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas.



DISPOSITION: Judgment affirmed. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant corporation sought review from an order of the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which dismissed its complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief against appellee city because it had an adequate remedy to challenge a special assessment against it.


OVERVIEW: The corporation owned several acres of land located in the city and the city declared the need to construct an improvement on the land. The corporation was notified of the city's assessment against the property and the corporation challenged the assessment. The Assessment Equalization Board recommended against any adjustments to the amount assessed. The corporation filed an action seeking declaratory and injunctive relief against the city, which was dismissed by the trial court. On appeal, the court determined that because of the preference of the court for administrative relief, rather than extraordinary injunctive relief, and because the corporation could have fully litigated its statutory and available constitutional challenges in the Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2506 appeal, it was not an abuse of discretion for the trial court to deny injunctive relief. The corporation had an adequate remedy at law. The court affirmed.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the order from the trial court.

 

191 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Richey


Case No. 12-87-2


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Third Appellate District, Putnam County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4923



December 28, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] CHARACTER OF PROCEEDING: Criminal Appeal from Common Pleas Court.

Original Opinion of December 28, 1989, Reported at: 1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4914.



DISPOSITION: JUDGMENT: Judgment affirmed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Common Pleas Court of Putnam County (Ohio), which sentenced him to death after it convicted him of aggravated arson, breaking and entering, child endangering, and aggravated murder.


OVERVIEW: A two year old died as a result of a fire that occurred in a certain apartment. Defendant was indicted by a grand jury. Defendant pled not guilty and not guilty by reason of insanity to all counts in the indictment and the specification. Subsequently, defendant withdrew his plea of not guilty by reason of insanity and waived his right to a trial by a jury. Trial was by a three judge panel. The panel returned its verdict finding defendant guilty of aggravated murder and the death penalty specification. The defendant was also found guilty of aggravated arson, breaking and entering, and child endangering. The panel sentenced defendant to death for the aggravated murder of the child and imposed consecutive sentences on the remaining charges. Defendant appealed and the court held that the imposition of cumulative punishment did not violate the double jeopardy clause. That the fire was arson-related was supported by evidence. The court was convinced beyond a reasonable doubt that the child was killed while defendant, being the principal offender, was committing, attempting to commit, or fleeing after committing aggravated arson.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the judgment of the trial court that convicted defendant and sentenced him to death.

 

192 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Mork v. Board of Zoning Appeals


C.A. No. 14108


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Ninth Appellate District, Summit County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4903



December 27, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM JUDGMENT ENTERED IN THE COMMON PLEAS COURT, COUNTY OF SUMMIT, OHIO, CASE NO. CV 88 10 3421.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owners challenged a judgment from the Summit County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which upheld the decision by appellee zoning appeals board. The board had granted a zoning variance to appellee company to allow expansion of an existing industrial facility.


OVERVIEW: The company sought several variances from the zoning regulations to expand. After two public meetings, the board granted the company's request. The owners challenged the board's decision, which was upheld by the trial court. The court found that the first variance granted, which relaxed the setback lines, was an area variance and not a use variance as argued by the owners. Moreover, the court determined that all of the area variances granted were proper.
