The decision was based on evidence taken in two public hearings on the matter and the evidence was sufficient as a matter of law to allow a reasonable finder of fact to conclude that the preponderance of the evidence supported granting the area variance sought by the company. The spirit of the zoning ordinance was fulfilled and substantial justice was done, in that the interests of both residential and industrial property owners benefitted from the variance.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

193 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Ferguson


No. 89AP-27


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Tenth Appellate District, Franklin County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4853



December 26, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL from the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed; cause remanded. 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a judgment from the Franklin County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) convicting him of failing to confine or restrain a dangerous or vicious dog in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 955.22(D).


OVERVIEW: Defendant's dogs, a Rottweiler and an American Pit Bull Terrier, attacked and killed a child. As a result defendant was charged with failing to confine or restrain a dangerous or vicious dog in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 955.22(D), and involuntary manslaughter. Defendant was convicted only on the charge of failing to confine the dangerous dogs, and challenged the convicting raising four points of error. The court chose to only discuss defendant's first assignment of error, which provided that the trial court erred in overruling his motion to dismiss the charge based on the fact that the statutory structure failed to comport with due process requirements of the United States and Ohio Constitutions. The court noted that a statute was unconstitutionally vague where it was not written in such a way that a man of common intelligence could have ascertained what conduct was prohibited and that the law did not provide explicit standards to prevent arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement. The statute in question was unconstitutionally vague as there was no dog "commonly known as a pit bull dog" and an attempt to enforce the statute resulted in very inconsistent determinations.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was reversed and the cause was remanded for further proceedings.

 

194 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Fraternal Order of Police, Lodge 39 v. East Cleveland


No. 57445


COURT OF APPEALS OF OHIO, EIGHTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, CUYAHOGA COUNTY


64 Ohio App. 3d 421; 581 N.E.2d 1131; 1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 5135



December 26, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [**1] CHARACTER OF PROCEEDING: Civil appeal from Common Pleas Court, Case No. 113,297.



DISPOSITION: JUDGMENT: REVERSED AND REMANDED.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff police officers appealed a decision of the Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court (Ohio), which granted summary judgment in favor of defendant City and denied the officers' request for relief in mandamus in an action that alleged the city wrongfully withheld payment of accrued sick leave benefits upon the retirement of each of the officers in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.39.


OVERVIEW: The City passed a resolution that upon their retirement, City employees would not receive any part of their unused sick leave as pay. City of East Cleveland, Ohio, Resolution No. 1767. The officers filed an action against the City that the resolution violated Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.39 which provided that an employee could elect to receive a portion of the unused sick pay. The trial court granted the City's motion for summary judgment and denied the officers' writ of mandamus. The officers appealed and the court reversed and remanded the decision. The court held that the City could not enact a resolution that denied the right to compensation provided for in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.39(B). The court found that the resolution was in direct conflict with the state law. The court found that Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 124.39 was a law of general nature, governing a statewide concern, which prevailed over conflicting municipal ordinances. The court concluded that its decision was supported by the supremacy clause of Ohio Const. art. II, § 34, that operated to invalidate conflicting legislation.


OUTCOME: The court reversed and remanded the decision of the trial court.

 

195 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. McNeal


No. 56383


COURT OF APPEALS OF OHIO, EIGHTH APPELLATE DISTRICT, CUYAHOGA COUNTY


64 Ohio App. 3d 447; 581 N.E.2d 1148; 1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 5091



December 26, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [***1] CHARACTER OF PROCEEDING: Criminal appeal from the Court of Common Pleas - Case No. 53800.



DISPOSITION: Judgment reversed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought review of a decision from the trial court (Ohio) denying his request for discharge from a mental health facility where defendant was placed after he was found not guilty by reason of insanity in the stabbing death of his girlfriend.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was found not guilty by reason of insanity in the stabbing death of his girlfriend. He was committed to a psychiatric institution, and thereafter, was placed on conditional release. The trial court, however, denied defendant's request for discharge, and defendant challenged the decision contending first that it was not supported by clear and convincing evidence. The court noted that hospitalization was required for a person found to be mentally ill and who represented a substantial risk of harm to himself or society. Proof of the necessity of hospitalization by the state required clear and convincing evidence. The state failed to present any evidence, much less to prove by clear and convincing evidence that defendant was mentally ill and a threat to himself and others. Therefore, the trial court erred in refusing to discharge him. Because defendant's first assignment of error was sustained, the court declined to discuss his second assignment of error regarding the constitutionality of the confinement statute.


OUTCOME: The judgment of the trial court was reversed.

 

196 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Howell


No. 1520


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fourth Appellate District, Ross County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4921



December 19, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [*1] JUDGMENT AFFIRMED


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed from a judgment of the Ross County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which convicted him of gross sexual imposition in violation of Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2907.05.


OVERVIEW: Defendant allegedly sexually assaulted his friend's 13-year-old daughter while she was trying to sleep. Defendant asserted an alibi defense that he was an hour away at his girlfriend's house when the assault took place. The daughter testified as to what he did to her. Defendant was convicted and sentenced to six months in the reformatory. Affirming, the court held that defendant waived any error regarding overruling his motion for acquittal by presenting a defense and not renewing the motion. The court also found that the motion was properly denied as there was sufficient evidence to submit to the jury. The court found that the trial court properly limited cross-examination of the victim and her father because the State had an interest in protecting the victim from undue harassment and testimony as to whether defendant ever had a relationship with the father's wife would have required the trial court to draw an inference.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

197 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Shelton v. Greater Cleveland Regional Transit Authority


Nos. 56287, 56431


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Eighth Appellate District, Cuyahoga County


65 Ohio App. 3d 665; 584 N.E.2d 1323; 1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 5088



December 18, 1989, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Reporter's Note: A motion to certify the record to the Supreme Court of Ohio was overruled in (1990), 52 Ohio St.3d 701, 556 N.E.2d 525.


PRIOR HISTORY: CHARACTER OF PROCEEDING: Civil appeal from Common Pleas Court, Case No. 118,941.



DISPOSITION: Judgment accordingly.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff victim brought a negligence action against defendant transit authority after she was raped at a transit authority station. The Common Pleas Court (Ohio) denied the transit authority's motion for a directed verdict, and the jury awarded the victim damages in the amount of $ 750,000. The transit authority appealed the denial of its motion for a directed verdict and the victim appealed the denial of her motion for prejudgment interest.


OVERVIEW: The transit authority contended that the trial court erred in denying its motion for a directed verdict and in admitting the testimony of a former transit authority board member who criticized management policies. The transit authority also argued that the court erred in admitting testimony relating to the attack of another woman at the transit station on the previous day. The court held that the trial court erred in denying the transit authority's motion for a directed finding. In so holding, the court found that 1) the victim failed to set forth any evidence that supported a claim for relief against the transit authority; 2) while the public duty rule was applicable to the transit authority's case, the transit authority had no special duty to the victim; 3) the transit authority waived its right to object to evidence about the prior rape by failing to object at trial; 4) the trial court committed reversible error in admitting the testimony of the former transit authority board member; 5) the trial court erred in holding that the damages limitation in Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 2744.05(C) was unconstitutional; and 6) the victim was not entitled to prejudgment interest.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the jury's verdict and ordered that judgment be entered in favor of the transit authority.

 

198 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


State v. Labeau


C. A. No. L-89-080


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth Appellate District, Lucas County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4663



December 15, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM TOLEDO MUNICIPAL COURT, NOS. CRB 87-12637, CRB 87-12638


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant appealed a judgment of the Toledo Municipal Court (Ohio), which, after a bench trial, found defendant guilty of refusing to remit his city income taxes for 1984 and 1985. Defendant was sentenced to 30 days imprisonment, and the sentence was suspended on the condition that defendant pay the taxes due within 90 days.


OVERVIEW: On appeal, defendant contended that city income taxes were a debt and that Toledo, Ohio, Municipal Code § 1905.01 et seq. was unconstitutional because it provided a criminal penalty of possible imprisonment for failure to pay a debt. Defendant also contended that the city failed to prove that his nonpayment of the taxes was willful or intentional. As to defendant's first contention, the court found that it was not well taken. The court held that § 1905.01 was not violative of Ohio Const. art. I, § 15, which forbade imprisonment for debt in any civil action, because a sovereign could impose sanctions, including criminal penalties, for a refusal to pay imposed taxes. Further, the requisite culpable mental state was specified in the ordinance by use of the terms "fail," "neglect," and "refuse." The court, however, reversed the decision because the city failed to prove, beyond a reasonable doubt, that defendant's failure to pay his taxes was willful or fraudulent. The only evidence offered as to defendant's intent was a statement that he was "unable" to pay the taxes at the time. Failure to remit payable and due taxes could not, in and of itself, be a basis for imprisoning the debtor.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the trial court's judgment and remanded the cause for further proceedings not inconsistent with the decision.

 

199 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


La Plant Enterprises v. Toledo


C. A. No. L-89-090


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Sixth Appellate District, Lucas County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4659



December 15, 1989, Decided


PRIOR HISTORY:  [*1] APPEAL FROM LUCAS COUNTY COMMON PLEAS COURT, NO. CV 87-2995.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant property owner sought review of a declaratory judgment entered by the Lucas County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio) in favor of appellee, the City of Toledo, finding that Toledo, Ohio, Ordinance § 1167.01(b)(13) was constitutionally valid. The trial court had previously dismissed as untimely an administrative appeal of the City's denial of a special use permit under § 1167.01(b)(13) for the owner's addition to its greenhouse.


OVERVIEW: The owner's greenhouse had existed as a nonconforming use in a residential area. Because the addition exceeded the allowable expansion of the nonconforming use, the owner was required to seek a special use permit. The owner claimed that the trial court improperly applied the standard for non-conforming uses to circumvent the vagueness of § 1167.01 and to uphold the constitutionality of § 1167.01 as it related to greenhouses. The court held that § 1167.01, as it was applied to the present facts, was not unconstitutionally vague and did not violate equal protection. The denial of the permit on the grounds of a commercial use of residential streets and illegal parking problems involved a concern for the orderly arrangement of compatible building and land uses and the social and economic welfare of the City. Thus, the ordinance was not unconstitutionally vague. The standard promulgated under § 1167.01(a) was not so incomprehensible as to provide no standard at all. The fact that the City approved a special use permit for another greenhouse was not an equal protection violation where there were sufficient differences between the two greenhouses.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's judgment.

 

200 of 1601 DOCUMENTS


Fyffe v. Jeno's, Inc.


Case No. 595


Court of Appeals of Ohio, Fourth Appellate District, Jackson County


1989 Ohio App. LEXIS 4929



December 14, 1989, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [*1] JUDGMENT AFFIRMED


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff employee challenged the decision of the Jackson County Court of Common Pleas (Ohio), which granted defendant employer's motion for summary judgment in the employer's personal injury action.


OVERVIEW: The employee was seriously injured while working on a machine in the employer's plant. As a result of such incident, the employer filed a worker's compensation claim and received compensation. However, the employer filed his personal injury action against the employer alleging the employer intentionally, maliciously, wilfully, and wantonly caused his injuries. On appeal, the court held that the first issue was whether Ohio Rev. Code Ann. § 4121.80(G)(1) was applicable to the employee's case. Section 4121.80(G)(1) was enacted after the commencement of the employee's case. The court held § 4121.80(G)(1) could not be applied retroactively because it imposed a new more difficult standard for the "intent" requirement of a worker's compensation intentional tort than the standard under common law. The court than determined that summary judgment was proper because the employee failed to establish that the employer was "substantially certain" that his injury would occur.


OUTCOME: The court affirmed the trial court's decision.
